column2: Prices of cotton futures were unchanged to 36 points up yesterday, with the strength most pronounced in old July.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 30-- Juvenile vandals in Nassau County have paid a total of $4,724 in the last six months in part reimbursement for the destruction they had caused.

I am here to ask for authority to continue our mutual security program in accordance with the President's message of March 19, 1956. This program is part of a national insurance policy which we take out as against a serious and evident threat from the Soviet Communists.
The city is considering special scholarships to facilitate the training of drastically needed science teachers for the public schools.

Cottonseed oil futures continued to rise sharply on the New York Produce Exchange. Closing prices rose 11 to 34 points (hundredths of a cent a pounds to the highest level since June, 1951. The volume was 428 tank cars.
FRANKFORT, Ky., April 30-- The vacancy in the United States Senate created by the death of Alben W. Barkley promises to aggravate, rather than heal, the Democratic rift in Kentucky.
ALBANY, April 30--Governor Harriman announced today the appointment of Russell G. Hunt of Albany and Sidney Squire of Brooklyn to the State Court of Claims. The posts pay $20,000 a year.
Summery breezes billowed past the Stork Club yesterday as the York Corporation joined the thin ranks of heat pump makers.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Senate Judiciary Committee asked today for contempt of Congress citations against four New York newspaper men.
Ray Bolger has been signed by the National Broadcasting Company to star in sixteen one-hour musical variety television programs, beginning in September.
Decontrol of residential rents next year would force many families to give up their homes, the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission said yesterday.
KATMANDU, Nepal, April 30 --King Mahendra rules over a country that is a tourist's dream and an economist's nightmare.
FLORENCE, Italy, April 30 (AP)--Althea Gibson of New York gained her fourth straight triumph on the European spring tennis circuit today by winning the final of the Florence international tournament.

MOSCOW, April 15--In the restaurant of the Precise Electrical Measuring Equipment factory in Kiev, the capital of the Ukraine, a worker can get strawberries and cream. He also can have his dinner served at his home.
First-quarter net income of the Armco Steel Corporation rose to a record $19,678,979 from $12,689,123 earned in the first three months last year.
WASHINGTON, April 30--A 5 per cent increase in railroad passenger fares in the East and West becomes effective tomorrow.
Vassily Smyslov captured the world championship challengers' chess tournament in Amsterdam yesterday, according to a report from the Netherlands.

Ground was broken at noon yesterday for a new $14,000,000 harness racing plant at Westbury, L.I.
The $60,000,000 "Terminal City" going up at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, reached the cornerstonelaying stage yesterday.
IN selecting a successor to Allan Sproul, president of New York's Federal Reserve Bank, the bank's directors are calling on Alfred Hayes, a young banker little known to the public.

Pacific Lighting Corporation and subsidiaries showed continued gains in operating revenues and net income for the twelve months ended March 31, according to this quarterly report released yesterday. Gross operating revenues totaled $216,435,554 against $192,567,979 a year ago.
LONDON, April 30--Government stocks lost some of their recent gains today. Industrial shares moved irregularly.
RUMSON, N.J., April 30-- Bertram H. Borden, long active in welfare and philanthropic activities in Monmouth County, died last night at his home on River Road here. His age was 87.
City school officials are making a new move to end the teacher boycott of extracurricular activities.

Albert M. Cole, administrator of the Housing and Home Finance Agency, renewed his plea yesterday for legislation that would re-establish the ties between public housing with Federal assistance and local "workable programs" for urban renewal.

TRENTON, April 30--The Esso Standard Oil Company instructed more than 2,000 New Jersey retail dealers today to charge a minimum of 25.9 cents a gallon for regular gasoline and 28.9 cents for premium grade fuel.

ANKARA, Turkey, April 30-- Authorization for a $10,000,000 oil refinery to be built with American capital at Izmit on the Sea of Marmora just south of Istanbul was announced today by the National Council of Ministers here.
"The Tempest," a new opera by Frank Martin, the Swiss composer, will open the six-week fall season of the New York City Opera Company on Sept. 20.

Federal agents broke up a smuggling ring yesterday with the seizure of two Cristoforo Colombo stewards and two fellow Italians who had paid the seamen $1,120 for secluded reservations in a linen locker.
ATLANTIC CITY, April 30-- An enzyme deficiency was described today as the cause of a disease linked to the drinking of milk.
The nation's greatest talent hunt came to the close of its first phase yesterday.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, April 30--Hungary's Communist Government apparently has come to the conclusion that it can have quick, which means compulsory, collectivization of agriculture or it can have more food, but not both at the same time.

New financing in April was marked by a decline in bond offerings and an increase in stock flotations from the March and 1955 levels. Bond offerings were the smallest for any April since 1953; stock emissions the largest since 1952.

The Boston Celtics yesterday acquired the rights to two of the country's top basketball players. Bill Russell and K.C. Jones of San Francisco, in the annual draft meeting of the National Basketball Association.
Alben W. Barkley of Paducah, Ky., was a professional politician of the old school and a man of great personal charm.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., and its consolidated subsidiaries turned in record sales and the highest earnings in five years in the fifty-two weeks ended last Jan. 28. Jack I. Straus, president, so reported yesterday
Richard Adler, who with the late Jerry Ross wrote the music and lyrics for the Broadway musical hits "The Pajama Game" and "Damn Yankees," will turn producer next season.

Retail dollar volume in shoes this year will be 5 to 6 per cent greater than last year, but unit volume will be about the same it was forecast yesterday at the sixteenth semi-annual Popular Price Shoe Show of America.
A legend has bene brought to life in Thailand by a party from the American Museum of Natural History.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., April 30--Prime Carnera, former heavyweight boxing champion of the world, started a $1,500,000 damage suit today against Columbia Pictures, producers of the movie "The Harder They Fall."
New York City has challenged tha ability of Delta Airlines to provide air service on the heavily traveled run between New York and Florida.
UPPSALA, Sweden, April 30 --Throughout Scandinavia tonight a thousand bonfires heralded the end of a long hard winter and recognized the beginning of spring.

Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) set a high record in sales and earnings for the first quarter. Its capital and exploration expenditures by consolidated companies of about $185,000,000 is the largest for the first three months of any year.
BOSTON, April 30--Representative Thomas J. Lane, Democrat of Massachusetts, was sentenced today to four months in jail and fined $10,000 for income tax evasion.

The Manhattan Shirt Company proposed yesterday to pay a 100 per cent stock dividend on the common shares.
President Eisenhower led the nation last night in paying tribute to Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, who died yesterday in Lexington, Va.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- Alben W. Barkley was one of the great professionals of American political folkways and one of the last public men to survive as a triumphant nonconformist in a conformist age.

PRODUCERS SHOWCASE" registered an other success last night on Channel 4. Its revival of "Dodsworth," with Frederic March and Claire Trevor in the leading roles, was richly satisfying theatre--ninety minutes of adult drama beautifully and faithfully produced.

PENSACOLA, Fla., April 30-- Senator Estes Kefauver said tonight that the Secretary of State should keep in mind that the subject of broadening the scope of the North Atlantic Alliance "is already well-plowed ground."

WASHINGTON, April 30-- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks reported to President Eisenhower today that all major forms of subsidies available to the merchant marine "are necessary and are of a direct type."

JERSEY CITY, April 30--The Dodgers are still losing. Tonight at Roosevelt Stadium the Cleveland Indians scored in the tenth inning to gain a 1-0 victory before 10,439 chilled fans.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- Forty years ago in Chicago a young geneticist named William Frederick Friedman developed a romantic interest in codes.
KARACHI, Pakistan, April 30 --A new Opposition party has been formed in West Pakistan by Dr. M.L.A. Khan Sahib, Chief Minister of the province.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- Prospects for the Administration's foreign aid bill improved suddenly tonight after President Eisenhower had appealed to Congressional leaders at a White House conference.
MADRID, April 30--The reaction of Spanish youth to coercive methods employed by authorities to suppress any criticism of the Government was brought out today at the trial of four university students.
The Fire Department's new inspection drive by water showed violations on one of the city's busiest cargo-handling terminals yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Agriculture Committee of the House of Representatives approved today a new Democratic farm bill with the Administration-backed $1,200,000,000 soil bank.

The head of the State Commission Against Discrimination charged yesterday that the attack on him by Oswald D. Heck had seriously impaired the state's fight against racial bias.

Warren Irving Glover, who as an Assistant Postmaster General in the Coolidge and Hoover Administrations fought for the expansion of airmail service, died Sunday afternoon at his home, 241 Dean Street, Brooklyn. Mr. Glover, who was 77 years old, had suffered from cancer.

BALTIMORE, April 30--Capt. John S. (Bud) Delano, president of the American Pilots Association since 1932 and president of the Maryland Pilots Association since 1929, died yesterday at his home in Chevy Chase. He was 66 years old.
NEW DELHI, India, April 30 --Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru announced today a new industrial policy envisaging rapid expansion of Government ownership and development.
The fear of public criticism was one of the factors that led Madison Square Garden to pay $100,000 to the late Mike Jacobs in 1949 to relinquish his boxing lease at the arena.
IT would be easy to smother Gerald Tarack in gratitude for his provocative choice of violin works for his Town Hall recital last night.
HONG KONG, April 29--Hundreds of thousands of Chinese are being resettled in the country's border areas. The objective is to reclaim barren land, to increase the food output for industrialization.
Sears, Roebuck Co., the nation's leading mail order and retail merchandising chain, estimates its profits before taxes in the quarter ended on April 30 to be about $3,500,000 above the 1955 level.
Seven secondary Communist leaders went on trial in Federal Court yesterday on charges of violating the Smith Act.
A nation-wide network of underwriters and securities dealers is making a distribution of 1,278,833 shares of General Motors Corporation formerly held by the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation.
Two eligibles for Saturday's 350,000 added Grey Lag Handicap were among the winners at Jamaica yesterday.
"Eisenhower's Six Great Decisions: Europe 1944-1945," by Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, will be published by Longmans, Green on June 6, the twelfth anniversary of D-Day. The decisions ...
HAMDEN, Conn., April 30-- Frederick Charles Hicks, librarian emeritus of the Yale Law School, where he had been a professor, died today at his home here. He was 80 years old.

The dedication of Harvard's sixtyfoot radio telescope, a parabolic open-work radio receiver, is an event of scientific importance. There are larger radio telescopes in Europe, but Harvard's is the largest so far constructed in this country.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 30 --Harry Lawrence Horton, a vice president of the Long Island Trust Company here, and a former Eastern zone executive of the Chevrolet Division of General Motors, died yesterday of cancer at his home, 67 Hilton Avenue. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Supreme Court upheld today the use of wire-tapping in the Government's case against an Arizona couple charged with violating the immigration laws.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Supreme Court sent the Communist party case back to the Subversive Activities Control Board today with orders to reappraise the testimony of three witnesses accused of perjury.

The stock market ended lower on the month for the first time since January, despite a sharp recovery in the final three sessions. Sales volume slackened from the previous month but was slightly above trading in April, 1955.

Gains and losses reached a virtual dead heat in yesterday's stock market as trading became exceedingly selective. At the close, the fifty issues that comprise The New York Times combined average showed a moderate gain.
Third-day crowds roamed the Coliseum yesterday while champagne corks popped in a barren lot behind the new exposition hall to salute the start of a $10,000,000 apartment development.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and the First Boston Corporation will place on the market today a new $7,000,000 preferred stock issue of the California Oregon Power Company.
DETROIT, April 30 (AP)--General Motors denounced today a recent Senate subcommittee report on that corporation.
JERUSALEM, April 30--Dag Hammarskjold arrived from Cairo late today for final talks with Premier David Ben-Gurion on preventing a conflict between the Arab states and Israel.

PROOF that all people enjoy eating outdoors is visible in the collection of attractive cooking and eating wares in Bloomingdale's newly opened Outdoor Living Shop.

WASHINGTON, April 30--The Supreme Court ruled today that an affidavit showing good cause was a prerequisite to a suit for denaturalization.

The United States possesses the largest, best seasoned corps of Foreign Service diplomats in the world, Dr. Henry M. Wriston, executive director of the American Assembly of Columbia University, said yesterday. He spoke at a luncheon of the Union League Club.
LONDON, April 30--Increased political authority for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization was advocated tonight by Lester B. Pearson.

MOSCOW, April 30--For a few hours last night and this morning a portrait of Stalin was paired with one of Lenin in a show window of one of Moscow's big stores on Gorki Street. This evening, as decorations were completed for tomorrow's traditional May Day celebration, the picture of Stalin was missing.
More than 1,500 Masonic dignitaries from all sections of this country, England, Scotland, Canada, Cuba and Italy arrived here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 30-- James A. Farley blamed the White House today for the lack of progress that the Hoover Commission's recommendations for Government reorganization had made in Congress.
LEXINGTON, Va., April 30-- Senator Alben W. Barkley of Kentucky, the beloved "veep" under President Harry S. Truman, died of a heart attack today while addressing a student political convention.

MILWAUKEE, April 30 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals, held hitless for six and three-quarter innings today, shattered Warren Spahn's spell with three singles for a run in the seventh and went on to post a 2-0 victory over the Milwaukee Braves.
The usually sedate Board of Education building in Brooklyn, where voices are seldom raised except during budget hearings and salary negotiations, was the scene of some unusual activities yesterday.
QUINCY, Mass., April 30-- The first keel work on the largest cargo vessel ever to be built in this country was skillfully handled today by Miss Madeleine Carroll, stage and screen star.

Glenn McCarthy, Texas oil man, bounced back into the limelight yesterday with the announcement that he would supply a large quantity of natural gas to the Anaconda Company's Chilean copper mining operations.
ASTORIA, Ore., April 30-- The "new" Adlai E. Stevenson shook almost every hand in sight today from Portland to the sea as he asked Oregonians to help him win the Presidency.

Party Chief Khrushchev and Premier Bulganin used the reception given them yesterday on their return to Moscow to launch another bid for an invitation to visit the United States for direct negotiations with our Government. The bid is clothed in fair words and beguiling professions.
Cleveland, Ohio, will borrow $16,230,000 in the public market on May 22, it was announced yesterday. The offering will consist of various purpose bonds dated May 1 and maturing from 1957 to 1976.
New efforts to deal with infant morality will be pressed on both Federal and local levels to reduce the "preventable" loss of thousands of babies a year.
Allan Sproul has resigned as president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, effective June 30. This was announced yesterday by Jay E. Crane, chairman of the board.
COLRAIN, Mass., April 30-- There is not much posted water in this immediate region but there is enough to keep the school boys happy.

AUGSBURG, Germany, April 30 (AP)--Former German Field Marshal Wilhelm Ritter von Leeb died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 79 years old.
The Colgate-Palmolive Company announced yesterday a public participation project through which the company would contribute $100,000 to the United States Olympic Committee.

WASHINGTON, April 30-- The Supreme court ruled today that employers may bar nonemployes from distributing union literature on company parking lots in certain circumstances.
John R. Inglis of the Fairview Country Club, Elmsford, N.Y., was elected president of the metropolitan section of the Professional Golfers Association yesterday for the twenty-eighth successive year.
A famous "war baby" celebrates its fifteenth birthday today.

A tract of 14,200 acres in Ocean County, N.J., has been purchased for improvement by the E.B. Leone Land Company. The property in Lacey, Union and Ocean Townships, is on Lacey Road, about one mile west of the Garden State Parkway.
HAVANA, April 30--The Cuban Government established censorship on the press and radio today in the wake of an unsuccessful attack by rebels yesterday on an army post in Matanzas.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) --Senator Alben W. Barkley liked to talk and people liked to listen to him.
Disturbed over traffic tie-ups caused by construction operations, Manhattan Borough President Hulan E. Jack conferred yesterday with city, civic, building and utility representatives.

But before Brooklyn fans are impelled to drown themselves in the Gowanus Canal, it might be advisable to consider that there is no need for despair. SAINT-CERE, France, April 30--Pierre Poujade, champion of French middle class discontent, issued today an implied challenge to the authority of the National Assembly and the Fourth Republic.
WASHINGTON, April 30 (AP) --Spokesmen for small steel producers and foundries today urged Congress to check booming exports of steel scrap.
Dick Granger, a 17-year-old senior at Curtis of St. George, S.I., is called "Little Poison." Though only 5 feet 5 inches tall, Granger impresses his golf opponents with his nerveless play.

The master, medical officer and several crew members of the Navy transport Pvt. W.H. Thomas were honored by the National Safety Council here yesterday for a mission of mercy completed under difficult circumstances.
OKLAHOMA CITY, APRIL 30 --Oklahoma Democrats in a sate convention named today an uninstructed delegation, bound by the unit rule, to the National Democratic Convention.

THE wares are international at Leon Feder's grocery, 563 Ninth Avenue, at Forty-first Street. The store is stocked with the foods that mean home to Italians, Greeks, Puerto Ricans, Yugoslavs and many others.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1-- The Eastern Railroad Presidents Conference and sixteen railroads were granted court authority today to file a $120,000,000 counter-claim against the Pennsylvania Motor Truck Association and thirty-seven trucking companies.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The Subversive Activities Control Board prepared today to suspend consideration of all cases pending study of a Supreme Court decision on the Communist party of the United States.
Motors and coppers took a beating yesterday, but the stock market as a whole held up well and losses in the averages were moderate. Even the weakest stocks hardened a little before the close.

Lewisohn Stadium will have pipe organists as soloists for the first time in its history on Wednesday, June 27, at a special concert honoring the sixtieth anniversary of the American Guild of Organists.
WASHINGTON, May 1-Secretary of State Dulles left for Paris today to "begin to search out new ways" of transforming the North Atlantic Treaty into something more than a military alliance.

PEIPING, May 1 (Reuters)-- Mao Tse-tung, Chinese Communist Chief of State, reviewed today an awe-inspiring parade of more than half a million Chinese, representing almost every branch of national life.
NEW ORLEANS, May 1 (AP)-- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's council today placed Texas A. and M., Kansas and Mississippi College on probation for violation of N.C.A.A. rules.

The number of Masonic Lodges in New York State has reached the record total of 1,070.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Congress paid tribute to Senator Alben W. Barkley today.

A sleek new streamlined train that will carry its passengers smoothly and comfortably eight feet above the rails will be placed in service in mid-July between Chicago and Los Angeles by the Atchison. Topeka and Santa Fe Railway.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 --"Almanac of Liberty," the book by Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas, will be the basis for five experimental television films, each of which will run five minutes. Justice Douglas' book consists of 365 episode dealing with man's fight for justice and liberty, one for each day of the year.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, May 2--Backers of Adlai E. Stevenson took an early lead last night over delegates favorable to Senator Estes Kefauver in inconclusive returns from the District of Columbia primary.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- Following are the texts of the findings of fact, opinions and recommendations of the Marine Corps court of inquiry into the deaths of six recruits during a Parris Island, S.C., night march, together with the report of Gen. Randolph McCall Pate, Marine Corps Commandant, to the Secretary of the Navy:

LONDON, May 1--The foreign ministers of Britain and West Germany agreed today that neither Government would take unilateral action toward reuniting Germany by negotiating with the Soviet Union or East Germany on that issue.
A select group of men and women homebound by disability will get a chance to become selfsupporting, the New York Federation of the Handicapped announced yesterday.

LAWRENCE, L.I., May 1-- Dr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Cronin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Camilla M. Cronin, to John F. Dinan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard J. Dinan of Lawrence and Los Angeles. The wedding will take place in the summer.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The Army is developing a "family" of missiles designed to stop enemy aircraft before they reach American shores.
TOKYO, May 1--Gen. Kazunari Ugaki, who was Minister of War of Japan four times and also served briefly as Foreign Minister in 1938, died last night of pneumonia. He was 87 years old.

PARIS, May 1--The keyword in the Soviet empire is they. They are the apparatus of control, the stultifying bureaucracy that embraces life. They are the top dictators of Communist government and the anonymous machinery that dictates even to them.
WASHINGTON, May 1--President Eisenhower said today that he hoped Congress would come as close as possible to approving the Administration's request for $4,900,000,000 for foreign aid.
Commissioner of Investigation Charles H. Tenney disclosed yesterday that he had been checking on reports of ticket-scalping on Broadway hit shows.
THERE is more to this birdbanding stiff than meets the eye, and the eye meets quite a lot of it when the Wildlife Management Institute turns itself loose among the statistics.
Management seems to be about as guilty of "featherbedding" as labor, according to a big non-profit foundation that examines management problems.
CINCINNATI, May 1--Duke Snider started hitting tonight by making three of the Dodgers' six hits. But he didn't get the hit needed in the ninth, leaving the tying run on base.
BERLIN, May 1--East Germany's new Army goosestepped into public view today as the climax of a May Day parade in East Berlin.
The Alleghany Corporation an investment company that controls the New York Centra Railroad, announced yesterday it planned to invest $20,000,000 in securities of Webb Knapp Inc., realty organization.
The city of Baltimore borrowed $25,045,000 in the public market yesterday on issues of serial bonds sold to finance various improvements. The bonds come due from 1961 to 1984.
When President Eisenhower sent his foreign aid message to Congress more than a month ago he described the program as "indispensable to the security of every American citizen."

Television rights to "High, Button Shoe." a musical comedy that opened on Broadway in 1947 have been outained by the National Broadcasting Company. The ninety-minute TV version will be presented in color some time next season.
In all the years since Mrs. Andrew Carnegie put up the trophy in honor of her husband in 1921, it is doubtful whether a Carnegie Cup race has been of greater interest than the one coming up Saturday.
HAVING devoted its first concert to music of the Americas, New Music Concerts last night turned to music of Europe.
Traffic in many sections of New Jersey came to a standstill for a few minutes yesterday and citizens in many communities took cover during a state-wide Civil Defense exercise.

LOUISVILLE, May 1--Fabius of the Calumet Farm won the Derby Trial at Churchill Downs today, defeating the Brandywine Stable's Countermand by a length. C.V. Whitney's Head Man finished third in the mile test, which was run in 1:36 3/5.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 1--Dr. Jonas E. Salk presented evidence today that man could look toward life-long immunity from paralytic poliomyelitis.
LAUREL, Md., May 1 (AP)-- Tony DeSpirito, leading rider of the Maryland spring racing season, broke three ribs today when he fell during the fifth race.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 1 --Two hundred thousand cheer ing demonstrators marched for nearly three hours in Budapest today past a bronze statue of Stalin and the living figure of his faithful disciple, Matyas Rakosi.

PHILADELPHIA, May 1-- Stockholders of the Atlantic Refining Company at their annual meeting today authorized an increase in the common stock from 12,500,000 to 15,000,000 shares and in indebtedness from $150,000,000 to $225,000,000.
BUENOS AIRES, May 1--The liberal Argentine Constitution of 1853, which was supplanted in 1949 by the Charter of Gen. Juan D. Per n, again became the law of this land today.
The school health survey that has been under way in this city since last September is being broadened to include the study of mental health programs for school children.

GUATEMALA, May 1--LeftWing elements took over the international Labor Day celebration this morning in this city and turned it into an anti-Government meeting. Ironically, the Government had subsidized the celebration.

MONTALTO DI CASTRO, Italy, May 1--Wartime techniques and scientific methods for exploring the subsoil have led to excavations near here that may prove to be a milestone in the translation of the Etruscan language.
Reflecting increased sales and prices, net income of the Kennecott Copper Corporation climbed to a first-quarter record of $44,135,744.
WINDSOR, Vt., May 1--Miss Sarah Bishop Perkins and John Francis Geary Jr. will be married in June.
Proposals for major increases in education budgets spurted interest last night in school elections in Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester and Rockland Counties.

For the Ballet Theatre to devote an entire program to works by Antony Tudor has not been an unusual practice over the years, but last night's "all-Tudor" evening at the Metropolitan had a special significance, for it marked the twentyfifth anniversary of his debut as a choreographer.

The Women's Metropolitan Golf Association opened its season yesterday by playing interclub matches. More than 600 golfers from the Westchester, New Jersey and Long Island districts took part in this series.
Nothing is certain in the life of the merchant except death, taxes and markdown.
The Soviet Union and its satellites are making a rich haul of American dollars as a byproduct of their "return-to-the homeland" crusade, according to refugee organizations here.

The scene: a car showroom in Wilmington, Del. The time: early last week. The occasion: a customer shopping for a Ford convertible. The outcome: a quick offer for a 1956 model at $800 below the list price.

L. Judson Morhouse, the Republican state chairman, declared that Governor Harriman's positions on education "seem to indict him as a confused, inept political opportunist unworthy of consideration for the Presidency or for re-election as Governor."

WITH each season that passes, decorating becomes more and more elaborate. The trend affects modern and traditional rooms alike, and the same set of rules applies to both. Some of the current edicts are illustrated in the new traditional settings at B. Altman, and in the modern rooms opening today at Gimbels.
TOMORROW'S first night at the Imperial Theatre will be the third first night for the cast that performs Frank Loesser's. "The Most Happy Fella."

HUNTINGTON, W. Va., May 1 (AP)--A solid blow in support of the United States Golf Associations' anti-gambling campaign was struck by 240 of the nation's better amateur players today. They agreed not to allow their names to be used in connection with auction or Calcutta pools.
Mrs. Jan Hochstraser Cox of Indian Creek Island, Miami Beach, was married to Gardner Cowles of 116 East Sixty-sixth Street yesterday noon in the New York County Supreme Court buildings.
Beau Diable, a 3-year-old chestnut son of Devil Diver, was one of the two odds-on choices to score at Jamaica yesterday. Six other favorites ran out of the money.
PARIS, May 1--The police announced the arrest today of 2,500 Algerians who attempted to make May Day the occasion for demonstrations in favor of the Algerian rebellion.

ANOTHER of the monthly exhibitions at the New York City Center Gallery, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, introduces a number of artists not previously exhibited there. Selected by a jury-Grogorio Prestopino, Michael Loew and ...

Sharp rises were registered yesterday near-by cottonseed oil futures on the New York Produce Exchange. This was the fourth consecutive trading day of substantial advances. Trading continued active, with the volume the fifth highest of the year. Prices climbed to the highest level since June, 1951.

Yesterday the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations passed a resolution which condemns forced labor wherever it exists, commends the International Labor Organization for the efforts already made to combat it, and expresses the council's interest in further action by the I.L.O.

THE story of the development of the Viking high altitude rocket, which in part led to the decision to launch a man-made satellite, was described in both dramatic and educational terms last night on "Circle Theatre," over Channel 4.

Sales of eight New York department stores were 1.5 per cent lower last month than in April of last year. No figures were available for Macy's, which was on strike for two weeks during April. The month's sales were the worst, on a year-to-year comparative basis for any month since October, 1954.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Communist Rumania has offered to negotiate a settlement of United States claims for war damages and property she has nationalized.

ON the occasion of its tenth annual print exhibition the Brooklyn Museum will open a double show today. In the print galleries on the second floor are displayed the selections in this year's nation-wide harvest, while prints purchased from preceding exhibitions and from this annual are displayed on the ground floor facing the entrance to the museum.
CHICAGO, May 1--Unmindful of a cold wind that swept in from Lake Michigan, the Giants today got off to a sprightly start in their first swing through the West.
CINCINNATI, May 1.--The world champion Brooklyn Dodgers have been invited to visit Japan after next fall's world's series.
An official of the John W. McGrath Corporation defended yesterday the concern's payments to an intermediary to obtain a lucrative stevedoring contract.
United Cerebral Palsy's monthlong national campaign for $10,000,000 was opened yesterday.
A free-for-all for the services of heavyweight boxing contenders appeared to be in the offing yesterday.

Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 8 points lower to 10 points higher, with some irregularity all day.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture said today that large food supplies were in prospect for the late spring and early summer. It said that prices would remain fairly close to present levels.

SHREVEPORT, La., May 1 (AP)--Edward E. Paramore Jr., Hollywood writer, died today of injuries received when he plunged ten feet in a parking garage accident yesterday and suffered a fractured skull. He was about 60 years old.
The Canadian National Railways had gross revenues of $177,989,000 in the first quarter this year, $24,130,000 above the like 1955 period. Operating expenses were held to $173,756,000
CHISLEHURST, England, May 1 (Reuters)--Stonemasons pried open a fifteenthcentury tomb here today for a New York literary detective seeking evidence that Shakespeare was a fake but found nothing.
WASHINGTON, May 1--President Eisenhower has taken personal charge of the Administration's foreign aid program in an effort to keep Congress from studying it to death.
WASHINGTON, May 1--Donald Ogden Stewart, playwright and author, filed suit in Federal District Court today to compel the State Department to give him a passport.

Primary contests for thirtytwo Democratic nominations for public office here were scheduled yesterday. In addition, three nominations by the Republican party and one by the Liberal party are subject to contests.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 1-- Italy in effect has been brought into a multilateral payments agreement that binds Brazil with a group of West European countries.
It is perennially fascinating to note the way the French Revolution and its forms continue to make their impress on French politics.
The city's proposed expense budget for 1956-57 of $1,917,229,968 was received by the City Council yesterday. The Board of Estimate approved the budget last Thursday.
SAINT-CERE, France, May 1 --Pierre Poujade broke spectacularly today with the lieutenant he had designated to enlist labor support for his anti-parliamentary movement.
WHERE do fashion ideas come from? Anywhere and everywhere. For example, Franklin Simon's new butterfly silks came right out of a hatbox.
The United Dye and Chemical Corporation, a holding company with interests in chemicals, heavy industry and insurance, added a cleaning compound to its roster yesterday.
Wellesley-in-Nassau has announced that the ninth annual Wellesley Garden Tour, for the benefit of the club's scholarship fund, will be held May 10 from 1 to 6 P.M.

The United Shoe Machinery Corporation cleared $5,972,537 in the final quarter of its fiscal year, ended Feb. 29. This raised net income for the year to $18,665,192, 160 per cent above the $7,177,481 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
Mayor Wagner said last night that he was heartily in favor of special scholarships to train science teachers for the public schools.

The order backlog of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation totaled $1,277,397,000 on March 25, a gain of $56,420,000 in three months, and was $192,996,000, or 18 per cent, above the backlog a year ago, Robert E. Gross, president, reported to stockholders yesterday at the annual meeting in Burbank, Calif.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 1 --Helen Hayes will make her first screen appearance in four years as the Russian countess in "Anastasia." This was the role played by Eugenie Leontovich on the Broadway stage.
WASHINGTON, May 1-- Charles E. Wilson conceded today that the Soviet Union was outstripping the United States in the production of globe-girdling planes that can carry hydrogen bombs.

WASHINGTON, May 1--Paul M. Butler, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, drew resounding boos from a business audience today when he asserted that the Republican party drew its financing from "vested interests."

WASHINGTON, May 1--Labor's high command decided today to press its inquiry into the dissolved pact between the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and the International Association of Longshoremen.

A record attendance of about 1,000 Radio Corporation of America stockholders was told yesterday at the annual meeting that first-quarter sales and earnings hit new peaks. A half hour later they were assured by David Sarnoff, chairman and chief executive officer, that even better days were ahead.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 1--A special sort of roving "ambassador," whose diplomatic duties required the selling of an unwanted product in his own country, retired today after twenty-eight years of service.

The extraordinary amount of new construction under way in Manhattan and the instant effect of any impediment to traffic in streets already so badly congested make the study being conducted by Borough President Hulan E. Jack both timely and important.

The retirement of fifty-six employes of the New York City Post Office was observed yesterday with a ceremony in the General Post Office, Thirty-Third Street and Eighth Avenue. The fifty-six had completed a total of 1,948 years of work.

WASHINGTON, May 1--A Marine Corps drill sergeant was accused today of having been under the influence of alcohol when he led a platoon of recruits into a swamp on April 8. Six of the recruits were drowned.

ST. LOUIS, May 1 (AP)--Cur Roberts tripled to set up on run and broke a ninth-inning tie with a two-run double tonight As a result, the Pittsburgh Pirates gained their third straight victory. 4--2, and ended a three game St. Louis Cardinal winnings streak.
WASHINGTON, May 1--The Senate committee to investigate lobbying held its first public hearing today.
"Wake Up, Darling," in which Barry Nelson Barbara Britton and Russell Nype are starred, will be presented at 8 o'clock tonight at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.
The non-scientific, upturnedcollar observers who said April was colder than usual were right.
LONDON, May 1--Apart from activity in oil shares, the stock markets were quiet today and showed little sign of improvement until the late dealings.

A new attempt to end the teacher boycott of extra-curricular activities will be made today.

LONDON, May 1--Harold E. Stassen acknowledged here today that the prospect for EastWest agreement on world disarmament was "not near at hand."
JERUSALEM May 1--Dag Hammarskjold appeared tonight to have run into unexpected trouble in his attempt to obtain an unconditional cease-fire agreement from Syria.

WASHINGTON, May 1--The Atomic Energy Commission announced today the signing of three contracts under an expanded program to assure a supply of zirconium metal and hafnium oxide to meet increasing reactor development requirements.

The New York Yankees mauled four Detroit pitchers for eleven hits and a 9-2 victory to register their fifth straight home decision of the season at Yankee Stadium yesterday. The triumph marked the opening of a fourteen-game home stand for the Bombers.

WASHINGTON, May 1 (AP)-- The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee called today for action by the United Nations to "prevent further wanton abuse" of United States hospitality by the chief Soviet delegate, Arkady A. Sobolev.
A tradition may have been born yesterday afternoon in Washington Square. Not since little Indians chased one another around Sappokanican (later Greenwich Village) has that region seen such an affair.
WASHINGTON, May 1--William Benton, former Democratic Senator from Connecticut, proposed today that Congress authorize a priority of Government fellowships for scientific and engineering students.

The Seamen's Church Institute of New York, the world's largest shore home for active merchant seamen, continues as a popular haven for seafarers after 121 years.

The decision of Allan Sproul, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank, to resin that important post will be received with mixed emotions by his colleagues in the System and by everyone who realized the vital role he has played in the System's affairs in recent years.
New issues of corporate securities totaling $62,000,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates.

KATMANDU, Nepal, May 1-- A package that had been in a New York museum basement for more than thirty years has been flown to Katmandu to make a gift for a king and spare the United States a small degree of embarrassment.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 1--Carroll Binder, editorial page editor of The Minneapolis Tribune, died here today of leukemia. His age was 60.
The Tavern-on-the-Green parking lot controversy became a lively issue at City Hall yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 15--A housewife of a middle income family, with about 2,000 rubles a month from all sources, went shopping one evening on her way home from teaching school.

A storm was brewing in the civic skies yesterday over the question what airline, if any, should be chosen to operate a third air route between New York City and Florida.

The question of what will happen to the 15 per cent commission system under which agencies operate is a hot topic along Madison Avenue. Ted Heath's English band made its first appearance in New York at Carnegie Hall last night, revealing to a packed and very responsive house that it is of the kind of versatile, highly skilled bands that has all but disappeared from these shores.

PITTSBURGH, May 1 (AP)--A busy steel industry that soon must negotiate a labor contracts with the United Steelworkers has taken legal steps to insure unity in event a dispute arises in coming talks with the union.
