FOR the newly-elected president of the World Zionist Organization, life is spelled out in ABZ's--agreement, Bach and Zionism.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 6-- Miriam Duffy's entries from Rye, N.Y., took the open jumper, working hunter and green working hunter championships in the Rice Farm's spring horse show today.
Cotton futures prices moved upward on the New York Cotton Exchange last week. At the close on Friday net gains posted ranged from 50 cents to $l.15 a bale.
By ranging over the whole field of human knowledge--or at least those parts of it that can be measured--W. Allen Wallis and Harry V. Roberts have made statistics fascinating.
ST. ALBANS, Vt., May 6-- George T. Tobin, artist and illustrator formerly of New Rochelle N.Y., died last night after a long illness. His age was 92.

TRENTON, May 6--Ch. Vilmar's Lucky, a 4-year-old white and liver pointer owned and Handled by Mary Ann Wadsworth of Auburn, N.Y., became best in show today in the twenty-seventh event of the Trenton Kennel Club.
VINCENT SHEEAN, famous for reporting wars and warriors, presents in his new book, "Oscar Hammerstein I," a magnificent picture of a rambunctious battler and theatrical buccaneer.

Eddie Cantor won't have to worry about getting laughs when he stars in a melodrama titled "George Has a Birthday" on "Matinee Theatre" June 11. The play about an attempted murder will be televised in color from 3 to 4 P.M. by the National Broadcasting Company.
The old Seventh Regiment ended yesterday the big week of its sesquicentennial year.
MONROEVILLE, Pa., May 6-- Competing materials are cutting inroads constantly into fields long dominated by steel, but the country's largest producer of the basic metal is little concerned.
Prevention of the spread of disease, an important phase of the work of many of the agen cies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund, is an old story in New York City.

BELA HERSKOVITS, former chief cantor of Buda pest, made his New York concert debut yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. He was assisted in some of his religious selections by the Samuel Sterner choir.
Two state officials called yesterday for an immediate conference to re-examine the housing problem and chart a new course for solving it.
WASHINGTON, May 6--Senator Herbert H. Lehman charged Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. today with "passing the buck" to Congress on "necessary reform" in security procedures for Federal employes.
LONDON, May 6--Shop stewards from Britain's major automotive factories recommended today an industry-wide voluntary assessment to support the country's first "automation strike."
CHICAGO, May 6--Last year burglars stole the Easter collection of $5,000 from a hiding place in St. Andrew's Greek Orthodox Church.
Two crusaders for freedom among Hungarian people joined yesterday to help celebrate the golden jubilee of the First Magyar Presbyterian Church 233 East 116th Street.
The contest between the Democrats and Republicans for Liberal party support in two Manhattan races for Surrogate appeared last night to have been won by the Democrats.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., May 6-A 74-year-old consulting engineer was charged today with the axe murder of his wife.
Despite record prosperity in the nation, the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago reports, many communities still have heavy, chronic unemployment.

ST. LOUIS, May 6--The Giants moved from the frosty North into midsummer temperature today, but it took them a long time to get used to the change. So the best they got out of the long afternoon was an even break in their twin bill with the Cardinals before a crowd of 25,466.
The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development had net income of $21,200,000 for the nine-month period ended March 31, compared with $18,600,000 for the similar period a year earlier.
The Chibuluma Mine, newest copper and cobalt producer of Northern Rhodesia's copper belt was formally opened over the week-end, it was announced by the American Metal Company.
Ravages of last summer's floods and of the most severe winter in recent history have added $10,000,000 to the state's highway maintenance cost this year.
SOUTHBOROUGH, Mass., May 6--Although the nearest water suitable for crew racing is an artificial pond five miles away, students at St. Mark's School have become surprisingly nautical-minded.
NEW HAVEN, May 6--Yale University Law School announced today the appointment of seven new faculty members, effective July 1.
A booklet designed to reduce the number of verbal duels between tenants and landlords of rent-controlled houses has been issued by the Temporary State Housing Rent Commission.

Attorney General Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he had "reservations" about the candidacy of Vice President Richard M. Nixon for re-election. He added that he was not alone among Republicans in this respect.

ALTHOUGH his daughter is naturally spotless, as girls should be, and his five sons are normally grubby, as boys can be, Arnold Perlman devotes his life to improving the grooming habits of little ladies.

This summer's Guggenheim Memorial Concerts in Central and Prospect parks will be conducted by Richard Franko Goldman, who has been named to succeed his father, the late Edwin Franko Goldman, as the conductor of the Goldman Band.
NORFOLK, Va., May 6--The battleship Wisconsin rammed the U.S.S. Eaton, an escort destroyer, in a fog off Virginia today.
CHICAGO, May 6--The fifteenth annual convention of the National Association for Practical Nurse Education will open here tomorrow in the Edgewater Beach Hotel.

Rallying for two goals in the second half, the West German Police Athletic League all-stars tied at 2--2 with the GermanAmerican Soccer League allstars at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday. A crowd of 19,786 looked on.
THE new tower searchlights cutting the night from the Empire State Building represent a turnabout in the tower's role, although not too many people would know that.

FORT WORTH, May 6 (UP)-- Mike Souchak, the former Duke University football player, won the Colonial national invitation golf tournament today with an even-par 280 that was worth $5,000. He shot a 69 on the final round.
BOGOTA, Colombia, May 6 (Reuters)--President Gustavo Rojas Pinilla has lifted a ban imposed last August on the publication of the liberal daily newspaper El Tiempo, it was disclosed today.
ALGIERS, Algeria, May 6-- New and spectacular rebel attacks over the week-end coincided with the arrival of fresh troops from France.
A search was begun yesterday by fifty detectives for the sniper who killed a church warden and wounded five other persons Saturday night.

Mr. and Mrs. Cleveland E. Dodge of Greyston, Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of his sister, Mrs. Elizabeth Dodge Huntington of Riverdale and Prouts Neck, Me., to the Rev. Dr. Dumont Clarke of Asheville, N.C. The couple will be married next month.
CHICAGO, May 6--Net income of the Household Finance Corporation in the three months ended March 31 rose 18 per cent to $4,811,278 from $4,072,793 a year ago, the corporation reported.
DALLAS, Tex., May 6--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson moved into the front rank of favorite son Presidential prospects today as a potent force for party unity among Southern Democrats.

WASHINGTON, May 6-- George F. Kennan, former Ambassador to Moscow and once head of the State Department's Policy Planning Staff, is making an original contribution to the developing debate on the redirection of United States foreign policy.
Brookhattan-Galicia crushed Hakoah of Brooklyn, 6--0, in the second game of an American Soccer League doubleheader at Zerega Oval, the Bronx, yesterday. George Andrade tallied four times.
WASHINGTON, May 6--Conflicts of jurisdiction between Federal and state or local authorities should be resolved in favor of the state and local ...

WHEN raspberries are ripe in Denmark, whole families troop out to the country to pick baskets of the fruit. Back home, the berries are converted into a juice used throughout the year in a dessert the Danes call rodgrod.
Nathan S. Sachs, president of Sachs Quality Stores Inc., a retail furniture chain, died yesterday of a heart attack in his home, 15 West Eighty-first Street. His age was 59.

LONDON, May 6--The Sadler's Wells Ballet cele brated last night its twentyfifth anniversary with a special performance at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden. The allegedly undemonstrative British public wiped out that libel for all time.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 6--The Quadrennial General Conference of the Methodist Church set its sights today on adjournment tomorrow.
The great need of the world is a deeper concept of morality based on understanding and goodwill, Judge Charles W. Froessel of the State Court of Appeals said yesterday.
Demolition of two buildings on Fifth Avenue will begin today to prepare for the construction of the first building in New York designed by Frank Lloyd Wright.
James Felt, chairman of the City Planning Commission, has asked city department heads to keep their requests for 1957 capital budget funds well below the levels of recent years.

Two alumnae of Barnard College have provided scholarship funds to be awarded for the first time in 1956-57, Mrs. Arthur Hays Sulzberger, chairman of the Barnard Trustees Committee on Development has announced.
The American Heart Association has published a pamphlet for laymen by its past president, Dr. Paul Dudley White. The title is "Heart Disease Caused by Coronary Artherosclerosis."
RANGOON, Burma, May 6-- Burma is fighting an uphill battles to achieve a healthy economy.
PARIS, May 6--One thing made clear by its latest council session is that NATO can no longer avoid the issue of Arab nationalism.
ANNE KLEIN, bright young designer for Junior So phisticates, has stepped out in a new direction. She is now dreaming up designs for Cellini shoes and Bonwit Teller.
OLD MYSTIC, Conn., May 6--An experiment in Methodist Church race relations has borne happy results. The nation's only Negro minister of an all-white Methodist congregation ...
WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)-- Four men were killed in the crash of a helicopter in the Bahamas Saturday, the Navy said tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)-- The National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics announced today the start of a new research program involving repeated and sustained airplane flights ten miles above the earth.
JERUSALEM, Monday, May 7--The World Zionist Congress in its closing hours early today rejected proposals of rightwing extremists who favor war by Israel against the Arab states.
The May 15 performance of "The Most Happy Fella" at the Imperial Theatre will benefit the Foster Home Division of the Children's Aid Society.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, May 6-- Prime Minister S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike has decided to deal firmly with the opposition of Trotskyites and Communists in and outside Parliament.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The Government's long-standing practice of buying transportation on a secret auction block was strained through a public sieve last week and appears headed for further study.

LOUISVILLE, May 6--"If Needless wins the Kentucky Derby," said one expert on matters equine just a few days ago, "it will set back the horse training profession twenty years. It's indecent to let a lazy horse train himself by not training at all."
LOS ANGELES, May 6 (UP)-- Jim Bailey, surprised at becoming the second fastest miler in history, said today he was still amazed by his time of 3:58.6 in beating his fellow-Australian John Landy.
The chicken-feed industry agreed last month to withdraw voluntarily feed containing a chemical additive that might possibly be dangerous.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold returned today from his mission to the Middle East. He was acclaimed by a welcoming group of United Nations diplomats on its success.
The Yankees blanked the Chicago White Sox, 4--0, in the opener at the Stadium yesterday. Then they duplicated the score in the second game.
The Waverly Terminal, an industrial development in Elizabeth, N.J., built in 1923 at a cost of $6,000,000, has been sold to two New York realty investing syndicates.
WASHINGTON, May 6--Private and public power advocates squared off today for a hard Senate battle over development of the vast hydro-electric resources at Niagara Falls.

NORFOLK, Va., May 6--Norfolk and State political leaders have devised a new plan to block immediate integration of public schools. The plan would place desegregation matters at the State Government level.

PHILADELPHIA, May 6 (AP) --The Philadelphia Crime Commission has proposed a meeting of the commission and other police authorities with representatives of the University of Pennsylvania in an effort to prevent further student disorders.

ROME, May 6 (AP)--Althea Gibson of New York gained the final round of the women's singles and Budge Patty and Herbie Flam advanced to the singles semi-finals of their division today in the Rome tennis tournament.
PARIS, May 6--Premier Guy Miollet challenged his fellow French republicans today to reform the regime to forestall those who would destroy the republic.
OLDWICK, N.J., May 6--Mr. and Mrs. Webster B. Todd have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kate Prentice Todd, to Charles O. Thompson.
Dr. and Mrs. Maurice Bruger of 45 Gramercy Park North have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Geraldine Bruges, to David S. Pollen of Glen Cove, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

LONDON, May 6--The stock markets gave a good account of themselves last week with a quietly upward trend. The impetus was provided by some good reports from a number of big industrial companies and a further improvement in the gold and dollar reserves in April.
WARSAW, May 6--Jakub Berman's resignation as a Deputy Premier and member of the Politburo of the United Workers (Communist) party was announced in the press today.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 6--Electors from the mountains and valleys of Mid-Ulster go to the polls Tuesday for the third time in a year to elect a member of the British Parliament.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP)-- Kansas City pounded Washington pitching for twenty-nine hits, including two homers by Gus Zernial and one each by Harry Simpson, Hector Lopez and Johnny Groth, to inflict 10-7 and 13-3 defeats on the Senators today.
GRAND FORKS, N.D., May 6 --Senator Estes Kefauver flew into North Dakota tonight for a whirlwind tour aimed at securing the state's eight votes at the Democratic National Convention.
Lightweight summer fabrics continued to dominate the readyto-wear ordering in the New York apparel markets last week, resident buying offices reported.

TO have missed "The Cradle Song" yesterday afternoon was to have missed one of the most beautiful and deeply stirring programs that television has ever offered. It was presented on Maurice Evans' "Hallmark Hall of Fame" over Channel 4.

In an Administration as committed as the present one claims to be to "businesslike procedures" it is surprising that so little attention has been paid to the legislation needed to carry out proposals of the second Hoover Commission for reorganization of the Executive branch of the Federal Government.
ZURICH, May 6--Swiss equities were in strong demand all last week.

Back in 1890 the Empire City Savings Bank opened for business in Harlem. In 1947 it opened a main office at 2 Park Avenue, but demonstrated its continued interest and confidence in the Harlem area by completing last year a $250,000 remodeling of its Harlem office at 231 West 125th Street.

It is with uneasiness bordering upon dismay that we read of the disorders in Korea which have followed the death of one of the Presidential candidates, P.H. Shinicky, who was the strongest of the opposition leaders. His death was from natural causes. It was not an act of politics; it was an act of God.
WASHINGTON, May 6--The Defense Department has asked the three services to come up with budget estimates for three years ahead.
BALTIMORE, May 6 (UP)-- The Baltimore Orioles toppled Detroit into the American League cellar today by sweepng a double-header from the Tigers, 6 to 2 and 4 to 3.

A Presbyterian case against religious training in the public schools was presented yesterday by the Rev. Dr. William B. McAlpin. His remarks came in the course of a sermon at West-Park Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.
PITTSBURGH, May 6 (AP)--A Negro church leader said today that the Negro church must retain its separate identity and not die through religious integration.
MILWAUKEE, May 6--Clem Labine may become a starting pitcher, Manager Smokey Alston said after the Dodger game with the Braves had been rained out today.
The orphaned International Longshoremen's Association is trying to get into the united labor movement.
PARIS, May 6--A new plan to insure Western political unity has been suggested by Secretary of State Dulles in the meetings of the North Atlantic Council that ended here today.

Murray Barron, chairman of the New York County Committee of the Liberal Party--apparently without knowing it--has given the advocates of court reform a telling argument for change in the way our judges are now chosen.
Net profit of the Coca-Cola Company for the first three months this year amounted to $4,479,576, against $4,114,554 earned in the corresponding quarter a year ago.
PARIS, May 7--President Tito of Yugoslavia appealed tonight for "new forms and new laws" to improve world relations.
ROME, May 7 (AP)--Australia's Lew Hoad gained the men's singles final of the Rome tennis tournament, then took a share of the men's doubles title today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 7--Dan McGugin, for thirty years the Vanderbilt football coach, is only a memory now. But the memory is so vivid that he's as much talked of hereabout as Knute Rockne is at Notre Dame. Dan did more than bring self-respect and national eminence to Vanderbilt football. He did the same thing for the entire South.
After five days, the Government finished yesterday the direct testimony of John Lautner, expelled Communist party official, at the trial of seven secondary party leaders.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., May 7-- Albert Isola, the 9-year-old nephew of Toney and Jim Tiso, gave his uncles some extracurricular worry today at the Westchester Professional Golf Association's opening pro-amateur tournament of the season.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP)-- The Senate paid its final respects today to Senator Alben W. Barkley, who died last week of a heart attack.
PARRIS ISLAND, S. C., May 7 (AP)--This Marine Corps recruit depot has undergone a drastic shake-up in the last seventy-two hours.
Eugene O'Neill's "The Iceman Cometh" will receive its first local revival at 2 P.M. today at the Circle in the Square, Seventh Avenue and West Fourth Street.
The Army's solicitousness for the morale of its married members was revised upward again yesterday.

Negotiations were competed yesterday for the construction of a thirty-story office building with 1,000,000 square feet of space to replace the present Produce Exchange Building on Broadway, between Beaver and Stone Streets. The site, running through the block to Broad Street, contains nearly 75,000 square feet of space.

MILWAUKEE, May 7--Bob Buhl, who previously had pitched only two complete games against the Dodgers in his career, made it three today at County Stadium. As a resalt, the world champions lost their third straight game, the Braves winning, 3-1, before a cold but happy Ladies' Day crowd of 18,845.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The Supreme Court ruled today that an employer who contended he could not afford to pay higher wages but refused to show his books had not bargained "in good faith" with his employes. The vote was 6 to 3.

WASHINGTON, May 7--Five Congressional committees took an interest today in the case of Sidney Hatkin, the Government employe suspended as a "security risk" who reported he way approached by a Soviet Embassy employe to do a report on the United States aircraft industry.

There could hardly be more vivid proof of the ferment now going on in Eastern Europe, and particularly in Poland, than the fall from grace of Jakub Berman. Long the gray eminence of the Polish Communist regime, he was the brains behind the Sovietization of Poland, the puller of the strings from behind the...

The hospitals in New York City serve as centers of preventive medicine, medical treatment and medical nursing education. The care of the sick in the city is common responsibility of the voluntary nonprofit hospitals of the Greater New York Hospital Association and the municipal hospitals of the Department of Hospitals.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon declined today to discuss the questioning of Murray N. Chotiner, his 1952 campaign manager, in a Senate investigation of alleged graft in Army uniform contracts.

CINCINNATI, May 7--The May Music Festivals in this city have a history going back to 1873, when Theodore Thomas conducted the first. They have been held every two years since, except on three occasions when there were three-year intervals between festivals.

DESIGNER Elizabeth Phelps breezed into Lord Taylor's Country Clothes Shop yesterday with her "Trade Winds" collection of two-faced separates that added up to a week-end wardrobe. It's a handful of cottons --reversible, mixable -- that would see many a woman through a summer of country living.

BALTIMORE, May 7 (AP)-- George Zuverink, the Orioles' bullpen ace, won a game on two pitches tonight. Hal Smith singled with the bases filled in the ninth to enable Baltimore to post a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 7 --Major league scouts have turned their eyes in the direction of this resort town to take a took at an 18-year-old high school senior who is the father of two children.

Save for a faint smell of smoke and an air of general curiosity, the New York Stock Exchange was normal yesterday. The damage by fire to most of its electrical communications system on Friday night was a thing of the past.
BALTIMORE, Tuesday, May 8--Milliard E. Tydings claimed victory early today in his comeback bid for Maryland's Democratic Senatorial nomination.
THE rainbow run from Ashokan Reservoir appears to be on in the Esopus and its tributaries.
WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- The Pennsylvania Railroad today opposed legislation to impose penalty charges against, roads that unduly detain freight cars of other lines.

David Dubinsky announced yesterday that he had promised the full cooperation of his International Ladies Garment Workers Union in the Federal inquiry into racketeering in the New York garment industry.
LONDON, May 7--The bells of St. Clement's will again peal out their celebrated "Oranges and Lemons" bell song to the delight of London's children, if present plans mature.

Mayor Wagner promised after a conference yesterday with officials of Northeast Airlines that he would study that company's petition to become the third carrier on the busy air route between New York and Miami.

WASHINGTON, May 7--A suspended Justice Department lawyer said today that a Government attorney had threatened to prosecute him unless he gave evidence in the tax fraud case against Matthew J. Connelly and T. Lamar Caudle.
Watch for this country's wines to splash "quality superiority" in an advertising campaign.
Charley (King) Cotton of Toledo, Ohio, upset Joe Giardello of Philadelphia in the ten-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Federal housing officials urged today that Congress give special mortgage assistance to elderly persons.
Eiffel Blue stretched an early lead like a rubber band to win the Greenvale Purse by twelve lengths at Jamaica yesterday.

ALGIERS, Algeria, May 7--Seventeen Europeans and an undetermined number of Arabs were killed in western Algeria last night in a series of coordinated attacks by na tionalist rebels. The French Army struck back quickly, and was reported to have killed more than 100 rebels.
THE Ballet Theatre Workshop presented a program called "Four Premieres" last night. It was the seventh and final "Sideshow" to be given at the Phoenix Theatre this season.
SAN JOSE, Calif., May 7-- Adlai E. Stevenson charged today that "America's moral direction of the world" had lost its momentum because of "foolish bumbling" by the Administration.

The Olin Downes Fellowship of the Edward MacDowell Association will gain from a benefit next Tuesday. It will be a feature of the annual exhibition of the National Association of Women Artists to be held in the National Academy Galleries, 1083 Fifth Avenue, from Thursday through May 27.

THE hit of a lively program of modern music last night in Town Hall was the most recent work of the Italian composer, Luigi Dallapiccola. Camera Concerts, Inc., presented the first American performance of his Cantata, "An Mathilde," composed in 1955 on poems of Heinrich Heine.

NORFOLK, Va., May 7-- The battleship Wisconsin, more heavily damaged than in two wars, steamed slowly into port today after a collison with a destroyer. The crash was ascribed to a mistaken report of a man overboard from a third warship.

SCHIZOMANIA is the occupational disease of Freudians. Earlier it had been such famous followers as Jung and Adler who split off from the teachings of the mind's most illustrious explorer and geographer. They had disciples who in turn found themselves compelled to chart consciously new ways through the illimitable unconscious.
NASHVILLE, May 7--A Chancery Court ruled today that state laws requiring racial segregation in public schools were invalid in Tennessee.
Ninety minutes of depressed trading near the end of yesterday's stock market session brought a generally lower close, although many oils, chemicals and atomic issues retained their gains to the end.
Thanks to Boston's triumph over Cleveland yesterday, the front-running New York Yankees will open their series with the Indians at the Stadium today enjoying a three-game American League lead.
A union-appointed referee recommended yesterday that the American Federation of Musicians expel eleven leaders of a Los Angeles revolt against the union's president, James C. Petrillo.
ABOARD U. S. S. MOUNT McKINLEY, off Eniwetok Atoll, Tuesday, May 8--Continued unfavorable weather has forced further postponement of the detonation of the newest type of hydrogen bomb.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 7 (AP)--Massachusetts Institute of Technology announced tonight that thirty-four young business executives, chosen from a wide range of industrial concerns, have been awarded Sloan Fellowships for participation in its executive development program.
GUILLAUME, celebrated Paris hair stylist, arrived in New York this week with a comb tucked in the pocket of his blue shadow-checked suit. A fat roll of sketches was under his arm.

WASHINGTON, May 7--A seven-year dispute between the Black River Regulating District of upstate New York and the Adirondack League Club, owner of a 100,000-acre mountain fishing and game preserve, was settled by the Supreme Court today.

ANCHORAGE, Alaska, May 7 (AP)--The more than 100 residents of the Kuskokwim River village of Sleitmut were reported today to be trapped by rising flood waters on the second floor of a two-story schoolhouse.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (UP)-- Admiral Arthur W. Radford has warned Congress that the United States cannot continue to adhere to the Korean armistice while the Communists build up their forces illegally in that area.

The companies in the Royal Dutch-Shell Group produced last year a record total of 551,700,000 barrels of crude oil and natural gasoline, according to the Dutch Petroleum Company. This compares with 507,400,000 barrels in 1954, the previous peak year.

It is good news that President Rojas Pinilla of Colombia has lifted the ban on the noted liberal newspaper El Tiempo of Bogota. The closing of El Tiempo last August aroused the condemnation of the hemisphere and of everyone interested in freedom of the press.

WAUKESHA, Wis., May 7 (AP) --An excursion train carrying 900 pupils to a baseball game in Milwaukee was derailed in a crash with a loaded gravel truck today. More than 100 persons were injured, mostly children.
WASHINGTON, May 7--The Kefauver-for--President campaign is pretty much a one-man band, And the one man, of course, is Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee.
WASHINGTON, May 7--The Senate Agriculture Committee decided today to forego hearings on the new Democratic farm bill in an attempt to clear it for Senate action early next week.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges were generally lower yesterday. Trading was light and featureless in most markets. Cocoa, hides, rubber, burlap, zinc and sugar declined; potatoes, coffee and silk rose and price movements for cottonseed oil, soybean oil and wool were mixed.
Governor Harriman called on New Yorkers yesterday to show "zeal, not moderation" in leading the nation in a war against discrimination.
The Liberal party gave its formal endorsement last night to the two Tammany candidates for the Surrogate bench--Supreme Court Justices Joseph A. Col and S. Samuel DiFalco.
A tidy sum was returned to holders of shares in big board companies in the first three months of this year, according to the New York Stock Exchange.
ALBANY, May 7--Governor Harriman will undergo what his office calls "a minor operation" at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in New York May 20.
The General Telephone Corporation confirmed yesterday plans for turning its wire and cable manufacturing operations over to the General Cable Corporation by means of an exchange of stock.

Yesterday morning was just like any other to Dr. Marion E. Kenworthy, noted psychiatrist and pioneer educator in psychiatry, social work and mental health. She saw three patients and took care of other matters as on any "work" day. But her afternoon was more unusual, because the day was a very special one.

The Fruehauf Trailer Finance Company, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Fruehauf Trailer Company, has arranged to borrow $235,000,000 on term bank loans and on issues of notes due in eight and in twenty years. Of the total, $95,000,000 represents new financing and the rest a refunding and recasting of old loans.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 7 (UP) --The Pacific Coast Conference college presidents, in the wake of startling disclosures of "under the table" payoffs to athletes at the University of Washington and other schools, today ordered "self examination" of athletic policies at all nine member schools.
The day of reckoning arrived yesterday for owners of rubbishstrewn vacant lots in the city.

The 1956 Pulitzer Prizes in letters, journalism, music and art were announced yesterday by Columbia University. The novel honored was "Andersonville," by MacKinlay Kantor, and the winning play was "The Diary of Anne Frank," by Frances Goodrich and Albert Hackett.

SEOUL, Korea, Tuesday, May 8--The first burst of emotion over the death of the principal Opposition candidate in next Tuesday's Presidential election appeared to have subsided today. The death led to rioting here and in Pusan Saturday.
The sniper who killed a church warden and injured five other persons with a rifle volley Saturday night gave himself up yesterday. He admitted the shooting but gave no coherent reason for his act.
Detroit Edison Company's growth in 1946 should be "about in line" with the most recent years, Walker L. Cisler, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday.
BUDAPEST, Hungary, May 7--The Cafe Belvarosi in Budapest reopened recently.
LONDON, May 7--The Labor Opposition voiced its uneasiness today over the recent breakdown of the United Nations disarmament talks here after seven weeks of secret negotiations.

BONN, Germany, May 7--A campaign is developing in West Germany to put pressure on East Germany for a wholesale release of its political prisoners. The Social Democratic party is the force behind the campaign.
Plans are being made to send a bus caravan of New York longshoremen to Washington on Thursday. They will lobby in behalf of increased workmen's compensation for dock workers injured on the job.

GREAT NECK, L.I., May 7-- Shelley Mayfield and W.G. Holloway of Meadow Brook comprised the winning pro-amateur team as the Long Island Professional Golfers Association opened its tournament season today.
Although the roster of athletes participating hasn't been completed yet, the uniforms for the United States Olympic team are designed and ready for action.

LONDON, May 7--Buying orders from the United States and France helped lift prices of the leading oil shares here today. Shell and Royal Dutch gained 3/16 and 2 points respectively and Ultarmar also advanced. Profit taking brought closing losses to British petroleum, however.

MAKINGS for an authentic, varied smorgasbord-at-home can be found in one Brooklyn shop, the Scandia, Delicatessen, 244 Flatbush Avenue. Big brown beans that Swedes bake with molasses and vinegar come in two-pound cloth sacks for 59 cents.
A pair of traditional Japanese figures sculptured lifesize in chrysanthemums are on display in the Japan Trade Center, Fifth Avenue at Thirty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Secretary of State Dulles gave a private forty-five-minute report to President Eisenhower late this afternoon on the Paris meeting of the North Atlantic Council.

The Society for the Rehabilitation of the Facially Disfigured will benefit from the Oaks Hunt twentieth annual Spring Horse Show. It will take place Sunday at the Greentree Polo Field on the John Hay Whitney estate in Manhasset, L.I.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 6 points up to 7 points off yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- The Supreme Court unanimously reinstated today an award of $100,000 damages won by a group of Navajo Indians against the Government. One hundred and sixteen horses and thirtyeight burros had been destroyed in lower San Juan County, Utah, by Federal agents.
AFTER seventy-seven years, "A Doll's House" may be excused for having lost the power it originally had to shock respectable people. It has also lost some of its literary distinction.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 7 --The arrival here today of twenty Soviet parliamentarians, sixteen of them members of the Supreme Soviet, had some sharp repercussions.
Anthony Anastasia extended his defiance of the top officials of the International Longshoremen's Association last night.
PHILADELPHIA, May 7-- Harry I. Stern, president of Stern Co., department store chain, died last night at his home in suburban Melrose Park, after an illness of five months. His age was 55.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Savings bankers heard a prediction here today that the Federal Reserve System would soon take steps to ease the credit supply.

CAIRO, May 7--Responsible Middle Eastern analysts believe Jordan has gained a strong diplomatic advantage by having agreed to join Egypt in unified defense planning without getting entangled in her Arab nationalist bloc.

If young men are to be drawn into the fields of teaching and medical and social work, "serious consideration" should be given to raising salaries in those professions, the Under Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 7--A lower court ruling upholding the right of the Postmaster General to establish an experimental program for the transportation of 3-cent mail by air was left standing by the Supreme Court today.
MOSCOW, May 7--Much of the Soviet Union's history is being rewritten these days, but, not the part about who invented wireless.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Secretary of State Dulls, back from Paris, will go before B'nai B'rith, a Jewish service organization, tomorrow night to explain his European policy.

FORT WORTH, May 7 (UP)-- Al Balding and Gordon Brydson of Toronto beat the cream of the United States Professional Golfers Association today, but the Americans walked off with a 5 -to-3 lead in the fourball portion of the international P.G.A. team matches.

CAIRO, May 7--The quiet that has prevailed along the Gaza strip for almost a month wad reported broken today. The incident occurred on the eve of negotiations there between the Egyptians and the United Nations truce chief on measures to prevent such clashes.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 7-- Brazil's War Minister is fast becoming one of the most influential political leaders here.

SHIPPINGPORT, Pa., May 7--Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that disposal of waste from atomic fuels presented no serious problem at this stage. Mr. Strauss said the term "atomic waste" was a misnomer.
Five thugs held up nine persons, including a policeman, early yesterday in a daring robbery at the Breslin Hotel, Broadway and Twenty-ninth Street. They escaped with $861 in cash.

An unusual dispute between the National Maritime Union and the Farrell Lines over surf conditions and native surf boats in some West African ports has cost the steamship company thousands of dollars in penalty overtime for seamen.
JOHNSON CITY, Tex., May 7--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson turned his back today on plans for an organized bid for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
ST. LOUIS, May 7--Bill White, who was awakened in Indianapolis last midnight to be informed he had become a Giant, made an auspicious debut as a major leaguer tonight.

CHICAGO, May 7--Wheat and corn futures met free selling today and showed no capacity for holding rallies, while old-crop soybeans were strong and sharply higher. No special change in the character of the news was indicated in reference...

Three apartment houses at 943-47 Teller Avenue, the Bronx, were bought by Friedman Abrams, operators, from the estate of Alexander Soling and immediately resold it to Louis Wenger, investor. The property is assessed at $135,000. M. Keener was the broker in both transactions.
OTTAWA, May 7 (Canadian Press)--Canada has successfully negotiated a number of tariff reductions with the United States and other countries, informants said today.
TRENTON, May 7--Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed a bill today that makes uninsured motorists solely responsible for maintaining the State Unsatisfied Claim and Judgment Fund.

A nonprofit group dental insurance plan for low-income employes was announced yesterday. The plan by Dental Insurance Plan, Inc., 26 Court Street, Brooklyn, covers employe and union groups of fifty or more persons.

BOSTON, May 7 (AP)--Boston's Tom Brewer baffled Cleveland on four hits today in posting his third victory of the season, 5-1.

MacKinlay Kantor's "Andersonville" was described in a New York Times review as a "tremendous novel on a tremendous theme." Its locale was the Confederate stockade in southwest central Georgia where 50,000 Union men were imprisoned in the Civil War. One-third of them died there.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 --The National Broadcasting Company is planning a twohour, live television production of Dostoevski's classic story, "Crime and Punishment." Elliot Lewis, the N. B. C. executive who coordinates the "spectacular" programs for the network's...
BOSTON, Mass., May 7-- Three parcels of abandoned textile property, here and in Lawrence, Mass., have been sold for other uses in the last three days.

WASHINGTON, May 7 (AP)-- The White House announced today the selection of Vice Admiral Robert P. Briscoe to be Commander in Chief of Allied Forces in Southern Europe, succeeding Admiral Wiliiam M. Fechteler.

When all the irrational rationalizations about abandonment of Congressional authority or surrender of united States interests are cut away there lies exposed the basic high-tariff philosophy of those who are fighting President Eisenhower's request than the United States join the proposed Organization for Trade Cooperation.
WASHINGTON, May 7--B'nai B'rith, the 113-year-old Jewish service organization, projected today a program to combat the increasing juvenile delinquency.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 7-- The two-day meeting of Indian and Pakistani officials on the increasing migration of Pakistani Hindus to India was cordial, but no agreement was reached.

HACKENSACK, N.J., May 7 --John Borg, former publisher and later chairman of the board of directors of The Bergen Evening Record, only daily newspaper in Bergen County, died in his sleep early this morning at his home at 282 Prospect...

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 7 --The Universal-International studio resembled a minor United Nations today. Flags of fiftyfive nations waved in greeting over the main entrance gate as seventy-two of the studio's sales executives gathered for the company's first global conference.
PATCHOGUE, L. I., May 7-- The Republican-controlled Legislature's "watchdog" committee has shifted its attention to this village, a Democratic stronghold in Republican Suffolk County.
The amount of fat in the diet and not merely the total number of calories appears to be important in the development of heart conditions in overweight people.

Representative Adam Clayton Powell's Congressional secretary had to kick back to him her salary from 1948 through 1952, Thomas A. Bolan, assistant United States Attorney, said yesterday. He added that a Government witness would testify to that effect today.

A seven-story building containing four stores and twentyfour apartments at 232-240 Sullivan Street has been purchased by Gertrude Viosky. The property occupies a plot 25 by 95 feet at the southwest corner of West Third Street opposite the new Law School building of New...
Evidence thus far indicates that an election for the presidency of the 125,000-member Teamsters Joint Council here was "tainted with illegality," Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri ruled yesterday.
MILLARD EVELYN TYDINGS never was one to run away from a scrap. For all of his 66 years, he has kept fists swinging.
RANGOON, Burma, May 7-- A plan to put 1,000,000 acres of Burmese land into wheat for Israel is symbolic of the friendship that has sprung up between the two countries.
Brewing coffee is not yet a lost art, but the instant variety is still charging ahead.
Tallahassee, Fla., announced yesterday plans for borrowing $6,000,000 in the bond market on June 7. The issue of bonds will mature serially from 1958 to 1986.

The Pulitzer Prize awards announced yesterday at Columbia University, awaited with the usual interest, were a final selection from a record field of competing entries this year. For the journalism awards there were 718 entries, 186 more than 1954's previous high. Several hundred entries were considered for the prizes in letters.

Promoters of the International Home Building Exposition, which will open in the New York Coliseum Saturday, announced yesterday that they had been forced to cancel plans for twelve television programs that would have originated there.

Poultry in interstate commerce should come under Federal control, a Mayo Foundation pathologist said yesterday. Dr. William H. Feldman urged legislation to specify for poultry the same compulsory inspection established fifty years ago for meat from cattle, swine and goats.

Winner over Cornell and Princeton in the Carnegie Cup race, Yale was seeded first yesterday for the sprint championships of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges. The regatta will be held Saturday, on the Potomac at Washington, with thirty-eight crews entered from thirteen colleges.
The country's second superliner now in the discussion stage will not be built as an atomicpowered passenger vessel.

WASHINGTON, May 7--The National Lawyers Guild received a setback in the Supreme Court today in its fight to bar Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. from adding it to his list of subversive organizations.

Clarence Wilson Brazer, an architect who had designed many public and private buildings here and in Pennsylvania, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home, 31-07 Union Street, Flushing, Queens. He was 76 years old.

HOBOKEN, N.J., May 7-- The United States Steel Corporations plans to spend at least --$2,500,000,000 in the next five years for expansion and modernization. Roger M. Blough, chairman of the nation's largest steel producer, disclosed the gigantic building program at the annual stockholders meeting here today.

Patrol judges are the traffic cops of thoroughbred racing. Their job is to watch the races for collisions, violations of the rules and the notably few attempts to influence the results by larcenous means.

SIMULTANEOUSLY with the publication of an essay en titled "The Nature of Space," I. Rice Pereira, artist, is holding an exhibition of work done since 1950. The show includes about thirty examples of Miss Pereira's quite individual and highly colorful work and is being held at the Wellons Gallery in its new and more spacious quarters at 17 East Sixty-fourth Street.

IRVINGTON, N.J., May 7-- A strike by teachers closed the public schools here today. They remained away from classrooms because town officials had not acted on their request for a $400-a-year pay increase.
WASHINGTON, May 7--Senator Hubert H. Humphrey challenged today the Administration's emphasis on the military side of its foreign-aid program.

WASHINGTON, May 7--It isn't as anomalous as it sounds that the good news just sent to the national Democratic party from Texas is bodeful of new trouble for the three Democrats now most prominently before the American people as aspirants to the Presidential nomination.

BISMARCK, N. D., May 7-- Senator Estes Kefauver, seeking nomination for President, careened across North Dakota today in a last-minute bid for the support of both the members of the Nonpartisan League and the state's regular Democrats.

JERUSALEM, May 7--The Executive of the Jewish Agency for Palestine will meet tomorrow to break the Zionist deadlock over whether Mrs. Rose L. Halgrin or Dr. Emanuel Neumann should be acting chairman of the Executive in New York.
Efforts are being made to match Mel Barnwell, Boys High's sprint champion, against Al Phillips, the Montclair (N. J.) dash sensation. A national schoolboy record could be the result.
Walter F. Tellier, head of a Jersey City brokerage firm, pleaded not guilty yesterday to an indictment charging him with heading a $15,000,000 uranium stock swindle.

HONG KONG, May 7--A recent Chinese Communist dispatch from Lhasa indicates heavy damage to a key river bridge on the eastern Tibetan border. The bridge spans the upper Yangtze River along the highway leading westward into Tibet from China proper.

Stockholders of the Boston Edison Company at a special meeting yesterday authorized issuance of 180,000 shares of $100 par first series cumulative preferred stock, the first senior stock issue in the company's history.

CLEVELAND, Miss., May 8-- Southern business men were urged here today by David Rockefeller to encourage investment locally by outside capital to speed a "quiet revolution" from an agricultural to an industrial economy.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Governor Harriman of New York came tp the Capitol today in the interests of flood control and politics.

ALGIERS, Algeria, May 8-- Observance of the eleventh anniversary of the Allied victory in Europe in World War II was disturbed here today by a demonstration of Europeans hostile to French policies in Algeria.
WASHINGTON, May 8-- Leaders and candidates of both major political parties were urged today to repudiate publicly the efforts "of hate mongers to inject bigotry" into the Presidential campaign.
New issues of public utility and railroad securities totaling $49,750,000 will be placed on the market today by investment banking syndicates. The issues are as follows:
LOS ANGELES, May 8-- Senator Estes Kefauver asserted today that the Eisenhower Administration had been making "deals" with "wrong-doing" business men instead of enforcing the antitrust laws.

CINCINNATI, May 8--The Giants were all braced for a tornado tonight as they opened a two-game series with the devastating Redlegs. However, when it finally struck, Bill Rigney's Polo Grounders had just enough to weather it and they made off with the game, 5 to 4.

Cottonseed oil futures tumbled yesterday in one of the sharpest declines in several years on the New York Produce Exchange. The volume, 534 tank cars, was the sixth largest of the year. Prices fell 47 to 97 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The July position was weakest.
Henry Ford 2d has retired as chairman of the board of trustees of the Ford Foundation, the Ford family's huge philanthropic trust.

VALHALLA, N.Y., May 8-- The engagement of Miss Virginia, Cram O'Sullivan to Alexander Lambert Blackburn of New York and Durham, N.C., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. O'Sullivan. The wedding will take place June 2.
WASHINGTON, May 8--A campaign against perils created by conflicting highway laws was urged today at the opening here of the sixth biennial Highway Transportation Congress.
WASHINGTON, May 8--The Administration reversed its position today and decided to support an International Labor Organization convention condemning forced labor.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 8--It was an awkward situation and no football coach in the country could have escaped as neatly as did Art Guepe of Vanderbilt University. The chancellor of the university demanded his presence at the same time he was supposed to be interviewed by a visiting sports columnist.
ROME, May 8 (UP)--Althea Gibson of New York won her sixth straight European tennis final today by defeating Hungary's Susi Kormoczy, 6--3, 7--5, in Rome's international tournament.
CHICAGO, May 8--Annual sales of Motorola, Inc., are expected to reach $400,000,000 by 1960, Paul V. Galvin, president, said during the company's annual stockholders' meeting yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Lehman bill for public development of Niagara Falls power was attacked sharply today in a memorandum handed to members of the Senate Republican Policy Committee by their chairman, Styles Bridges of New Hampshire.
THE new president of the city's lawyers is a man of such judicial temperament that his clients sometimes have been tempted to ask him whether he was sure which side had retained him.

The Government's pirincipal witness in the trial of seven secondary Communist party leaders testified yesterday that he had received $22,000 from the Department of Justice as an employe for the last five years.
BALTIMORE, May 8--Unofficial returns today from yesterday's Maryland primary made Millard E. Tydings the winner of the Democratic Senatorial nomination.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday its opposition to a proposed code for television film producers. The organization said it opposed all codes in the communication industry because they restrained the trade of ideas and interfered with freedom of expression.

Columbia University's baseball team gained its first Eastern Intercollegiate League victory of the season yesterday by defeating Pennsylvania, 10--7, at Baker Field. The decision broke a last-place tie between the teams. They had entered the contest with 0-3 league marks.
TODAY'S housewife picking a can off a grocery shelf knows at a glance what is inside. But it was not always so.

FORT WORTH, May 8 (AP)-- Tommy Bolt and Jack Fleck, the National Open champion, shot one-under-par 69's today as the United States scored its most overwhelming victory over Canada in the international Processional Golfers Association matches.

Americans must wonder sometimes why the French are expending so much blood and treasure to hold Algeria. It seems like an impossible task, and there are those who think in terms of pure "colonialism" and who condemn the French on that often hazy and mistaken principle.
WASHINGTON, May 8-- Charles E. Wilson characterized the defense budget of $36,200,000,000 today as "austere" and adequate for the "critical needs" of the armed forces.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., May 8--The "tight-money policies" of the Republican national Administration have cost suburban residents millions of dollars in unnecessary interest, Governor Harriman declared here tonight.
MILWAUKEE, May 8 (AP)-- Warren Spahn allowed three hits tonight and struck out ten to shut out the Pittsburgh Pirates, 5--0, and keep the Milwaukee Braves in the National League lead.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 8 --"Kings Go Forth," the newly published, novel by Joe David Brown, will be made into a motion picture by Frank Ross. The purchase agreement calls for a "large cash payment," plus a financial participation for the author in the prospective film profits.

In taking the preliminary steps of his freshman year's work on the capital budget the new chairman of the City Planning Commission, James Felt, can see trouble ahead. Debt-limit exemptions that allowed considerable space for maneuver are about used up.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Seventeen House Democrats from New York today urged that the damaged battleship Wisconsin be sent for repairs to the Brooklyn naval shipyard.
MONTREAL, May 8--Canada's shipping industry faced today its most serious crisis in years.

For many years, slim Jim Barnes, who was born in Cornwall, England, was one of the game's leading campaigners. Back in 1921 he won the United States Open and four years later he captured the British Open.

OTTAWA, May 8--The Canadian Government gave TransCanada Pipe Lines, Ltd., not only the green light but a nudge today to get started on the western leg of the pipeline eventually to bring Alberta Natural gas to Ontario and Quebec.
RANGOON, Burma, May 8-- The cement is everywhere. It is piled high in the warehouses, the docks are choked with it and more ships are waiting to unload it when berthing room becomes available.
DALLAS, Tex., May 8--Senator Lyndon B. Johnson nailed down at the county convention level today his control of the Texas Democratic party by a decisive margin.

LONDON, May 8--Roland Petit and his Ballets de Paris opened a four-week engagement tonight at the Palace Theatre as part of Peter Daubeny's international season there. The company was newly assembled only a few months ago and is shortly to be disbanded again to allow M. Petit to make another film.
Following is the text of an address by Secretary of State Dulles last night to the triennial convention in Washington of the Supreme Lodge of B'nai B'rith, as recorded by The New York Times:

CINCINNATI, May 8--It has taken almost three years for Benjamin Britten's opera, "Gloriana," to cross the Atlantic. Its American premiere took place tonight as the second event of the forty-first Cincinnati May Music Festival.
Louis M. Loeb was elected president of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York at its annual meeting last night.
BALDWINSVILLE, N.Y., May 8--Dr. James H. Bennett, cited as the state's outstanding general practitioner for 1955, died at his home here today after a long illness. His age was 47.

More than 1,000 students and instructors of Columbia University have signed petitions asking a waiver of the mandatory retirement for age of Boris M. Stanfield, Russian-born Associate Professor of Economics.
Morton Sobell, serving thirty years for conspiracy to commit wartime espionage, petitioned in Federal Court yesterday for his freedom or a new trial.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Texas joined New York today in asking a rehearing of the Slochower case by the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Sales, earnings and dividend payments for United States manufacturing corporations climbed to record levels in 1955, according to the joint report for the final quarter of last year made public today by the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Federal Trade Commission.
Health insurance plans are rapidly easing the demand for free municipal hospital beds, the city's Commissioner of Hospitals reported last night.
VANCOUVER, B.C., May 8-- Three convicts held a guard hostage at razor's edge last night but freed him after a newspaper man had promised them an extra edition to tell their story.

Prices of cotton futures moved 1 point up to 12 points off today. The market opened 7 points off to point up and during the late trading fluctuated in a narrow range. There was some commission house liquidation in old crop months. There were four May notices issued in the local market.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture, in a final report based on ginnings, today estimated the 1955 cotton crop at 14,721,000 bales of 500 pounds gross weight, valued at $2,382,000,000.
Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism will retire at the end of the current academic year. He has served as head of the school for twentyfive years.

Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt said yesterday that he would cut his racing string from forty-two to five thoroughbreds for the remainder of this season.

Brokers and bond buyers will be watching closely today the public sale of a $30,000,000 Niagara Mohawk Power bond issue. The offering will test the scope of a market turnabout that began a few weeks ago.

The city moved again yesterday to delay the trial of a suit opposing a half-acre parking lot at the Tavern on the Green in Central Park.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Wednesday, May 9 (AP)--Gov. William C. Marland early today led a field of five West Virginia Democrats seeking nomination to the unexpired term of Senator Harley Kilgore, who died Feb. 28.
OSSINING, N.Y., May 8-- The chapel at Maryknoll was dedicated today on the hilltop where its two founders once knelt in the grass to pray.
WASHINGTON, May 8--A major expansion goal aimed at increasing supplies of nickel 30 to 50 per cent is expected to be announced soon by the Office of Defense Mobilization.
WARSAW, May 8--A comparative political unknown was chosen today to succeed Jakub Berman, Poland's former strong man, a Deputy Premier.

"Kiss Me, Kate," which had attained a run of 1,077 performances when it closed here in 1951, returns at 8 o'clock tonight at the City Center, where the engagement will continue through May 27.
Bill Boland completed a riding double at Jamaica yesterday by winning the $7,500 Prospect Park Handicap aboard the oddson favorite, Midafternoon. The winner paid $3.60, $2.70 and $2.30 for $2.

Earnings of the Amerada Petroleum Corporation in the first quarter were about $1.20 a share against $1.02 a share in the 1955 period, A. Jacobsen, chairman, told shareholders attending the annual meeting here yesterday.

The sixteen-story office building at 45 West Forty-fifth Street has figured in a sale and leaseback transaction. It was sold by Henry Goelet, investor and builder, to Morris Furman and Associates, with the seller taking back a long-term lease.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell was accused yesterday of having received the salary paid to his Congressional secretary.
PARIS, May 8--France found today in President Tito of Yugoslavia a sympathetic listener to her views on disarmament.

ALBANY, May 8 (AP)--Governor Harriman's counsel declared today that he had "no intention" of acting as a go-between in an effort of the International Longshoremen's Association to return to the federation of labor unions.

The Mayors of Fair Lawn, Montclair and Ridgefield Park were re-elected yesterday and carried to victory with them all members of their tickets.

DANBURY, Conn., May 8-- Announcement has been made of the engagement of Miss Jane Shalley, daughter of Mrs. John T. Shalley and the late Mr. Shalley, to John Kenneth Mansfield, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Anthony Mansfield of Chicago.
A 130-year-old church in a forgotten segment of New York, the ruin of a once handsome structure of colonial neo-classical design, was ordered closed yesterday as a fire hazard.
INDIANAPOLIS, Wednesday, May 9--President Eisenhower held early today a comfortable lead over Senator Estes Kefauver in the Indiana primary election popularity contest held yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Secretary of State Dulles said tonight that there were "grounds for hope" of an Arab-Israeli settlement if the Soviet Union made good its pledge to work for peace through the United Nations.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Prospects brightened today for an increase in the disposal abroad of the Government's multi-billion-dollar holdings of surplus farm products.
OTTAWA, May 8--Corliss Lamont, author and lecturer known for his left-wing ideas, was denied admission to Canada today. He was barred at Windsor, Ont., after his arrival by train from Detroit.

WASHINGTON, May 8--Israel has asked the ExportImport Bank for a loan of $75,000,000 to finance development of water resources. The bank is an agency of the United States Government. The application became known today, as diplomatic sources reported
The election of women as church wardens and vestrymen and as delegates to diocesan conventions of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York was approved yesterday.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Wednesday, May 9--Michael V. DiSalle, former Federal Price Administrator, held a commanding lead early today in the five-man primary race for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Ohio.
LANDSHUT, Bavaria, May 5 --Sasha Likhonovich, Soviet Army deserter, veteran of the anti-Communist Vlasov Army in World War II, refugee from Soviet justice for twelve years, is going home.

CHICAGO, May 8--Livingston E. Osborne, Chicago attorney and chairman of the Illinois Athletic Commission, died of a heart ailment today in St. Luke's Hospital here. He was 71 years old.

"PLAY wrights '56," which for much of the season has smarted under the competition of "The $64,000 Question," evened a couple of scores last night by offering an acidulous comedy, "You Sometimes Get Rich," about an Army sergeant who wins $80,000. While it wasn't always too good a play it wasn't a bad trade joke.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Mandatory sentences for narcotics traffickers would be doubled and probation barred under an enforcement program unanimously approved today by a House Ways and Means subcommittee.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May. 8-- The North Country Community Association will present Patrice Munsel, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera, in a benefit program on Saturday evening for its scholarship and nursing funds. The entertainment will take place in the auditorium of the high school.

BISMARCK, N.D., May 8-- Senator Estes Kefauver appeared tonight assured of support from at least half of the delegates North Dakota Democrats will send to their party's national convention at Chicago opening Aug. 13.

THE National Association of Women Artists' sixty-fourth exhibition of oils, water-colors, prints and sculpture opens this evening at the National Academy, 1083 Fifth Avenue, with a special reception, and will open to the public tomorrow. The closing date is May 27.

Dr. Morris M. Slotnick of 44 North Broadway, White Plains, geophysical consultant for the Standard-Vacuum Oil Company of New York died. Monday in Dallas, Tex. Dr. Slotnick, who was about to board a plane when he suffered a heart attack, was 54 years old.
With only two matches remaining in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub series, one district champion took a commanding lead yesterday.

ONLY one resident on Gramercy Square has the right to enter Gramercy Park without the special key, whenever he's minded to do it. He moves around the Square at his own slow pace with no fear of rushing cabs or trucks.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP)-- North American Airlines said today it had sent President Eisenhower an explanation why it had hired Murray Chotiner to represent it in Washington.

It is seventeen months until Army and Notre Dame get together again on the gridiron, but orders are being sent in for the game that is the biggest draw in football next to the Army-Navy rivalry.

In the strategic areas immediately to the north of India there are some signs of political ferment. There are repeated reports of anti Communist revolts in Tibet, now under nominal Chinese Communist rule.

HYANNIS, Mass., May 8 (AP)-- Dr. Gordon Keith Chalmers, president of Kenyon College in Gambier, Ohio, died today in Cape Cod Hospital of a cerebral hemorrhage. Dr. Chalmers, Whose age was 52, was stricken while on a business trip in this area.
THE blackfish season has started in Long Island waters and pollock are striking for those who care to fish the rips.
In an effort to foster the "amateur ideal," five major sports organizations have formed a National Committee on Amateurism in Sports, it was disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 8--W. Randolph Burgess, Under Secretary of the Treasury, said today that when "market conditions are somewhat better" the Treasury would offer another longterm bond.

BALBOA, C.Z., May 8--John S. Seybold, who is retiring as Canal Zone Governor, advanced the theory last night that it was not the locks so much as Culebra Cut that would be the determining feature in any decision to increase the Panama Canal's capacity.
That milling, yammering, weird-hatted crowd that used to be the old Outdoor Curb Market milled and yammered again yesterday, this time on a movie screen.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Four legal authorities urged Congress today to approve tight restrictions on the power of Government agencies to withhold information from the public, press or Congress.
ALGIERS, Algeria, May 8-- Irving Brown, American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations representstive in Europe, has been barred from Algeria.
WASHINGTON, May 8--Harold E. Stassen said today that the United States was seeking "safeguarded semi - disarmament" now.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 8--Dag Hammarskjold will report to the Security Council that he has achieved the specific objectives assigned him by the Council on his mission to the Middle East.

TANGIER, Morocco, May 8-- The French High Commission in Morocco halted military operations north of Fez today "to permit Moroccan authorities to negotiate" the release of a group of Senegalese riflemen captured by a band of Moroccans yesterday.
SINCE Jose Quintero's productions at Circle in the Square are always admirable, no one should be surprised by his latest achievement.
Joint Resolution 97, recently passed by the Senate, increases the ceiling on United States contributions to the International Labor Organization from the present one of $1,750,000 to $3,000,000.
BOSTON, May 8 (UP)--Dick Gernert's single in the thirteenth, which scored Billy Consolo, gave the Boston Red Sox a 4-3 victory over the Chicago White Sox today in an errorfilled game.
Strength for the rails yesterday failed to overcome weakness in the industrial list and the stock market declined moderately. Motors, chemicals and metals led prices downward.

Stockholders of North American Refractories Company, Cleveland, were informed yesterday in a letter signed by E.W. Valensi, president, that several efforts have been made since February to acquire the company and that none of them
ST. LOUIS, May 8 (AP)--A tax official testified today that he had made no promises of immunity in the tax case that led to a conspiracy indictment against two officials of the Truman Administration.

CAIRO, May 9--Egypt accused the Western powers today of having decided to grant Israel superiority of arms over the Arabs. The Government of Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser planned to take "all measures necessary to insure her safety in face of the threat from imperialist countries and their arming of Israel," it was announced.
RABAT, Morocco, May 9-- The Moroccan Government's official spokesman said today the country was in a state of "psychological disarray" and that the Government was seeking to re-establish order.

The first name in the Congressional Directory's list showing "continuous service of Senators" is that of Walter F. George, Democrat of Georgia, who began his Senatorial career in November, 1922. Next year a different name will head the...
New air raid warning signals go into effect today throughout New York State. Admiral Alan G. Kirk, retired,
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, May 9 --The Scandinavian Airlines System and the Soviet airline Aeroflot opened today a joint scheduled service between the Scandinavian capitals and Moscow.

A statement by Mrs. Hattie Freeman Dodson, in which she denied giving Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. the salaxy she had received as his Congressional secretary, was read into the record yesterday at her trial for income tax evasion.
LOS ANGELES, May 9--Adlai E. Stevenson came out tonight for a program of low interest Government loans to advance the cause of voluntary prepaid health insurance for the nation.
WARSAW, May 9--The Polish press, freer than in many years, has let loose a flood of criticism of the Government for its persecution of the Home Army.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, May 9--At the third attempt in a year, the Parliamentary constituency of MidUlster was indisputably held today by an unofficial candidate pledged to uphold the union of Northern Ireland with Britain.
Settlement houses and neighborhood centers are easing the assimilation of newcomers in urban communities, Councilman Stanley M. Isaacs said yesterday.

BOSTON, May 9--The power of public opinion in determining national policies in a democracy places a "grave responsibility" on citizens to be soundly informed, Arthur Hays Sulzberger, president and publisher of The New York Times, asserted tonight.

TORONTO, May 9 (Canadian Press)--Control of Morrison Brass Corporation, Ltd., has been acquired for $5,000,000 by Acme Subdivisions, Ltd., of Toronto, it was announced today. The deal involves purchase of 1,250,000 shares at $4 a share.

THE PRESIDENT--Good morning. Please sit down. I suppose that all the representatives of the radio industry here know that next week is Radio Week, and I want to pay my little tribute to radio, not only as a medium of bringing education, information, entertainment into the home, but for its very wide value in the international world.
Whimsical newspaper advertising, new merchandising methods for securities and group selling have paid off for the New York Stock Exchange Corporation of Arthur M. Krensky Co., Inc.

The heavyweight picture regarding a successor to the retired champion, Rocky Marciano, was brightened yesterday when Floyd Patterson of Brooklyn and Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson of Far Rockaway, L.I., signed for a twelve-round fight at Madison Square Garden on Friday night, June 8.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., May 9--Spring flowering gardens never before opened to the public are to be included in a garden tour for the benefit of Guild Hall which has been planned by Eastern Gate and East Hampton Garden Club members for Sunday afternoon. In case of rain the tour will be held on May 20.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 9-- Two seasoned campaigners, both short, stocky and energetic, have won overwhelming Ohio primary victories. They will meet in November's gubernatorial election.

The American Cancer Society reported yesterday that 400,000 Americans now alive had been cured of cancer. At least 800,000 more now fated to die of cancer can be saved in the next ten years if the disease is detected early and treated promptly, the society added.
St. John's University broke a 2-2 tie with four runs in the seventh and defeated Hofstra, 7--2, in a Metropolitan Conference game at Alley Pond Park, Queens, yesterday.
BALTIMORE, May 9 (UP)-- Needles, the 1956 Kentucky Derby winner, arrived at Pimlico from Churchill Downs today to begin prepping for the $100,000 added Preakness Stakes on May 19.
EVERY now and then glamour sneaks into the High School of Fashion Industries, 225 West Twenty-fourth Street.
AN extraordinary survey of German graphic art from the late fourteenth century to the present will open to the public today at the Metropolitan Museum.

A frequent casualty of slumclearance for public housing, both low rent and middle income, is the displaced shopkeeper. The displaced housing tenant is also a problem, and opinions differ on how well he is handled, but some attention at least is given to him. But the shopkeeper is likely to be a forgotten man when a site is cleared.
The "habit-forming drugs-- alcohol, tobacco and barbiturates"--are high among the major causes of human deterioration. This assertion was made yesterday by an elder statesman of public health.
ATHENS, May 9 (AP)--Vassili Dendramis, former Greek Ambassador to the United States, died in a hospital here today. He was 73 years old.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9-- Martin Manulis, producer of the "Playhouse 90" TV program, which will be introduced in the fall by the Columbia Broadcasting System, is delving into the book market in his quest for subject material.

There is general agreement among those scanning the business skies for signs of what lies ahead that the portents do not by any means point in the same direction. One of the areas, however, that is considered to have potential inflationary implications is to be found in those industries that are faced with a greater production demand than they can meet with their existing facilities.

"Obsolete management," not the rise of suburban shopping areas, caused the closing of three downtown New York City department stores, a leading retail executive said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP)-- Paul Foytack, a right-hander, gained his first major league victory tonight. He pitched the Detroit Tigers to a 7-3 triumph over the Washington Senators with the help of homers by Charlie Maxwell and Al Kaline.

TOMORROW, 4 P.M.: A puppet show will take place at the New York Public Library, Tremont Branch, 1866 Washington Avenue. Free tickets of admission are available at the branch library and must be obtained before performance time.
"The Lovers," a new play by Leslie Stevens, will have its Broadway premiere at the Martin Beck Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock.
