A group of Lincoln Square business men decided yesterday to make common cause with their residential neighbors in trying to delay the $150,000,000 redevelopment of that area. The change has been proposed by Robert Moses, chairman of the Committee on Slum Clearance.
Radio and television engineers and camera men employed by the Columbia Broadcasting System have rejected a proposed contract that had been agreed upon by negotiators for the network and the union.
William B. Rourke, former Commissioner of Purchase, died yesterday in his home at 67-92 Groton Street, Forest Hills, Queens. His age was 79.
A new world will be built about every two weeks in New York's Coliseum--and be taken apart again after several wonderful days.

NUREMBERG, Germany, May 5--At a rate of 120 a month, new fugitives from Communist lands straggle into the West German Government's big reception center here in Bavaria to join the foreign refugee community.

NOT too long after the finish of the Kentucky Derby last Saturday, the steaming jockey room at Churchill Downs was starting to disgorge the photographers, writers and jockeys who had jammed into the tiny cubicle. Things were quieting down when a new and arresting voice was heard in the background. In the foreground, though, was the usual hubbub.
The State Commission Against Discrimination is investigating complaints that major airlines operating in and out of the city have refused to hire qualified Negro applicants for jobs.
A one-story taxpayer on plot 100 by 100 feet at 5102-5112 Third Avenue in Brooklyn, occupied under lease by Safeway Stores, Inc., has been purchased by Jacob L. Rosenthal.
TORONTO, May 9--Corliss Lamont was admitted to Canada today after Ottawa reversed an immigration decision that barred him yesterday.
The International Ladies Garment Worker's Union is considering merging its 134 welfare and pension funds into one giant fund.
WASHINGTON, May 9--The chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today that its easing of credit to member savings and loan associations did not conflict with Administration credit policy.

LONDON, May 9--Prime Minister Eden said today that the frogman who was lost while diving near the Soviet cruiser Ordzhonikidze in Portsmouth Harbor was not engaged in operations sanctioned by the British Government.

WASHINGTON, May 9-- Senator Walter Franklin George, the most influential Congressional supporter of the bipartisan foreign policy since the late Senator Arthur H. Vandenberg, announced today that he would not seek re-election in November.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 9-- President Eisenhower easily walked away with Indiana's popular vote over Senator Estes Kefauver in yesterday's primary election.
Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges moved irregularly yesterday. With the exception of cottonseed oil and potatoes, trading was dull in most markets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 9 --A 78 per cent increase in foreign business during the last five years for Universal-International was disclosed today by Americo Aboaf, foreign general manager. He also said the company's overseas earnings this year are running ahead of 1955, when these revenues amounted to 43 per cent of the total income.
A New York County grand jury voiced suspicion yesterday that narcotics were being smuggled into Manhattan City Prison (the Tombs) and were being used by inmates.
WASHINGTON, May 9--Senator J. William Fulbright denounced the Administration's foreign aid program today as "militaristic."
OTTAWA, May 9--One of the biggest political storms in years has blown up over the Canadian Government's proposal to help finance the building of a transCanada gas pipeline.

ST. LOUIS, May 9 (AP)--Tom Poholsky, pitching his third straight victory, limited Philadelphia to four hits tonight as the Cardinals triumphed, 3--0. It was their sixth victory in their last seven starts.
Alexsandr K. Guryanov, one of the Soviet diplomats at the United Nations who was asked by the State Department to leave the country, departed yesterday on the Cunard liner Queen Mary.
ATLANTA, May 9--Former Gov. Herman E. Talmadge stepped forward rapidly tonight to advance his claim to the Senate seat being vacated by Senator Walter F. George.
LONDON, May 9--Britain's first "automation strike" failed today to win official recognition from the leaders of the ten unions involved.
FLEMINGTON, N.J., May 9 (AP)--C.M. White, president of Republic Steel Company, today predicted a bright year for the company.
Former President Truman pictured Governor Harriman last night as a person who could be depended upon to cope effectively with Communist imperialism.
Cotton futures moved irregularly yesterday on the Never York Cotton Exchange. Final prices were 8 points higher to 7 points lower than on Tuesday.

Plans for a new apartment building on the upper East Side were announced yesterday along with a report of the purchase of a plot 100 by 102 feet at 315 to 321 East Seventy-first Street by the Preston Realty Corporation.
AT the City Center, "another o'p'nin', another show." This time it is "Kiss Me Kate," which opened there last evening as the second production of the Spring Musical Season.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (UP)-- A former Army purchasing agent testified today that his wife had banked $12,231 more than he earned one year and also had hidden money in a closet at home.
WASHINGTON, May 9--President Eisenhower said today that he would have a complete physical check-up this week.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 9 (UP) --Tiny Volo won the one-mile Woodmere Trot in 2:06 3-5 by two lengths from M.C. Rose at Roosevelt Raceway tonight. Lady M. was third.
After tying the score in the seventh inning on Yogi Berra's ninth homer, the Yankees bumbled themselves into a 6-5 setback by the Indians before 12,225 spectators at the Stadium yesterday.
LONDON, May 9--Despite a late rally, most prices on the stock markets were slightly lower today. Sentiment was again affected by the dullness of Wall Street.

Varied diversions have been planned for the seventeenth annual spring festival of Ecole Francaise du St. Esprit to be held on Saturday afternoon in the garden of the school of 109 East Sixtieth Street.

Dr. M. Joseph Mandelbaum, an ear, nose and throat specialist, and a bronchoscopist, died Tuesday in the Park Town House Nursing Home, 61 East Ninetyfirst Street, after a long illness. His age was 74. He formerly resided at the Alcott Hotel.

ROME, May 9--The frequency of heart attacks is a warning to the Twentieth Century man to seek inner peace, according to Pope Pius XII. The Pontiff said modern science appeared to be powerless in its efforts to stave off the threat of sudden death.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee voted unanimous approval today of the nomination of Thomas E. Stakem Jr. of Arlington, Va., to be a member of the Federal Maritime Board.
The Interstate Commerce Commission was directed yesterday to give further consideration to the Long Island Rail Road's opposition to a proposed "piggyback" operation by three competing railroads.
BHATGAON, India, May 9-- This was a fine day for fifty Indian farmers. Each received a gift of one iron plow and four other agricultural implements.
Judge Jacob Gould Schurman of General Sessions and the office of District Attorney Frank S. Hogan were at odds again yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The 78-year-old dean of the United States Senate announced his retirement today without using the word "retirement."
A decline of 968,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute.

Julie Oshins of 19 West Fiftyfifth Street, comedian, died yesterday at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospital. His age was 50. Mr. Oshins was well known for his parts in the stage productions "This Is the Army" and "Make Mine Manhattan."
ATLANTA, May 9 (AP)--The defending champion and the medalist won easily today in the first round of the fiftieth Southern amateur golf tournament.
LONDON, May 9--Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong tonight broke all rules of theatrical protocol before Princess Margaret and the Princess apparently loved it.

TOKYO, May 9--The sunny month of May is being called the "evil season" in some circles here because of the current and forthcoming nuclear weapon tests by the United States and Britain in the Pacific.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., May 9--Walter S. Hallanan, Republican National Committeeman, apparently retained his party leadership in yesterday's primary election. However, the voting, brought the downfall of the long-established Democratic Statehouse machine.

A novel British "bypass" engine has broken the hold of American manufacturers on the long-range jet-airliner market.

BONN, Germany, May 9--Sir Winston Churchill arrived in Germany today amid controversy as to his fitness to receive an award for contributions to European unity. It was the first time he had stepped onto German soil in eleven years.

IF commercial airlines had arrived 200 years ago, few pas sengers would have gotten beyond the weighing-in platform. The deerskin-covered hollow logs that served luggage needs in the eighteenth century could hardly compete with today's plastic suitcases weighing ounces.

ATHENS, May 9--Sympathy for two Greek Cypriote terrorists condemned to be hanged boiled up here today in rioting against Britain and the United States. Three persons were killed and 124 injured before Greek troops and the police restored order.
WASHINGTON, May 9--A major expansion in the production goal for nickel has been approved by the Defense Mobilization Board, according to reports today.
Four youths were arrested early today and three others were being sought in the stoning on Sunday and Monday nights of a Ngro couple's home in a predominantly white East Bronx neighborhood.
A large-scale test of American diet to determine if it contributes importantly to the onset of heart ills was suggested here yesterday.

The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday rejected in its present form a proposed plan of reorganization submitted by the trustee for the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation and its subsidiaries.

NEW DELHI, India, May 8-- The brother-in-law of the Dragon King hitched his great broadsword, teetered on embroidered boots and talked with a knowledge that has come to a few men in the world's most hidden land.

MIAMI BEACH, May 9 (UP)-- Bob Baker of Pittsburgh opened the scramble for the vacated heavyweight throne tonight with a unanimous twelve-round decision over John Holman at they Miami Beach Auditorium.
John Dio Guardia, a labor racketeer known also as Johnny Dio, was adjudged in criminal contempt of court yesterday by General Sessions Judge Mitchell D. Schweitzer.

Forty American steamship companies operating from East and Gulf Coast ports offered yesterday to increase seamen's wages by 4 per cent. The offer was rejected as "unrealistic" by Joseph Curran president of the National Maritime Union.
MOSCOW, May 9--A sharp dispute in highest military quarters over the rewriting of the history of World War II was revealed today in an unusual way.
Rail stocks rolled ahead yesterday to the highest point since June 7, 1930. The rest of the market was highly irregular.

WE joined the gold rush at Bloomingdale's yesterday, arriving by easy escalator stages at the third-floor beachwear shop. There Cathy Grand-Jean, a blonde attired in a bathing suit covered with gold coins, and Barbara Benz, a brunette wearing a gold sequin suit, had stopped all traffic.

A marketing syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., is offering a new issue of $4,500,000 of first mortgage 3 7/8 per cent bonds of Savannah Electric and Power Company due May 1, 1986 at 102.239 to yield 3.75 per cent to maturity.
WASHINGTON, May 9-B'nai B'rith, 113-year-old Jewish philanthropic organization, voted today to participate in an international federation that would act as consultant on world Jewish problems.
This will be a cruising summer. The family owning a sizable pleasure craft will be on the move. All signs point to it.

CHICAGO, May 9--Soybeans tumbled in trading today on the Board of Trade. The May and July futures fell 10 cents, the permissible limit for a day. But there was a partial recovery with the new-crop futures showing comparative strength.

ATLANTA, May 9--Herman E. Talmadge, Georgia's former Governor and probable choice for Senator, is a refined version of his father, the late Eugene "Ol' Gene" Talmadge, who made the snapping of his red galluses a successful political trademark.

LANSING, Mich., May 9--Gov. G. Mennen Williams announced today he would seek a fifth term. The Governor has frequently been mentioned as a dark horse Presidential or Vice Presidential possibility. He said he did not consider himself "a candidate for national office."

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Atomic Energy Commission issued revised personnel security regulations today in a new effort to balance national safety and individual rights. A policy statement in the new rules said it had been the commission's intent to safeguard security "in a manner consistent with traditional American concepts of justice."

The financial condition of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation continued to deteriorate in the first quarter of the year. It reported yesterday a loss of $14,311,173 on sales of $106,795,438. This compares with a deficit of $5,694,141 on sales of $152,196,287 in the like period last year.

AT this season the apple a day that keeps the doctor away may come in a jar or can. Storage bins of apples picked last fall are almost empty; any fresh apples they maay still be offered have become so indifferent in quality as to hold little attraction for cooks.
The improvement of downtown Manhattan as a place to live as well as work was suggested yesterday. It would be part of the projected redevelopment of the financial area.

WASHINGTON, May 9--President Eisenhower signed "with some reluctance" today the bill to control future expansion of bank holding companies and require a few of them to get rid of all nonbanking assets.

PARIS, May 9--Algerian rebel hopes of evicting France from North Africa rest exclusively on the possibility of foreign pressure and intervention, Robert Lacoste, French Minister Residing in Algeria, said today.

Searching closed last to win the $22,550 Correction Handicap at Jamaica yesterday. Permitting the favorite and the second choice to wear each other down, Conn McCreary on Searching managed to take the seventeenth running of the stakes by almost a length.
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 9-- Army's baseball team scored a 2-1 Eastern Intercollegiate League victory over Princeton at Doubleday Field today.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)-- President Eisenhower nominated today four new members and four others for reappointment to the National Science Board, a Government research organization.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 9-- The Rockefeller brothers' theological fellowship program, which seeks to attract outstanding young men and women into religious work, has made awards to forty-seven college graduates. MANILA, May 9--The Philippines and Japan signed a World War II reparations agreement today that makes the former the No. 1 customer for Japanese industrial goods and manufactures for the next twenty years and probably also the best source of raw materials.

BOSTON, May 9 (AP)--Three racing shells, one from Harvard and two from Andover Academy, each carrying nine men, filled with water and sank in the choppy Charles River today. All were hauled out safely.
CINCINNATI, May 9--The Redlegs hit no home runs tonight. In fact, they hit nothing but singles.

MIAMI, May 9--Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, arrived here by plane today.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The gross national product of the country ran at an annual rate of $398,500,000,000 in the first quarter of this year, the Government announced today. The gross national product is the total value of all goods and services produced in the country.

HARTFORD, May 9--Ever since the spring of 1942 the Hartt Opera-Theatre Guild has been presenting opera in the Connecticut capital. It has consistently sought fresh material, and last night for its annual spring bill it presented two oneact operas that had never been done before.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Senate Agriculture Committee approved tonight a modified version of the new Democratic farm bill that was adopted last week by the House of Representatives.

Strong United States support for Israel was advocated last light at a public meeting at the Town Hall. The session was the climax of seventy-fifth anniversary observances of the New York Board of Rabbis.

The Pennsylvania General State Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids June 12 on $20,00,000 of revenue bonds.

John W. Chamberlin, president of the Automatic Washer Company. Newton, Iowa, announced yesterday that John MacArthur, Chicago investor, had bought all of Automatic Washer holdings of the Bellanca Aircraft Corporation. New Castle, Del., and of Sydney L. Albert.

Jed Prouty, a motion picture and stage actor for fifty years, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a brief illness. He was 77 years old.

The newly formed Tri-State College Basketball League, an affiliate of the Eastern Collegiate Athletic Conference, yesterday completed the organization of its nine charter members.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10--Initial returns received here today from yesterday's plebiscite in British Togoland indicated a preference among the voters for future union with the Gold Coast.

Harry, Albert and Jack L. Warner, who are the last pioneer dynasty in motion-picture production, have agreed to sell their controlling interest in Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., the company they founded in 1923. The sale is to a group of investors headed by Sere Semenenko.

CLEVELAND, May 15--Rain prevented the Yankees and the Indians from playing tonight at Municipal Stadium. But it did not stop Hank Greenberg, the Cleveland general manager, from indulging in one of his favorite pastimes--firing a barb at the Yankees.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 15-- David Dubinsky estimated today that the united labor movement would raise a maximum of $3,000,000 in voluntary political contributions for this year's Presidential and Congressional elections.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 15 --Before an audience of 5,000, Gov. Earl K. Long was sworn in today for a third time. He is the first Governor in Louisiana to serve three terms.
JACKSON, Miss., May 15 (AP) --Mississippi's State Sovereignty Commission, "watchdog" of states' rights, voted today to hire secret agents to serve as "eyes and ears" in the fight to keep segregation.

DETROIT, May 15 (UP)--The Detroit Tigers routed Willard Nixon with eight hits and five runs in the first four innings today and gained a 6-3 triumph over the Boston Red Sox. The victory snapped Detroit's threegame losing streak.

WASHINGTON, May 18--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee was told today that the real enemies of the world were poverty, hunger, disease and economic despair.
The Board of Education has approved a new teacher salary schedule. It will increase salaries for 40,000 teachers and other school personnel by $21,000,000.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18 (AP) --An official of the South Bergen Savings and Loan Association of Wood-Ridge, N.J., says the housing boom may taper off in the next few years because of a low birth rate in the early Nineteen Thirties.
The California Packing Corporation had record sales in its fiscal year ended Feb. 29, and earnings rose sharply over those of the previous year.

DENVER, May 18--Mrs. Mary-Josephine Gardner Cumings of Princeton, N.J., and Hamilton Stearns Gregg 2d of this city were married here at noon today in the Church of Bonnie Brae (Congregational). The Rev. Eugene Van Kranenburgh performed the ceremony.
CHICAGO, May 18--Unless the nursing profession can obtain more funds for education, the present nurse shortage cannot be alleviated, the president of 177,000 professional nurses declared here today.

WARSAW, May 17--The Polish Government is prepared to grant full personal liberty to Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski and his right to return to Warsaw provided that he does not reassume his functions as Primate of Poland.

BALTIMORE, May 18--The D. and H. Stable's late-charging Needles, winner of three successive big-money stakes, figures to be the 4-to-5 favorite in the eightieth Preakness Stakes at Pimlico's old horse park tomorrow. The purse will total $132,800 if all nine of today's entrants go to the post.
Directors of Dan River Mills, Inc., at a meeting in Danville, Va., yesterday, cleared the way for the acquisition of four concerns.

Two more banks are going underground. The Central Savings Bank and Union Square Savings Bank plan to open annexes on the mezzanine level of the IRT Lexington Avenue and BMT stations, respectively, at Union Square.
The Chain Belt Company filed yesterday with the Securities and Exchange Commission a registration statement covering a proposed offering of 76,543 shares of common stock.
WASHINGTON, May 18-- The Textile Workers Union thrust aside the warnings of its Southern delegates today and adopted a resolution favoring school integration and condemning White Citizens' Councils.
The Dodgers tied the score against the Redlegs in the ninth inning at Ebbets Field last night and had the 10,520 fans standing and yelling for a victory. But the Brooks couldn't make it.
HAWORTH, N.J., May 18-- The Montclair Golf Club won the Woman's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team championship today at the White Beeches course.
Between April 13 and May 15, the New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday, the aggregate short interest in its listed stocks fell from 2,529,580 to 2,453,409 shares.

PARIS, Saturday, May 19 --The opposition to the dispatch of French reservists to fight the rebellion in Algeria exploded in serious rioting in the southern provincial city of Grenoble last night and early today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 --Representative Joseph Holt, Republican of California, charged today that the Administration and Members of Congress had brought pressure to bear in an effort to halt House Subcommittee hearings on the American Federation of Musicians.
RIO DE JANEIRO, May 18-- Brazil requested the International Monetary Fund today to authorize modifications in the exchange regulations aimed at encouraging the export of secondary products.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 18 --Members of the General Federation of Women's Clubs were urged today to get on their local school boards.

LOS ANGELES, May 18--Ray Robinson retained his world middleweight championship tonight by knocking out Carl (Bobo) Olson. Sugar Ray stopped his rival in 2 minutes 51 seconds of the fourth round of a scheduled fifteen-round scrap at Wrigley Field.

THE latest contestants in the international art field are the members of the PotoPoto School in French Equatorial Africa. A selection of their sprightly and gaily fantastic drawings is now on view at The Little Studio, 680 Madison Avenue.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18 --Mrs. Peter Frelinghuysen's 2-year-old toy poodle, Ch Nibroc Gary, was a six-pound giant killer in the specialty of the Poodle Club of America today...

Tobaccos and metals staged an upward flurry yesterday, but the rest of the stock market remained unimpressed. Gains for the leaders were nibbled away, and at the close the market was slightly lower and showed more losers than gainers.
Form players had the best of the going at Belmont Park yesterday as favorites accounted for five events. In the featured seventh race, Lawless, 6-5 on the morning line, was backed...
CLEVELAND, May 18 (AP)-- Pete Runnels' fifth straight hit, an eleventh-inning single, gained a 5-4 victory for the Washington Senators over the Cleveland Indians tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)-- President Eisenhower today nominated T.A.M. Craven, a Washington engineer to be a member of the Federal Communications Commission for a seven-year term.

Pentecost will be celebrated in churches tomorrow. It commemorates the descent of the Holy Ghost upon the apostles and early Christians fifty days after the first Easter. Pentecost is often called the birthday of the Christian Church.

A newspaper editor called on women yesterday to become more "fully informed" on the affairs of the community, the state and the world and to avoid the "dangerous tendency of letting others do our thinking for us."
There will be no strike on the Long Island Rail Road on Monday.
WASHINGTON, May 18--The State Department disclosed today that shipment of twenty-one Army surplus half-track vehicles to Israel was barred last week because they lacked a valid export license.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation's handling of the theft of a classified Government document was called a "spy scare" yesterday by an attorney.

PARIS, May 18--The Middle East crisis seems to be assuming a new aspect. There appears to be less chance of imminent outbreak of fullscale fighting in Palestine but possibly more chance of ultimate war.

The animal kingdom made news yesterday from Madison Square Garden to New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens. At the airport five beasts arrived from Africa. At the Garden seventeen Mexican burros trotted in.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 18 --Jack Lyons and Dan Dayton, the medalists, shot sub-par golf in winning their opening match in the Walter J. Travis Memorial tourney today at the Garden City Golf Club.
Harry Gross was found guilty of grand larceny last night. An all-male jury in Kings County Court returned its verdict at 10:40 P.M. after eight hours of deliberation.
CAMDEN, N.J., May 18 (AP)-- "Let's win the race first then we'll talk about retirement."
The Bronx Democratic political organization has chosen a Grade A egghead as a district leader.
PARIS, May 18 (UP)--Four Californians--Budge Patty, Art Larsen, Herb Flam and Bob Perry--swept into the fourth round in men's singles today at the French tennis championships.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 18-- A peppery little man with gray crew-cut hair took a cold shower this morning. He came out with a $120,000 idea that means better health for Puerto Rican garment workers.

EMMA SMITH is the pseudonym of an Englishwoman, now in her sixties, and "A Cornish Waif's Story"* is her re markable autobiography, most of it dealing with her childhood and early life. Edith Sitwell, who does not bestow praise haphazardly, has called this book "one of the most moving...

WASHINGTON, May 18--The Administration won a major victory on the domestic farm front tonight but lost on the international front as the Senate passed a second election-year farm bill. Final passage was on voice vote.

BONN, May 18--West Germany's central bank raised its rediscount rate sharply today. It was the third time in the last nine months that a stiff dose of anti-inflation medicine had been administered to the German economy.
THOUGH not as obsolete as the blasksmith shops, fish stores certainly are far fewer than then used to be. The decline is regrettable, as a visit to one of the remaining establishments will show.

TORONTO, May 18 (Canadian Press)--Shareholders of British American Oil Company Ltd., today approved a proposal under which British American will acquire Canadian Gulf Oil Company, and Gulf Oil Corporation of the United States gets a majority interest in British American.
Salo Katzman, a vice president of the Associated Metals and Minerals Corporation, died Thursday night at the University Heights Sanitarium in the Bronx. His age was 52.
An expert on public information said yesterday that the United States should try to "sell" the rest of the world on the value of modern American free enterprise as a bulwark of human freedom.
The Board of Directors of the Metropolitan Opera has given the American Guild of Musical Artists until June 1 to withdraw contract demands that the Metropolitan is unwilling to grant.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)-- The Labor Department estimated today that unemployment in the automobile industry had risen to 159,000 on May 12. This was a net increase of 11,000 for that week.
WASHINGTON, May 18-- Senator Paul H. Douglas of Illinois, thwarted at least twice in earlier bids, realized a longstanding aspiration today. He was assigned a seat on the Senate Finance Committee.
Electric blankets are "old hat" but the United States Rubber Company has developed a completely new type with industrial applications.
An active period for the new capital market lies immediately ahead. Underwriting capital is in a good position to take down new commitments and go in for sharp pricing.

A plan for converting the old Mills Hotel at 153-61 West Thirty-sixth Street at Seventh Avenue into showrooms has been advanced with the passing of title to the property to the Style Center Realty Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 18--For the vessel against an enemy ship the man who wants to hang his or pier and then explode the own wallpaper, Joseph C. Nowak main charge.

WESTPORT, Conn., May 18-- Karl Anderson, portrait and landscape painter who was dean of the Westport art colony, died today in the Westport Sanitarium, of a cerebral hemorrhage. He was 82 years old and had been ill for several years. He was a brother of Sherwood Anderson, the author.
LONDON, May 18--The BritishSingapore talks on self-government for the colony, which had shown fleeting signs of life after its collapse Tuesday, was pronounced dead today.
By the stability of the Central Committee [of the Communist party], of which I spoke before, I mean measures to prevent a split, so far as such measures can be taken.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 8 to 23 points up yesterday in moderate business.
HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 18-- Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, was told today that private industry had made tremendous strides in peaceful uses of atomic energy in the last two years.

ATLANTIC CITY, May 18-- The International Ladies Garment Workers Union warned today that labor might decide to sit out the Presidential election and concentrate its political strength on Congressional contests this year.

TRENTON, May 18--Gov. Robert B. Meyner will discuss the status of Averell Harriman as a Presidential candidate in the presence of the New York Governor tomorrow night. The occasion will be the third annual $100-a-plate fund-raising dinner of the Democratic State Committee.
TAMPA, Fla., May 18--Clutching a stuffed alligator and campaigning to the wail of mountain music, Adlai E. Stevenson today renewed his Florida fight for political survival.

HONOLULU, May 18--A $24,000,000 investment in roll-on, roll-off rail freight shipping facilities between the West Coast and Hawaii is being considered seriously by the Walter F. Dillingham interests of Honolulu.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 18-- The British authorities banned today all shipping in the coastal waters of northwestern Cyprus. They did so as a precaution against the smugling of men, arms and ammunition to terrorists in the mountains back of the port of Karavostasi.
ROME, May 18--Pope Pius XII recommended today devotion of the Sacred Heart of Jesus as the essence of Christianity and as an antidote against hatred.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 18 --A new economy program got under way today at Warner Brothers.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)-- Joseph C. Duke, the Senate Sergeant-at-Arms, said today that films surrendered to Capitol police by a Negro photographer on orders of Senator Olin D. Johnston "hadn't even been exposed."
MONTREAL, May 18--The eight-day strike that tied up almost 100 Great Lakes vessels ended late today with full agreement by all the unions involved and the Association of Lake Carriers.
VIENNA, May 18--Hungary's leading Communist said tonight that all Hungarian Social Democrats whose release had been requested by British Laborites had been freed before that request.
WASHINGTON, May 18-- Harold E. Stassen said today the Russians' announced decision to cut their armed forces by 1,200,000 men was an "initiative we wanted them to take."

The New York Chapter of the Society of Colonial Wars will be host to the General Council of the National Society and officials of the twenty-five state chapters at a series of meetings and social events next Friday and Saturday.

WASHINGTON, May 18--The House Foreign Affairs Committee knocked out today a structure on Iron Curtain trade that it had added yesterday to the Eisenhower Administration's $4,900,000,000 foreign aid bill.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 18--Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom's Nationalist party Government won another round today in South Africa's constitutional struggle.

RALEIGH, N.C., May 19-- Dave Sime of Duke equaled world records in two events to dominate the annual Carolinas Amateur Athletic Union track meet today.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 19--Mr. and Mrs. Manion J. Pritchard have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Pritchard, to Kevin Vincent McGarry. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. McGarry of Flushing, Queens, New York.
ESSEX FELLS, N.J., May 19 --Miss Susannah Harlow Lyman was married here this evening in St. Peter's Protestant Episcopal Church to Sherman Brownell Chace by the Rev. Harold R. Onderdonk.

Two events last week pointed up the increasing difficulty of getting into college. On Friday, thousands of high-school seniors were notified whether or not they had been accepted by the colleges of their choice--and a large proportion got bad news.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., May 19--President Sukarno of Indonesia motored 100 miles from Washington through the Virginia countryside today. On the way he stopped for friendly visits with scores of Americans of all ages; and everybody seemed to get along fine.

ST. LOUIS, May 19--A person's use of the Fifth Amendment to protect himself is not proper cause for his dismissal from his job, the representatives of 22,000 social workers of the country asserted here today.

Benjamin B. Greenberg will retire at the end of the academic year as Assistant Superintendent of Schools. He has spent most of the last fifty years dealing with two extremes--the delinquent pupil and the gifted.
RAPALLO, Italy, Sunday, May 20 (Reuters)--Sir Max Beerbohm, the British essayist, critic and caricaturist, died here at 2 A.M. today, after an illness of several weeks. He was 83 years old.

A sort of cosmic variety show, "The Grand Universal Circus," with music by Henry Brant and text by his wife, Patricia, had its first performance yesterday afternoon at the McMillin Theatre of Columbia University. The performance was part of David Broeckman's concert series "Music in the Making."
Columbia's varsity heavyweights ended their rowing season on a disappointing note yesterday. Matched against a Rutgets eight that never let up, the Lions lost by a length and a quarter.
MOSCOW, May 19--Ambassador Charles E. Bohlen told Nikita S. Khrushchev today that there was no question of liquidating the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

WASHINGTON, May 19--The most determined effort since 1938 is now being pressed to check and reverse the trend of Supreme Court decisions. In 1938 President Roosevelt pursued this objective through a statute to enlarge the Court's membership and put an age limit on the tenure of the justices. In 1956 twelve Senators, former Associate Justice James F. Byrnes and the sponsors of about seventy legislative proposals led the attack.

Plans for expanding United States participation in international trade fairs will include exhibits behind the Iron Curtain. This was disclosed yesterday by the program's new director, Harrison T. MacClung.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 21-- Last week-end's garbage stood uncollected today outside 30,000 homes and business places in Sanitary District 6 when the district's 105 workers failed to report for work.
Risks to the public from a nuclear power plant are greatly exaggerated, according to Hudson R. Searing, chairman of Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc.
LIVERPOOL, England, May 21 (AP)--Leo Valentin, French "birdman," dived 9,000 feet to his death today trying to fly with wooden wings.

JOHN LANDY of Australia is so intelligent, clear-thinking and logical that his words should never be ripped away from the general background of his conversation. It's when they are taken from context that they seem shocking or vainglorious or both. Want a sample?

LONDON, May 21 (UP)--Ira Murchison, a stocky, 22-year-old Army serviceman from Chicago, completed a sprint "double" in the two-day international track meet at White City Stadium today when he won the 100-meter dash in 10.6 seconds.
New York World Trade Week got off to a noisy start yesterday as ocean and harbor shipping let loose at the stroke of noon with port-wide thirty-second whistle blasts.

Stockholders of the Natomas Company at a meeting yesterday in Sacramento, Calif., authorized the company to enter the steamship business by acquiring assets of A.P.L. Associates, Inc. Natomas operates placer deposits in Sacramento County, Calif.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The Supreme Coprt ruled today that state "right-to-work" laws prohibiting railroad union shop agreements were invalid. Eighteen states have such laws.

AN electronic innovation in political campaigning--an informal studio chat between two Presidential aspirants-- was provided in last night's appearance of Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, and former Gov. Adlai E. Stevenson of Illinois on the American Broadcasting Company's network.
Tuberculosis specialists are puzzled and alarmed over the increasing appearance of a disase that looks like, but is not, tuberculosis.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The Supreme Court today invoked an incongruous trio of the illustrious dead to support its finding that, if Congress sanctions compulsory unionism and an employer grants it in collective bargaining, any provision to the contrary in a state constitution or late is thereby overridden.
A syndicate headed by Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co., is offering about $3,316,500 of new Class A and Class B common stock of American Shopping Centers, Inc.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --Senate investigators made public today evidence to show that the late Harry Dexter White tried to block shipments of $200,000,000 in gold to Nationalist China in 1945.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 21-- The Republican National Chairman said today his party would "slug it out" with the Democrats in every one of the forty-eight states from now until election day.
EL PASO, Tex., May 21--The Army will test its controversial Nike anti-aircraft missile tomorrow for the first time before a press audience.
CLEVELAND, May 21-- Warnings that soft spots in the economy might develop into a recession or even a depression were sounded here today.

For the past three years the official Temporary Commission on the Courts has been studying the administration of justice in the state and how it should be improved. In March of last year the unofficial Committee for Modern Courts was organized to inform the ...
RICHMOND, Va., May 21--Dr. Carlos Prio Soccaras, a former President of Cuba, and an aide have been excluded from the United States, the Immigration Service said here today.
ROME, May 21--Former President Harry S. Truman suggested today that after the Presidential election Democrats and Republicans should "get together and support the Government."

PARIS, May 21 (AP)--France's uninhibited tennis fans razzed court officials and cheered the point-throwing gestures of two Italian players today as they saw Australia's Lew Hoad and Italy's Giuseppe Merlo win places in the semi-finals of the French tennis championship.

CHICAGO, May 21 (AP)--The Chicago White Sox today obtained Jim Wilson, a pitcher, and Dave Philley, an outfielder, from the Baltimore Orioles in exchange for four players, including their third baseman, George Kell.
Stocks yesterday broke to the lowest levels silice March 2-- but did it in the slowest trading since mid-February.
Have advertisers been plugging brand-names to no avail while competitors have been walking off with the market? Has the campaign clicked in some areas but not in others?
RYE, N.Y., May 21--Jim Marotta, the Maplemoor pro, and Mike Hirsch of Quaker Ridge won the opening 1956 Westchester County Golf Association pro-amateur tournament by a stroke today.
CHICAGO, May 21 (AP)-- Butcher hogs and sows jumped 25 to 50 cents today for the tenth straight session of advancing prices, one of the longest sustained upturns on record.
Turnpike bond underwriters and investors are keeping a worried eye on current earnings of the nation's expressways. Yesterday some less-than-happy news came from Ohio.

TAKING a tip from the Southern Belle--who isn't afraid to use lace, ruffles, soft lines and pastel colors to her advantage--Designer Hope Reed has turned out a collection of pretty summer dresses with an ultrafeminine confectionary look.
WHITE PLAINS, May 21-- shotgun pellets ripped through the side of an armored truck here today and wounded five pedestrians. The weapon had been fired accidentally inside the vehicle.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 21 (AP)--A Jewish leader denounced today what he called "brazen interference in domestic American politics" by an Arab diplomat.

There seems to be no connection between the awesome explosion of the H-bomb, dropped from an airplane at Bikini, and the role of science a century or so hence as it has been depicted in a "speculative projection" by professors of the California Institute of Technology.
DETROIT, May 21 (AP)--A leveling off of car output is in prospect this week for the auto industry.

Dr. Thomas Alexander C. Rennie of 34 Gramercy Park, Professor of Social Psychiatry at Cornell University Medical College, died yesterday at New York Hospital of a brain hemorrhage after a brief illness. His age was 52.

In a mood in which the pride of Victorian days is giving way to a justifiable sense of achievement in another direction, the British people prepare to celebrate on Thursday this week a traditional holiday-- Empire Day.

PAMPLONA, Spain, May 21-- Civil authorities in San Sebastian were reported today to have requested the banishment from that city of four Roman Catholic priests who sympathized with workers during the strikes staged there last month.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --A National Airlines spokesman accused North American Airlines today of using Murray Chotiner, Los Angeles attorney, to win White House influence for North American's "illegal" operations.
WASHINGTON, May 21--An extraordinary conference of judges and leaders of the bar met at the Justice Department today to consider ways of ending congestion in the courts.
NEW DELHI, May 21--The Soviet Union will supply India with two oil drilling rigs complete with accessories at a cost of $1,554,000 under an agreement signed by the two Governments today.

The Kaiser Steel Corporation plans to start at once on a $113,000,000 expansion program at its Fontana, Calif., steel mill. The ingot and finished steel capacity of the plant, fortyfive miles east of Los Angeles, will be increased 40 per cent, the company announced yesterday. Production of finished
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --The Supreme Court upheld today the authority of the Federal Communications Commission to limit the number of radio and television stations held by one owner.
The Adjacent Hunts Racing Association will hold its ninth annual meeting Saturday on the grounds of the Blind Brook Turf and Polo Club in Purchase, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --A House-Senate conference committee tentatively agreed today to write a compromise farm bill considered generally acceptable to President Eisenhower, informed sources reported.

Special to The New York Times. CHICAGO, May 21--Selling skill must keep pace with technology if industry is to meet the challenge of an expanding national economy, an executive vice president of the United States Steel Corporation declared today.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --The United States Communist party, offering "new evidence," asked the Subversive Activities Control Board today to reverse its finding that the party was manipulated by Moscow.
The Better Business Bureau warned yesterday that new seven-and-one-half-ampere airconditioners should not be advertised in the city as an appliance that "just plugs in."
BONN, Germany, May 21-- The Bonn Government has promised 11,000,000 displaced Germans living in West Germany it never will sell out their "natural right to a home."
Mink-stoled lady owners mingled vrith muddy-booted thoroughbred trainers yesterday when thirty-three race horses sold by Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt brought $563,700 in a public auction at Belmont Park.

WASHINGTON, May 21-- Charles E. Wilson marched the nation's military chiefs before an extraordinary news conference today to put a damper on interservice squabbling that he said was "not good for the country."
Unions that have been involved in jurisdictional disputes at the Coliseum reached a basis for an agreement yesterday that was expected to eliminate future labor difficulties.

WASHINGTON, May 21--Following is the transcript of a news conference today on the question of interservice rivalries by the Secretary of Defense, Charles E. Wilson, the Secretaries of Army, Navy and Air Force and the members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff:
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21-- Lebanon and Jordan have agreed to coordinate their defense plans and unite their forces in case of war.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 21 --Joseph W. Holman Jr., president of the architectural and engineering firm of Marr Holman, died unexpectedly of a heart attack at his home here yesterday. He was 41 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The Federal Controller General accused the Defense Department today of illegally holding $400,000,000 in foreign aid funds that should have been handed back to the Treasury.
Confirmation that coffee was not affected by Brazil's latest revision of its foreign exchange program strengthened coffee options yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

Cleveland Rodgers, former editor of The Brooklyn Eagle and former City Planning Commissioner, died yesterday of a coronary thrombosis in his home, 80-32 Grenfell Street, Kew Gardens, Queens. His age was 71.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 21-- Dr. Charles Malik, a leading Lebanese statesman, said today the Western powers must find a sound policy toward the Arab countries or see the Arab world throw its lot with the Soviet Union.
GIVEN some harrowing material to work with, Jack Kirkland has made it almost unbearably agonizing in "The Man With the Golden Arm," which opened at the Cherry Lane last evening.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --The Supreme Court refused today to rule whether Government anti-trust charges are automatically canceled if the defendant corporations are dissolved or merge with a nondefendant. The brief order left in effect conflicting decisions by lower courts.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (UP) --Southern members of the House Judiciary Committee denounced President Eisenhower's civil-rights program today as a threat to states' rights.

MOSCOW, May 21--Several United States scientists here to attend a conference have come to the preliminary conclusion that the Soviet Union is shifting its intellectual resources from a military to a peacetime basis.

"ALL Expenses Paid," the play on "Robert Mont gomery Presents" last night' over Channel 4 was rewarding entertainment for several reasons. The principal one was the appearance of Lee Remick in the leading feminine role.

Exercising his watchdog function Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa has submitted to the Board of Estimate a detailed report on the cost to the city of Title I slum-clearance projects to "assist you in determining policy" in the future. He also raises the question of revenue loss by grant of tax exemption or relief.

The Port of New York Authority borrowed $30,000,000 in the public market yesterday at a cost of 3.04269 per cent to finance construction projects at the International and La Guardia Airports and at the Port Newark and Hoboken-Port Authority piers.
WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Seven eastern states would have Federal consent to enter into military aid compacts under a bill passed by the Senate today and sent to the White House.
Every week-end several thousand city dwellers leave their homes to walk the thousand miles of paths that slice through woodlands close to New York.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 --Teresa Wright will portray the Colorado housewife who undergoes a fabulous age regression journey in "The Search for Bridey Murphy." She will be co-starred as Mrs. Ruth Simmons, pseudonym for the young ...

Joe Marchiony has fourteen more official chances to become the Metropolitan area's first 60foot high school shot-putter. The 6-foot 3-inch 235-pound stalwart is confident he can hit the mark on one of those throws.

WASHINGTON, May 21--The president of the National Association of Home Builders said today that mortgage money conditions now "are more severe that at any time since World War II --more severe than in the 'mortgage drought' of 1953."
ALBANY, May 21--The Democratic state organization took aim today at twenty-two seats in the Legislature now held by Republicans.
It was still on the coolishside at the Polo Grounds yesterday, but not for Umpire Stan Landes, who officiated behind the plate at the GiantCardinal game.
The Giants, who finally seemed to be off and running on Sunday when they wrenched a doubleheader from the Cardinals, ran out of gas at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
LONDON, May 21--The British Government's unswerving allegiance to a film policy, including the use of force when necessary, to hold Cyprus, Aden and Singapore was emphasized by Selwyn Lloyd today.
WASHINGTON, May 21--It is now six days since the Soviet Union announced that it planned to cut its armed forces by 1,200,000 men, but the official reaction in the Capital is still confused.
CHICAGO, May 21--Sears, Roebuck Co. today reported an operating income of $64,358,015 for the quarter ended on April 30. Operating income for the same period last year was $61,281,815.

WASHINGTON, May 21--A ranking union official indicated today that labor's chief reliance in seeking to defeat President Eisenhower would be a warning that Vice President Richard M. Nixon might take over the Presidency.
An employment security plan covering 40,000 seamen in the National Maritime Union will begin June 16.
Among the sure signs of spring in New York--along with skates on the sidewalks, flowers in the parks and bedding on the fire escapes--are the holes in the streets.
The bi-state Waterfront Commission has asked the Governors of New York and New Jersey for $1,984,093 for the next year's budget.
The Government may collect tomorrow its first dividend under the Immunity Act of 1954.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 21 --Major television networks face a strike June 4 by members of the Writers Guild of America unless "a satisfactory working agreement" is reached by the deadline, according to the guild.

A report that the Board of Education would approve new salary schedules today giving high-ranking administrators increases up to $1,400 a year touched off new protests from the city's teachers yesterday.
The special committee named by Mayor Wagner last Saturday to "improve" the Correction Department held its organizational meeting yesterday.

TOKYO, May 21--Japan reached what many Japanese regard as a milestone in her social development today. The Diet (Parliament) adopted the country's first law aimed at abolishing brothels, most of which are in the notorious and brightly lighted "gay quarters" of the cities.
Eighty-five members of the Police Department were promoted yesterday. It was the largest number advanced since Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy took office on last Aug. 2.
A warning was sounded yesterday that 14,000,000 consumers in the New York marketing area might have to pay up to 2 cents more for a quart of milk.
PARIS, May 21--The worldwide automobile empires of Ford faced by an attempt at coordinated international action of their employes.
Wayne Bethea of the Bronx gained a unanimous decision over Ezzard Charles, former world heavyweight champion, in the ten-round main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.

MIAMI, Fla., May 21--Senator Estes Kefauver and Adlai E. Stevenson canvassed their political differences for an hour on television tonight and found very little to disagree about. The nationally televised "debate" found the two chief contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination taking virtually identical positions on almost every issue discussed.

CHICAGO, May 21--Erratic price moves marked trading today in the grain futures markets. This was the final session for May, 1956, contracts. Between now and the end of the month any open contracts will have to be evened up by cash deliveries.

Congratulations are in order for Ernesto de la Guardia Jr., who appears to have won the Presidency of Panama in the recent election. As candidate of the governing National Coalition party, Senor de la Guardia's victory was not unexpected. But the campaign's very lack of bitterness was itself described as historic.

RABAT, Morocco, May 21-- The United States will be among the first countries to have ambassadorial representation in Rabat now that Morocco and France have reached agreement on Moroccan diplomatic sovereignty.
Webb Knapp, Inc., is adding another 33,000 to 35,000 acres of land in Louisiana to its extensive real estate holdings.

In the face of a modified filibuster, the City Council late yesterday adopted a record budget, $1,917,058,098, for 1956-57. The vote was 22 to 1. Councilman Robert E. Barnes, Republican of Queens, tied up the session for the better part of two hours as he moved in vain for deletions of scores of budget items.
MANILA, May 21--A molehill of manganese ore in central Luzon has become a small mountain of concern regarding Philippine-United States relations.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 21 --It was piggy-back in reverse here this morning as a 109-ton steam locomotive was loaded onto a huge tractor-trailer for a three-mile trip to Nassau County Park in Salisbury.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 21-- Counting on the theory that the average dog will not bite the hand that feeds it, the Long Island Lighting Company started arming its meter readers with sweet biscuits today.

ABOARD U.S.S. MOUNT McKINLEY, off Bikini, Tuesday, May 22--Nuclear scientists began a detailed analysis today of what the first American air-dropped hydrogen bomb did when it exploded two miles above a test target island in the mid-Pacific yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The Supreme Court refused today to hear an appeal from a judgment of Ohio's highest court that the City of Cleveland had a right to add fluorides to its water supply.

INCOMES are at the highest levels ever, but Americans do not eat as well as they should. Malnutrition still is found, even among those with plenty of money. The many overweights, who got that way from wrong diet, are evidence.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The long-delayed Senate decision on the nomination of Solicitor General Simon E. Sobeloff to the United States Court of Appeals ran into more Southern opposition today.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The Soviet bloc's exports to the rest of the world increased by 35 per cent last year Government analysts reported today.

KANSAS CITY, May 21--For a time today it appeared that the Yankees would have to fight their way out of town with or without their sixth straight victory. While the New Yorkers were en route to an 8--5 triumph over the Athletics, tempers flared all over Municipal Stadium--on the mound in the dugout and through the stands.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 21-- Claude Harmon of Winged Foot and Bill Collins of Grossinger shared the pace-setter's place in qualifying for the National Professional Golfers Association championship today.
WASHINGTON, May 21--Administration power policies touched off new sparks in the House of Representatives today.

Hortense Monath, an outstanding American concert pianist and for sixteen years program director of the New Friends of Music, was found dead in her bed yesterday morning at the Hotel Bretton Hall, 2350 Broadway. She was 52 years old.
KENNEBUNKPORT, Me., May 21--Charles Carleton Small, retired president and board chairman of the American Ice Company, died today in a Biddeford hospital after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 21 (AP)-- Loring Milton Black, a former United States Representative from New York, died unexpectedly this morning of a heart attack while in a drugstore near his law office. His age was 70.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., May 21--Mr. and Mrs. Herman C. Schutt of Framingham, formerly of Scarborough, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Schutt, to David C. Thompson, son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Thompson of Rockville Centre, L.I.
NEW DELHI, India, May 21-- Prince Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia said today his country was getting economic aid from the Soviet Union and Poland.
Cotton futures declined 13 to 28 points yesterday, with the weakness most pronounced in July.

The crews ranked as the leading contenders were drawn in outside lanes in the championship regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association. The races will be held June 16 on Onondaga Lake, Syracuse, and the lane drawings were announced yesterday at the rowing luncheon at Leone's Restaurant by Asa S. Bushnell, secretary of the I.R.A.

WASHINGTON, May 21-- Seven stretcher cases headed the line of 811 hospitalized veterans and others who shook hands with President and Mrs. Eisenhower today at the annual White House garden party for veterans.

A study made for the TwentyThird Street Association characterizes the proposed Thirtieth Street elevated expressway as a "Chinese Wall." The report says it would have a damaging effect on business and realty values south of Thirtieth Street.

JERUSALEM, May 21--Israel is now willing to meet Egypt at El Auja to approve the United Nations Secretary General's plan to strengthen enforcement of the cease-fire along the Gaza Strip border, it was learned tonight.
WASHINGTON, May 21--The Soviet Union has indicated that it would permit Pan American Airways to fly to Moscow, the State Department said today.

RABAT, Morocco, May 21-- Like most of the effective leaders of North African nationalism and political foes of French "colonialism," Ahmed Balafrej, Foreign Minister of Morocco, has a thorough French education.

"The Littlest Revue" arrives at 8 o'clock tonight at the Phoenix. Keeping in step with the title is a complement of eight entertainers. They are Charlotte Rae, Larry Storch, Tammy Grimes, Joel Grey, Tommy Morton, George Marcy, Dorothy Jarnac and Beverley Bozeman.

A FORCEFUL and committed personality emerges in the expressionist paintings of Leon Golub at the Feigl Gallery, 601 Madison Avenue. Golub, who is an instructor in painting and art history at the Illinois Institute of Technology, has examined his premises for painting exhaustively, and has apparently reached a positive guiding esthetic.

A Government civil antitrust suit against four groups of newspaper and magazine publishers was ended yesterday in Federal District Court here with the approval of judgments consented to by the parties.
New issues of coroporate debt securities totaling more than $69,000,000 will be offered to investors today, as follows:

Today's new film is "Crime in the Streets," starring James Whitmore, John Cassavetes, Sal Mineo and Mark Rydell, at the Victoria. Reginald Rose's adaptation of his television drama was directed by Donald Siegel. Vincent M. Fennelly produced for Allied Artists.
CLEVELAND, May 22 (UP)-- Aided by Dave Sisler, Tom Brewer of the Red Sox continued his domination of the Cleveland Indians tonight with a 5-3 victory before a crowd of 15,286.

BAWDSEY, England, May 22 (U.P.)--Two United States Air Force F-84F jets collided and crashed today, killing one pilot and a civilian. The other pilot and a second civilian were injured. One of the jets fell in a garden, killing an 85-year-old gardener and injuring his son.

The Truax-Traer Coal Company, Chicago, announced yesterday the acquisition of all the outstanding capital stock of Little Sister Coal Corporation in exchange for 174,000 shares of Truax-Traer common stock.
LONDON, May 22--The British Commonwealth Conference next month will be faced with the prospect that Britain soon may not possess a single usable air or naval base between Aden and Australia.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22-- "Biggest flop of the year" was the description applied today by the Republican National Chairman to the Stevenson-Kefauver debate last night at Miami, Fla.
The Diana Stores Corporation, womens' apparel chain, realized a 20.7 per cent increase in earnings in the nine months ended April 30 on a sales gain of 8.6 per cent above the figures a year earlier.
PITTSBURGH, May 22 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals scored two runs in the seventh tonight to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6--3 and snap a Pirate threegame winning streak.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, May 22--Dr. A.J.R. Vanrhyn, Minister of Economic Affairs, appealed today for an increase in national production to offset a growing shortage of skilled labor. He reported a survey showed the skilled labor force would have to be increased by at least 14 per cent to meet essential requirements if existing methods and standards of labor performance were to be maintained.
PITTSBURGH, May 22 (AP)-- The Rev. Richard H. Ackerman, a native of Pittsburgh's South Side, was consecrated today auxiliary Bishop of the Roman
ALBANY, May 22 (UP)--A proposal by the Pennsylvania Gas Company to increase its charges to its New York State cutomers by $421,500 a year was suspended today by the Public Service Commission.
The Milwaukee Braves shattered the Dodgers' immediate hopes of achieving first place with a barrage of extra base hits, including three home runs, at Ebbets Field last night.

GLEN COVE, L.I., May 22-- A son, their second, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Wright Rumbough Jr. of Locust Valley on Saturday at the Community Hospital here. Mrs. Rumbough is the former Miss Melissa Moffett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Moffett 2d of Glen Head. The child, who has been named Douglas Moffett, is a grandson also of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph W. Rumbough of New York and Smithtown.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 22--The Royal Danish Ballet tonight gave the only performance scheduled during its current festival season at the Royal Theatre of August Bournonville's "Napoli," which was created by that great father of the Danish ballet 114 years ago.
A business man who refused to answer questions before a grand jury concerning alleged payments to union officials was convicted yesterday of criminal contempt.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman, said today Senator Barry M. Goldwater, Republican of Arizona, has failed to prove his charge that compulsory union dues were used for political contributions.

Sixteen teen-age sandlot baseball players from various sections of the country will make a goodwill tour of seven Latin American countries and Puerto Rico this fall under the auspices of the American Legion.

DENVER, May 22 (AP)--John Gibbons, a court-appointed lawyer for John Gilbert Graham, condemned murderer, said today the case would be appealed to the Colorado Supreme Court whether Graham likes it or not. Graham was convicted of first degree murder May 4 in the death of his mother, one of forty-four persons who died last Nov. 1 in the explosion and crash of an airliner.

MIAMI, Fla., May 22 (AP)--A Federal judge stopped the United States Department of Justice today from expelling Carlos Prio Socarras, a former President of Cuba, from this country immediately. Judge Emett Choate, in granting Senor Prio a writ of habeas Corpus, gave the Department of Justice five days in which to make charges against Senor Prio in support of its exclusion order.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) --President Eisenhower today nominated Chief Judge Frederick G. Hamlet of the Washington State Supreme Court to be United States Judge for the Ninth Circuit. He would succeed Homer T. Bone, who has retired.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- The Navy's Aviation Supply Office showed today how it keeps abreast of constantly expanding inventory control problems through the wizardry of an electronic data processing machine.

BONN, May 22 (AP)--West Germany's Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Foreign Minister Heinrich von Brentano plan to make a state visit to Italy in the fall. They were invited in February by Premier Antonio Segni and Foreign Minister Gaetano Martino on their visit to Bonn.

WASHINGTON, May 22--A House committee voted today to increase the cost of first-class mail and airmail letters a cent an ounce. The action backed the Administration's effort to balance the budget of the postal service. Mail has been running a deficit of about $470,000,000 a year.
SEVERAL years ago when Dr. William Jansen was Assistant Superintendent of Schools, a teacher came to see him with an unhappy story.
MILWAUKEE, May 22--Directors of the Cutler-Hammer Corporation today called a special meeting of stockholders July 9 to consider a two-for-one split in the company's shares of common stock.
Victor Alessandro, conductor of the San Antonio (Tex.) Symphony Orchestra, has been named 1956 winner of the Alice M. Ditson Award "for distinguished service to American music."
WASHINGTON, May 22--A group of lawyers, judges and Federal law enforcement officers agreed today to set up a permanent Attorney General's Conference on Court Congestion and Delay.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, May 22 (Reuters)--Three leading United States banks will lend the Royal Dutch K.L.M. Airlines $50,000,000 to finance in part the purchase of new aircraft, including eight Douglas DC-8 jet liners, it was announced here tonight. A K.L.M. spokesman said the loan would be available between 1956 and 1960. The banks are the First National City Bank of New York, the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bank of America.
There is a coterie in the country composed of people who never stop talking to listen when someone points out that the art of conversation has disappeared. These are the people who

Miss Graziella Ghiron, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ghiron of New York and Turin, Italy, and Giannetto di Segni, son of Signor and Signora Giacomo di Segni of Rome, were married on Sunday in the Jewish Temple in Turin. The bride, who made her debut here in 1952, graduated from the Dalton School and Finch Junior College here. Signor di Segni is an alumnus of the University of Rome.
The Ford Foundation is mailing checks this week totaling $31,072,150 to 1,000 voluntary hospitals in the forty-eight states, the District of Columbia, Alaska, Hawaii and Puerto Rico.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation announced yesterday the sale of its entire holdings of 384,816 shares of common stock in the Westpan Hydrocarbon Company to Jalco, Inc., of Dallas, Tex. The price received was $12.70 a share, or a total of $4,887,163.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP)-- The Senate Finance Committee voted today to increase Federal gasoline and other highway "user" taxes over the next sixteen years to help pay for a vast new road-building program.
BATON ROUGE, La., May 22 (UP)--Mrs. Winnice Clement, who aroused the ire of Louisiana's White Citizens Councils
NICOSIA, Cyprus, May 22-- An underwater explosion was set off today in an attempt to kill a group of British soldiers while they were swimming.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 22--The race issue was brought into the open today in Florida's presidential primary campaign between Adlai E. Stevenson and Senator Estes Kefauver.

Devereux Milburn Jr., the chairman of the United States Polo Association, was re-elected president of the Sportsmanship Brotherhood for a one-year term yesterday. The Brotherhood conducted its election of officers at its annual meeting at the National Arts Club.

Jacob D. Fuchsberg of New York has been elected president of the New York University Law Review Alumni Association. Other officers are Bernard Newman, Leo Pfeffer and Harold Panken, vice presidents; Kalman Oravetz, treasurer, and Beatrice Feinstein, recording secretary. The association is composed of graduates of the last thirty-five years who served on The Law Review.

Andrew F. Shannon of 9430 Ridge Boulevard, Brooklyn, president of Shannon Brothers, Inc., truckmen of 340 West Street, died yesterday in Victory Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. His age was 60. The company is engaged principally in the trucking of newsprint. Mr. Shannon had been in the trucking business for thirty-five years.

Cushman's Sons, Inc., bakery, will hold a special stockholders' meeting July 10 in Chicago to vote on a proposal to make the 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock redeemable at the option of the company. Stockholders of record of June 4 will be entitled to vote.
President Eisenhower's move to eliminate an "interlocking directorate" within the Government has come under fire.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --Judith Burganger, a 16-yearold pianist from Buffalo, tonight won a year's scholarship at the Juilliard School of Music in New York.

A liberation rally will be held by the American Friends of the Captive Nations Friday evening at Town Hall, 123 West Fortythird Street. Speakers will include United States Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, and Gen. William J. Donovan, who recently returned from a mission investigating Communist redefections among Iron Curtain refugees.

OMAHA, May 22 (AP)--The thirty-five-day Ak-Sar-Ben race meet opened today with Vino Supremo, from the Denver stable of M.H. Robinson, winning the six-furlong feature in 1:10. Switch was second and Molly Darling third. The victor returned $27, $12.40 and $7.40 for $2.

NEW CITY, N.Y., May 22-- Supreme Court Justice William H. Munson sentenced Donald Theis, maintenance worker at the Dellwood Country Club, to twenty years to life in Sing Sing Prison today. Theis had pleaded guilty earlier to murder in the second degree, abruptly ending a seven-day trial on a first-degree murder indictment.
Sunshine and optimism pervaded Seventh Avenue yesterday as the fall buying season for better-priced apparel gained momentum.

The engagement of Miss Lynette Jacobson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Jacobson of 930 Fifth Avenue, to Stanley Selig Saltzman, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Saltzman of Riverdale, the Bronx, has been announced by Miss Jacobson's parents. An October wedding is planned.
LONDON, May 22--After nine years of negotiation, arrangements have been completed for the ballet company of the Bolshoi Theatre, Moscow, to make its first appearance outside the Soviet Union.
CHICAGO, May 22--Stock holders of the Commonwealth Edison Company today approved an increase in the electric utility's common stock from 24,000,000 to 30,000,000 shares.
BOSTON, May 22 (AP)--Apprentice Allen Fairbanks of Jersey City today rode R.R. Damon's Hat Box to a halflength victory over G.R. White's Black Gallant in the Boston Club Purse at Suffolk Downs.
LONDON, May 22--A twentyfour-hour fire was brought under control tonight in disused subway tunnels under Tottenham Court Road in London's West End.

Directors of the Granite City Steel Company elected Geo. B. Schierberg president and treasurer at a meeting here yesterday. N.P. Veeder was named executive vice president and James L. Hamilton Jr. was elected vice president and general manager of sales.
BUFFALO, N.Y., May 22 (AP) --The directors of the Erie Railroad today declared a regular divident of 37 cents a common share for the second quarter, payable June 29 to stockholders of record June 1.
Donald J. Slattery Jr. and Robert P. Wilson have been elected vice presidents of Geyer Advertising, Inc. Mr. Slattery, an account executive, has been

The National Biscuit Company has Gold its Los Angeles plant and bakery at 673 Mateo Street in Los Angeles, Calif., to the Essex Corporation, owner and operator of the Gold Furniture Company, a chain of stores in the West. The buyer plans to use the property for warehouse and storage purpose. William A. White Sons were the brokers.

Plans for a shopping center on the site of the old plant of the Creamery Package Corporation on Roosevelt Drive, Derby, Conn., have been announced. A new building for which the A. P. is negotiating, is included in the plans. Samuel A. Rifkin is handling the renting.
Luncheon meeting, Brooklyn Rotary Club, St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, 12:30 P.M. "The New York City Water Supply System," Edward J. Clark.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 22--Cuba, the world's largest exporter of sugar, served notice today that she would resist all attempts to reduce her annual quota as specified in a 1953 London agreement on international control of that commodity.
LONDON, May 22--A bear in a goose-drawn chariot and a clown, possibly the best clown between Land's End and Vladivostok, are members of the third Soviet mission to Britain this year.

NAGS HEAD, N.C., May 22 --The Outer Banks of North Carolina are a tremendous sand reef extending from Virginia to South Carolina and inhabited almost entirely by people who fish either for fun or for profit.
TELL a Dartmouth man that your lipstick stars on, and you may get a disappointing reaction. He'll write a report about it to the Toilet Goods Association.

ST. LOUIS, May 22--Recent pressure for passage of a oneyear residence law for relief eligibility in New York State was due largely to prejudice against its citizens of Puerto Rican origin, a state official said here today.

ELKINS, W. Va., May 22 (AP)-- A fire started by a bolt of lightning burned for several hours in the science hall of Davis and Elkins College today. The building was evacuated without incident. One fireman suffered minor injuries.

Standards for rayon and acetate will be revised according to "advances in technology and experience of the industry," the American Standards Association announced yesterday. These standards will be merged with those on all textiles and the result will be designated "L22," the group said.
Record sales and earnings were attained by the West Virginia Pulp and Paper Company in its half-year period ended April 30, according to results announced yesterday by David L. Luke Jr., president.

OTTAWA, May 22--The Government acted again today to hasten the passage of legislation to authorize a loan of up to $80,000,000 to Trans-Canada Pipe Lines, Ltd., to finance a gas pipeline. It was the second time in a week that the Canadian Government resorted to a closure motion limiting debate. There probably will be two more as the bill reaches the committee stage and finally the third reading.
Miss Christa Paul and Dr. James Paul Nolan will be married in July.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 --An unspecified number of Republic Pictures employes have received ninety-day layoff notices, effective this week, it was confirmed today. Some workers in the company's home office in New York also are affected.

The thirteen Banks for Cooperatives, which make loans to farmers and allied borrowers, are offering publicly today $55,000,000 of nine-month consolidated collateral trust debentures through John T. Knox, fiscal agent, and a nation-wide group of security dealers.

Three new directors were elected yesterday by the board of Group Health Insurance, Inc., to help guide the expanded operations of the nonprofit medical insurance plan. They were Dr. Robert F. Warren, president of the Kings County Medical Society; Harold J. Garno, secretary-treasurer of the New York State C.I.O. Council, and Dr. Charles Fama, chairman of the National Evangelical Committee for Relief to Italy.
LONDON, May 22 (Reuters) --The Moscow radio said today a new ten-story 2,700-room hotel would be built in Moscow next year. The broadcast said it would be the biggest in Europe.

Maurice Couve de Murville, French Ambassador to the United States, said yesterday that the free world, in the light of a changing Soviet foreign policy, must establish a new course of its own with "vision and a spirit of solidarity."

THE Parsons School of Design, a fashion incubator that has hatched many talented young designers and sent them out into the world of Seventh Avenue, held its thirty-second annual fashion show yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --The House shouted approval today for a $790,748,000 bill to finance public works in the fiscal year starting July 1.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 22-- The change of government in Jordan is a definite loss for the Western powers, according to Arab opinion here.
Shareholders of Procter Gamble Company at a special meeting in Cincinnati yesterday approved a two-for-one split of the common stock.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- President Eisenhower said today the nation needed an older person's wisdom and experience as much as a young man's energy.
A new fund to aid physicians planning to take up group practice was announced yesterday at the ninth annual meeting of the Health Insurance Plan of Greater New York.
The annual communion breakfast of longshoremen, checkers and affiliated groups in the Port of New York will be held June 3.

DOBBS FERRY, N.Y., May 22--Dick Graham, a 16-yearold 6-foot 5-inch right-hander, pitched his fifth no-hitter of the season for Dobbs Ferry High today in beating Alexander Hamilton of Elmsford, N.Y., 7--2. The junior, who hurled his fourth straight no-hit game today, had tossed shutouts in his previous hitless performances.
Children's cardboard games can last longer, advises the Shellac Information Bureau, if a thinned coat of fresh white shellac is applied to their surface.
A public offering of 228,028 shares of Fruehauf Trailer Company common stock at $32,875 a share is being made by an underwriting group headed by Kidder, Peabody Co.
MIAMI BEACH, May 22 (AP) --Chico Vejar, 159 pounds, Stamford, Conn., scored a close decision tonight over Gus Rubicini, 155, Toronto, in a furious ten-round bout.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --"I'm probably not much to look at," Representative Kenneth J. Gray told the House of Representatives today.
American aid to India is neither adequate nor flexible enough to meet India's industrial needs, John Sherman Cooper, Ambassador to India, declared yesterday.
SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 22 (AP)--Lafayette cemented its claim to a District 2 National Collegiate play-off berth and knocked Seton Hall out of the running by edging the Pirates today, 2--1.
Daniel Blum's annual Theatre World awards to "the promising personalities of the 1955-56 season" were distributed yesterday afternoon at the Gotham Hotel.
PUT the table broiler-rotisserie to work at cocktail time. Do piping hot hors d'oeuvre in it, quickly, deliciously and dramatically.

CRESTWOOD, N.Y., May 22 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Albert W. Doyle of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Doyle, to Ensign Charles Edward Garrison. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo M. Garrison of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Patterson, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 22 (AP) --The International Typographical Union headquarters said today nearly complete returns showed Woodruff Randolph had been re-elected to a seventh term as president.
A shop called "Serendipity," from the word coined by Hugh Walpole to mean "the art of finding the unusual," is upholding its reputation by introducing an unusual swimsuit for men.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP)--Hogs continued their sharp upward push today, although at the close the market had lost gains that had extended to 50 cents in early dealings.
