WHITE SANDS, N.M., May 22--The Army announced tonight that the Nike, pride of its anti-aircraft weapons, had struck its target during a public test held here today. examination of the Firebee drone target showed that the first of two Nikes fired had punctured the under side of the little drone, the Army reported.
Carl W. Badenhausen, president of P. Ballentine and Sons, has been re-elected president of the New Jersey Brewers Association. Thomas Liebmann, vice president, Liebmann Brewers.

PARIS, May 22 (UP)--France's bantamweight boxing star, Alphonse Halimi, who was scheduled to fight Spain's Im Navarro at Tunis June 2, has been called back in the French Army because of the Algerian rebellion, it was learned today.

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP)--The Misouri-Kansas-Texas (Katy) Railroad announced today an affiliation with the Trailer Train Company of Philadelphia, from which it will lease flat cars designed for carrying highway trailers.
PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, May 22--Port-au-Prince, Jacmel and Les Cayes today were put under a state of siege after a week of unrest.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 22 (UP)--Empire Hanover won the Greenvale Trot tonight at Roosevelt Raceway with John Simpson handling the reins.

THE SCHOLARS at the Brooklyn Museum may be light hearted but never heavy-handed. They have come up with a pun and a new exhibit--"The Lace With the Delicate Air"--a gay review of what the needle-andbobbin set has produced over the centuries.

The Board of Education broke ground yesterday for two junior high schools in the Bronx. This was largely a victory for a group of parents who refused to settle for "half a loaf" two years ago. While hundreds

An Italian Government program to increase exports to the United States was outlined yesterday. Its scope and aims were detailed by Dr. Aldo Morante, Commercial Counselor of the Italian Embassy in Washington, at the New Weston Hotel here.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 22-- Dr. Howard I. Dillingham was elected President of Ithaca College today.
ROSEJEANNE SHIFER, who earns her living by collect ing rare maps, books and documents, has bad news for European souvenir hunters.

KANSAS CITY, May 22 (UP)-- The Athletics combined two doubles and four walks into a fiverun second inning and Troy Herriage defeated the Senators tonight, 6--1, for his first major league victory. The Kansas City rookie pitched a three-hitter.
Purchases of apartment houses by operators formed the bulk of Bronx realty trading reported yesterday.

SALERNO, Italy, May 22--Harry S. Truman looked with an old soldier's eye today on the site of the World War II battle of Salerno. Later the former President, a World War I artillery officer, delivered his opinion that the battle and the later Anzio beach landing were "totally unnecessary and planned by some squirrelheaded general."
Underwriting syndicates will offer new issues of common stock valued at more than $8,000,000 for public subscription today, as follows:

In the obituary of Dr. William J. Gies, biochemist and a former member of the faculty of Columbia University, published in Monday's New York Times, his age was given incorrectly. Dr. Gies was 84 years old. Because of a typographical error, his age was given as 54.

STONY BROOK, L.I., May 22 --Al Brosch, the Woodmere Club pro, fired a 3-over-par 73 to pace the qualifiers as play in the thirty-second Long Island Golf Association open championship tournament began today on the wind-swept St. George's Golf and Country Club course.

The American merchant marine was hailed yesterday as an equal partner with the combat elements of the armed forces in the pattern of national defense. As the nation marked Maritime Day, thousands attending New York's observance packed the
Edward L. Love, a consultant to the Chase Manhattan Bank, has been elected a director of Stone Webster, Inc., engineering concern. Mr. Love is a former executive vice president of Chase.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- A White House conference on "Fitness of American Youth," canceled in September because of President Eisenhower's heart attack, was rescheduled today. The conference will be held at the Naval Academy at Annapolis, Md., June 18 to 19. General Eisenhower plans to attend on the second day.
Two studies of James Joyce and his literary symbolism are scheduled for publication a week apart.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 22 --Mr. and Mrs. Charles K. Kruger have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marguerite Kruger, to Dr. Philip Hobart Voorhees of Morristown. He is a son of Mrs. Philip H. Voorhees of Jamaica. Queens, and the late Mr. Voorhees. The couple plan to be married in September.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 22 (Reuters)--W.S. Kent Hughes, chairman of the 1956 Olympic Games organizing committee, left here by air today to visit the United States and Europe. He will attend the equestrian Olympics in Stockholm next month.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --The Census Bureau reported today that the number of regular motion-picture theatres dropped 17 per cent between 1948 and 1954. Drive-in theatres, however, increased more than 350 per cent. There were 17,689 regular theatres in 1948. By 1954 this number had shrunk to 14,761. In the same period, drive-in theatres increased from 820 in 1948 to 3,799 in 1954.

PARIS, May 22 (AP)--The Russians, who couldn't match height or skill with the United States team in the 1952 Olympic basketball competition, have the biggest center on record for 1956. But French fans who had a look at towering Yan Krouminch decided he resembled Primo Carnera a lot more than America's Bill Russell.

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 22--A daughter, their third child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. W. Thomas Kelly on May 13 at the Lawrence Hospital in Bronxville. Mrs. Kelly is the former Miss Jane E. MacCabe, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas B. MacCabe of Philadelphia. The child has been named Barbara Ann.

"Three Times Three" will bring back the intimate Chanin Auditorium, on the fiftieth floor of the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street, to the legitimate fold. The event will take place at 8 o'clock tonight. Up for examination in the comfortable 192-seat playhouse are three one-acters of respectable lineage, all of which lean toward farce.
Ninety-six convicts in the Ohio State Penitentiary have volunteered for live cancer injections to help try to solve the causes of the disease.
FLORENCE, Italy, May 22 (Reuters)--Swedish-born film actress Anita Ekberg was married today to Anthony Steel, British movie actor, in a civil ceremony in Florence's Town Hall.
Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan dismissed yesterday a series of challenges to the primary designating petitions of regular Democratic candidates for judicial nominations in Manhattan.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 22 (UP)--Ronald Grosso, 20, a Fairfield (Conn.) University baseball player, remained in critical condition today after suffering a fractured skull in a game with Holy Cross Saturday. Grosso, a second baseman, was hit on the head by a pitched ball.

M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., in the first quarter this year lifted its sales 50.2 per cent and earnings 11.9 per cent over the similar period a year ago, according to the report to be issued to stockholders today.
A new "sky bus" fare of $45 between New York and Puerto Rico, lower than that offered by any scheduled service, will be started on June 15 by Trans Caribbean Airways.

BOSTON, May 22--H. Clay Burkholder, a lawyer of Lancaster, Pa., was elected today moderator of the American Unitarian Association. This is the highest lay position in the denomination. The term is two years.
MANILA, May 22 (AP)--A Filipino staked claim last night to a scattering of uninhabited islands, coral reefs, sandbars and shoals across a vast stretch of the South China Sea.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) --The Navy disclosed today that it has successfully used an electronic brain to keep 7,000 aircraft all over the world equipped with 150,000 different parts.
Mrs. Luisita Leland Cofer of 563 Park Avenue, widow of Dr. Leland Eggleston Cofer, former Health Officer of the Port of New York, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 --Cecil B. de Mille, veteran movie director-producer, was honored by the government of Thailand today. Acting for King Phumiphol, Ambassador Pote Sarasin conferred on Mr. de Mille the Most Exalted Order of the White Elephant. The presentation was made at a luncheon in the Paramount Studio.
The Brown Shoe Company announced yesterday it had sold $10,000,000 of 3 per cent notes to a group of banks and insurance companies.
Wasting away on a four-hit-aday diet that has Manager Bill Rigney banging his head against walls in utter frustration, the Giants dropped a 6-3 decision to the Redlegs at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22-- America on the move was cited today as a serious threat to a child's educational career.

CALGARY, Alberta, May 22 (Canadian Press)--Francis Fournier Reeve, an oil man, died in hospital here today after a long illness. His age was 78. In 1938 he was named president and managing director of Commonwealth Petroleum Company and vice president and managing director of Commoil and Command Oils, Ltd.

The American Irish Historical Society will honor the memory of George William Russell (AE), Irish poet, philosopher and painter, tomorrow night. Mrs. W. Murray Crane will present two of his paintings to the society, which is at 991 Fifth Avenue.
Standard issues--many of them the investment favorites called "blue chips"--bore the brunt of another sharp drop in the stock market yesterday. Prices fell 1 to 5 points.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The Department of Commerce said today that business activity continued stable through April. In a round-up of significant elements in the business picture ...
Five teen-age baseball players were injured in a bat-swinging brawl last night on Randall's Island.

An estate holding consisting of three parcels on Washington Heights has passed to new control with the sale of 1460-62 St. Nicholas Avenue, 1291-97 St. Nicholas Avenue and 1381-85 St. Nicholas Avenue by the heirs of C.V. Smith. The deal was negotiated by Nehring Brothers, brokers.

Columbia and New York University are feuding again. A short time back their classicists went at each other hip and thigh on the matter of the assassination of Julius Caesar. Now baseball is the bone of contention.

Stuyvesant High School finished first in two events and second in two others to win the Manhattan Public Schools Athletic League track and field meet at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx yesterday. The Peglegs compiled 29 points.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 22-- An F-84 jet fighter plane attached to the Ramey Air Force Base crashed into the sea of Santa Isabel on the southern coast today. The pilot, Capt. Fred A. Treyz of Tucson, Ariz., bailed out at 20,000 feet and was picked up safely.

All that now remains of the old Third Avenue Railroad Bridge is a wooden apron. The last of the structure--it and a predecessor had spanned the Harlem River for seventy years--was demolished yesterday.

CAMDEN, N.J., May 22-- Nearly 2,500 business and residential telephones were put out of order today when a cable beneath the Cooper River was damaged. Bell Telephone Company officials said the cable, which feeds the east section of the city might have been cut by a dredge removing silt from the river. The cable is to be raised and inspected.

NASHVILLE, May 22 (AP)-- Elmer Reed of Atlanta and Ralph Dillow of Auburn, Ala., posted 36-hole cards of 141, one under par, to tie for the medal in the Southeastern qualifying trial for the Professional Golf Association tournament.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., May 22 (AP)--James R. Shreve, assistant football and baseball coach at George Washington University, today was named backfield coach at Lehigh University.

Thomas J. Cochrane will retire as advertising director of The New York News, it was announced yesterday by F.M. Flynn, president and publisher. The retirement is effective July 7, the end of his forty-seventh year with The News and The Chicago Tribune organization.
Mme. Maria Winetzkaja, a mezzo-soprano who had sung in opera and concert, died yesterday in Misericordia Hospital after a long illness. She was 68 years old and lived at 127 West Ninety-sixth Street.

Confidence that Mrs. Clare Boothe Luce would recover her health completely in about six weeks was expressed by her husband, Henry R. Luce, as he arrived here yesterday. Mrs. Luce, the Ambassador to Italy, returned here May 11 for medical care and is now at home, 450 East Fifty-second Street.

Oils joined the game of follow the leader in yesterday's declining market, despite the fact that most oil companies continue to have record or nearrecord earnings. Just a sampling showed Standard Oil (New Jersey) off 1 5/8, Standard Oil of California down 3, Amerada Petroleum, 3 down and the Texas Company off 2 .
Mayor Wagner said yesterday he was "very much interested" in the proposal to build a 110,000-seat sports stadium on the West Side "if it can be done."
ALGIERS, Algeria, May 22 (Reuters)--French troops have razed a Moslem village for its inhabitants' part in the death by torture of seventeen soldiers according to reports reaching here.

THE country fair, or weekly market, has pretty much vanished from the American scene in the last fifty years, at least within hollering distance of big cities. In the New York area only a few hang on in vestigial form.

LONDON, May 22 (AP)--Three women riders today won places on Britain's team for the equestrian Olympic Games in Stockholm June 10-17. This will be the first time women have been allowed to compete in the equestrian Olympics.
ANDOVER, Mass., May 22-- The Raytheon Manufacturing Company exercised an option today to lease the Shawsheen Mill property from Textron, Inc., with a further option to buy.

NEW DELHI, India, May 22-- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru called today for a cease-fire in Algeria as the "first and essential step" toward settling the conflict between the French and the nationalists.

The majority and minority reports of the House Judiciary Committee on the Administration's belated civil rights bill may not add greatly to the sum total of human knowledge, but they do emphasize the unhappy sectional split over this issue, which needs no emphasizing.

TOKYO, May 22--Japan appears to be approaching closer diplomatic and commercial relations with Communist countries. However, official uncertainty and even timidity seem to be accompanying this movement on the Japanese side.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics fell to 90.6 on Monday from 90.7 on Friday. The figure for May 23, 1955, was 89.

SAN JOSE, Calif., May 22 (UP)-- --Ed Sobczak, who played in the Boston Red Sox chain for five years, was named head baseball coach of San Jose State today. Tom O'Neill was appointed swimming coach. Sobczak won seven letters in baseball and football at Michigan State. O'Neill was graduated from Michigan in 1948.

Reflecting expansion in oil production in Venezuela, Texas and Canada, first-quarter operations of the American Maracaibo Company showed further improvement, Hadley Case, president, told the annual meeting here yesterday. Current indications are that earnings will increase during the rest of the year, he said.
The National Broadcasting Company hopes to weave a bit of intellectual variety into the television pattern next season with a new series of lofty programs titled "Telescope."
TRIPOLI, Libya, May 22-- A shipload of United States military equipment to bolster the tiny Libyan Army was unloaded today in Tripoli harbor.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- The Federal Trade Commission today announced approval of a consent order prohibiting the Cordage Institute, New York, and its member manufacturers from maintaining uniform geographical price zones in the sale of hard fiber rope and twine.

An issue of $20,000,000 of revenue bonds of the Chesapeake Bay Ferry District, an agency of the State of Virginia, will be offered for public subscription today by a syndicate headed by Allen Co, and Willis, Kenny Ayres, Inc. The bonds bear interest of 4 per cent and will come due on April 1, 1986. They are priced at 100.
CHICAGO, May 22--A break in soybean prices featured the grain market today. Longs unloaded following substantial recessions in oil prices.

The British Victory tournament is a team competition to be played tomorrow at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Scarborough-on-Hudson, N.Y. It has not always had that name. When it was listed on the schedule of the Westchester County Golf Association for the first time in 1927, it was the "Jess Sweetser Victory Cup."

The hearing of contempt proceedings against Albert G. Glass Lindenhurst realty dealer, was postponed yesterday until Tuesday. The stay was granted by Supreme Court Justice Joseph A. Gavagan. J. Irwin Shapiro, State Commissioner of Investigation, charged that Mr. Glass had refused to appear for questioning in an inquiry into an asserted $370,000 "land grab" in Suffolk County.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., May 22--The strike of municipal garbage and trash collectors of Sanitary District 6, called yesterday because of a dispute over union recognition, was continued today.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., May 22--Striking employes at E.R. Squibb and Sons' plants here and in Brooklyn and Queens, ended their seventeenday walkout today.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., May 22 (AP)--Thomas H. Nicholl, president of the Lehigh Valley Transit Company, died last night at his home after a brief illness. His age was 63.
CHICAGO, May 22--Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer warned tonight that ignorance and the power to do evil could make chaos of the brave new world promised by modern science.
The appointment of Wesby R. Parker as executive vice president of the Dr. Pepper Company, soft drink producer, was announced yesterday by Leonard Green, president.

The laws of eighteen states, mostly in the South, forbid employer-union agreements which make union membership a condition of employment. These "union-shop" contracts provide that, while membership is not required for employment, a worker cannot hold his job for more than a certain period, commonly sixty days, unless he has joined the union
The country's leading art auction concern was involved yesterday in a dispute involving its advertising of a recent sale.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- The Department of Agriculture announced today that it would wind up on May 31 a program designed to encourage diversion of low-grade potatoes into livestock feed and starch.
The West German Police soccer stars bowed to the German Hungarians, champions of the German-American Soccer League, 4 to 2, last night at Metropolitan Oval in Maspeth, Queens.
HARRISBURG, Pa., May 22--The Pennsylvania Turnuike Commission rejected, 2 to 1, today a proposal to defer a 41 per cent rise in passenger car toll rates.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- United States archaeologists have completed plans to search for the ancient city of Gibeon this summer in the hope of shedding new light on Joshua's conquest of Palestine.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced yesterday that its investment in synthetic rubber and petrochemical manufacturing plants in Ohio, Louisiana and Texas would amount to about $50,000,000.

Commodity futures moved irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges in generally dull trading. Price moves for coffee, potatoes, wool and hides were mixed; cocoa, copper, silk and cottonseed oil eased and lead and rubber rose.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 22 --The rule of three men over Thailand is in delicate balance. Without warning the scales could shift and everything, including Thailand's pro-Western position in world politics, could come crashing down. Although political intrigue here has comic opera overtones it is a deadly serious business.
President Sukarno of Indonesia smilingly stretched out his arms and said "New York, New York, here I come" as he hailed welcomers at La Guardia Airport yesterday afternoon.

Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel N. Serper of Long Beach, L.I., and San Juan, P.R., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss June Carol Serper, to Lieut. (j.g.) Samuel. L. Rosenfeld, U.S.C.G.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred R. Rosenfeld of 870 Fifth Avenue and Long Beach. The wedding will take place in the autumn.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities reported today that it has evidence American passports have been "an important instrument in the Soviet espionage operation" for years.

Anita Ahlum, 6 years old, of 1062 Lafayette Avenue, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday by a three-ton oil truck while crossing Quincy Street between Lewis and Stuyvesant Avenues, Brooklyn. The police said she ran into a double rear wheel of the truck. The child had been dismissed at noon from the kindergarten of Public School 129, 648 Quincy Street. No charge was made against the truck driver.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) --The University of Pennsylvania disclosed Today it had disciplined six of its thirty-eight fraternities for a campus disturbance that erupted into street rioting three weeks ago.
BOLZANO, Italy, May 22 (Reuters)--Eighteen persons were killed tonight when an Austrian bus loaded with about forty tourists skidded off a mountain road and crashed into a ravine.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 22 (Reuters)--Birmingham City, an English first-division soccer team, beat Zagreb, 1--0, in soccer today on a first-half goal.

Two paintings, picked up for $40 at a country auction two years ago, will be reunited today with a pair from which they were parted twenty-five years ago. The four are now estimated to be worth $150,000.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) -President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of J. Monroe Johnson, from the Interstate Commerce Commission. Donald P. McPherson of Gettysburg, Pa., has been confirmed by the Senate as Mr. Johnson's successor.

Ottawa, May 22 (Canadian Press)--The Royal Canadian Mounted Police's famed musical ride will be performed in four Canadian and three United States cities between Aug. 13 and Dec. 1, the R.C.M.P. announced today.
CHICAGO, May 22 (AP)--The Zenith Radio Corporation sought today to raise the amount of damages it seeks from three companies by about $45,000,000 to a total of $61,750,000.
PHOENIX, Ariz., May 22-- Legal advisers of several states opposed today legislation to give the states concurrent jurisdiction with the Federal Government in the field of subversion.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The House Foreign Affairs Committee recommended today a $1,109,000,000 reduction in the Eisenhower Administration's $4,900,000,000 foreign-aid bill.
In spite of the big public housing program here, private build ers are putting up more than half of the new apartments in Manhattan.
PARIS, May 22 (AP)--Sven Davidson of Sweden bowled over Herbie Flam of Beverly Hills, Calif., 6-2, 6-4, 7-5, today to gain the semi-finals of the French international tennis championships.
Paperboard production in the week ended on Saturday was 2.3 per cent above that in the like week of last year, the National Paprboard Association reported yesterday.

LONDON, Ont., ,May 22 (Canadian Press)--Jack Jacobs, a former quarterback with the Winnipeg Blue Bombers, agreed today to act as head coach and quarterback with London in the senior Ontario Rugby Football Union next season.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 22--An atmosphere of political tension is pervading the Honduran capital.

An impressive array of police converged yesterday on the High School of Commerce, 155 West Sixty-fifth Street after rumors that trouble was expected between the school's Negro and white students. Nothing developed, however.
A City Hall conference of officials from communities throughout the metropolitan area was called yesterday by Mayor Wagner to discuss regional problems. The parley will open on June 18.
Met with Secretary of Defence Charles E. Wilson and Admiral Arthur W. Radford, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- President Eisenhower was described today as "a bit unhappy" about the Army, Navy and Air Force differences over missions in the atomic age.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 --Joseph N. Welch, the Boston attorney who gained national prominence during the ArmyMcCarthy televised hearings in 1954, is going on television as an actor.

The second mate of the tanker that collided Sunday with a cabin cruiser in the East River testified yesterday that a person on the bridge could not see what was going on in the water fifty feet ahead or to either side of the ship.

TOKYO, May 22 (UP)--The old United States battleship Oregon will be cut up for Japanese scrap metal next month. The 10,000-ton ship was the pride of the Navy when built in 1896. Her superstructure was removed at the start of World War II and she has served since as an ammunition barge.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP)-- Senate investigators were told today that Soviet kidnapping tactics used on Russian refugees and German scientists in postwar Europe had been extended to this country.
LONDON, May 22--The stock markets here, reopening after the Whitsun holiday, struck a dull note today. Sentiment was restrained by Wall Street's weakness.
"The 1956 Pulitzer Prize for News Photography was won by the New York Daily News for its consistently excellent news picture coverage in 1955 ...
ALBANY, May 22 (AP)--Gov. Harriman designated today May 21 through June 6 as the period for the Red Cross diamond jubilee observance in the state.
The chairmanship of the 1957 campaign for members and funds of the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross has been accepted by Robert E. McNeill Jr. He is president of the Hanover Bank.

CHICAGO, May 22 (AP)--Colonels Image, a 19-5 shot ridden by Eldon Coffman, today beat Redruth by a neck to win Balmoral's $3,500 Viscounty Purse at Washington Park. Wailabhai was third in the field of seven juveniles. Colonels Image stepped the five furlongs in 0:58 4-5.

Among the 20,514 customers at Belmont Park yesterday were close to 1,000 members of a New York A.C. delegation. It was the fifth annual New York A.C. Day at the big horse park, and the main event was the Julien J. Soubiran Handicap, named for the newly-elected president of the Winged Footers.

The former assistant business manager of Hunter College pleaded guilty yesterday in General Sessions Court to the larceny of $64,310 from a college fund. Judge Ambrose J. Haddock scheduled sentencing for June 27.
MOSCOW, May 22--Pravda assailed the United States today for maintaining trade embargoes with Communist countries.

BONN, Germany, May 22-- The West German Foreign Office rejected today as untrue Soviet allegations that "sound and healthy" Soviet citizens were being detained in West German mental hospitals to prevent their repatriation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (UP) --Elmer Valo, 35, a left-handed outfielder released by the Kansas City Athletics last week, was signed by Philadelphia today. The Phils sent Glen Gorbous to Miami of the International League to make room.
PITTSBURGH, May 23 (UP)-- The University of Pittsburgh today accepted an invitation to play in the second annual Orange Bowl basketball tournament at Miami Beach, Dec. 26-29.

TEL AVIV, Israel, May 22-- Emergency tax measures designed to yield 75,000,000 Israeli pounds (about $41,500,000) for armament and fortifications were approved in Jerusalem tonight by the Knesset (Parliament). The Communists alone opposed the measure.

Some 1,364,000 Americans should travel abroad by sea and air in 1956, Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways, told stockholders attending the airline's twentyeighth annual meeting yesterday. This would be 15 per cent more people than went overseas last year, and set a new record, he said.

VIENNA, May 22 (AP)--Premier Viliam Siroky of Czechoslovakia now says President Tito of Yugoslavia was slandered when he was condemned as a "Western imperialist agent" in Czech purge trials of the Stalin era.
NEW DELHI, India, May 22 (AP)--India has made a gift of 5,000 tons of rice to relieve distress in East Pakistan, the Foreign Ministry announced.

A son, their second child, was born on May 8 at Polyclinic Hospital to Mr. and Mrs. Herman Haimes of 1025 Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Haimes is the former Miss Helaine Shachter of this city. The child has been named Bernard Todd.

A $6,000,000 civil anti-trust suit was filed yesterday in Federal Court by the Eastern Wine Corporation of New York City against five large wine distributors, Eastern manufactures and sells Chateau Martin wine.

PARIS, May 22--American diplomacy has had no success in budging Soviet opposition to President Eisenhower's "open skies" inspection plan. The Russians consider this merely a formula to permit espionage. Yet we believe until some such agreement is reached there can never be valid disarmament.

Election of William K. Warren as a director of the Gulf Oil Corporation was announced last night. He is chairman and chief executive officer of the Warren Petroleum Corporation, which recently merged with Gulf.

A supervisory company to manage properties for its clients has been formed by the C.B. Snyder Organizations of Hoboken, N.J. The new unit has been named the Snyder-Amy Management Company of New York and ...

Governor Harriman spent a comfortable day yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. He underwent an operation for a prostate condition Monday. Dr. George F. Cahill, who performed the operation, and Dr. Alvan L. Barach, Mr. Harriman's personal physician, issued the following statement:
SAN FRANCISCO, May 22-- A "floating winery" to carry 2,500,000 gallons of California wines to the East Coast in a single trip is to be built here.
Directors of the National Gypsum Company yesterday elected Leonard L. Hank vice president of manufacturing. Mr. Hank, formerly general
VICTORIA, B.C., May 22 (AP) --The Pacific Coast Conference assessed fines of up to $1,550 on eight of its nine member schools today and tightened the strings on alumni and booster clubs.
A more flexible foreign-policy approach to problems of the age of communism and the atom has been outlined by a group headed by John J. McCloy, former United States High Commissioner in Germany.
WASHINGTON, May 22--A Senate Judiciary subcommittee adjourned its hearings for a second time today on the nomination of Solicitor General Simon E. Sobeloff to the United States Court of Appeals.

MILWAUKEE, May 22 (AP)-- Chet Nichols of the Milwaukee Braves today was assigned outright to Wichita, Kan., the Braves' American Association farm. The move made room for the return of Gene Conley, a right-handed pitcher, from the disabled list next Friday.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 22--The wreck of the United States destroyer Peary, sunk by the Japanese in Darwin Harbor in 1942, is believed to have been found by the Australian submarine chaser Quadrant. There has been a story that the Peary was loaded with bullion. She is the only ship sunk at Darwin still unaccounted for.

Monday's extraordinary news conference in the Pentagon of all the nation's military chiefs has helped, as Secretary of Defense Wilson hoped it would, to put great military issues into clearer perspective. Inter-service and intra-service differences, always existent, had emerged from the academic freedom of the war colleges and the sanctity of

MIAMI, Fla., May 22 (UP)-- The Mediterranean fruit fly has spread across Lake Okeechobee from the edge of the central Florida citrus belt, the State Plant Board reported today. Reports circulated that the United States Department of Agriculture planned an embargo on all south Florida fruit and produce,

Unaccustomed though it was to budget cutting, the City Council has broken a ten-year record by making a small reduction in the amount that Mayor Wagner and the Board of Estimate had proposed spending for the 1956-57 fiscal year.

LOS ANGELES, May 22-- James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, and his international executive board were described today as feeling that one of their most contentious trust fund policies was a mistake.

Two student publications at Hunter College made their debuts this week. Perspective, a magazine sponsored by the Collegium Musicum study organization, is devoted to music, the visual arts and literature.
The Board of Education made public yesterday its $21,000,000 salary increase schedule for teachers and other personnel. Final action, however, was delayed until tomorrow.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., May 22--Senator Estes Kefauver, campaigning for the Democratic Presidential nomination, bid tonight for the support of needy elderly citizens.
Abe Stark, president of the City Council, proposed yesterday that the city hire outside experts to study the garment area's traffic woes.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) --A small fossil plant leaf in the National Museum has been identified as being about 60,000,000 years old.

STANTON, Del., May 22 (UP) --Three Calumet Farm thoroughbreds arrived at Delaware Park today, the first of the twentyone expected for the thirty-three day meeting opening next Monday. Trentonian, an expected starter in the Wilmington Handicap on the first day; Commodore M., a candidate for the Brandywine Handicap on Memorial Day, and Cherokee Chief were in the shipment.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 22 (AP)--Charles D. Nord of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., was announced today as winner of the first annual Grantland Rice memorial scholarship to Vanderbilt University. The scholarship to the alma mater of the sportswriter who died in 1954 is supported by a grant from the Thoroughbred Racing Association.
Eight manufacturers of children's wear will join a producer of home laundry equipment in a $500,000 cooperative national merchandising campaign.

BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, May 22 (Reuters)--A strike that has halted shipping at Bridgetown, the only port on this British West Indian island, entered its tenth day today with a general food shortage threatened.

Mayor Wagner and Joseph P. McMurray, State Housing Commissioner, will speak this morning at ceremonies breaking ground for Frederick Douglas Houses at Columbus Avenue and West 101st Street. The project will have 1,999 apartments in fifteen buildings, including special units for the elderly. The cost is put at $36,735,000.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- Representative Wright Patman criticized high Administration officials today for failing to answer his questions on their disagreements with the Federal Reserve Board.
W.R. Grace Co. has announced the election of D. Walter Robbins Jr. as a vice president. Mr. Robbins, formerly ...

ST. LOUIS, May 22 (AP)--The Government offered evidence today to show T. Lamar Caudle had fought against criminal prosecution of a tax dodger suffering from epilepsy. Mr. Caudle then was head of the Justice Department's tax division.

WASHINGTON, May 22-- There has been so much emphasis on "teamwork" in the Eisenhower Administration during the last three years that the automatic official response to any outbreak of public bickering within the Cabinet or the armed services is to hush it up or play it down.

TORONTO, May 22 (AP)--Accidents killed seventy-one persons during Canada's three-day Victoria Holiday, against seventyfour on the 1955 holiday. A Canadian Press survey until midnight yesterday showed thirty-three persons died in traffic accidents, twenty-six by drowning, two in fires and ten in miscellaneous accidents.
BONN, Germany, May 22-- Shipping from Baltic ports tends to confirm the view that the economic recovery of East Germany has at last hit its stride.
SECRETARY DULLES--I have no initial statement of my own to make so I will be glad to receive your questions.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that a number of changes had been made in the bureau that handles criminal and fingerprint records.
TOKYO, May 22 (UP)--A Japanese ship reported radioactivity today 1,300 miles south of the scene of the United States hydrogen bomb test.

ATHENS, May 22 (Reuters)-- President Theodor Heuss of West Germany left here for home today after a state visit to Greece. Heinrich von Brentano, West German Foreign Minister, who accompanied Dr. Heuss, left here by air earlier today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Minn., May 22 (UP)--The Big Ten's plan for a round robin football schedule in 1959 and 1960 struck a snag today and a committee was appointed to prepare slates of eight conference games for each team for the two years.
The Wabash Railroad, controlled by the Pennsylvania Railroad, plans to spend $34,000,000 this year on capital improvements, stockholders were told yesterday at the annual meeting in St. Louis.
The Sheraton Corporation of America completed a $30,000,000 deal yesterday whereby it acquired twenty-two hotels with 5,420 rooms in fifteen cities in six states.
DALLAS, Tex., May 22-- Texas Democrats named today a national convention delegation led by Senator Lyndon B. Johnson and pledged to support him for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

DETROIT, May 22--Three Yankee strings, two personal and one that had belonged to the team, were snapped at Briggs Stadium today. A 3-2 triumph by Bucky Harris Bengals over Casey Stengel's Bombers put to an abrupt end the six-game winning streaks of the Yankees and of Whitey Ford.
An economist for a farm group declared yesterday that unless dairy farmers received more for milk their unrest might develop into a strike.
Cotton futures prices were unchanged to 21 points ($1.05 a bale) higher yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. July deliveries showed the greatest strength.

The last of three men charged with robbing the Port Chester branch of the County Trust Company of $188,785 last March 2 pleaded guilty yesterday. Federal Judge Gregory F. Noonan will sentence all three on June 5.
Arthur F., 64 years old, sat most of the time in the window of his furnished room in
HEREFORD, England, May 22 (AP)--Mervyn Wilkins, a National Hunt jockey, died in a hospital today from injuries received when his horse fell in a steeplechase race a week ago. He was 35.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) --President Eisenhower discussed today--in a joking manner--the possibility of a high-level meeting with European leaders at his country place in Scotland.

RANGOON, Burma, May 22 (Reuters)--Burmese voters braved monsoon weather today for elections that will determine whether Burma's left-wing Opposition party will gain a foothold in the Upper House of Parliament. Forty-five seats will be contested in a "staggered" election that will extend over three months.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 22-- Dr. and Mrs. Fred Wolfsohn have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Wolfsohn, to Lieut. David Remley Wood of the Air Force. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Price Wood of Short Hills, N.J.

Before the expansion of thoroughbred racing in the United States after World War I you could count the turf contests of outstanding national interest on your fingers, and you wouldn't need the thumbs.
WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --W. Barton Greenwood, Assistant Commissioner of Indian Affairs, was named today Deputy Commissioner, a new position.

ROSLYN, L.I., May 22--A 21year-old airman died in a barracks fire that broke out here early this morning at the Roslyn Air Force Base, nerve center of the nation's Northeastern radar and communications defense system.

The Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court was asked yesterday to dismiss the taxpayers' action against construction of an additional parking lot for the Tavern-on-the-Green in Central Park. Decision was reserved.
PARIS, May 22--Two civil servants sentenced to prison for having divulged military secrets appealed today.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, said today the United States welcomed the offer of the Soviet Government to allow Pan American World Airways to operate flights into Moscow.
WASHINGTON, May 22-- Secretary of State Dulles uttered his first word of public reproach today for the Egyptian Government of Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The head of the British Labor Party was told by a leading American unionist today that formation of a labor party in this country would not be "realistic" now.
Bloodmobiles of the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today will visit the Brooklyn Army Terminal and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, 195 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The leading question here today was: Just what did Nikita S. Khrushchev tell Harold E. Stassen in London April 24 about the Soviet Union's plans to cut back its military manpower?

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 22 (UP)--Senator John J. Sparkman, Democrat of Alabama, said today he would not seek the Vice Presidential nomination again this year. Mr. Sparkman ran with Adlai E. Stevenson in 1952.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (AP) --Dr. William F. Foshag, head curator of the Department of Geology at the Smithsonian Institution, died yesterday of a heart attack. His age was 62. He was one of the country's foremost gem experts.
TIME for the annual May dance having turned up, the Phoenix is celebrating with a bright, gay gambol, "The Littlest Revue," which opened for the friends and subscribers last evening.
Dirty city air must be studied as bacteria were studied half a century ago, experts said yesterday in a discussion of environmental cancer-causing agents in lung diseases.

Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Weiss have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Louise Weiss, to Franklin Kavaler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Kavaler of Jamaica, Queens. The wedding will take place in August.

THE program called "Warner Brothers Presents" turned back to Geoffrey Chaucer last night for inspiration for its filmed television presentation, "The Deadly Riddle," on Channel 7. The excursion into the classics was a sound idea.
A formal request for a public hearing on the budget of the Waterfront Commission was sent to the Governors of New York and New Jersey yesterday by a dock union official.

CLEVELAND, May 22--The steel industry faces a 260 per cent increase in the cost of building new plants not too long from now, it was estimated today by Charles M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- Members of the Lucy Stone League and the sponsors of five scholarships provided by the league for women students at the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School of Finance and Commerce were guests of the university yesterday at a luncheon.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (AP) --The Philadelphia Electric Com pany announced today it was expanding its electric and gas facilities with an outlay of $1,500,000 a week. H.S. Davis Philadelphia manager of the company, said the expansion was in anticipation of economic growth from the new Delaware River Turnpike bridge to be opened on Friday.
PARIS, May 22--Pierre Mendes-France was reported tonight to be prepared to resign from the Cabinet in disagreement over policy in Algeria.

OTTAWA, May 23--Canada will join with Britain to test a new radio system for guiding planes over the North Atlantic, it was announced today. The system, known as Dectra, will involve installation of two sets of long-distance radio stations on either side of the Atlantic. One pair will be situated in New Brunswick and the other in Scotland.

WASHINGTON, May 22 (UP) --The Department of Justice said today the press had been barred from a Federal Bureau of Investigation police-training school on civil rights in Columbia, S.C., because confidential information was discussed.

MARION, Mass., May 22-- The Eastern eliminations of the United States Olympic trials for the 12-square-meter Sharpie Class ended today. C. Eric Olsen Jr. and Stanley Renahan of Essex, Conn., were the top qualifying crew among six to move into the United States finals, which will start here Friday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 22-- Mr. and Mrs. George K.G. Hammer of Philadelphia and Odessa, Del., have announced the engagement and forthcoming marriage of their daughter, Miss Lenora Katharine Hammer, to Lieut. (j.g.) William Joseph Aston, U.S.N., son of Dr. and Mrs. Melville J. Aston of Philadelphia.
A 17-year-old boy was shot in the back in the Bronx last night, apparently without provocation. He and a friend first were assaulted by two other boys, one of whom carried a pistol.
WASHINGTON, May 22--The Senate unanimously approved today a compromise farm bill that President Eisenhower is expected to sign.
PHILADELPHIA, May 22 (UP) --The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. considered today a merger with the United Presbyterian Church of North America.

"EVERY morning she wrapped a small package in gift paper, tied it with colored string, put it under the old man's arm and sent him off with it. He would be back in less than an hour without the package. It was some days before Dove saw that all the paper contained was garbage.

HARTFORD, May 22 (UP)-- Gov. Abraham Ribicoff said he was "appalled and shocked" at the number of slayings and shootings in Connecticut involving teen-agers. He proposed that Congress pass a law prohibiting the mail-order sale of firearms in states requiring permits for

In a new and dramatic bid for peace Premier Ben-Gurion of Israel has offered to meet Premier Nasser of Egypt at any time and in any place, including Cairo itself, to discuss a settlement that would end the technical state of war between their countries and serve as a model for a peace settlement for the whole Middle East.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 22 (AP)--"I Love Lucy" the Columbia Broadcasting System television show starring Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz, today was signed to a one-year contract by its sponsors, Procter Gamble and General Foods. Terms of the new pact were not disclosed. The current five-year contract with Desilu Productions expires next month.
THE adolescents in the auditorium were a notably atten tive group. When questions were invited from the floor, a dozen hands shot up at once.
We all now know how easy it is to borrow from a local library. The procedure is not so simple for the men who go to sea. Fortunately, the American Merchant Marine Library Association, more common
PARIS, May 23 (UP)--Althea Gibson of New York and Britain's-Angela Buxton today gained the women's doubles semi-finals in the French tennis championships.

NAPLES, Italy, May 23-- Harry S. Truman said today he did not want to embarrass anybody but that he had never held "squirrel-headed" generalship responsible for the way Allied landings were carried out south of Rome in 1943-44.
Observers of the money market found it knee deep in lendable cash late yesterday. They looked quickly to see if the Federal Reserve had opened the dam.

Mayor Wagner for some time has been feeling his way toward a cooperative approach to metropolitan problems. Now he is sending out invitations to a City Hall conference on June 18 of officials of near-by communities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

MOSCOW, May 22--Russians are being urged in newspaper articles to go east to the empty reaches of Siberia. The Government has renewed its efforts to turn large natural resources there into great industrial centers.

LOS ANGELES, May 23 (UP) --A charge the University of Southern California paid $71,235 over a two-year period in "secret" aid to athletes was presented to the Pacific Coast Conference today by a University of California at Los Angeles alumnus.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Eisenhower flashed a warning light to the embattled armed services today.
Protectionist efforts to "sterilize" this country's trade program were assailed yesterday as contrary to national interests of securing peace and future economic needs.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., May 23--Adlai E. Stevenson spent today in Jacksonville shaking hands.

BUENOS AIRES, May 23-- Argentine Army generals have scored a notable victory over lower-echelon officers. With the approval of the provisional,President, Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu, the top officers announced that "discipline" was being restored to the Army.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Eisenhower threw cold water today on a proposal that he call a conference of Southern Governors to discuss racial integration of the public schools.
The city and the First Army command have joined in a move to eliminate a traffic hazard involving the Staten Island and Governors Island ferries.
TENAFLY, N.J., May 23-- No issue will arise over the question of drinking at the Tenafly High School senior prom --there won't be any prom.

Directors of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., raised the quarterly dividend yesterday with the declaration of 50 cents a share on the common stock. The big department store chain has been paying 40 cents quarterly since Oct. 1, 1952. The first dividend at the new rate will be paid on July 2 to common stockholders of record of June 7.
A hit show completed its scheduled run in the Custom House yesterday, but was held over for an additional two days by popular demand.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 --Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer today reported that production on "Raintree County" will not be resumed before July 4. Filming was halted after Montgomery Clift, the co-star, was injured May 13 in an automobile accident. On the basis of early medi
A bearded scholar told the story yesterday of the microfilmed writings of a Hebrew genius shipped to this country from Latvia just before nazism crushed the Jewish communities there.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 --An offer to purchase the working control of Republic Pictures Corporation for $8,125,000 to $10,000,000 has been made by Cantor, Fitzgerald Co., Inc., investment bankers of Beverly Hills.
HARTFORD, May 23--Ones hundred members of the Connecticut National Guard were ordered today to report for traffic duty on Memorial Day in an effort to reduce the state's highway deaths.

A complete shutdown of operations of CBS-Columbia, television and radio set manufacturing division of the Columbia Broadcasting System is being considered, Frank M. Stanton, president of the parent company, revealed yesterday.
PARIS, May 22--The rebellion in Algeria is chewing steadily at France's economic strength, and the bites are getting bigger.
The Board of Education's school supply depot in Queens looked more like a toy shop yesterday than the $30,000,000 annual operation it represents.
TRIPOLI, Libya, May 23-- United States and British diplomats in Tripoli are becoming alarmed over extensive efforts by Egypt to woo Libya away from her stanch pro-Western position.

Negotiations are in progress whereby "Zane Grey Theatre," a filmed Western series with Dick Powell as host and narrator, would snake its debut next fall over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.

WASHINGTON, May 23--A member of the Joint Atomic Energy Committee said today that this country was being outstripped in the race for peacetime atom power. However, the chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission retorted that "we are not behind any country."

Stocks tried to rally yesterday but gave up in the early afternoon and closed considerably lower. At its bottom for the day. The New York Times combined average stood at the lowest level since Feb. 23.

GRACIE FIELDS gave a subdued and convincing performance last night in "The Old Lady Shows Her Medals." The James M. Barrie play, expertly adapted to television by Robert Anderson, was presented over the "United States Steel Hour" on Channel 2.
NUTLEY, N.J., May 23-- Stockholders of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation bade fond farewell here today to the founder of their company and greeted their new president.
Twenty-four artists, writers and musicians received money and medals yesterday at the fifteenth annual ceremonial of the American Academy and the National. Institute of Arts and Letters.

Copper futures prices dropped sharply yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. The sharp decline was influenced by a continuing lower London market and a drop in the customary smelter price of 2 cents a pound to 43 cents here.
The proposed $1,216,800 parking garage at Eighth Avenue and West Fifty-third Street won the approval of the City Planning Commission yesterday with a proviso.

Houston, Tex., received bids yesterday on $17,000,000 of bonds to finance various municipal improvements. The best bid, submitted by a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers, Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and Phelps, Fenn Co., set an interest cost of 2.8645 per cent. A syndicate headed by Kidder, Peabody Co. put in the next best bid, a cost of 2.867 per cent.

A decline of 955,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies stood at 186,753,000 barrels, compared with 187,708,000 a week earlier and 170,677,000 a year earlier.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 23 --Contract negotiations between the Writers Guild of America and the television networks will be resumed tomorrow in the face of a threatened June 4 strike deadline. Guild and network officials from New York have flown here for the talks.
Zionist leaders stressed last night the need for a strong Zionist movement for Jewish cultural and spiritual survival in all lands outside of Israel.

Miss Blue Jay closed fast to win the $17,425 Fashion Stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The daughter of Double Jay opposed nine other 2-year-old fillies in the fifty-eighth running of the five-furlong event, and at the end she had a margin of almost two lengths over Marullah.

A Queens County jury set some kind of record for zeal yesterday afternoon. In bringing in a verdict of guilty against a defendant charged with grand larceny, it named the state's principal witness as his accomplice.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Eisenhower declared today that although the state of international affairs was far from ideal there was "too much pessimism" about it.
BOSTON, May 23 (AP)--Industrialists in different fields today pictured research, new and improved products, and automatic production as major keys to future prosperity.

Operations of Dresser Industries, Inc., in the six months ended April 30 resulted in a net income of $7,050,000, an increase of 63 per cent over the period of the prior year. The earnings are the highest for any half-year period in the company's history and compare with $4,324,772 made in the six months to April 30, 1955.
A new development was disclosed yesterday concerning a narcotics defendant over whom District Attorney Frank S. Hogan and General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman had clashed.
LINDEN, N.J., May 23--Earnings of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) this year are expected to top those of 1955, M.J. Rathbone, president, told some 2,500 stock
OSLO, Norway, May 23--Henrik Ibsen Week was opened officially in Oslo today with a reception in the Oslo Town Hall. The event marks the fiftieth anniversary of the dramatist's death.
Diamonds and rings worth $250,000 were reported to have been stolen yesterday from two New York dealers.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- Howard Pyle, a deputy assistant to President Eisenhower, apologized tonight for saying in unemployment-hit Detroit that the "right to suffer is one of the joys of a free economy."

After more than 104 years under unpaid member presidents, the Toronto Stock Exchange has adopted the New York system. Arthur J. Trebilcock, a 63-yearold lawyer, has been made its first paid president.
PHOENIX, Ariz., May 23-- The National Association of Attorneys General approved today two resolutions designed to curb the power of the Supreme Court to nullify state laws.
WASHINGTON, May 23--The battle of Washington calmed down today as the President defended inter-service differences, while demanding a higher loyalty.
WHITE SANDS, N.M. May 23--The Army has fired eight of its controversial Nike missiles in two days. A number of shrapnel hits were scored, the Army said, but only one drone target was destroyed.
New issues of public utility securities valued at more than $52,000,000 will be offered to investors today, as follows:

Rain prevented both the Giants and Dodgers from playing yesterday. The Polo Grounders didn't even try to start their game with Cincinnati, but the Brooks attempted to defy the weather by engaging the Braves at Ebbets Field.
NUTLEY, N.J., May 23-- One of the world's most colorful corporate executives, Col. Sosthenes Behn, bowed out today as chairman of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.

A five-story store and apartment building on plot 25 by 130 feet at 210 West Fourteenth Street was sold by P. Coppina to Joseph Torch. The buyer plans to occupy the store for the sale of artists' supplies. The property is assessed at $43,000 and was sold through John A. Montagna, broker, who also arranged a fifteen-year mortgage of $38,500 at 5 per cent on the property.

ACCRA, Gold Coast, May 23 (AP)--Louis (Satchmo) Armstrong proudly proclaimed his Afro-American origin today and, with his jazz, thrilled 100,000 enthusiastic listeners at a concert in Accra's largest park. It was the first concert of his three-day visit to the African west coast.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- Albert M. Cole, the Government's housing chief, has conceded that his prediction of 1,300,000 starts this year will not come true "unless there is a significant increase in the flow of mortgage funds to serve our demands."
PARIS, May 23--Pierre Mendes-France, Radical party leader, resigned today from the Cabinet in disagreement over Government measures to counter the rebellion in Algeria.
President Sukarno of Indonesia looked carefully and enthusiastically at several aspects of New York City yesterday and said several times during the day, "I love Americans." At the insistence of his
All pleasure boating is not serious and straight faced. There have been gay blades who added a chuckle.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 23--Frederick Ash ton's full-length ballet "Romeo and Juliet" to the music of Serge Prokofieff was presented tonight by the Royal Danish Ballet in its festival season at the Royal Theatre.

WASHINGTON, May 23--A subcontractor for parts of Air Force uniforms swore today she had been forced to provide nearly $28,000 in "kickbacks" for the payment of "under the table" bribes to military personnel.
NEWTOWN, Conn., May 23-- Gov. Abraham A. Ribicoff dedicated the $15,000,000 Shepaug Dam here today to the "service of the people of Connecticut."

William Z. Foster, national chairman of the Communist party, and six associate, yesterday won part of their appeal to reinstate their old-age Social Security benefits based on Communist party earnings.

THE old-fashioned family, toting overstuffed wicker ham pers and watermelons, armed with citronella and with Towser in tow, once marked the opening of the picnic season with a gastronomical feast in the woods or at the shore.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- When President Eisenhower permitted his news conferences to be televised, it was widely assumed that this half-hour of questions and answers would be carried complete to the nation once every week.

Three automobile manufacturers took top places in dollar volume spent on national newspaper advertising last year, according to the Bureau of Advertising of the American Newspaper Publishers Association.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- Brainstorming, the art of successful idea-production, came to the Navy Department today.

An eyewitness to last Sunday's collision between a cabin cruiser and a 180-foot tanker in the East River said yesterday that the pleasure craft appeared to be in difficulty with exhaust trouble just before the accident.

LONDON, May 23--Rain in Britain, like the dog biting the man, is not news. But the man has bitten the dog. There is a drought.
WASHINGTON, May 23--The House of Representatives approved a compromise farm bill today, 304 to 59, and sent it to the White House.

ALGIERS, Algeria, May 23-- More than 3,000 troops swung into action today against rebels in a hilly area where a French patrol was ambushed last Friday.

"MODERN" is a furniture term that oan mean Chippendale to one generation, Herman Miller to another. And what we call modern today is fast becoming a period style, in the opinion of Hugh De Pree, general manager of the Herman Miller Furniture Company.

Harry R. Gelwicks, dean of newspaper men in Queens, where he knew "everybody who was anybody," died Tuesday night in the Middletown (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 85 years old. He had been inactive since he suffered a stroke several years ago.

A SLIP that shows can be a sign of good grooming as well as bad. When worn under a sheer blouse, made, for example. of chiffon, which is now so fashionable, carefully selected underpinnings become an important part of a complete costume.

SANTIAGO, Chile, May 23-- The Chilean Foreign Ministry is sounding out other Governments as to the possibility of concrete action at the meeting in Panama of Presidents of American Republics.
PARIS, May 23--Pierre Mendes-France has become a lone wolf again. His resignation as Minister of State today ended an uneasy partnership that suited neither his character nor his aims.

NICOSIA, May 23--Individuals in seventy-three villages in the Troodos Mountain area have been ordered to register. Moreover, the removal of all slogans from sides of dwellings, stores, churches or public buildings has been decreed.

DETROIT, May 23 (AP)--Johnny Summerlin of Detroit gained a unanimous ten-round decision tonight over Harold Carter of Linden, N.J. Summerlin weighed 194 pounds and Carter 195.

Seventeen New York City banks reduced their loans to business $60,000,000 during the week ended Wednesday, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 24 --Two all-Army and three interservice marks were unofficially battered during the second day of the First Army track and field meet today.
TAMPA, Fla., May 24--Senator Estes Kefauver described Adlai E. Stevenson today as a pawn of political bosses and a corporation lawyer "curiously silent" about monopolistic business practices.
CAIRO, May 24--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser accepted today an invitation to visit Communist China in the near future.

The Joint Council on Educational Television, which is concerned about the delay in the development of ultra-high-frequency television channels, has suggested steps that it feels are necessary to put U.H.F. "back on the road to health and growth."
WASHINGTON, May 24--The long-stalled nomination of Simon E. Sobeloff, Solicitor General, to the United States Court of Appeals cleared its first hurdle in the path of Senate confirmation today.

BOSTON, May 24 (UP)--A physician at Lahey Clinic tonight confirmed the original diagnosis of what's wrong with the nation's most-publicized foot.
WASHINGTON, May 24--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 6 percent above sales in the corresponding week last year.
WASHINGTON, May 24--The Eisenhower Administration's foreign-aid bill was cleared today for action by the House of Representatives. Further reductions in the outlays proposed appeared possible.
Political leaders, and Congress in particular, were accused last night at a civil-rights rally in Madison Square Garden of not insuring the rights of individuals.
Connecticut plans to sell $50,400,000 of state temporary housing notes, series L, in the public market on June 5, it was announced yesterday. The notes are dated June 14 and will mature on Dec. 14.

The $1 minimum hourly wage, which went into effect on March 1, ate into the April earnings of Western Union Telegraph Company, according to the monthly report released yesterday. Gross operating revenues for the month also slid slightly behind those of April, 1955, dropping to $19,933,573 from $19,970,278 a year ago. Net income of $1,032,891 compared with $1,193,751 in April, 1955.

The long debate in Congress over farm legislation this year would seem to be over. Both houses have now passed the new compromise bill which replaces the measure vetoed by President Eisenhower last month. The indications are that the President will sign this compromise.
President Sukarno of Indonesia told the Foreign Policy Association last night that his country's chief aim was to preserve the peace of the world.
Hulbert S. Aldrich, city-wide campaign chairman of the Greater New York Fund, said yesterday that prospects for the success of the 1956 drive were the best in the history of the fund.

DEARBORN, Mich., May 24-- Henry Ford 2d said today that no major economic pick-up was in sight for the rest of this year. On the other hand, he indicated that he did not expect a material decline from present levels.

TRENTON, May 24--The Governors of New Jersey and Pennsylvania will open tomorrow the Delaware River Turnpike Bridge, which will enable motorists to travel from Manhattan to Indiana with nothing to slow the trip but toll gates.

DETROIT, May 24--Just to watch Mickey Mantle swing a bat is worth the price of admission. Fans all over the circuit have applauded the Yankee slugger. In two stops on the current road trip they have booed the home side for declining to pitch to him.

WASHINGTON, May 24--The United States Air Force has been invited informally to send two or three senior officers to Moscow for Soviet Aviation Day June 24. No decision on acceptance appears to have been reached yet.

Before George S. Kaufman departed for London on May 9 to spend his annual vacation there, he was fostering an idea about a musical to fit Bert Lahr. Research discloses that Mr. Kaufman and Alan Campbell are collaborating on the book.

WASHINGTON, May 24-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 778,997 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

Twenty members of the Park Association of New York City went on a tour of Brooklyn yesterday to see if the grass grows greener there.

The Waterfront Commission has acted wisely in making public a summary of its budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1 next, complete texts of which are now in the hands of the Governors of New York and New Jersey.

EGGS are about as cheap now as they will be in some time, a trade observer said yesterday. Supplies are abundant, as is usual at this season, and prices, down 2 cents a dozen since last Friday, have hit rock bottom.

Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, who will be retired for age on July 31, declared yesterday that "it is wasteful to discard" capable persons more than 65 years old, particularly educators. He recommended extending the mandatory retirement age to 70.

General Session Judge Jacob Gould Schurman closed a hearing against two narcotics defendants yesterday with a vague threat to an assistant district attorney.
WASHINGTON, May 24-- The United States Consumer Price Index rose 0.2 per cent between mid-March and midApril, for the second consecutive monthly increase.

William F. Wund, an attorney, died Wednesday in his home at Manhattan House, 200 East Sixty-sixth Street. His age was 75.

Stocks continued downward yesterday, stretching the loss in The New York Times combined average for the week so far to 15.66 points, or 4.74 per cent. The whole market suffered from the sell-off, for only 130 of the 1,210 issues traded were able to gain. There were 866 declines and 214 issues closed unchanged.
Cotton futures prices on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 4 points up to 16 points off yesterday.

The New York City Omnibus Corporation offered yesterday to take over operation of the bankrupt Third Avenue Transit Corporation.

THE opera workshop of the Third Street Music School Settlement last night presented three one-act comic operas by contemporary composers. One of them, "The Ordeal of Osbert," was by Allan Davis, the school's music director.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 24 --The climate for industrialization is critically handicapped in Thailand.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 --The cancellation of the "Medic" series on the National Broadcasting Company television network involves a good deal more bitterness than is generally known.

Rubber and copper future prices tumbled sharply yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange. The drop in both commodities was influenced by lower London markets.
ROME, May 24--The new big jet and turboprop airliners that will be flying in the early Nineteen Sixties will not need runways any wider than the present international standard.

A housing project for medical workers in the Yorkville area was assailed yesterday before the Board of Estimate. Speakers attacked the proposed $5,205,500 plan for homes for middleincome residents as a "gross misuse of public funds."
Long-term steel labor contracts to avoid "the dubious choice of a nation-wide strike or a dose of inflation" were urged yesterday by Joseph L. Block, president of the Inland Steel Company.
A broader and more intensive drive to win the Democratic Presidential nomination for Governor Harriman was started yesterday.

The names of the young women who will be included among the provisional debutante members to be honored at the eighth annual Debutante Ball of the Junior League of New York have been announced by Mrs. C. Spencer Huffman, chairman of the ball, and her committee.
The State Supreme Court will hold summer trials this year in an attempt to relieve congestion and delay in the courts.
Inadequately treated tuberculosis cases are believed to cause more than 75,000 new cases of the disease each year in the nation.

Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, yesterday condemned variable annuities as "an unregulated financial device that invites misuse." He expressed his opposition to three bills, Nos. 450, 451...

PARIS, May 24--Premier Guy Mollet made a bold bid today for broad Assembly support for all his policies to compensate for the defection of his principal ally, former Premier Pierre Mendes France.

OAKLAND, Calif., May 24 (AP) --Seven of the nine men aboard a United States patrol bomber shot down by the Soviet Union have received a total of $35,080 in compensation for their injuries. The plane was destroyed last June over the Bering Sea.

Miss Iris M. Broverman was married to Howard Kaplan last night in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frederick S. Broverman, at 1060 Fifth Avenue. The bridegroom is a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Tobias D. Kaplan of New York.

In an "anguished appeal" to the French Government and people to take some necessary, fundamental decisions, Pierre Mend s-France has resigned from the Cabinet. His resignation does not necessarily doom the Socialist-led Cabinet of Premier...

WASHINGTON, May 24 (UP) --The National Association of Manufacturers criticized today a bill that mould authorize the building of six Government nuclear poorer reactors. It said private industry should be allowed to do the job.

ROME, May 24--Former President Truman said here today that it was his considered opinion that the Allies' Salerno landing in 1943 had been made to win the war and that this objective had been attained.

CAROLLA ISLAND, N.C., May 24--The invincible enemy of all East Coast anglers, a northeaster, was doing its malicious worst here today. Therefore, gin rummy was raging without hindrance all along the Outer Banks.

WASHINGTON, May 24--The Soviet suggestion that the United States send several top Air Force officers to Moscow for the Aviation Day exercises on June 24 has come at an embarrassing time for the Eisenhower Administration.

FASHION models, like prizefighters, are allowed only a brief moment of glory in their chosen work. They start young, reach the peak early, and are finished at an age that is the prime of life for ordinary mortals.
WASHINGTON, May 24--The Senate Internal Security Subcommittee called today for the expulsion of the Soviet Government's chief representative at the United Nations, Ambassador Arkady A. Sobolev.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, May 24--Premier Viliam Siroky said today that Czechoslovakia and Syria were negotiating a general trade agreement and that "naturally Syria is interested in arms."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 24-- Allan Sprout, retiring president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, today called for a broad national inquiry into the banking and monetary system of the United States.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 24--Mike Volpe and Anthony J. Sforza of the Harrison Country Club proved to be the winning pair in the British Victory Golf Tournament at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy announced yesterday that this year's 1,000th arrest for driving while intoxicated was made Wednesday. The number includes twenty-three women.

The fuse for the two-day eightieth annual Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America (I.C. 4-A) track and field championships will be touched off this afternoon at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island.
SARA REAVIN'S "The Ivory Branch," which opened at the Provincetown last evening, is the sort of drama that proper academicians used to call a "thesis play."
The Gottfried Baking Company announced yesterday the purchase of the restaurant business of Cushman's Sons, Inc., subsidiary of the American Bakeries Company, for an undisclosed sum.

The Coast Guard took testimony again yesterday from witnesses who saw the collision of the cabin cruiser Escape II and the 180-foot tanker M.J. Derby II. The vessels collided last Sunday in the East River off Fifty-first Street, Manhattan.

Readers in their wheelchairs may now roll right into the New York Public Library, thanks to one of their number who thought up a way of doing it. He is Richard Match, a free-lance writer of 1165 East Ninth Street, Brooklyn.

CHICAGO, May 24--Reports of rain in the Southwest hard winter wheat areas and increased marketing of new wheat depressed wheat prices today on the Board of Trade. These factors checked demand for other grains and soybeans.
BUENOS AIRES, May 24--In an attempt to break the most serious strike it has faced, the Provisional Government of Gen. Pedro Eugenio Aramburu arrested today 356 striking transport workers.
A young Japanese woman who was among the world's first atomic bomb casualties died here yesterday while physicians were trying to erase the scars inflicted more than ten years ago.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 24 --The motion-picture industry is preparing to launch an extensive promotion campaign to help stimulate attendance at theatres. Company heads are no longer attempting to cover up the alarm caused by the sharp decline in box-office receipts that began late last fall.

WASHINGTON, May 24--Sinclair Weeks, Secretary of Commerce, took issue today with proposed antitrust legislation that had the backing of the Justice Department and an endorsement in principle by President Eisenhower.

TRENTON, May 24--International tensions, social and economic conditions in the nation and community environment were cited today as factors contributing to the spread of juvenile delinquency.
