PHILADELPHIA, May 25-- Southern Protestantism is said to be facing its "most difficult" crisis since the "dark days" of the Civil War.

KABUL, Afghanistan, May 25 (UP)--The Government has charged that Pakistani troops attacked a border outpost last Sunday and killed at least seven persons. Afghanistan handed a formal protest yesterday to Pakistan's chargd d'affaires here.

BRIELLE, N.J., May 25-- Robert Hausen and Carl Klein of Lakewood High shared the individual title and led their school to a repeat victory in the New Jersey interscholastic golf championships at the Manasquan Country Club today.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, May 25 (UP)--Relay runners from all over Yugoslavia converged on Belgrade today carrying greetings to President Tito on his sixty-fourth birthday. Two million persons from throughout the nation took part in the relay race.
SANTIAGO, Chile, May 25-- The Chilean Government said tonight it had no proposals to submit to the forthcoming conference of Presidents of Ameri-- can nations.
BRIDGEWATER TOWNSHIP, N.J., May 25--William S. Weeks, prominent New Jersey business executive and civic leader, died last night in a hotel in London. His age was 73.
The residents of Woodside, Queens, are getting a little confused. They do not know from one day to the next whether their statue of a World War I doughboy is up or down.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) --The Supreme Court today gave Louisiana until June 4 to answer a Justice Department motion to bar offshore oil proceedings in a state court at Lake Charles.
LONG BEACH, Calif., May 25 (AP)--Two men were rescued from the sea by a passing freighter when their rented private plane crashed 200 miles off the coast, ...
A READER who has been "long in city pent" writes to ask where he can buy good trout. Unable to pursue his avocation as an angler, he is longing for a taste of that fine fish.
General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman was in the midst of another controversy yesterday--this time with another jurist.
The BMT Astoria line will operate in both directions on the Manhattan-bound track through the Sixtieth Street tunnel this week-end.
GLEN HEAD, L.I., May 25 Mrs. Robert Cukierski of Brookville won low gross honors in a one-day tournament of the Women's Cross-County Golf Association today.
FLORAL PARK, L.I, May 25 (AP)--Sewanhaka High School's lacrosse team scored its eightyfifth successive victory today, an 8-3 conquest of Manhasset High.

DETROIT, May 25 (UP)--Baseball Commissioner Ford C. Frick said today major league players henceforth would be barred from playing in Latin and South American leagues if those leagues were not parties to an agreement with the majors.

Dr. Willis C. Noble Jr. of 55 South Fullerton Avenue, Montclair, N.J., for many years supervisor of the biochemical laboratory of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died Thursday night of a heart attack suffered in the Garden Skating Club, Madison Square Garden. His age was 71.
Cesare Barbieri of 14 East Sixty-fifth Street, an inventor, mechanical engineer and philanthropist, died yesterday at Doctors Hospital. His age was 78.
Representatives of British and United States protective committees for holders of foreign bonds have reached agreement "in principle" with officials of Berlin, Germany, as to a settle-dollar ...
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)-- The House Committee on UnAmerican Activities will start hearings in St. Louis June 4 on Communist activities in the area.

Walter Marais, former Capetown University Rugby star, has been elected captain of the New York Rugby Football Club. Edward Lee and Bradley Brady have been renamed as president and secretary, respectively.

A new chairman of the board of the Health Information Foundation, Inc., was named yesterday. He is George F. Smith, president of Johnson Johnson, manufacturer of surgical dressings and other products.
MILWAUKEE, May 25--Senator Alexander Wiley of Wisconsin, a champion of President Eisenhower's foreign policy, was plunged today into a showdown struggle for political survival.

A daughter was born in the New York Hospital on May 9 to Don Filippo and Donna LeGrand dei Marchesi Theodoli of Rome and New York. Donna LeGrand Theodoli is the former Miss LeGrand Scott Briggs, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. LeGrand Geary Briggs of Lexington, Ky. The child has been named Lavinia.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., May 25--Senator Estes Kefauver accused Adlai E. Stevenson today of employing "a smear and smile technique" in discussing the thorny issue of race relations in this state's Presidential primary.

GENEVA, May 25 (Reuters) --The first major meeting in Eastern Europe of the World Council of Churches will be held in Matrahaza, Hungray, northeast of Budapest. The Council's ninety-member Central Committee will meet there from July 28 to Aug. 5, it was announced here today.

NORTH CHICAGO, Ill., May 25 (AP)--A Navy officer said today a preliminary investigation showed that Maurice G. Everett, a 17-year-old recurit, had undergone nothing more than "normal" training before he collapsed and died Tuesday.
This post-war era of diversification has brought a raft of name changes. The most recent move is that of the Detroit Hardware Manufacturing Company (listed on the American ...

Former President Carlos Prio Socarras of Cuba and an aide have been excluded from this country by the Immigration Service on the ground that their admission would be "prejudicial to the public interest, safety and security."
MOSCOW, May 13--City official have announced plans for reconstruction well as new construction in Moscow. Special emphasis is on housing, one of the Soviet capital's major shortages.
The eightieth Intercollegiate Association of Amateur Athletes of America (I.C. 4-A.) track and field championships opened at a leisurely pace at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday.

The International Longshoremen's Association and two of its top officials were found guilty yesterday of "willfully and deliberately" flouting a court's return-to-work order issued during a strike last September.
ATLANTA, May 25 (UP)--The United States Public Health Service reported today an "encouraging" decrease in the number of poliomyelitis cases in the wake of the nation-wide Salk vaccine program.
BALTIMORE, May 25--Two weeks ago the Orioles' Don Ferrarese blanked the Yankees, 1--0, barely missing a no-hitter. Said the Bombers at the time:
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)-- The National Coal Association, from incomplete car loading reports from the railroads, today ...

ST. LOUIS, Mo., May 25--Industrialization and its modern ally, automation, may be able to solve the social crises they create if they progress to their logical conclusions, a social scientist predicted today.
In an investment deal in the Bedford Park district of the Bronx, the six-story apartment house for sixty-two families at 457 East 201st Street, northeast ...
LONDON, May 25--An agreement signed today between Britain and the Soviet Union gave British trawlers the right to fish to within three miles of Soviet shores in the Barents Sea.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) --Senator Price Daniel, Democrat of Texas, urged the Senate today to approve a stiff new narcotics-control bill authorizing death sentences for persons selling heroin to children.
PROMISE outdistances fame in a number of one-man exhibitions of paintings opening in local galleries this week.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25-- Drexel Institute's College of Business Administration presented its annual award to Henry R. Luce today for his "administrative acumen and editorial judgement." Mr. Luce, editor in chief of Time, Life and Fortune magazines, received the award at a day-long convocation on the theme, "The Business Publications Industry."
Eighteen justices of the State Supreme Court will be available to hold trials in Manhattan and the Bronx this summer.
A son, their second child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. Eric Moses Javits of 1025 Fifth Avenue on Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital.

BOSTON, May 25 (AP)--Richard S. Robie, president of the Avis Rent-A-Car System, said today that negotiations were under way for sale of his interests in the system. The system operates in 600 United States communities and in eleven foreign countries.
The sun never sets on the British Empire. It also never sets on the Empire's favorite sport--cricket.
LONDON, May 25--The United States is making serious inroads into Britain's scientific manpower, according to a leading British educator.
Verne S. Atwater, former assistant to the chairman of the board of the County Bank and Trust Company, Paterson, N.J., has been appointed director of administration of the Ford Foundation.
Gene Fullmer, a busy puncher from West Jordan, Utah, gained the decision over Charles Humez of Paris, France, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.
The Giants last night became the proud possessors of their first triumph in five 1956 meetings with the Dodgers.

DANVILLE, Pa., May 25--Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Mumper Keefer have announced the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Patricia Keefer, to Richard Joseph Stoeffel. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. John A. Stoeffel of Wilmington, Del.

SAYREVILLE, N.J., May 25 (AP)--Robert Wickowski, 18, pitched his fourth no-hitter of the season today as Sayreville, High blanked Carteret, 4--0. He has won nine and lost two this year. His strike-out record for the four no-hitters totals sixtytwo.
Abraham Slabot, publisher of The Jewish Ledger of New Orlean, has been elected president of the American Association of English-Jewish Newspapers.

Miss Colette T. Lorenz of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph John Lorenz of Long Branch, N.J., was married yesterday morning to Franklin S. Judson, also of this city. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin I, Judson of 1185 Park Avenue.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)--Billy Pierce handcuffed the Cleveland Indians on three hits tonight in pitching the Chicago White Sox to a 2-1 victory before a crowd of 31,840. Larry Doby scored the deciding run on some clever base running.

ALBANY, May 25 (AP)--The state will deduct Civil Service Employes Association dues from employes' salary checks starting Oct. 1, John F. Powers, president of the association, announced today. The plan will be on a voluntary basis for approximately 50,000 State workers. The dues are $7.50 a year and will be deducted at the rate of 28 cents each pay day.
Twelve members of a nationally operated auto theft gang were sentenced to penitentiary terms yesterday in Federal Court, Brooklyn. Two other men were placed on probation for two years.

The newly ormed North Hills League for Retarded Children will hold its first annual luncheon today in the Roosevelt Hotel. The league membership is comprised of Long Island residents. Mrs. Harry Bernstein is its president. Proceeds from the luncheon, of which Mrs. Edith Schwalbe is chairman, will go to the Association for the Help of Retarded Children.
WASHINGTON, May 25-- Passengers who flew from Baltimore to Pittsburgh in a Capital Airlines plane last night were urged to take anti-polio shots today "purely as a precautionary measure."
MILWAUKEE, May 25 (UP)-- Ted Kluszewski drove in three runs on four hits and the Milwaukee Braves committed four errors tonight as the Cincinnati Redlegs posted a 6-5 victory over the league leaders.

LONDON, May 25 (AP)--Kentucky-bred Never Say Die, winner of the 1954 Epsom Derby and the highest priced stallion in England, was donated to the British National Stud today by his American owner, Robert S. Clark.

Stockholders of the Bush Manufacturing Company will vote on a proposed consolidation with the C.A. Dunham Company at a special meeting on June 26, according to Cecil Boling, president of Bush. Dunham makes heating items. Bush manufactures air-conditioning and refrigeration equipment.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) --Senator Wililam E. Jenner said today that "the squirrelheaded attitude of our country at Yalta" had opened the way for the Soviet Union to use "blackmail" tactics against Russians who came here under false identities after World War II.
A Congressional inquiry into "the Communist conspiracy within the churches" of this country was demanded last night at a Fundamentalist Protestant meeting.

NEW DELHI, India, May 25-- India will establish diplomatic relations with Spain at the embassy level, the Ministry of External Affairs announced today. The decision has been taken despite the fact that Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru has been one of the stanchest critics of the Spanish regime.
LONDON, May 25--The stock markets here today shrugged off Wall Street's relapse. Most losses of importance, especially among oil and copper shares, were eliminated before the markets closed.
Joske's department store, Houston, Tex., will be the leading tenant in the new Gulfgate regional shopping center being erected on the outskirts of the city.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., May 25 (UP)--The Attorney--General of Indiana ruled today that industrial workers in his state could not collect benefits under both the state unemployment compensation law and "guaranteed annual wage" plans in labor contracts.
REDWOOD CITY, Calif., May 25 (AP)--Carl (Bobo) Olson, former middleweight champion, was defeated again today--to the tune of $49,600.
PARIS, May 25-United States political elections have become a factor of immense international importance.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (UP) --Dale Long equaled a major league record tonight when he hit a homer in his sixth straight game as the Pittsburgh Pirates beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 8--5.

WASHINGTON, May 25-- A daughter was born on May 19 in the George Washington University Hospital here to Mr. and Mrs. David Peacock Jr. Mrs. Peacock is the former Miss Judith Van Orden, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. T. Durland Van Orden of Pottersville, N.J., formerly of New York. The child has been named Sarah Durland.
VANCOUVER, B.C., May 25 (Canadian Press)--Pancho Gonzales registered his seventy-first victory last night in his professional tennis series with Tony Trabert.
The city has long-range plans to widen Park Avenue north of Ninety-sixth Street to the Harlem River and eliminate the New York Central's overhead railroad tracks there.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., May 25--With eighty-eight entries from twelve states, the annual tournament for the amateur championship of the United States Chess Federation got under way tonight.
OYSTER BAY, L.I., May 25 --Sjohaxa, sailed by Bill Luders Jr., today won the first of three races in the Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club's 5.5-meter spring regatta.
Directors of the Chicago North Shore System, Inc., yesterday declared a 100 per cent stock dividend.

A reduction of 1 cent a pound in the wholesale prices of its shortening was announced yesterday by Swift Co. It is the first price cut this year and follows six consecutive 1-cent-apound advances since early January.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 25-- Seton Hall of South Orange, N.J., beat Ithaca's nine, 4--2, at Perry Field tonight. Charley Calcagno, with a run-scoring single and fourth-inning home ...
A late spring frost, with temperatures dropping twenty degrees to record lows in many areas, inflicted damage estimated in the millions to crops throughout the Northeast yesterday.
Officers were elected last night for the National Tuberculosis Association at the annual board of directors meeting at the Statler Hotel.
Frederick Joubert Duquesne, soldier of fortune and convicted spy, died at 3:50 P.M. Thursday in City Hospital.

Events tonight: Jewish People's Philharmonic Chorus, Eugene Malek, conductor, Carnegie Hall; Russian A Cappella Chorus, Town Hall; Uri Zifroni, tenor, assisted by Gunther Sprecher, pianist, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, all at 8:30.
Mayor Wagner called yesterday on groups and individuals to consider the needs of the city's men and women more than 60 years old.

ROME, N.Y., May 25 (AP)-- Officers of District 3 of the United Electrical Workers, an independent union, have recommended that the district's fifteen locals merge with the International Association of Machinists.
Cotton futures moved irregularly on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. July advanced 33 points but other months were 10 up to 4 points off.

A concert version of Sean O'Casey's autobiographical novel "Pictures in the Hallway" will be presented tomorrow at 3 and 8:40 P.M. at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association Poetry Center, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.
WASHINGTON, May 25--The Treasury has abandoned hope of devising a tough formula for the taxation of life insurance companies in time for Congressional action this session.
PHILADELPHIA, May 25-- President Sukarno of Indonesia caressed the Liberty Bell in Independence Hall here today. He said he was happy to be "at the place where American history was made."

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 25 (UP)--Floyd Patterson went a total of five rounds with three sparring partners today in preparation for his twelve-round heavyweight bout with Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson at Madison Square Garden June 8. Patterson weighed 181 pounds after the workout.
OSLO, Norway, May 25--The Bergen Music Festival opened today in the presence of Crown Prince Olav and high-ranking Norwegian and foreign dignitaries.
CLEARWATER BEACH, Fla., May 25--Maj. Gen. Earl S. Gruver, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Gruver have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sue Gruver, to Charles ...

TRENTON, May 25--Gov. Robert B. Meyner moved today to end the month-long wage strike of 240 drivers and mechanics employed by Rockland Coaches and the Hill Bus Company. The walkout has affected 40,000 commuters in Bergen County, N.J., and Rockland County, N.Y.
The Chain Belt Company yesterday reported its net profit for the six months ended April 30 at $2,335,847 on sales of $28,101,007.
Three graduating students received 1956 Pulitzer Traveling Scholarships yesterday at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism. Three alternates also were named.
REGINA, Sask., May 25 (Canadian Press)--Vic Buccola, a guard and linebacker from California Poly, signed with the Saskatchewan Roughriders of the Western Interprovincial Football Union today.
BALTIMORE, May 25 (AP)-- Marco Reginelli, 58-year-old racketeer, died here in a hospital today.

Gross revenues of the Southern Railway dropped by more than $1,000,000 last month to $23,087,395, but the road managed to report a net income of $3,226,239, barely changed from the $3,281,679 of April last year.
The twenty-five nations that have had representatives at the fourth post-war tariff conference at Geneva have negotiated reductions in tariffs that affect some $2 billions in international trade.
JERUSALEM, May 25 (AP)--A tomb believed to be one of the oldest stone structures known to man has been discovered in Israel by a French archaeologist, Jean Perrot.
TORONTO, May 25 (Canadian Press)--The Republic of Ireland, one of fourteen countries invited, today accepted the bid to the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show.
ALGIERS, Algeria, May 25-- Algeria is being separated from Morocco by a stretch of barbedwire entanglements almost a hundred miles long.
STERLING, Ill., May 25 (AP) --Jim Bowers, 17-year-old Sterling High senior, today set a national secondary school mile run record of 4:16.1 in the North Central Illinois high school track meet.
SUNNINGDALE, England, May 25 (AP)--Three Americans today entered the women's British amateur golf championship June 26-29.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics decreased to 89.5 on Thursday from 90.1 on Wednesday. The figure for May 26, 1955, was 89.1.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)--The National Safety Council today declined to present to any state or city its grand award for traffic safety performance in 1955. A worsening traffic safety situation throughout the United States was given by the council as its reason for withholding the award.
PORTLAND, Me., May 25-- The scientist who discovered "orgone energy" and his New York associate were sentenced to prison in Federal court here today on contempt of court charges.
LONDON, May 25 (Reuters) --A top spokesman for the tiny Communist state of Albania bid today for better relations with the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP)-- Three women accused of attending the Communist World Youth Festival in Poland last year refused to discuss their travels today or to answer questions about alleged Communist affiliations.
CEDAR CITY, Utah, May 25-- A parachute failed to open today as an instrument-crammed dummy was propelled from a 1,500 foot escarpment at 612 miles an hour.

PHILADELPHIA, May 25 (UP) --Gene Freese of the Pittsburgh Pirates was fined $50 today by the National League president, Warren Giles, for "inciting a riot" in the ninth inning of Pittsburgh's 6-3 loss to the St. Louis Cardinals at Forbes Field Tuesday night.
Margaret Truman is suffering from laryngitis, and is canceling her television appearances for the time being. "It's nothing serious," her husband, Clifton Daniel, said yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, May 25 (UP) --Vietnamese Government troops have killed the leader of the rebel Hoa Hao sect and captured his chief of staff, military sources said today.
EDMONTON, May 25 (Canadian Press)--The Provincial Government was enriched by $33,283,861 today from a sale of petroleum and natural-gas leases in proven fields and on wildcat lands.
Prof. Josef Hoffmann, Viennese architect and designer, died May 7 in his home in Vienna at the age of 85, according to word received here yesterday by his biographer and pupil, Prof. Leopold Kleiner.
CHICAGO, May 25--The shadow of the Southwest's new crop wheat movement was over the wheat pit today and weakness in this quarter induced selling of both coarse grains and soybeans.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 25 --No distance yacht race on Long Island Sound ever had been bigger and few probably colder than the one that began off the Larchmont Yacht Club this evening.

BOSTON, May 25 (UP)--The first kidney transplant operation ever performed on a woman was termed an initial success today. But doctors at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital said it would be several weeks before they know if the kidney will function properly.
The 46-year-old treasurer of a Federal credit union in New Britain, Conn., was accused yesterday of embezzling $180,000 from the union.

SHANNON, Ireland, May 25 (Reuters)--An Air France Super-Constellation carrying fiftyone passengers made a forced landing here today after having flown the last 1,000 miles of a direct flight from New York to Paris on three engines. No one was hurt. A relief plane new the passengers to Paris.
MARION, Mass., May 25-- George Whitney and his crew, Davis Taylor of the Beverly Y.C., won the opening race of the United States Olympic Sharpie Class trials today.
Stockholders of the United States Rubber Company at a special meeting on June 29 will vote on a proposal to amend the cereificate of organization permitting the company to issue convertible bonds.

Sam Minskoff Sons, Inc., have completed the Wykagyl Shopping Center in New Rochelle, N.Y. The development, consisting of eleven stores, was built on a three-acre site at North Avenue and Northfield Road.
Prices zigzagged on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, starting strong, dipping to the lowest point since Feb. 17, rising in the early afternoon and slipping once more at the end.
WASHINGTON, May 25-- Judge Finis James Garrett, who retired last Sept. 15 as chief judge of the United States Court of Customs and Patent Appeals, died at his home here early today. His age was 80.
Bond prices fell in April, according to a compilation by the New York Stock Exchange. The average price of listed bonds on April 30 was $95.50 for each $100 of par value, against $96.32 on March 31.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)--A week-old European tarpan, or forest horse, described as one of the world's most unusual animals and the first to be foaled in the United States, was put on display at the Brookfield Zoo yesterday.
FLINT, Mich., May 25 (AP)-- A jurisdictional dispute among craft unions over the right to install machinery in an auto plant flared today into a headcracking battle in suburban Grand Blanc.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, May 25--With policemen and soldiers standing guard, 250 Honduran women met today in the country's first women's political party convention.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., May 25 --West German officials today toured Oak Ridge atomic energy installations. They said they foresaw a time when West Germany would be able to produce commercial electric power from atomic energy.
THIS morning's books are contrasting ventures in civilized exploration and the varieties of colonial experience.
WHITE PLAINS, May 25-- Mrs. Louis M. Loeb of Mount Kisco, retiring after three years as the first board president of the Adoption Service of Westchester, was honored here tonight.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 25 (AP)--Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, said today that although Americans were buying fewer automobiles than in 1955, "we will still have a very good year--the third best in our history."

WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP)-- The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today the resignation of Roderick Kreger as chief information officer and the appointment of his predecessor, Edward E. Slattery Jr., to the post.
C.V. Whitney's Head Man, in his first start since finishing eighth in the Kentucky Derby, won handsomely in the role of 7-to-10 favorite in Belmont Park's top race yesterday.

Kings County Judge Samuel S. Leibowitz threatened yesterdy to hold a Bronx physician in criminal contempt if he failed to testify truthfully before the rackets grand jury investigating a city-wide ambulance-chasing ring.
Six repatriates have left the Port of New York for Russia and Iron Curtain countries in the last two weeks, it was disclosed yesterday.
The hazards of fire and poisonous gas from illegally stored old film resulted in an order to vacate an upper West Side building, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. reported yesterday.
Members of the Prince Hall Masons will give blood to the Red Cross today at 1255 Bedford Avenue, Brooklyn.
THE birds are back, and so is Miss Wiley. There was a rumor last spring that Miss Wiley was going to retire.
A former ship master was honored for heroism yesterday by the New York Board of Trade. He is Brother Marinus, who in December, 1950, ...
LINDEN, N.J, May 25--A Virginia man innocently brought about the death of his brother in a pile-up of three trailer-trucks on Route 1 here this afternoon.

A daughter was born to Nobile Demetrio and Donna Antoinette Guerrini-Maraldi of Rome on May 13 in LeRoy Hospital here. Donna Guerrini-Maraldi is the former Miss Antoinette Sickles, daughter of Mrs. Jorge R. Andre Jr., of 120 East Seventy-eighth Street and of Col. Daniel E. Sickles of Paris. The child will be named Vanessa.
A West Side sale and leaseback featured realty deals in Manhattan reported yesterday.

First priority for the construction of hospital facilities providing general beds has been assigned to Richmond, the Hospital Council of Greater New York said yesterday in its seventeenth annual report.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 25 (UP) --Unofficial returns from 662 of 785 local unions gave Woodruff Randolph a lead of 9,661 votes over Laurence Victory of New York. Mr. Randolph is bidding for a seventh two-year term as president of the International Typographical Union.
Egyptian hieroglyphs, old when the pyramids were young, and as dead as Horus for the last 2,000 years, recently felt the blush of new life.
Miss Susan Roberta Bennett was married yesterday at noon to Samuel W. Altman in Temple ...
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)-- An Administration spokesman today recommended that the Government "not embark upon a program to subsidize in peacetime the mining of submarginal ores."
C.K. McLeod has been elected president of Walter Kidde Co. of Canada, Ltd., manufacturers of fire-extinguishing equipment, fire detection devices and ultrasonic ...
PHILADELPHIA, May 25-- Edward E. Reardon, controller of the Budd Company, makers of transportation equipment, died today in his home in Jenkintown, a suburb. His age was 55.

Nearly 170 antiques dealers from many parts of the country will take part in the first Coliseum antique show, which opens today for a nine-day run. Varied decorations and art objects from primitive African masks to sophisticated Chinese porcelains will be shown on the fourth floor.

UTICA, N.Y., May 25 (AP)-- Gerald T. McHugh, 26-year-old State Trooper from the Bronx, was injured fatally today when his patrol car left Route 5 and struck two utility poles. The accident happened about a mile from the new Hartford substation, where Mr. McHugh was temporarily assigned.

The forty-ninth Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit opened yesterday. The paintings are displayed along the sidewalks and against fences and the sides of buildings from the Avenue of the Americas to south of Washington Square.
For the first time, Brooklyn College will present a play in its new open-air theatre on its campus at Germania Place and Campus Road.

GENEVA, May 25 (Reuters --The ninth assembly of the World Health Organization. United Nation's agency, attended by delegations from seventy-six countries, ended here today. I approved an atomic energy program covering studies of health risks connected with radiation and the disposal of radioactitve waste.
The new capital market continues to reflect the growing feeling that economic activity for this year may be fairly well below that of 1955.
President Eisenhower last night assured captive peoples behind the Iron Curtain that the Free World had not forgotten them.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 25-- William A. Lucas of 710 Floral Avenue, a consulting chemical engineer for the Peyton-Hunt Company of New York for seventeen years until his retirement in 1950, died yesterday at the Alexian Brothers Hospital after a long illness. His age was as 71.
Correction Commissioner Anna M. Kross announced yesterday a complete reorganization of the supervisory personnel in her department. The transfers and promotions are effective Monday.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 25 --The evening newspaper El Heraldo published yesterday the text of a controversial article from the New York magazine Vision on the pros and cons of the Perez Jimenez Government.
ROME, May 25--About 2O,000 rallies concluded tonight the campaign for nation-wide administrative elections that are to be held Sunday and Monday.
BRUSSELS, May 25--The Belgian Government may soon begin to mint gold coins.
DALLAS, May 25 (UP)--Don January fired a four-under-par 67 for a 131 and a three-stroke lead in the Dallas Centennial open golf tournament today.
Governor Harriman's consumer counsel warned yesterday that any "substantial" increase in the retail price of milk might cut sales.

LOS ANGELES, May 25-- Mrs. Collette Lyons Hearst filed suit in Santa Monica superior court today for separate maintenance from George Randolph Hearst, 51 years old. Mr. Hearst is the oldest son of the late William Randolph Hearst.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, May 23--The chief ballet on tonight's program in the festival season of the Royal Danish Ballet at the Royal Theatre was "Coppelia," but a very different "Coppelia" from any that New York is familiar with.
The heart of an 11-year-old Brooklyn girl was stopped for half an hour by an electric currrent for an operation performed in Kings County Hospital a month ago.
Communist arms are going into the Middle East today and apparently there will now be more of them, perhaps through different channels.

CHICAGO, May 25 (AP)--Flying Bird defeated Roman Boss by one length today to win the Whichone Purse at Balmoral's Washington Park meeting. Flying Bird paid $38.80 for $2 and ran the six furlongs in 1:11 2/5 under Wayne Beck. Running Wolf finished third.
B. ALTMAN has set out to create a holiday mood for shoppers this week, whether they plan to spend the summer in the north woods, the South Seas or their own back yard.

William Ludwig Ullmann, former Treasury Department official, has denied to a Federal grand jury that he was a member of a Washington wartime espionage ring or was ever a member of the Communist party.
WESTBURY, L.I., May 25 (UP) --Henry Thomas, 66, retired from active competition tonight during ceremonies watched by 22,696 fans at Roosevelt Raceway. He will become a harness racing judge.
BERLIN, May 25--The Soviet Union rejected tonight an Allied protest against the march of East German army troops in Berlin last May 1.
PARIS, May 25 (U.P.)--United States tennis stars, led by three women, today gained the women's and men's doubles finals in the French international championships at windswept Roland Garros Stadium.
A new salary agreement providing pay rises for 3,700 employes of school custodians was announced yesterday by Charles H. Silver, president of the Board of Education.
The Catholic Guardian Society of New York Catholic Charities appealed yesterday for homes in New York City for adolescent girls discharged from Catholic child care institutions in the archdiocese.

The first annual Enterprise Award of the New York Young Men's Board of Trade was presented yesterday to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd for his accomplishments as head of the United States antarctic expeditions.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 25-- The President of the American Society of Engineering Education said here today "much hysteria" had surrounded the shortage of engineers in this country.

Lloyd Moglen of Scarborough School defeated Alan Roberts of Columbia Grammar, 1--6, 6--0, 6--2, 6--4, yesterday in the final of the Eastern Private and Parochial Schools tennis championship at the College Courts in Brooklyn. Lloyd and his brother Leslie beat Roberts and Robert Lubow, 6--3, 4--6, 6--0, in the doubles final.

It has been seventeen years since the name of Spratly Island had any significant space in an American newspaper. It is now back in the news.
Stockholders of Lear, Inc., at the annual meeting yesterday in Santa Monica, Calif., approved an increase in the authorized common stock to 5,000,000 from 3,000,000 shares.

Doubleday Co., book pubfisher, said yesterday that on or about June 28 it would close its Country Life Press division at its Garden City plant. For greater efficiency, printing and binding will be concentrated at its plants at Hanover, Pa., and Smithsburg, Md., the concern said.

Mrs. Edward A. Spalthoff of 47 East Eighty-eighth Street has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dorothy Marguerite Spalthoff, to Paul J. Benziger. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph P. Benziger of Riverdale, the Bronx, and Spring Lake, N.J.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., May 25--A psychiatric examination was ordered today for John Santoro of Byram, Conn., accused of shooting and seriously injuring two men on downtown streets here yesterday.
ST. CLOUD, Minn., May 25 (AP)--Jack Wink, a Wisconsin quarterback in the forties, today was named head football coach at St. Cloud State Teachers College.

SPRINGFIELD, N.J., May 25 --Approval of an offer from the board of directors of the Na-- tional State Bank of Elizabeth, N.J., to buy the assets and assume the deposit liabilities of the First National Bank of Springfield was announced here today by Robert S. Bunnell, president of the local bank.
KARACHI, May 25--Starvation in numerous villages of East Pakistan has been reported by competent observers. Moreover a shortage of coal supplies is said to have threatened the region's railroad.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP)-- A Social Security bill tailored to fit Administration wishes was approved by the Senate Finance Committee today.
Oakite Products, Inc., manufacturers of industrial cleaning and metal treating compounds, announced yesterday the election of J.J. Basch as vice president.

MONTREAL, May 25 (Canadian Press)--K.L.M. Royal Dutch Airlines announced today that Montreal would be linked by way of Amsterdam with Hungary and Bulgaria in air services scheduled to begin June 19 and June 28, respectively.
AMMAN, Jordan, May 25-- Maj. Gen. Ali Abu Nuwar said today that Jordan's army would be considerably enlarged and that the expansion already had begun.
WASHINGTON, May 25 (UP) --The Senate approved today a $556,271,517 money bill to run the State and Justice Departments and the Federal courts.
WASHINGTON, May 25-- Shoes with no uppers, straps or anything but soles are among this week's new patents.
STANFORD, Calif., May 25 (UP)--Alexander Kerensky has arrived quietly on the Stanford University campus to do research for the Herbert Hoover Institute, it has been learned.
Election of Walter J.A. Connor as president of the American Plastics Corporation, a subsidiary of the Heyden Chemical Corporation, was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 25 (AP) --Roy Wilkins, executive secretary of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, urged the Senate today to approve the same civil rights bill already voted by the House Judiciary Committee.

Miss Emily Henry, assistant principal of the Ethical Culture Schools, has been appointed principal. She succeeds William C. Swallow, who has been named assistant to director, Mrs. Victoria Wagner.
LONDON, May 25--The Soviet Union, using the international machinery of communism, is concentrating its attention on Africa, according to evidence accumulated here by authoritative analysts.

PANAMA, May 25--Ernesto de la Guardia Jr., candidate of the governing coalition, will be proclaimed president-elect Sunday, it was announced today. With returns virtually complete from the May 13 election, Senor de la Guardia leads Victor Florencio Goytia of the National Liberal party by 173,196 to 80,442.

LOS ANGELES, May 25 (UP) --The chairman of the Olympic Games committee of Australia, W.S. Kent Hughes, arrived today to confer with officials about arrangements for the international competition. Formation of a new company, Haesler Metal and Ore Corporation, to engage in international trading in ferrous and nonferrous metals and ores, was announced yesterday by Joseph J. Haesler. STRAVINSKY and Bach were the stars of the season's twelfth and last "Twilight Concert" late yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Recital Hall.

LONDON, May 25--Harold Macmillan, Chancellor of the Exchequer, gravely warned British industry today against the disastrous consequences of another round of wage increases.
DETROIT, May 25 (UP)--The Kansas City Athletics, aided by six errors and two balks, tonight defeated the Tigers, 6--3, and went into sixth place ahead of Detroit.

Stephenson of the College of Wooster, Wooster, Ohio, has been named technical director of summer training for the science demonstration lecture program at Oak Ridge. WASHINGTON, May 27--A successful effort to bring symphony orchestra music to the rock-and-roll set comes to an end this week. By Wednesday more than 61,000 teen-age visitors, most of them high school seniors, will have attended free concerts by the National Symphony Orchestra.

The contract bridge pair of Monroe Newman and Sidney Ritter, both of New York, posted a score of 199 match points yesterday afternoon to take a half-way lead over a field of 154 pairs in the 1956 Greater New York Open Pair championship.

The subscription salesman may be doing a good job, but news-stands have increased their sales of magazines. Distributors of new bond issues took heart yesterday. From Washington over the week-end came word that the Federal Reserve System would not be grudging in making money readily available to the banking system over the coming weeks.

WASHINGTON, May 28-- Clarence O. Tormoen, personnel security officer for the Treasury Department, died in his office today. He was 53 years old. His Treasury Department appointment was made on April 1, 1954.
"BLOOMER GIRL," a Broadway hit of a decade ago, was revived last night on Channel 4. It was good to hear the songs of Harold Arlen and E.Y. Harburg again, but the same cannot be said for the book.
Receipt of contracts for construction of three paper mills in Colombia at a cost of about $30,000,000 was announced yesterday by the Parsons Whittemore-Lyddon Organization.

Traffic Commissioner Wiley once said that there were no "big, bold strokes" that would solve New York City's traffic problem. But on Tuesday, June 5, he will begin trying out a plan to expedite crosstown movement that is about as drastic as any reforms he has proposed.

Commodity futures prices were mostly lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. Rubber, copper, cottonseed oil, tin, lead, zinc, hides and sugar declined; coffee, cocoa, and potatoes rose, and wool was mixed.

New England Electric System looks for net income this year of $13,250,000, or $1,25 a share, Irwin L. Moore, president, said at yesterday's annual meeting at Boston. This would compare with $12,448,259 or $1,24 a share on fewer shares in 1955.
WOOD-RIDGE, N. J., May 29 (UP)--The Curtiss-Wright Corporation announced today it planned to build a nuclear materials laboratory, including art.
Robert Parsons has been elected president of the Associated American Artists Galleries. Albert Landry has been elected executive vice president. Both had been vice presidents.
Robert Moses yesterday inspected highway and housing projects whose further development, he said, depend on Federal aid.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) --Representative Alfred D. Sieminski introduced legislation today to forgive Joe Louis, former heavyweight boxing champion, for $1,000,000 in back taxes.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., May 29 (AP)--Fire that swept an apartment building here early today killed a 75-year-old woman and injured two other persons.
Police Commissioner Stephen P. Kennedy reluctantly accepted the resignation of Vincent L. Broderick yesterday a deputy commissioner in charge of legal matters.

SALVATORE CALABRESE the cobbler says stones talk to him. His dark bright eyes seek them out around mansions where wreckers have mounded debris, in backyards and in countryside on weekend visits to kin.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- The office of Senate majority leader Lyndon B. Johnson announced today he had left for a "routine checkup" at the Mayo Clinic, Rochester, Minn.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 29--Britain urged the Security Council today to go along with Dag Hammarskjold's approach to a solution of the Palestine problem. A majority of the Council, including the United States and France, endorsed a British resolution requesting Mr. Hammarskjold, the Secretary General, to ...

Fashion Park, Inc., which makes and sells men's clothing through a chain of stores operated by its wholly owned subsidiary, Weber Heilbroner, Inc., operated in the black during the fiscal year ended Nov. 30.
The Chicago and North Western Railway had a net loss of $7,461,058 in the first four months this year. In the same months last year the company reported a $2,706,887 net loss.

Word has been received here of the birth of a daughter to Mr. and Mrs. Anthony N. Steel in London last Wednesday. Mrs. Steel is the former Miss Anne Husted, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John J. W. Husted of Bedford Hills, N. Y. The child will be named Louise.

The High School Teachers Association called upon teachers yesterday to continue the boycott of extracurricular activities, even if payment for certain after-school services was offered. The association asserted that the real issue at the heart of the two-year boycott was that of inadequate salaries for high school teachers.

Mayor Wagner urged help yesterday for the city's colleges and universities to meet their growing needs. He proposed that philanthropic and business foundations consider setting up a program to help the fifty institutions here.
NEW ROCHELLE. N. Y., May 29--This city will pay its "Fatt Calfe" debt this year by entertaining descendants of Lord John Pell at a dinner.
VENICE, Italy, May 29 (AP)-- Mr. and Mrs. Harry S. Truman and their party came here today from Florence. They are on a pleasure trip.

CHICAGO, May 29 (UP)--The Chicago Cardinals of the National Football League today signed Lawrence Williams, who played tackle at Xavier University in Cincinnati and with the Army in Germany. Williams signed as a free agent after his release from service.

KANSAS CITY, May 29 (UP) --The Kansas City Athletics to day signed a Kansas State basketball star, Dick Stone, as right-handed pitcher. Stone was optioned to Seminole of the Class D Sooner State League.

Jose Maria de Areilza, Count of Motrico, Spanish Ambassador to the United States, and the Countess of Motrico are honorary chairmen for the Fiesta in Spain, to be held Friday evening in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 29 (AP)--Jack Parnell of Nashviile, a senior at Oklahoma A. and M., fired another sub-par round today for a 36-hole score of 138 and a stroke lead in the qualifying round of the Western amateur golf tournament.

BUENOS AIRES, May 29-- Provisional President Pedro E. Aramburu issued a veiled warning to the Army today that his revolutionary regime planned to stay in power until it could hand the reins to an elected Government.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 29 (UP) --The Governmeent decreed an emergency three-day school holiday today an an attempt to prevent further student riots over the Presidential campaign.
ROME, May 29--Pope Pius XII showed today some signs of fatigue that alarmed his aides. They entreated him to reduce his work and take more rest.

BONN, Germany, May 29 (AP) --West Germany's Citizens' Committee has rejected the appointment of eighteen generals and colonels for the high command of the country's new armed forces, officials disclosed today.
MEMORIAL Day traditionally starts the real, knuckle-down fishing season in Long Island waters. Today will be no exception if the weather hold fair. Fishermen are more creatures of habit than fish.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The Internal Revenue Service ruled today that supplemental unemployment benefits were not wages. It thus removed a poten tial threat to the guaranteed annual wage plan worked out last year in the auto industry.

The book by Dr. Jesus de Galindez about the Trujillo regime in the Dominican Republic is neither a revelation nor an expose. It is rather a documented critical analysis of a twenty-six-year-old dictatorship.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- Lawrence R. Buol, former Stockton, Calif., pilot held prisoner by the Chinese Communists for nearly six years, died Sunday at Bordeaux, France, where he had been visiting. His age was 35.
NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., May 29 (AP)--The widely known Narragansett Casino, playground of the rich in years gone by, was 90 per cent destroyed by fire today.
Last night's scheduled opening of "Kismet" at the Paper Mill Playhouse, Millburn, N.J., was set back until tonight. The leading roles will be sung by Gail Manners and Ted Scott.
ITHACA, N.Y., May 29-- President Eisenhower was told today that the Premier of Communist China held him in "high regard" as a "force for peace" in the world.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP)--The Association of Insurance Commissioners was told today that state regulation of the insurance business "is faced with the most serious crisis in its history" because of threats of Federal control.

WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- The United States Tax Court was told today that George E. Allen, financier friend of three Presidents, had been sold $22,500 worth of stock for $100 because he was "a very prominent citizen."
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) --Senator Irving M. Ives entered George Washington University Hospital today in preparation for a major operation scheduled for Friday.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., May 29-- A son, their third child, was born to Mr. and Mrs. William Scott Sneath on Saturday at the Green wich Hospital. Mrs. Sneath is the former Miss Nancy Thornton daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Thornton of Philadelphia. phia.
MOSCOW, May 29--At a students' sports festival Sunday several leaders of the Komsomol (Communist Youth Organization) were entered in a foot race.

DETROIT. May 30 (AP)--The Kelvinator division of American Motors today announced the election of Walter Jeffrey as vice president and general manager and Homer Travis as vice president in charge of sales.
A "double check" of the volunteer program of the Office of Civil Defense was ordered yes terday by Mayor Wagner.

LONDON, Wednesday, May 30 --Pressure on the British Government to reopen negotiations for a settlement in Cyprus intensified yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- President Eisenhower today signed a bill providing for redistribution of marketing quotas for both domestic and foreign suppliers of sugar.

HOLLYWOOD, May 29 (AP)-- A gold recording of the "Who's on First?" routine of Bud Abbott and Lou Costello will be placed on permanent display at the National Baseball Hall of Fame museum in Cooperstown, N. Y., a spokesman for the comedians said today.
LOS ANGELES, May 29 (AP)-- Senator Kefauver tonight termed the close vote in the Florida primary a "great moral victory for me" in his contest with Mr. Stevenson.

TORONTO, May 29 (Canadian Press)--The Toronto Stock Exchange announced today that to simplify trading in active markets minimum spreads between quotations on mining and oil stocks will be increased, beginning June 1.
NEW CITY, N.Y., May 29-- A baffling, but pleasant, mystery has manifested itself here in the last two days.
The five Dayton, Ohio, household appliance plants of General Motors Corporation's Frigidaire division will be shut down completely tomorrow and Friday, as well as today.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics declined to 88.6 on Monday from 89.3 on Friday. The figure for May 31, 1955, was 89.

LONDON, May 29 (AP)--Soviet Premier Nikolai A. Bulganin told the Yugoslav people tonight that Moscow's foreign policy was based on the principle of "not interfering in the internal affairs of other states."
GROTON, Conn., May 29 (UP) --Keels for two more atomic submarines were laid today.

Guessing when the big copper producers would trim prices was a popular pastime yesterday in the metal market. The speculation was stimulated by the latest cut in the custom smelters' price--down 2 cents a pound yesterday, to 40 cents.

The ABC Vending Corporation has increased its' board to eight members with the election of David G. Baird as a director. Charles O'Reilly, chairman, also announced yesterday that Mr. Baird has been elected to the new office of chairman of the finance committee.
Union scholarships worth $4,800 each were awarded yesterday to the daughter of a handyman, the sons of two doormen and the daughter of an elevator operator.

Thirty-six persons and nine corporations were charged with the sale of pornographic literature yesterday in indictments handed up by the Kings County Rackets Grand Jury. Thirtythree of the individuals were arrested early in the day.
The Broadway Association, Inc., headed by Ralph T. Horgan, has elected eight new directors. They are Walter C. Aberg, of the Greenwich Savings Bank;

BALTIMORE, May 29 (AP)-- Harmon Killebrew got into the game by accident today and socked two home runs for his first hits this season to propel the Washington Senators to a 6-5 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

Philip Barry Jr., associate producer of "Goodyear Playhouse" and the "Alcoa Hour," will serve as producer of the drama shows for a period of twelve weeks beginning June 17. The two series are presented alternately on Sundays from 9 to 10 P. M. over the National Broadcasting Company television network.
WASHINGTON, May 29-- President Eisenhower received today something Presidents must have wanted since the United States began--a machine to make decisions.

Saturday matinees, this week and next, of "Uncle Vanya" at the Fourth Street Theatre have been canceled. Both performances were bought out by Franchot Tone to permit him and other players in the company to proceed with the film version of the revival.

The Petroleum Corporation of America yesterday issued to stockholders rights to subscribe to 328,400 new shares at $15 each. Holders of record on May 29 may buy the stock in the ratio of one new share for each five held.
PARSIPPANY-TROY HILLS, N.J., May 29--An attempt to recall four township Councilmen was defeated here today in the first such election ever held in Morris County.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) --Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, will fly to Dez Moines, Iowa, Thursday to begin a twice-postponed tour of Iowa and Nebraska farm areas, an aide said today.

Was it cricket? Or was it baseball? Here is another episode in the fred-hot battle of the record books between Columbia and New York University.
PITTSFIELD. Mass., May 29 (AP)--The Rev. George F, Davis, 56-year-old pastor of the Hinsdale Christian Church, was sentenced today to two years in the House of Correction.
Election of Henry E. Bowes as vice president and general manager of the television division of the Philco Corporation was announced yesterday by James M. Skinner Jr., president.

ST. LOUIS, May 29 (AP)--Evidence presented today at the conspiracy trial of two Truman Administration officials showed that a Federal judge and the Justice Department had clashed in 1951 over whether certain income tax matters should be presented to a Federal grand jury.
Fifteen witnesses appeared yesterday before the Kings County Rackets Grand Jury investigating a city-wide ambulance-chasing racket.

MIAMI, FLA., Wednesday, May 30--Adlai E. Stevenson defeated Senator Estes Kefauver in yesterday's Florida Presidential primary election.

The New York City Housing Authority received bids yesterday on issues of notes totaling $24,084,000 to further the temporary financing of two stateaided projects, Howard Houses and Sumner Houses in Brooklyn.
Two teen-age youths who found $60 in the cellar of an empty house in Queens and turned their findings over to the police are being held as juvenile delinquents.
WORCESTER, Mass., May 29 --The scheduled showing of Ira Marion's new play, "Stairway to Nowhere," on Sunday, June 17, has been banned on the ground that it is not suitable for Sunday showing.
ROME, May 29--The Italian Communist party appeared today to have suffered a severe setback in the nation-wide elections Sunday and yesterday.

Ranco, Inc., producer of temperature controls for refrigerators, air conditioners and the automotive industry, has registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission a proposed public offering of 216,950 shares of its common stock through a syndicate headed by Smith, Barney Co.
BUFFALO, May 29--Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Jay James Risman of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Kassel Risman, to Leo Forst Oppenheimer,
NEWARK, May 29--A volunteer fire lieutenant from Dumont, N.J., who is free in $10,000 bail on an arson charge was credited today with the rescue of a mother and her baby in a tenement fire here.

DEVON, Pa., May 29--Peggy Augustus of Cobham, Va., added a blue ribbon to her winnings today at the Devon Horse Show when her 9-year-old chestnut gelding, Waiting Home, scored in the lightweight model hunter class.
Dr. Jack Geller of Post Chester led the way into the quarterfinal round of the annual interAmerican invitation tennis tournament at the Hispano Tennis Club, Flushing, Queens, yesterday.

MILWAUKEE, May 29 (UP)-- The Milwaukee Braves today signed an outfielder-pitcher. Bill Moss, and a pitcher. Dave Centi to minor league contracts. Moss will report to Austin tomorrow and Centi, from Elmsford, N. Y., received a Wellsville contract.

TORONTO, May 29 (AP)--The University of Toronto's Connaught Laboratories announced today it would be able to deliver only a third of the 6,000,000 doses of Salk poliomyelitis vaccine ordered for shipment by June 30.

NEW DELHI, India, May 29 (Reuters)--Sir Edmund Hillary of New Zealand and Tenzing, a Sherpa guide, the first men to reach the top of Mount Everest, paid tribute today to the Swiss climbers who scaled it twice.
The Regent Hotel Corporation Charles Drukier, president, has purchased the seventeen-story Regent Hotel at 2720 Broadway, northeast corner of West 104th Street, from the Regent Hotel.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 --The "dangers and weaknesses inherent" in a merger of the Screen Actors Guild and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists "are greater than any benefits to be derived," according to the movie union.

CHAPEL HILL, N. C., May 29 (AP)--Jerry Vayda of Bayonne, N. J., today received the University of North Carolina's highest athletic award, the Joseph H. Patterson Medal. Vayda, a basketball player who will be graduated this year, received the award for general excellence in athletics.

A grant of funds made to the twenty-one-year-old Federation of the Handicapped, 211 West Fourteenth Street, New York 11, will enable that agency to give special training to a group of selected homebound men and women--persons so badly disabled that they cannot work regularly outside their homes.

Miss Sarah Louise Andrews and John Peters Holmes were married here yesterday afternoon in the chapel of St. James Protestant Episcopal Church by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving. A reception was held at the Colony Club.
Two new films open at first run theatres today.
Miss Ruth Weisler, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Weisler of Lawrence, L. I., was married here last night to Harvey L. Lebo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Lebo of Brooklyn.
Pale suede shoes are pretty and popular, but they're often hard to clean. A new cleaner called Rubgum is made especially for fine-nan suede finishes.

LONDON, May 29--Industrial shares joined with Government stocks in moving to lower levels in the stock markets here today. The fresh losses on Wall Street yesterday unsettled sentiment, though prices closed steadier in the absence of much selling.
PITTSBURGH, May 29--The Dodgers finally got around today to checking both Dale Long and the Pirates. What is more, they did a thorough job of it on both counts.
NEWARK, May 29--Thomas L. Black will be readmitted to the laboratories of the Atlas Refining Company plant here on Friday, Arthur F. Schroeder Jr., Atlas' president, announced today.

Events tonight: Program of new music, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 9; Naumburg Symphony Orchestra, The Mall. Central Park, 8:30; "The Abduction From the Seraglio." Minor Latham Drama Workshop, Columbia University, 8.

HONOLULU, May 29 (UP)-- Jimmy Ukauka said today he would be unable to represent Hawaii in the United States open golf championship tournament. Instead, the territory will be represented by Ted Makalena. Ukauka shot a 146 yesterday to pace a field of eleven. Makalena scored 149 for second.
JIM TURNER, the Yankees pitching coach, walked into the dressing room at 11 A. M. yesterday and he gasped. Whitey Ford, the mound hero of the night before, was in full uniform and ready for action.
CHICAGO, May 29 (UP)--Gus Bell hit three homers and two singles and batted in seven runs today to lead the Cincinnati Redlegs to a 10-4 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

William J. Poyle was sentenced yesterday by Federal Judge Edward Weinfeld to six months in prison for failing to file income tax returns for 1952 and 1953. Poyle, 48 years old, lives at 433 West Twenty-fourth Street.
The General Telephone Company of Indiana, yesterday sold at par $3,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, 4 per cent series, due 1986.
TROON, Scotland, May 29 (UP) --Joe Conrad, the 26-year-old defending champion from San Antonio, Tex., survived a day of disaster for favored Americans in the British amateur golf championship today.
NICE, France, May 29-- (Reuters)--Sir Winston Churchill arrived here by air today from London to join Lady Churchill for a two-week vacation in the south of France.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 29 (UP)--Rolyat equaled the track record of 1:08 4/5 for six furlongs at Hollywood Park today in capturing the $10,000 Brentwood Purse by a length and a half.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The Administration was reported tonight to have authorized Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Air Force Chief of Staff, to accept the Soviet invitation to an air show in Moscow. There were signs that the White House has "downgraded" the project, however.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- The National Park Service announced today plans to spend $3,812,000 in the next ten years at ten parks commemorating phases and heroes of the Revolutionary War.
SURBITON, England, May 29 (UP)--Althea Gibson of New York, the winner of seven straight European tournaments, captured her second-round match today in the Surrey grass courts tennis championships.

Thomas G. Daniel, 25-year-old clothing salesman, was convicted of first-degree manslaughter yesterday by a jury of ten men and two women. It took the jury an hour and thirty-five minutes to reach its verdict.

MADRID, May 29--The Spanish Government made known today that it had protested against the Moroccan Government's decision to grant the French Ambassador in Rabat the rank of Dean of the diplomatic corps.

ITHACA, N.Y., May 29 (UP)-- E.S. Foster, secretary of the New York Farm Bureau, said today that the new Government farm bill "can't produce much good" for upstate farmers. He labeled it a combination of "much politics and little economics."
The National Securities Series of mutual Funds reported yesterday record final fiscal quarter sales of $24,368,872.

CHIMBOTE, Peru, May 25-- More than 100,000 tons of coal, briquettes and anthracite, will be shipped to Argentina in 1956 from this northern Peruvian port. The initial shipment will be made June 4.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 29 (UP)--President Eisenhower played eighteen holes of golf today. He said he would have gone another nine if he had not feared it would attract too much attention.

Alan Bunce of the "Ethel and Albert" television comedy series will be starred in next week's presentation of "The Seven Year Itch' at the Melody Circle, Allentown, Pa. Appearing with him will be Jet MacDonald and Ritz Morley.

CHICAGO, May 29--Raymond J. Hurley, former chairman of the board of the Thor Corporation, died yesterday at his home in suburban Evanston. He was 61 years old. A member of the family said his death resulted from cancer.

TOKYO, May 29--Japan's House of Representatives approved today the $800,000,000 Philippines reparations and loan agreement by a vote of 227 to 134. The measure now goes to the upper house of the Diet (Parliament).
BOSTON, May 29--Four men and a woman were arrested here today on indictments alleging violation of the Smith Act.

The International Harvester Company, the nation's largest producer of farm implements and farm tractors, bettered sales and profits for the six months ended April 30 over the corresponding period a year earlier.
New York Telephone Company reported yesterday continuing gains in gross revenues and net income for April and the first four months of 1956.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 29 --Roy V. Perry, who has collected $150,000,000 from Harvard students during his sixteen years as university bursar, will retire June 30.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 29 (AP)--Syria today banned the export of wheat to France or Algeria, the National Economy Ministry announced.

CHICAGO, May 29--Grain futures showed a stronger tone today, with wheat leading a modest recovery. Commission buying was in evidence, with some support for wheat from commercial interests. There did not appear to be much hedging.

Copper futures tumbled the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit in early trading yesterday on the Commodity Exchange of New York. All traded months fell to new lows for the move during the session.

Stocks rushed upward yesterday in a sharp reaction to three weeks of decline. Their gain, as measured by The New York Times combined average of fifty stocks, equaled that of Feb. 17, the day after Edgar Eisenhower predicted that his brother would be a candidate.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, May 29 (Reuters)--Delegates representing students in twenty-two Asian and African countries meet in Bandung tomorrow for the first African-Asian students' conference.

CANNES, France, May 29 --Fourteen European governments issued a joint declaration today of their intention to block the plan of United States airlines for a bargain-rate third-class trans-Atlantic airline service.

JOHORE BAHRU, Malaya, May 29--Malayan rubber planters yesterday asked the Federation Government for immediate action to avert a national economic crisis. The steady decline in rubber prices, decreased world demand and increased competition from synthetics were given as reasons.

Frankie Marlowe, George Prentice and Buddy Clayton will head the new vaudeville program opening at the Palace Theatre on Friday. Other acts will be The Marvellos, Mac and Lorraine, the Three Swifts, Eddie Innes and Dolly Dawson and The Yokoi Troupe.

John M. Budinger and J. Richardson Dilworth have been elected directors of the Rockwell Spring and Axle Campany, Coraopolis, Pa., a leading supplier of axles, bumpers and brakes for the automotive industry.
Directors of the Penn-Texas Corporation yesterday voted the regular quarterly dividend of 40 cents on the $1.60 cumulative preferred stock and a 2 per cent stock dividend on the commort stock.
BUENOS AIRES, May 29-- W. P. Orr, treasurer, of Ducilo S. A., was re-elected president today of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States in the Argentine Republic.
MOSCOW, May 29 (AP)--The Soviet Government today accused the West German Embassy in Moscow of issuing illegal German passports to Soviet citizens to enable them to leave Russia.
TORONTO, May 29 (AP)-- Three members of the United Church of Canada will arrive in Moscow Aug. 6 for a ten-day visit as guests of the Russian Orthodox Church, it was announced today.
PITTSBURGH, May 29--The biggest man in Pittsburgh right now is a fellow named Dale Long. And it isn't merely because he happens to stand 6 feet 4 inches and weighs around 215.

Joseph H. Moss Jr. has been named president of C. M. Industries, Inc., national merchandising and selling organization in the plastics and electronics fields. Mr. Moss had been an account executive for the Kenyon Eckhardt advertising agency.
PERRY, N.Y., May 29 (AP)-- Former Lieut. Gov. Joe R. Hanley retured home today after two months in a hospital.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 29 --A bus boycott started by Negro university students spread through the Tallahassee Negro community today.

ELIZABETH, N. J., May 29 --Sale of the First National Bank of Springfield to the National State Bank here has been approved by the Controller of the Currency in Washington, it has been announced here.
By mutual agreement, Governor Harriman's television and radio "Monthly Report to the People" is being dropped by the National Broadcasting Company for the summer.
PARIS, May 28--The French economy, bubbling with energy like a good Burgundian stew, is beginning to send forth a few odors that the expert cooks around the stove find slightly unsavory.

CHAPEL HILL, N.C., May 29 (UP)--Eleven Negro students have applied for admission to the University of North Carolina graduate school and nine of them may be admitted within a week, the university news bureau said today. It called the applications "just routine enrollment."
The Boeing Airplane Company of Seattle has completed negotiations with seventeen banks for an open line of credit of $75,000,000 running through June, 1957, Evan M. Nelson, treasurer.

There will be no blood donations to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program today. As a Memorial Day contribution, officers and crew members of the aircraft carrier Lake Champlain at the New York Naval Shipyard, Brooklyn, gave 326 pints of blood yesterday.

GENEVA, N. Y., May 29 (UP) --Milton Roberts, the University of Delaware lacrosse coach, today announced his South team for the fifteenth annual NorthSouth All-Star game at Hobart College here on June 9.

The 1956 Life and Senior Master Pairs championship, most highly coveted pair title at stake during the six-day 1956 Greater New York Contract Bridge Championships now in session at the Park Sheraton Hotel, went early this moring to Cecil Head of Stamford, Conn., and David Mason, New York.

A write-in campaign to wrest the Liberal party nomination for Surrogate from Supreme Court Justice S. Samuel DiFalco, a Democrat, was announced yesterday by Morton Baum, one of two Republican designees for Surrogate.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 29 --One of golf's leading seniors, Thomas C. Robbins, added another victory to his long list of trophies today. He captured the spring one-day tournament of the Westchester County Golf Association. The Winged Foot star scored a 38, 36--74 over the 6,082-yard Siwanoy Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) --John Lautner, former Communist, testified today that the Communist party wanted to overthrow state governments as well as the Federal Government.

More than 68 per cent of the outstanding stock of Fulton Bag and Cotton Mills, Atlanta, has been placed in escrow, meeting a condition put by a North Carolina group on its offer to buy Fulton stock, a stockholders' committee announced in Atlanta yesterday.

MONTREAL, May 29 (Canadian Press)--The Aberdeen Red Devils routed the Montreal All-Stars, 8--0, tonight in the opening game of the Scottish Football League team's North American tour. The Scots held a 2-0 lead at half-time.
The grounds of the Victoria Home for Aged British Men and Women in Ossining, N. Y., will be the setting Saturday afternoon for a garden party.
PITTSBURGH, May 29--The country's three biggest steel companies agreed today to a farreaching experiment in joint bargaining with the United Steelworkers of America.
Graduation week, at West Point this year will have a nautical flavor.
From Iceland to Okinawa the insular and peripheral bases of Allied power are now subject to assault.

The National Biscuit Company has elected John A. Hart as vice president for traffic, it was announced yesterday by George H. Coppers, president.

Wiretap evidence was introduced at a Waterfront Commission hearing yesterday. A city detective told of overhearing Michael J. Clemente, former East River dock leader, give instructions to "pick up an envelope."

BOSTON. May 29--Mr. and Mrs. Charles Z. Case have made known the engagement of Mrs. Case's daughter, Miss Mary Abigail Shiverick to Everett Morss Jr. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Morss of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

CAMDEN, N. J., May 29 (AP) --The River Divide Farm's Decathlon resumed his winning ways at Garden State Park today. At the same time the 3-5 favorite brought a halt to the victory skein of Mrs. Colin MacLeod's Obair.

VALLEJO, Calif., May 29-- Mr. Stevenson expressed deep gratitude tonight to the people of Florida for their endorsement. In a statement tonight he said: "And I am especially thankful to all those who helped me so loyally. Their efforts meant all the difference."

WASHINGTON, May 29--Financial and other records of Col. Louis H. Shirley, U. S. A., were seized tonight by the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
THE Museum of Modern Art's major summer exhibition of contemporary painting and sculpture, opening today, is entitled "Twelve Americans."

CROYDON, England, May 29 --The Bowater Paper Corporation, Ltd., announced today it would build a sulphate pulp mill in South Carolina.

WASHINGTON, May 29--The State Department has heard from the United States Embassy at Haiti that "some arrests" have taken place there in connection with political strife in the last two weeks.
EASTON, Pa., May 29--Harvey F. Mack, chairman of the board of the Mack Printing Company, one of the nation's leading publishers of scientific periodicals and books, died here today. His age was 77.

HAVANA, May 29 (AP)--Plans for construction of a multi-million dollar bottle manufacturing plant at San Jose De las Lajas, twenty miles southeast of here, were announced today by the Owens-Illinois Glass Company.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (AP)-- The Interstate Commerce Commission established today stricter requirements for braking systems on interstate trucks in an effort to prevent highway "runaways."

KANSAS CITY, May 29 (UP) --Heavy rain halted the game in the twelfth inning today for 1 hour 15 minutes and then the Chicago White Sox went on to beat the Kansas City Athletics, 7--4, on three runs in the same inning.
LONDON, May 29 (Reuters) --Cecil Smith, American music critic of The London Daily Express, died last night at the age of 49. He had been in poor health for some time.

New Yorkers will observe the eighty-eighth anniversary of Memorial Day today with parades and ceremonies honoring the dead of this nation's wars.

MARION, Mass., May 29-- C. Eric Olsen Jr. and Stanley Renahan of Essex, Conn., today won the nomination to represent the United States in the twelvesquare meter Sharpie Class in the Olympic Games.

TORONTO, May 29 (Canadian Press)--Brazilian Traction, Light and Power Company, Ltd., had a net profit in 1955 of $18,492,251, or $1.18 a common share, compared with $19,1849,015, or $1.27 a share in 1954.
WASHINGTON, May 29 (UP) --The Washington Redskins added ,a real Indian to their roster today with the signing of a Clemson halfback.

Myrna Ruiz, a young Cuban pianist, made her debut at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. A native of Santiago de Cuba, Miss Ruiz studied at the Havana Conservatory and, in this country, at Bennington College. For the last year she has studied in this city.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 29 (UP)--Cutty Sark won the onemile Fordham Trot by a length from Miss Titan in 2:07 tonight at Roosevelt Raceway.

BROOKFIELD CENTER, Conn., May 29--Mr. and Mrs. Lester Beall have made known the engagement and approaching marriage of their daughter, Miss Joanna May Beall, to Gaylord Treat Meech.

WASHINGTON, May 29-- Democratic investigators circu lated today a report calling on the Justice Department to cancel mining patents granted to the Al Sarena Mining Company in the Rogue River National Forest of Oregon.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., May 29 (UP)--Joan Collins, English film actress, received a divorce today from Maxwell Reed, an actor, on charges of cruelty and desertion. She was not required to pay him alimony as he originally asked.
PARIS, May 29--France tacked up new "no trespassing" signs on Algeria today.

QUANTICO, Va., May 29 (UP) --Wes Santee, the American mile record-holder sped to victory in the 800-meter run today at the ninth annual All-Marine track and field championships. His time was 1:49.5.

Frankie Ryff, Bronx lightweight, and Larry Boardman of Marlboro, Conn., will complete training today for their listed ten-round fight Friday night at Madison Sauare Garden.
