The high command of the united labor movement got a new headache in the anti-racket field yesterday.

The New York Shipping Association has requested Governors Harriman and Meyner for a conference on the Waterfront Commission's budget for the next fiscal year, now before them for approval or reduction by June 9.

WASHINGTON, June 1--A method of converting atomic energy directly into alternating current has been invented by a member of the Harvard University faculty. A patent covering the generator used was issued this week to Dr. Reinhold Rudenberg of Belmont, Mass.

A new star rose in the boxing world last night. Larry Boardman, a 20-yearold lightweight from Marlboro, Conn., made his first appearance in Madison Square Garden a memorable one by knocking out Frankie Ryff, a New York contender for the championship, in 46 seconds of the ninth round.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, June 1 --The World Veterans Federation concluded its sixth annual assembly here today with the possibility of an application for membership by the Soviet Union threatening a disruptive session in 1957.

MOSCOW, June 1--Yugoslav-Soviet cooperation in an effort to create a popular front of Socialists and Communists was disclosed today on the eve of Marshal Tito's arrival in Moscow. The Yugoslav President crossed the Soviet border this morning on a special train from Belgrade via Bucharest. He is expected in the Soviet capital tomorrow afternoon.

DENVER, June 1 (AP)--Faltering shortly after take-off, an Air Force twin-engine B-25 bomber crashed today among scattered houses. It set one afire. Four were killed and three of four others aboard the plane were hurt.
WASHINGTON, June 1--Republican hopes of winning at least one of the Kentucky Senate seats this year took a sharp drop today. With it came diminished party chances of capturing control of the Senate.
The decision on whether to suspend the Metropolitan Opera's 1956-57 season has been postponed until next Wednesday.
Those "Standards" are everywhere. This week the oil industry is agog about a move by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) to expand its marketing to the Midwest--straight into...
The sharp increase in United States imports of Japanese cotton cloths and apparel was highlighted yesterday by a report issued by the Northern Textile Association of Boston.
PITTSBURGH, June 1 (UP)-- Fay Crocker, the United States Women's open golf champion, shot a par 70 today for a onestroke lead in the invitation tournament at the Churchill Valley Country Club.
CHICAGO, June 1--The Dodgers sailed into the wake of the Wrigley Field home run storm today, battled stiff headwinds for more than four hours, then bowed to the Cubs, 4 to 2, in fifteen innings.

ORANGEBURG, N.Y., June 1--The liquidation of Camp Shanks, the nation's largest embarkation-debarkation point in World War II, was virtually completed today. Seven houses still owned by the Government on the post were sold.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)-- Washington sent Bob Lemon to his first defeat since opening day tonight as the Senators beat Cleveland, 5--3. Bob Wiesler pitched the route to achieve his first victory as Lemon's string of six triumphs was snapped.
CAIRO, June 1--Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser pledged today he would end military rule over Egypt and seek to turn the country into a "cooperative society."

ST. LOUIS, June 1 (AP)--A former Federal probation officer testified today that T. Lamar Caudle, when head of the Justice Department's Tax Division, told him that Irving Sachs, convicted tax evader, should not have been indicted.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., June 1 --The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People was ordered by a state court today to stop operating in Alabama.

While contract talks recessed last night in Washington between the Western Union Company and two unions of employes, a confused picture of stoppages, threatened strikes and walkouts emerged in some eastern cities.
Sales of New York's nine major department stores averaged 9.5 per cent higher last month than in May, 1955. The gain was the best since October.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 --Irving Briskin, studio manager of Columbia Pictures and head of the company's thriving television operation, Screen Gems, has been released from his contract to enable him to form an independent TV film unit.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1-- Admiral Arthur W. Radford urged 681 graduating midshipmen at the United States Naval Academy today to set their course toward "progress"...

Recognition, long overdue, has been attained by one of the best friends and patrons of lawn tennis. The Professional Lawn Tennis Association chose Alastair Bradley Martin of Glen Head, L.I., in making its annual award to the one who has done most for the game and for promoting good sportsmanship.
SCARBOROUGH N.Y., June 1--The Scarborough Presbyterian Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Judith Broome to Lieut. Edgar Raymond Stoddart Jr., U.S.M.C.
Special to The New York Times. WASHINGTON, June 1-- President Eisenhower established today a Cabinet-level committee to deal with the problems of small business.
WASHINGTON, June 1--Consumer installment debt rose $296,000,000 in April, the biggest increase this year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, June 1-- With such accessories as kilted bagpipers and a sound truck blaring "Robin Hood," Senator Estes Kefauver hammered away today at the idea that Adlai Stevenson was equivocal about civil rights.
A six-month jail sentence for contempt of court was canceled yesterday for William Ludwig Ullmann, former Treasury, Department official.

LONDON, June 1--There can be no confidence or friendship between Britain and Greece so long as the latter incites terrorism against the British forces in Cyprus, Sir Anthony Eden declared tonight in a speech at Norwich.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 1 (UP) --New York University downed Penn State, 15--7, and St. John's of Brooklyn defeated Delaware, 3--1, in the semi-finals of the National Collegiate District 2 baseball competition.
BERLIN, May 24--This city's East and West sectors impress a visitor as rival showcases, with the display in the West sector much the richer.

THERE is a steady trickle of inquiries here about skeet-shooting facilities for the public. Apparently it is something of a problem for many shotgun shooters who live in the city and are not affiliated with gun clubs.

MOSCOW, June 1--Metropolitan Nokolai left by plane today as leader of an eight-man church delegation to visit the United States for eleven days. Metropolitan Nikolai is head of the Moscow Diocese of the Russian Orthodox Church and also is Primate of the Ukraine.
The Metropolitan Missions Training Institute will meet for its twenty-eighth season on Monday and on June 11.
COMPTON, Calif., June 1(AP) --Ron Delany of Villanova defeated Gunnar Nielsen of Denmark tonight as both were timed in less than four minutes for the mile in the Compton track and field meet.

DALLAS, June 1 (UP)--Billy Casper Jr. of Chula Vista, Calif., fashioned a 6-under-par 33, 31-- 64 today to tie Cary Middlecoff and Gene Littler for the opening-round lead in the $70,000 Texas international golf tournament.
The New Haven Railroad asked for permission yesterday to make July 1 the effective date for its proposed 25 per cent rise in commutation fares in New York State.

Mrs. Gallatin Cobb of 1109 Madison Avenue and Ferney, Lloyd Harbor, Huntington, L.I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Jean Gal latin Cobb, to Frank L. Crocker, a son of Mrs. Edwin A. Fish of Locust Valley, L. I., and The Mallows, Southampton, L. I., and the late Frank Longfellow Crocker.
Small apartment buildings formed the bulk of realty passing to new control in Bronx deals reported yesterday.
LONDON, June 1--Prices fell sharply again on the stock markets today following the warning by the Chancellor of the Exchequer of the consequences of a further round of wage rises.
HONOLULU, June 1--The man believed to be the nation's senior airline pilot has closed out a pioneering career that stretches from the dangerous days of World War I to the coming of the jet airliner.
GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., June 1--Michigan Democratic leaders proposed today a "bold, aggressive" program for the Democratic party.

There are hundreds of synthetic dyes, medicines, drugs, photographic developers, plastics and useful compounds that nature, forgot to make. We take them for granted. Yet a hundred years ago our only dyestuffs were extracts of plants and animal tissues.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 1 --The American motion picture was characterized "as being amongst the greatest of all revolutionary forces" by President Sukarno of Indonesia in a talk here last night.
Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed generally higher yesterday. Volume was light in most markets, with dealers evening holdings for the week-end.
DETROIT, June 1 (AP)--Industry-wide schedule slashing will reduce this week's motor vehicle output to the lowest level since October, 1954.
WASHINGTON, June 1--Vice President Richard M. Nixon put his finger today on the main Republican election-year worry-- that not enough Eisenhower supporters would bother to vote.

BATON ROUGE, La., June 1 --Leaders in the sulphur industry assert that a proposed $3-aton severance (production) tax on sulphur would stunt one of Louisiana's key industries and scare off others planning to come to the state.

LOS ANGELES, June 1--Mrs. Brenetta Herrman Crawford, well known painter of miniatures, landscapes and portraits, died Wednesday at her home in Pasadena. Her age was 79. She was the wife of E. Stetson Crawford.

The Appellate Division in Brooklyn yesterday named Supreme Court Referee Frank F. Adel to preside at hearings on unspecified charges against charges against three Suffolk County justices of the peace.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The departure of Vyacheslav M. Molotov from the Soviet Foreign Ministry suprised no one in authority here.

Miss Barbara Nancy Sassoon, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Sassoon of London and Tryon, N.C., was married here yesterday afternoon to Frank Morse Smith Lyons. He is a son of Mrs. Kenneth Lyons of 1088 Park Avenue and the late Mr. Lyons.
PARIS, June 1 (AP)--The International Chamber of Commerce today advocated a series of measures aimed at speeding up the economic development of Asia and promoting world trade in general.

MARACAIBO, Venezuela, June 1 (AP)--Lake Maracaibo was formally opened to ocean-going tankers today when the Kermia of the Netherlands left for Europe with a cargo of 115,000 barrels of oil pumped from the Shell company's wells.
A READER writes to ask whether she can partially cook potatoes in advance, refrigerate them, then finish the cooking just before dinner.

WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP) --The General Accounting Office said today the United States had spent more than $1,250,000 for a road for a dam project in Iran--but a final decision to build the dam had yet to be made.

DALLAS, Tex., June 1 (AP)-- Herbert Hoover Jr., Undersecretary of State, today told a meeting of oil men the United States probably would need to import "appreciable quantities" of oil in the years to come.

Matthew Woll, a vice president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., vice president of the International Photoengravers Union and a labor leader for more than fifty years, died yesterday in New York Hospital, where he had been a patient since April 2. His age was 76.

TOKYO, June 1 (AP)--A Socialist non-confidence motion against Premier Ichiro Hatoyama's Cabinet was beaten down today. The action came as a climax of three day's of chaos and fighting in the Diet (Parliament).
The Mayor's Committee on Slum Clearance should be reorganized or disbanded if housing financial policies favored by Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa are to be adopted, Mayor Wagner was told yesterday.
Ralph E. Casey, president of the American Merchant Marine Institute, yesterday forecast greater employment opportunities for maritime school graduates.
PHILADELPHIA, June 1 (UP) --Paul Anderson of Toccoa, Ga., bettered three world records tonight in retaining the heavyweight title at the National Amateur Athletic Union weightlifting championships.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, June 1--Last night's per formance by the Royal Danish Ballet marked the end of its seventh annual festival season at the Royal Opera House, It was also the farewell appearance of the greatly loved character dancer, Gerda Karstens. King Frederik IX was present, and everything went to make it a memorable occasion.
WASHINGTON, June 1 (AP)-- Senate investigators, in a widening inquiry into the law practice of Murray M. Chotiner, were reported today to be asking his clients what he did to earn his fees.

A full graduate school, with a five-year program leading to the ordination of Reform rabbis, will be re-established, starting next fall, by the New York branch of the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., June 1 --The first flames of an antiNixon movement among New York's Young Republicans were stamped out tonight by the firm but ladylike foot of the State's National Committeewoman.
LOS ANGELES, June 1-- Adlai E. Stevenson sought the political support of pensioners in southern California's "utopia for the aging" today in his bid for the Presidential nomination.

With the assistance of a fifthinning grand-slam homer by Bob Kennedy, Frank Lary of the Tigers pitched his third straight complete-game victory over the Yankees at the rain-lashed Stadium last night.
Three ninety-minute Saturday morning spectaculars aimed at children will be presented by the American Broadcasting Company's television network.
PARIS, June 1--Paul Reynaud, a French elder statesman, called on Premier Guy Mollet today to define "peace aims" for France in her struggle to master the Moslem rebellion in Algeria.
The City Court and the Municipal Court in New York City are planning to follow the lead of the State Supreme Court in holding jury trials this summer to reduce congestion and delay.

The completion early next year of improvements being made on the Suez Canal will increase its ship capacity by more than 20 per cent, Jacques Georges-Picot, director general of the canal operating company, said yesterday.
The stir over the Federal Reserve discount rates is raising questions as to how deeply rooted in reality are certain attitudes about the cost and availability of capital.
A huge cooperative housing development is being considered for the Chelsea area as part of the Federal-city slum clearance program.

Mrs. Madalyn O'Shea Gray, of 119 East Seventeenth Street, head of the Theatre Department at Sarah Lawrence College, died yesterday of cancer at New York Hospital. Her age was 54. She was the widow of Jabez Gray, actor, and was well known as an actress under her maiden name.

MONTREAT, N.C., June 1--Women churchgoers got support from the Bible here today. A report presented to the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States (Southern) found no scriptural basis for limiting women's work to menial and unofficial tasks.
WEST ORANGE, N.J., June 1--Charlotte DeCozen of Montclair and Mrs. Marge Mason of Ridgewood finished the second round of the Elizabeth Goss round-robin golf tournament today in a tie for first place.

Although June and Christmas normally have little in common, they go together like love and marriage at the Papercraft Corporation in Pittsburgh.
Production of cars by General Motors Corporation in May dipped 17.1 per cent below the April rate and 34.2 per cent below that of May, 1955.
WASHINGTON, June 1--The Republican National Committee is considering a plan to cut its San Francisco convention from four days to three.
CHICAGO, June 1--A courtappointed receiver was ordered today to liquidate the Lyric Theatre of Chicago, Inc., sponsor of a grand opera company here.

Mary K. Frank has engaged Josef Marais and his wife Miranda to provide the South African folk songs for "Too Late the Phalarope." This is the Robert Yale Libott dramatization of Alan Paton's best-selling novel of the same name.

Those items in the apparel and accessory field made by hand have a universal appeal among women consumers. The problem is: How can a sufficient quantity be produced to meet the demand and, if possible, bring the cost within the reach of all who want to own them?

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 1--Arab representatives refused today to approve a modified British resolution for continued efforts by the United Nations Secretary General toward a settlement in Palestine.
KANSAS CITY, June 1 (AP)-- The right of a Baptist church to determine its own affairs by Congregational vote was reaffirmed today by the Southern Baptist Convention.
WASHINGTON, June 1--William B. Rodman, North Carolina's Attorney General, urged Congress today to reject the entire pending civil rights program.
MUSCATINE, Iowa, June 1 (AP)--When a 160-foot span of a toll bridge collapsed into the Mississippi River here early today, two truck drivers narrowly escaped injury or death.
BUENOS AIRES, June 1--A group of 8l2 more Ukrainians and Byelorussians responded today to the call of the Soviet Union's repatriation program.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla. June 1 --Attorneys for both sides met today on means of stopping a city-wide boycott of buses by Negro patrons. There was no indication that an agreement had been reached.
Vyacheslav M. Molotov's resignation as Soviet Foreign Minister seems to mark the end of an era of Soviet diplomacy.
A 28-year-old lawyer was indicted yesterday by the Kings County rackets grand jury on a charge of subornation of perjury.
Through an agreement with State Housing Commissioner Joseph P. McMurray, Schenectady will become the first city to use state aid in applying for Federal assistance under the urban renewal program.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange fell away yesterday to the lowest level since Feb. 13 as prices churned and closed irregularly up. Turnover was 1,446,182 shares, against 2,015,150 on Thursday.

Grover B., under a pace-setting ride by Paul Bailey, won the feature at Belmont Park yesterday. Running in the silks of Thomas P. Morgan, Grover B. was established the 3-1 second choice by the crowd of 18,608, and he won by a neck from Sidney Barton's Devastation.
MOSCOW, June 1--Vyacheslav M. Molotov, veteran Soviet revolutionary and diplomat, has resigned as Foreign Minister.
TROON Scotland, June 1 (UP) --John Beharrell, an 18-yearold Englishman, and Leslie Tayor, a 32-year-old Scottish salesman, reached the final of the British amateur golf championship today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., June 1-- Eighteen young women became the brides today of members of the Naval Academy's class of '56.
HOUSTON, Tex., June 1-- Jesse H. Jones, a financier and former high Government official, died tonight. He was 82 years of age.

LEON, Iowa, June 1--Ezra Taft Benson, the Secretary of Agriculture, promised today that farmers in the drought areas of southwest Iowa would get all the benefits from the new soil bank program that he could legally give them.

A circular plan has been evolved for the 33,000 square feet of showroom space being used by Coro, Inc., costume jewelry manufacturer, in its new quarters at 47 West Thirtyfourth Street. TRENTON, June 1--Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed a bill today authorizing the state to purchase Round Valley at a cost of $3,000,000. The discussions, dealing primarily with the course of Western alliances, will point up the relationship of Canada and the United States.

Isaac Stern, concert violinist, urged a greater exchange of American and Russian artists yesterday. He made the recommendation after returning from a tour on which he gave twentyone concerts in twenty-seven days in the Soviet Union.

The stock market staged a strong comeback last week, closing with a gain for the first time in four weeks. After it had sagged on Monday to the lowest level since January, a spirited rally on Tuesday gained twice as much ground as was lost the day before.

FOR three-quarters of an hour last night "The Pri mary Colors" was an effective drama on National Broadcasting Company television, thanks to mobile dialogue and excellent acting.
Congress was asked yesterday to legislate, against communities that offered cheap labor and cheap production costs to lure industrial plants from unionized localities.

BOLOGNA, Italy, June 3 (AP) Italy gained a 2-1 lead over Denmark in their third-round European Davis Cup play today has Nicola Pietrangeli and Orlando Sirola defeated Kurt Nielsen and Torben Ulrich, 6--4, 6--2, 3--6, 6--3, in the doubles.
Moral and spiritual values should be taught in the public schools to protect the rights of the "overwhelming majority," an education official declared here yesterday.
TRIPOLI, Libya, May 22-- Libya is having a boom in oil men. The black gold fever has hit the ancient land of desert, oasis and Mediterranean coast.

PARIS, June 3--In seeking to erase the myth of Stalin, Khrushchev has set himself a herculean task. For probably never in history has there been such an instance of a man who succeeded in inventing himself.

Zionist leaders urged yesterday the strengthening of their organization to "insure the cultural and spiritual survival of the Jewish community" in this country. They also asked greater effort to safeguard Israel's security.
The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen has stepped up its campaign against the independent International Longshoremen's Association.
Third Avenue is scheduled to be rezoned from East Fifteenth Street to East Ninety-sixth Street.
ROME, June 3--The Christian Democrats turned down today insistent offers of collaboration by the Left-Wing Socialists. However the rejection was qualified.

Pete Rothermel, head football coach at St. George's School in Newport, R.I., found himself using words of high praise the other day. Strangely enough, his words were not directed at members of his gridiron team. He was talking tennis.

This summer, for the first time in several years, the Guggenheim Memorial Concerts will present vocal soloists with the regular programs of the Goldman Band under the direction of Richard Franko Goldman.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 3--George Osmar Reynolds Jr. of 60 Sutton Manor here, a retired insurance executive, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage at his summer home in Oxford, Conn. His age was 71.
BOSTON, June 3--Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower expressed skepticism today concerning Russia's conciliatory gestures and repudiation of Stalin.
James Lawrence Head of 250 Arleigh Road, Douglas Manor, Queens, a retired mining engineer with the Anaconda Copper Mining Company, 25 Broadway, died yesterday after a long illness. His age was 61.
HORSE players almost never know or understand much about jockeys' silks, possibly because they are insensitive to any color but long green. Yet racing silks have a long history.

GRINNELL, Iowa, June 3 (AP) --Donald A. Quarles, Secretary of the Air Force, discussing rivalry among the armed forces, said today, "It does not promote our national welfare to argue these technical matters in public, since security prevents a full disclosure of the facts."

"Eisenhower: The Inside Story," by Robert J. Donova an unofficial report, will be published by Harper on July 2. Dealing with inner-circle debates, impromptu conferences, closeddoor meetings, the book is based on unpublished informa tion and numerous interviews ...

Title has been taken by Jack Brause, realty investor, to the eight-story loft building on a lot 25 by 95 feet at 682 Avenue of the Americas, near Twenty-second Street, which he plans to renovate. Assessed at $77,000, the property was bought for cash over mortgages amounting to $70,000 and title was taken in the name of Rita Properties, Inc. It was acquired in a deal negotiaited by the Murrimac Realty Company broker.

WASHINGTON, June 3--The Republican party, confident of the re-election of President Eisenhower, is going after the votes of Negroes in the large urban areas of the North in an effort to regain control of the Congress.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 3 --Since the Dow-Jones United States industrial stock dropped to 464 last Monday, attention has been focused apprehensively on New York. Recovery of the index to 480 by the week-end did not relieve the uneasiness.

In the Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue here yesterday afternoon, Dr. Ruth Priscilla Zager and Dr. Murray Gerstenhaber were married by the Rev. Dr. Louis C. Gerstein.

Flank Lloyd Wright mounted a pulpit here yesterday and proceeded to assail, among other things, "America's cultural poverty," the New York skyline, highbrows, "the tyranny of the common man," American colleges and communism.
A civil defense volunteer worker and his chief traded criticisms yesterday on a television stage and, later outside the studio.

It was a proud day for the supporters of Dublin yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Restricting their rugged foes to 1 point in the second half, the slick-passing County Dublin fifteen crushed County Kerry, the All-Ireland champion, 21 to 7, in a Gaelic football match.
CLEVELAND, June 3--Miss Virginia deConingh was married this afternoon to Murray Walter Frank in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Edward Hurlbut deConingh of Shaker Heights.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 3--A show of patience, a saving wind and well-charted courses saved the Beach Point Yacht Club regatta today from becoming either a joke or a canceled event.

The tent caterpillars are out in force in the neighboring countryside. By now, however, it is too late to do very much about them, for generally they have already had the meal of their generation.
LONDON, June 3--The stock markets here last week, while still brooding over the continued uncertainty in Wall Street, became increasingly depressed by the aspects of the British economic situation.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., June 3-- Admiral Arleigh A. Burke, Chief of Naval Operations, said here today that because of the "strength of our moral principles" this nation "will never wage a war of aggression."

IT'S been such a beautiful bubble that it would seem fitting to take an admiring glance at its irridescent sheen before it bursts. And if it doesn't burst, so much the better. At the moment, though, the Pittsburgh Pirates appear to have neither transparency nor flimsiness. They seem to be solid sensations.
JERSEY CITY, June 3--Nine high school teachers received honorary degrees by St. Peter's College here today in recognition of their decades of service to youth.
Interrcaial harmony was accented in deed and word in several Protestant church services here yesterday.

CORNING, N.Y., June 3--A bitter controversy over whether this Steuben County municipality of 18,000 will become the first city in New York State to assess properties on a full valuation may be decided tomorrow night.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4--A report to the United Nations today raised questions on the fate of Eastern European refugees seeking asylum in Yugoslavia.
CINCINNATI, June 4 (UP)-- Art Fowler racked up his fourth victory of the season tonight as the Cincinnati Redlegs downed the Philadelphia Phillies, 8-2.
OTTAWA, June 4--A human drama arising from a political crisis was played out today in the Canadian House of Commons.

The city is likely to require soon that fuel oil burned here contain not more than 1 per cent sulphur.

Two young American artists will make their first appearances at the Lewisohn Stadium Concerts on July 11 playing a concerto each. They are the 14-yearold violinist Marilyn Dubow, who will play the Wieniawski D minor Concerto, and Joel Rosen, who will be the soloist in Brahms' B flat major Piano Concerto.

The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development is faced with one of its busiest lending periods. The world-wide lending agency expects to extend $450,000,000 in loans between now and September.
Two city firemen with long records of service were suspended at midnight last night after being accused of having taken gratuities in connection with an exhibition at the Statler Hotel.

The great majority of Americans today are immigrants from Europe or the descendants of such immigrants. From the time of the Mayflower to the present day such immigration has been a pioneering venture for those engaged in it, a shift often accompanied by difficulties that had to be overcome.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)-- The Supreme Court today refused to intervene in a suit filed in the United States District Court in New York by Breswick Co. and Myron Neisloss against the Alleghany Corporation.
LONDON, June 4 (Reuters)-- The sterling area's gold and dollar reserves, a key factor in Britain's battle to keep her economy stable, rose only $41,000,000 in May, official figures showed today.

QUITO, Ecuador, June 4--The Conservative party candidate, Camilo Ponce Enriquez, appeared victorious tonight in the Ecuadorian Presidential elections on the basis of unofficial returns announced by the Government Press Office.
The Radio Corporation of America announced a new color television receiver yesterday that will retail for $200 less than the manufacturer's present lowestpriced color set.
Public utility companies raised $23,000,000 in the public market yesterday by the sale of bond issues at public sealed bidding.

The Temporary State Housing Rent Commission reported yesterday that it had recovered $211,435 in 1955 for tenants victimized by rent overcharges, bonus payments, tie-in sales and other improper rental practices. Tenants in this city received $178,712.
WASHINGTON, June 4--President Eisenhower shared in the dedication today of the new headquarters of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations.

Plans were formulated at a recent meeting for a theatre benefit to aid the Presbyterian Home for Aged Women. The play chosen is the Oct. 25 performance of the Gilbert Miller production of "The Reluctant Debutante," which will be preceded by a Dutch treat dinner in the Rendez-Vous of the Plaza.
The bitter, 108-day-old strike of production workers of the Republic Aviation Corporation appeared close to settlement today.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 --The Writers Guild of America and the television networks have agreed on a new contract for writers, averting a strike deadline which had been set for today.

DHEKELIA, Cyprus, June 4-- A British soldier and a Turkish Cypriote policeman were slain and an 18-year-old son of a British warrant officer was shot in the back in terrorism in Cyprus last night and today.
Columbia College will build a student center with the help of a new $1,000,000 gift. It will be named Ferris Booth Hall--The Columbia College Citizenship Center.

A 200-foot section of scaffolding collapsed into West Fifty-sixth Street yesterday. Two men, one an iron worker on the job, and the other a passer-by, were slightly injured. The scaffolding had been erected at the second floor level for a job of renovating.

PHILADELPHIA, June 4 (AP) --Yale University, with eleven men in ten of the fourteen events, dominated the twelfth annual all--America college swimming team named today by the coaches selection committee.
WASHINGTON, June 4--David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers, attacked the Government of India today for trying to cenosr the union's motion picture, "With These Hands."

MONTREAT, N. C., June 4-- The General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the U. S. (Southern) approved unanimously today a series of recommendations clarifying the church's stand on marriage after divorce.
CAIRO, June 4 (AP)--Ibrahim Izzat wrote today that 98 per cent of the Arabs inside Israel "live in subhuman conditions."
JERSEY CITY, June 4--Behind the two-hit pitching of Bob Goldsholl, New York University's nine--defeated St. John's, 6-2, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's District 2 final today.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Harold E. Stassen strongly urged tonight that the aggression of war must be declared "off limits" by every nation in the world.

THE first heavyweight champion listed in Nat Fleischer's Ring Record Book is that boisterous bloke from blighty, Jem Figg. Once a successful swordsman and cudgel expert, Figg opened a fistic academy, to teach the toffs the most elementary methods of protecting their aristocratic profiles. And by 1719 Figg was acknowledged as king of the heavyweights.

LONDON, June 4 (AP)--Archie Moore's manager predicted today the light-heavyweight champion would make the 175-pound limit with ounces to spare tomorrow, when he defends his title against Yolande Pompey of Trinidad in a fifteen-round match at Harringay Arena.

DES MOINES, Tuesday, June 5 (AP)--The Republican primary opponent of Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper last night conceded victory to the Senator with the words, "the farmers have shown that they are happy."
Eberhard A. Krumschmidt, an actor and stage director, died in New York Hospital Sunday after a brief illness. Mr. Krumschmidt was 51 years old and lived at 181 Waverly Place.
WASHINGTON, June 4-Under the pacific leadership of Lyndon B. Johnson of Texas the Senate for months has been one of the most polite forums in this country's political history.

Contract negotiations between the Western Union Telegraph Company and two unions representing 34,000 employes resumed yesterday in Washington. But spotty work stoppages continued to disrupt traffic to large sections of the nation.

TODAY'S books are volumes of short takes for brief, quickening exposures to the written word. One is "Selected Letters of Sydney Smith" (1771-1845), edited by Nowell C. Smith for Oxford's admirable The World's Classics series. The other is "Small Sounds in the Night," a new collection of Eric Sevareid's five-minute airborne commentaries on the passing scene in contemporary America.

Mrs. T.C.G. Herwig of Medina, Ohio, and Norman J. Brickner of Cuyahoga Falls, Ohio, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sue Brickner, to Lieut. Bruce Backe of the Air Force. He is the son of Mr. and. Mrs. Earle C. Backe of Merrick, L. I.
WELLESLEY, Mass., June 4 --Gifts and bequests totaling $2,919,400 were reported by Miss Margaret Clapp, president of Wellesley College, at the seventyeighth commencement exercises today.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- Stalin in his later years ran the Soviet Union through what he called "quintets," "sextets," "septets" and "novenaries."
Henry Cotton of London set the qualifying pace in the metropolitan district yesterday in the sectional trials for the United States Open golf championship.

STAMFORD, Conn., June 4--One hundred and fifty portable houses that had given shelter to refugees from last fall's floods were offered today to rehouse families who are in the path of the Connecticut Turnpike.
The Venezuelan Government has sought vainly to get the United States Department of State to help it quash a libel suit against its consul general here.
Judge Norman F. Lent of the Nassau County Court died of cancer in Memorial Hospital here yesterday after a long illness. He was 50 years old and resided at 190 Kensington Road, Lynbrook, L.I.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Supreme Court upheld today the dismissal by the Cutter Laboratories in 1949 of Mrs. Doris Walker because she was an active member of the Communist party.
DETROIT, June 4 (AP)--The auto industry got production back to a more nearly industrywide basis today after a week that was marked by the deepest schedule slashing in nearly two years.

Electronics has moved into the showroom in Seventh Avenue's apparel industry. Jonathan Logan, Inc., apparel manufacturer with sales volume of $36,000,000 a year, announced the development yesterday of a new system in conjunction with Remington Rand, Inc., business machine manufacturer.

Futures prices on the New York commodity exchanges closed mostly higher yesterday. Coffee, potatoes, cocoa, rubber, cottonseed oil, zinc and hides rose; copper and lead declined, and price movements for sugar and wool were mixed.

In order to meet the challenge of the Soviet Union's "conscription of brains," American industry must attack the serious shortage of engineers at the high school level. That warning was sounded recently by Frederic O. Hess, president of Selas Corporation of America.
MIAMI, Fla., June 4 (AP)--Carlos Prio Socarras, former President of Cuba, won today his fight to remain in the United States.

TRENTON, June 4--The sixweek strike of employes of Rockland Coaches and the Hill Bus Company was called off today. Normal bus service will be restored by both concerns in the pre-dawn hours of Wednesday.

American ship lines were warned yesterday that it was "high time" they began thinking in terms of 20-knot freighters. The majority of such ships currently in existence range in speed from 10 to 16 knots.

The United Nations and the Security Council never seemed weaker than they did yesterday when the Council allowed four Arab states, aided and abetted by Russia, to take out of the Palestine resolution the words that expressed hope for "a peaceful settlement on a mutually acceptable basis." .

Agencies of the provincial government of British Columbia are planning to raise $40,000,000 in the United States capital market to finance expansion of electric power, railroad and toll bridge and highway facilities.

Prof. Emmy Zweybrueck, industrial designer and educator, died Sunday in her home, 17 West Fifty-fourth Street, after a brief illness. She was the wife of Ernst A. Prochaska of Vienna, Austria. Her age was 66.
MOSCOW, June 4--President Tito of Yugoslavia reminded the leaders of the Soviet Union today that future relations between their countries depended fundamentally on a reform of Stalin's policies.

The Cudahy Packing Company had net income of $3,405,153 in the six months ended April 28, exceeding that for the full fiscal year ended Oct. 31, 1955. In the first half of the preceding fiscal year the net was $1,174,372.

As part of its plan to expand and diversify its real estate portfolio, the Wiss Realty Corporation, of Newark, N.J., William S. Taylor, president, has sold the Wiss Building, at 665671 Broad Street, Newark, and the adjoining property at 22 West Park Street.
BOSTON, June 4--About $90,000 in loot from the Brink's robbery was recovered today from a cache in a South End tenement.
Trading remained dull and largely professional yesterday as the stock market pushed forward on a fairly broad front. More than half the issues traded closed with gains.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 4--The Security Council unanimously adopted today a resolution requesting Dag Hammarskjold to "continue his good offices" toward full compliance with the Israeli-Arab armistice.
PARIS, June 4--A growing gap between energy resources and energy needs in the next twenty years is forecast by the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
Marso moved into first place Mate to win the Forget Hurdle Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. Among the many who wagered on Marso, there was little concern that he took his time going into the lead.
LUXEMBOURG, Tuesday, June 5--An agreement on the Saar and other questions dividing France and West Germany was reached late last night by the leaders of the two countries.
A statuette of St. Stephen, made by goldsmiths in the valley of the Meuse early in the thirteenth century, goes on public exhibition today in the Cloisters, above the Hudson River.
PARIS, June 4--France's Finance Minister, Paul Ramadier, gave the nation today a first installment on the bill for keeping Algeria French: the equivalent of $285,000,000.
WASHINGTON, June 4--The Supreme Court ruled today that states might enjoin violence in labor disputes under their own laws, regardless of the provisions of the National Labor Relations Act.

Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Magnus of 500 West End Avenue of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Magnus, to Stanley M. Rubel Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Rubel of Chicago.
DETROIT, June 4--General Motors announced today 100 winners of the four-year college scholarships awarded annually to high school seniors.
Lola D'Annunzio, a promising young actress, was killed Saturday in an automobile accident near Meade, Kan., her friends here were advised yesterday.
RICHMOND, Va., June 4--A special legislative commission convened here today for a new look at the Virginia plan for coping with the Supreme Court's ban on segregated public schools.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 4 --The life of Gene Austin, Texasborn blacksmith and cowboy who helped to establish the singing vogue called crooning in the early Twenties, will be portrayed in a motion picture.
ST. LOUIS, June 4--Belting four pitchers for fifteen hits, good for twenty-five bases, the Cardinals tonight subjected the Giants to their worst defeat of the season before 10,566 Busch Stadium fans.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 4 -- Private electric, utilities have been so successful in the past year's battle against public ownership that the "private-versuspublic-power" issue is practically dead in both national and local elections, the head of the Edison Electric Institute said here today.
LOS ANGELES, June 4-- Several million Californians will vote tomorrow in a primary election expected to affect materially the shape of the Presidential contest in the fall.
Now identified as "Shinbone Alley," the musical transition of the Don Marquis stories concerning archy and mehitabel is to be produced by Peter Lawrence.
Without spending a cent or appearing on a quiz show, this year's graduates of the University of Georgia are each about $19 richer.

SINGAPORE, June 4--Removal on the ban on shipments of rubber from Singapore and the Federation of Malaya to Communist China is expected to have wide repercussions in the rubber-producing countries of Asia.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Following, in translation, is the text of a document that purports to be a version of the speech delivered by Nikita S. Khrushchev, First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, at a secret session of the party's Twentieth Congress in Moscow, Feb. 24 and 25, 1956.
A key measure in the program Of the Defense Department for improving the attractiveness of a service career comes before a Senate committee for hearings this week.
The Transit Authority has established a project to untangle the rush-hour chaos in the Times Square subway station. effect last night, will sort passengers according to their destination.

WASHINGTON, June 4--Senator Alexander Wiley asserted today that his repudiation by the Republican organization in Wisconsin was the work of "Eisenhower-haters" seeking to sabotage the President's foreign policy.

With the vacation season about to start, New England is in there pitching, William M. Tetrick, chairman of the New England Council's vacation travel committee, told a regional meeting of the National Association of Travel Organizations in Boston yesterday that the $28,000 privately financed advertising program coordinated by the council so far had produced more than 16,000 inquiries from all sections of the country.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., June 4-- A smattering of opposition to Adlai E. Stevenson's Presidential hopes appeared at the Illinois State Democratic Convention today.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., June 4 --Negro leaders today rejected a compromise offer to end the week-old bus boycott. They demanded full integration of all bus passengers.
MOSCOW, June 4--Thanks enirely to the state visit by Marhal Tito it was possible tonight o see a ballet performance in he Bolshoi Theatre.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., June 4 (AP) -The Republican and Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives shared a platform here today, but there were no political overtones in, their talks to Syracuse University graduates.
ST. LOUIS, June 4 (AP)--President Eisenhower in a message today called 1955 "a difficult but magnificent year" for the American Red Cross. The organization opened its three-day convention here today.
This morning this newspaper publishes the fullest available text of Nikita S. Khrushchev's attack on Joseph Stalin. It is a searing experience to read that speech.

ORANGE, Mass., June 4-- Massachusetts brags with good reason about the public hunting and fishing and recreation provided by its big and relatively new Quabbin Reservoir. It is an all-around public treasure.

The chapel of Riverside Church was the setting yesterday afternoon for the marriage of Miss Lillian Mae Henderson to Hainon Alfred Miller. The Rev. Dr. Robert James McCracken performed the ceremony, after which there was a reception in the Women's Faculty Club of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, June 4-- The Navy has discovered that Venus is a sizzling hot planet.

DALLAS, June 4 (AP)--Peter Thomson defeated Cary Middlecoff of Dallas and Gene Littler of Singing Hills, Calif., in a sudden-death play-off today for $14,000 first money in the $70,000 Texas international open.

THANKS to Tiffany, the newest crop of infants may be born with golden spoons in their mouths. For designers at the Fifth Avenue jewelry store, convinced that the current era of elegance is here to stay, have revived the old French silver-gilt process called Vermeil.

Allan Jong of City College, the defending champion and the No. 1 seeded player, advanced through two rounds of the Metropolitan College Tennis Conference post-season tournament yesterday. Jong gained the semifinals at the Boulevard Gardens Courts in Woodside, Queens, by playing and winning only one set.
MOSCOW, June 4--Many observers think that Soviet Communist party leaders wish to avoid going too far in permitting attacks on Stalin.
BOLOGNA, Italy, June 4 (UP)--Italy, last year's European Zone winner in the Davis Cup, gained the semi-finals today by defeating Denmark, 4-1.

When Don Large pitched against Evander in a Public Schools baseball semi-final last year he didn't get a man out. The Bryant hurler was clipped for a single, a homer and two doubles, charged with four runs and banished to the showers.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 4-- The selection of a special grand jury to look into charges of official corruption in Suffolk County began today. There was a strong indication that the inquiry, ordered by Governor Harriman, would include gambling as well.

WASHINGTON, June 4--A musicians' union that picketed the Yankee Stadium in 1954 lost in the Supreme Court today an appeal from a finding that it had been guilty of violating the secondary boycott provisions of the Taft-Hartley Act.

Publication by the United States Government of a document purporting to be the text of Nikita S. Khrushchev's attack on Stalin raises the question of whether the Soviet Government will follow suit shortly.
Lucy Fitch Perkins, writer and illustrator of juvenile books, is the subject of a biography by her daughter, Eleanor Ellis Perkins, entitled "Eve Among the Puritans."

A Federal Maritime Board examiner has decided that the Grace Line, Inc., is a common carrier of bananas. He ruled that the line henceforth should pro-rate refrigerated space on a fair and reasonable basis among existing shippers for the transportation of bananas.
The traffic relief test plan limiting standing on one side of six crosstown streets in the morning and on the alternate side in the afternoon will go into effect today.

BALTIMORE, June 4 (AP)-- Billy Pierce notched his seventh victory behind a fourteen-hit attack as the Chicago White Sox walloped the Baltimore Orioles, 13-4, before, 7,387 spectators tonight. It was the third in a row for the White Sox over the local club.

Walter Burkemo, the 1953 Professional Golfers Association champion, played a featured role yesterday as close to 2,000 golfers competed for 146 places in the National Open championship. Sixteen players were exempt from qualifying.
Labor disputes broke out on two Hudson River piers yesterday and disrupted operations on a passenger liner and a freighter.

PEPPER, on the table at most homes every day, now retails for 16 to 19 cents for two ounces. The price, though reasonable, may not seem noteworthy unless it is remembered that just five years ago two ounces of the spice cost about 35 cents more than today.
MOSCOW, June 4--An exhibit on the use of atomic energy for peaceful purposes was featured at the opening today of this season's exhibition at the permanent Agricultural Exhibition Grounds.

WASHINGTON, June 4 (AP)-- Mike Garcia struck out twelve and his team-mates hit for distance tonight as the Cleveland Indians scored a 7-0 victory over the last-place Washington senators. Garcia gave seven safeties in gaining his fourth victory of the season.
Today will be the first of two consecutive days in which employes of the New York Central System and the Pullman Company will give blood to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.
MILWAUKEE, June 4--The Dodgers tonight became involved in two spectacular developments that could have yielded anyone a fortune had he bet on them in a winter book.
Americans and Indonesia's Dr. Sukarno have developed a strong mutual liking for each other.
The Police Department's heroes of the year were honored yesterday at a ceremony on the plaza in front of City Hall.
Mrs. Hattie Freeman Dodson, Congressional secretary to Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., was sentenced yesterday to seven months in prison and fined $1,000 for income tax evasion.
BANDUNG, Indonesia, June 4 --The Egyptian delegation proposed at the Asian and African students' conference here today that a permanent body known as the Asiatic-African. Youth Federation be formed.

LONDON, June 4-A sharp decline in British Government securities led to an all-round weakness on the stock market here today. Only a few selected issues, including some South African gold mining stocks, went against the trend.

The Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art graduated 205 students from its arts and engineering schools at its ninety-seventh annual commencement exercises last night.

Commission house selling and tired long liquidation dropped coffee prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Scale-down trade buying and light short covering limited the decline. Trading was influenced by lower prices at the source. The decline was considered a technical reaction to recent strength.
Angered at the failure of motorists to yield the right-of-way to emergency fire apparatus, Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. said yesterday that he would ask for extra-weight fines.

Today's new film is "Storm Over the Nile," a British drama, at the Palace. Laurence Harvey, Anthony Steel, James Robertson Justice and Mary Ure head the cast. The screen play by R.C. Sherriff was from the novel "The Four Feathers" by A. E. W. Mason.

The appointment of Laurence C. (Larry) Hart as national executive vice president of Junior Achievement, Inc., was announced yesterday by the chairman of the youth organization's advisory council, G. Kellogg Rose.
LONDON, June 7--An offer by an American concern to buy the British-controlled Trinidad Oil Company evoked bitter opposition today in Parliament.

MOSCOW, June 7 (AP)--A difference of opinion between Nikita S. Khrushchev, Communist party leader, and Mme. Ekaterina A. Furtseva, highest ranking woman Communist, over plans to develop Siberia was disclosed today.
A story about pigeons had Health Department officials eating their words yesterday.

ALBANY, June 7--The president of the Civil Service Employes Association asserted today that Commissioner Louis A. Wehle had made "intemperate and unproved charges" against Conservation Department personnel. Mr. Wehle heads the department.
The mood of the Arab refugees from Israel has turned uglier and is likely to result in some kind of explosion within four years, a United States missionary leader said yesterday.
BONN, Germany, June 7-- West Germany agreed today to contribute part of the cost of maintaining United States troops in West Germany for another fiscal year.

The National-U.S. Radiator Corporation had net income of $1,210,928 on sales of $54,673,921 in the year ended March 31, T.B. Focke, president, announced yesterday. The report covers the first full year of operations of the company, which was formed ...

LOU BOUDREAU is an ingenious and imaginative young man. His Kansas City Athletics may be dull but he never is. The inventor of the Boudreau Shift against Ted Williams has just bobbed up with a new brainstorm, a defensive device rigged to balk Master Mickey Mantle. It's still too early to report on how uniformly effective it will be but it makes for good conversation.
CHICAGO, June 7--W.A. Patterson, president of United Airlines, said today that air carriers might seek to penalize passengers who failed to show up for reservations.

OTTAWA, June 7 (Canadian) Press)--An hour after the bill was passed, officials of TransCanada Pipe Lines signed an agreement with the Government covering the $80,000,000 loan.
Murray Baron, Liberal party chairman for New York County, proposed yesterday that all judicial elections in the state be held in odd-numbered years, when there are no state or national contests.

New York County delegates to the Republican National Convention let the public in on their caucus for President and Vice President yesterday. The delegates chose, to nobody's surprise, an Eisenhower-Nixon ticket.
The near-by July rubber posttion on the Commodity Exchange of New York soared yesterday in fairly active trading. There was switching from July to September at a widening differential.
Floyd Patterson and Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson will fight at Madison Square Garden tonight. Their bout has aroused more interest than has any other non-championship fight in a half dozen years.
The "Big Three" steel companies said yesterday that it would take them until Wednesday or Thursday of next week to draft counter-proposals to union contract demands.

BANDUNG, Indonesia, June 7 --The United States Embassy in Jakarta emphatically denied today that it had extracted from Indonesian newspaper men any pledge not to write about the Negro problem in the United States.

Double covers on three manholes blew off in an explosion yesterday on crowded West Thirty-third Street, between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, at the height of the shopping and commuting rush.

Cotton futures prices were unchanged to 2 points down yesterday on small volume.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 7--The engagement of Miss Joan Patricia Bartels to James Augustine Delay has been announced by her mother, Mrs. Harold Charles Bartels. Mr. Delay is a son of Mrs. James A. Delay of Boston and the late District Court Judge Delay of Boston.

Motorists traveling in the metropolitan area over the week-end may expect detours or delays on the following principal routes. Letters on the map indicate more or less permanent bottlenecks stemming mainly from too much traffic on inadequate roads; numbers show where new construction or repairs will cause considerable inconvenience for only a part of the summer.

Stocks yesterday made the best gains in more than a week, with oils and metals pushing forward. Although trading was light--1,630,000 shares against 1,460,000 on Wednesday--the market held its strength throughout the session.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., June 7--Mrs. Morris H. Schlain has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Phyllis Susan Schlain, to Richard J. Kluger, who will graduate from Princeton on Tuesday. He is the son of Mrs. Ida Kluger of 400 West End Avenue, New York, and David Kluger of 7 East Seventy-ninth Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, June 7--The Army announced today a reorganization of the Reserves to place them on a more realistic basis.

CHICKEN--meaty, flavorful broilers and fryers--stands out as a particularly good choice for this week-end. Probably many shoppers will select poultry because lamb and pork are relatively expensive, and beef is less plentiful and more expensive than recently at retail counters.

The streets of Brooklyn--traditional "Borough of Churches" --blossomed yesterday with 120,000 Protestant Sunday school children in colorful costumes who participated in the 127th annual parade of the Brooklyn Sunday School Union.

Neji, carrying top weight of 165 pounds, scored an impressive victory in the forty-first Meadow Brook Steeplechase Handicap at Belmont Park yesterday. The even-money favorite, ridden by Frank (Dooley) Adams, romped to a three-and-a-half-length triumph in the $17,600 stakes.

The formation of the Anti-Forgery League of America has been postponed indefinitely. Its founder was arrested yesterday for forgery. The founding father, Charles Carson Chitty, had grand plans for the league: alert business men, psychological weapons and membership 50 cents annually. Despite his 33 years, Chitty is well versed in the field. He has been arrested seven times since 1939, six times for forging a signature on a check.

BUENOS AIRES. June 7--The chain reaction of dismissals and new appointments in the Argentine Army continued today.

N., who were graduated on Tuesday from Pembroke College and Brown University, respectively, Mere married today in Christ Protestant Episcopal Church, Washington Parish. The Rev. Ivan Merrick performed the ceremony.

Miss Kay Simonson was married yesterday afternoon to James M. Waterbury of 48 East Eighty-third Street in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola by Msgr. John J. Dougherty. There was a reception at the Ambassador.

Mrs. Otis T. Bradley of 1160 Park Avenue and Westhampton Beach, L. I., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marian Alling Bradley, to Michael Blow, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Waller Blow of Yorktown, Va.

ROME, June 8--The Italian Communist party is preparing for a major change in its strategy.
NEWARK, June 8--The disciplinary power of the Passaic Alcohol Beverage Control Board was suspended today by William Howe Davis, New Jersey A.B.C. Commissioner.
The cotton futures market moved 5 points lower to 4 points up yesterday. The volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange still was light but improved slightly over the previous day.
Twenty-four disabled men and women were honored last night for their efforts to become selfsupporting by the Federation of the Handicapped, 211 West Fourteenth Street.
PARIS, June 8--Mrs. Margaret Thompson Biddle, American heiress who made her home here, died this morning apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage. Her age was reported to be 58.

Early Wynn, who possesses more victories than any active pitcher except his Cleveland team-mate, Bobby Feller, fashioned one of his easiest triumphs last night.

PRINCETON, N. J., June 8 --A 91-year-old Princeton University alumnus returned to the campus this week-end, after more than a half-century of absence, to find Princeton "much more of a university than it was in my day."
A "little Coliseum" is included in plans of the Mid-Harlem slum clearance development for which Robert Moses is seeking Federal subsidy.
WASHINGTON, June 8--President Eisenhower had a heavy schedule yesterday, running from 8:30 o'clock in the morning until 11 at night. Those who saw him thought he looked fine.
One dispute involving a narcotics case between General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office seemed to vanish in court yesterday.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., June 8--Dr. Milton S. Eisenhower, president of Pennsylvania State University for the past six years, submitted his resignation today in a letter dated yesterday. He cited "personal reasons."
CANNES, France, June 8 (UP) --The International Air Transport Association Conference, deadlocked on the issue of lower trans-Atlantic air fares, may be extended, a spokesman said today.
WASHINGTON, June 8--Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin has called on the United States, Britain and France to cut their armed forces in Germany without waiting for an over-all disarmament agreement.

Former President Carlos Prio Socarras of Cuba has been permitted to remain in this country. The United States Immigration Service reversed itself in an agreement signed only a few minutes before Dr. Prio's fight against an exclusion order was to go before a Federal court in Miami.
NEWARK, June 8--An armed intruder shot and seriously wounded City Councilman Jack M. Waldor tonight in his home, 9 Wilbur Avenue. The attack occurred about 10:45 P.M.

CINCINNATI, June 8--Rocky Nelson, fresh from Montreal, made his debut as a Dodger tonight by hitting a two-run homer. Duke Snider and Roy Campanella also hit for the circuit. But that still wasn't enough to halt Cincinnati's inspired Redlegs.
WASHINGTON, Saturday, June 9--President Eisenhower was operated on at 2:59 A.M. today for relief of an intestinal obstruction. At 4:55 A.M., the operation was pronounced a success by the surgeons.

WASHINGTON, June 8--The weekly index of average primary market prices declined 0.1 per cent in the week ended last Tuesday to 114.2 per cent of its 1947-49 level, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

Preliminary examination of President Eisenhower led at first to a diagnosis of ileitis. The condition is marked by an inflamation of the ileum, the lower portion of the small intestine.

IN the surging oratory of a Presidential campaign year we generally hear a lot about Abraham Lincoln and very little, comparatively, about Woodrow Wilson. It is as if men of all parties were happy to claim Lincoln, while Wilson could be safely invoked by few speakers and seekers.

CLEVELAND, June 8 (AP)--A Negro mother who said she had come here because she could not support her family in the South was forced to leave town today with her eight dependents. They ranged in age from 11 days to 17 years.

Only 500 characters a minute can be printed on the New York Stock Exchange ticker tape and sometimes that isn't enough. Yesterday, owing to the rush of business following the announcement that President Eisenhower had been hospitalized, the tape ran as much as five minutes late.

The Colombian Government has contracted for three paper mills, expected to be in operation by mid1958. It is good to know that Colombian presses may soon count on more paper, to the end that information and comment may be less restricted for sheer lack of space.

Two youths led the police in a chase over a forty-block area of Brooklyn early yesterday at speeds ranging up to 90 miles an hour. They were both slightly wounded before their capture.

Some of the nation's laundries and linen supply companies are cleaning up as a result of the increased fringe benefits now enjoyed by American workers.

Carrol M. Shanks, president of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, told the graduating class of 352 at Long Island University yesterday that despite the trend toward bigness in business and government, the individual is more important than ever.

Floyd Patterson and Tommy (Hurricane) Jackson threw punches at each other for twelve rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. When it was all over Patterson, as expected, received the decision, although the vote was not unanimous.
Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. received assurances yesterday that he would be named as one of twenty-four New York State delegates at large to the Democratic national convention.
It became official yesterday: The city will spend $1,917,058,908 on its housekeeping bills in 1956-57.

WASHINGTON, June 8-- President Eisenhower's sudden new illness shook the political world today.

WASHINGTON, June 8--President Eisenhower signed the dependents medical care bill, the White House said today. It is one of the measures being relied on by the Defense Department to induce service men to make a career of military service.

WASHINGTON, June 9 (UP)-- Lieut. Gen. Emmett O'Donnell Jr., chief of Air Force personnel, has warned Congress the Air Force is so seriously undermanned the matter "must be given the highest priority."
MADRID, June 9--An agreement in principle was reported today to have been reached between Washington and Madrid on the selection of three sites for additional United States air bases in Spain.

BOGOTA, Colombia, June 9-- A Government-sponsored press congress ended tonight two days of deliberation on every conceivable problem of newspapers and newspaper men except that of the freedom of the press.

KINGSTON--Nature serves many purposes up here in the Catskills. For the vacationist, nature can be an end in itself--streams to fish in, mountains to climb, woods to walk in, green hills and tranquil lakes to contemplate.

Housing codes that regulate the number of persons that may occupy one room and establish standards for such items as heating, lighting, plumbing and garbage disposal are in effect in at least forty-five American cities.

WEST GLACIER, Mont.-- Tourist or resident, almost everyone who lives in or has visited the Northwest has gone a round or two in the conversational hassle over the area's National Parks, and in particular, over which one is better--Glacier or Yellowstone.

The Coaching Club American Oaks, the longest race in the land for 3-year-old fillies, was won at Belmont Park yesterday by Mrs. Vernon G. Cardy's Levee. She was the $11.90-for-$2 fourth choice in a nine-filly line-up.
