A report from the Educational Testing Service of Princeton reveals that in elementary and secondary schools mathematics is found to be "the most hated subject." Yet it must be cultivated if we are to develop scientists and engineers who will hold their own in competition with the Russians.

LONDON, June 9--Stanislaw Mackiewicz, former Premier of the Polish Government-inExile, renounced the West today. He said he would return to his Communist homeland disillusioned by British and American "betrayal."

BEDFORD, N.Y., June 9-- The marriage of Miss Nancy Weightman Jacob to Peter Laverack Winslow took place this afternoon in St. Matthew's Protestant Episcopal Church. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur Ketchum.
Good selling activity on summer merchandise in most departments, coupled with some early promotions of fall goods, was reported last week by resident buying offices.
LONDON, June 9--Britain has been warned by Turkey that she has already gone too far in offers of self-government to Cyprus.
Our Lady of Refuge Roman Catholic Church, Brooklyn, was the scene yesterday morning of the marriage of Dr. Nancy Ellen Shevell to Dr. William John Sciales.
WASHINGTON, June 9--Vice President Richard M. Nixon prepared today to take over some of the ceremonial, social and other public duties of President Eisenhower's schedule.
RENO, Nev., June 9--Senator Alan Bible is facing two major political battles to retain his seat this year because of his late entrance into the election picture here.
MARION, Mass., June 9-- George O'Day, sailing under the colors of the host Beverly Yacht Club, won the opening race of the Eastern trials for the Olympic monotype sailing this afternoon.
In St. Mark's in-the-Bouwerie Protestant Episcopal Church yesterday afternoon Miss Cynthia Alice McEvoy was married to Donald Day Boyer.

JUNE is hardly "bustin' out all over" this week, for there are only scattered spots where the traditional roses are in bloom. In most sections roses are taking their time arriving. But there are high hopes that warm weather will give June a shove and bring on the bloom. After all this is National Rose Week.
"By the hokies, there was a man in this place one time by the name of Ned Sullivan, and he had a queer thing happen him late one night and he coming up the Valley Road from Durlas."
WORCESTER, Mass., June 9-- Massachusetts Democrats wound up their pre-primary convention today. It was devoted chiefly to repairing breaches in party unity.
LONDON, June 9--The British Army is beginning to complete its post-war strategic redeployment.

TOKYO, June 9--Japan's two principal parties, the LiberalDemocrats and the Socialists, are shaping up what promises to be a lively campaign for crucial elections to the upper house of the Diet (Parliament) July 8.
LONDON, June 10--Hugh Gaitskell urged Britain today to resume negotiations with Archbishop Makarios or ask for the cooperation of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization in solving the Cyprus problem.
MONTREAL, June 10--A big question at the International Civil Aviation Organization's tenth assembly session, opening June 19 in Caracas, Venezuela, will be the Soviet Union's future role.

The burgeoning plans for the Columbus Circle area have grown to include a new art gallery. Huntington Hartford, member of the family that founded the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, plans to build the gallery.

MILWAUKEE, June 10-- Johnny Antonelli hasn't been able to win as a starting pitcher, but he has done all right in relief. Today he blanked the Braves for the last four innings as the Giants won, 5--3, before 34,441 County Stadium fans.
ST. LOUIS June 10--Jules Bebie, Swiss-born consulting chemist and retired officer of the Monsanto Chemical Company, died of a heart ailment yesterday. His age was 79.

Cotton futures fluctuated in narrow ranges in light trading last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices at the week-end were up 5 points (hun dredths of a cent a pound) to off 7 from the close a week earlier.

British pound sterling rallied to recover some of its early loss and the Canadian dollar continued to show a strong undertone in the foreign exchange market during the past week. Business transacted was fairly brisk following brief intervals of dullness.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., June 10 (AP)--Edgar S. Jennings, retired brigadier general in the National Guard and former warden at Auburn, (N.Y.) State Prison, died today. He was 84 years old.
The television industry, which in ten years has grown from a gadget to a giant, is facing a series of king-sized investigations and controversies.
MEDFORD, Mass., June 10-- Preaching morality to other nations is not a good substitute for practicing it yourself, the American Ambassador to Sweden said today.

One interesting aspect of Indonesian President Sukarno's recent visit to the United States has received little attention here. This is the reaction of the Dutch public and press to the honors that have been heaped upon a self-proclaimed enemy of our ally, the Netherlands. The Dutch attitude has been surprisingly temperate and gratifying.
WALTHAM, Mass., June 10-- Dean Acheson asserted today that the new Soviet leaders "seem to me every bit as ruthless and dangerous as the old ones."

The Communist--as well as the really neutral--members of the socalled Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission in Korea have now been moved, without incident, into the demilitarized zone. The Communist members, as President Syngman Rhee rightly demanded, are no longer free to roam South Korea to further what the United Nations Command called "unneutral actions" and what the free Koreans call espionage and sabotage.
Latin America is gaining in importance in advertising. Two developments over the week-end point up the increased attention paid by Madison Avenue to what's going on south of the Rio Grande.
PARIS, June 10--French Premier Guy Mollet won support today from the Socialist party's National council after having declared he had made a standing offer to the Algerian rebels for a cease-fire.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 10--John Judge's S boat, Celerity, Bus Mosbacher Jr.'s International, Sunsan; Bob Weil's 210, Bounty, and Owen Torrey Jr.'s Star, Cygnet, were among the winners in today's Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound regatta.
BABYLON, L.I., June 10-- Erosion is posing a threat to Fire Island Inlet and near-by beaches.

RYE, N.Y., June 10--The garden of the home of Mr. and Mrs. Milton L. Bruenn was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of their daughter, Miss Carol Bruenn, to John Glass 3d. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Glass Jr. of New Rochelle. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Bernard Bamberger.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 --Hubbell Robinson, vice president in charge of programming for the Columbia Broadcasting System, has commissioned three pilot films from Ticonderoga Productions. Two are planned as situation comedies and one an adventure show.

The dedication of a chain of ten new hospitals, built and operated by the United Mine Workers Welfare Fund, and the joint action by the International Association of Machinists and U.S. Industries Incorporated to set up a research and advisory foundation on collectively bargained welfare funds are striking evidence of the value of labor-management cooperation in protecting the health of American workers.

MEXICO, Mo., June 10--Allen P. Green, who built the largest single plant in the world manufacturing fire clay products, died last night of a coronary thrombosis in Missouri Baptist Hospital, St. Louis. His age was 80.

A HOUSE looking like the one below, completely made of molded plastic pieces, soon will be a reality. Developed by the Monsanto Chemical Company, it is the result of extensive studies of the use of plastics in housing and was worked out with the cooperation of the Department of Architecture of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Seniors at Fordham University were reminded yesterday that, after graduation, they had a new role as salesmen of God. They were told also that the practice of humility was a means of "selling" Roman Catholicism and of gaining "minimum personal sanctification."
BUENOS AIRES, June 10-- Navy and Air Force planes smashed an attempted Peronist counter-revolution early this morning.
LARCHMONT, N.Y., June 10 --Walter H. Wheeler Jr. scored an emphatic victory with his huge yawl, Cotton Blossom IV, in the Larchmont Yacht Club's overnight race which ended today.
SANGER, Calif., June 10 (AP) --Dave Sime today credited the flying feet of Mike Agostini and the "best track I've ever seen" for one of the greatest one-man shows in the history of foot racing.
LONDON, June 10--Maurice Webb, Laborite Minister of Food in 1950-51, died taday at his home in Pinner, near London. His age was 51.
A Protestant clergyman yesterday fired one of the preliminary salvos in Billy Graham's forthcoming crusade here for the revival of religion.

TORONTO, June 9--The Toronto Stock Exchange--world's largest in volume of shares traded and the leader in mining transactions--recently decided that the sheer weight of business ($2,500,000,000 gross in 1955) required a quintupling of its facilities and appointment of its first paid president.
PEIPING, June 10--The Chinese Communist Foreign Ministry said tonight that the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission in Korea had the right to send its teams again to the ports of entry.

Holy communion brings the recipient into spiritual and corporal union with Jesus Christ "for at least fifteen minutes," the Rev. Charles J. McManus declared yesterday at solemn mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

Coal and grain rates "softened" last week, forcing down the over-all dry Cargo freight date index for the second consecutive week. The decline, however, was again fractional and strong volume compensated somewhat for the rate losses.

ITHACA, N.Y., June 10-- Prof. Horace E. Whiteside, a leading authority on the law of contracts, trusts and wills, died here last night in Tompkins County Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old Last Tuesday.

While President Eisenhower was getting over the first shock of his operation last Saturday Secretary Dulles was out in the Middle West delivering a carefully prepared commencement address on our foreign policy. Mr. Dulles wouldn't have had to discuss any last-minute changes with the President, because there couldn't have been any. The speech had been sent to the press on Friday, with the usual hold-for-release slug on it.
The biggest savings bank in the world stands near the Southwest corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-second Street, across from the Grand Central Station.

WASHINGTON, June 10-- Sherman Adams was on the job in the White House today doing what comes naturally, He was tightening up his already tight organization to carry through with a minimum of disruption the complex work of the White House staff.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., June 10--Dr. Henry M. Wriston, former President of Brown University, today called the United States Foreign Service "as good" as any nation's in the world.

R. Richard Dyer of Salle Csiszar in Philadelphia, the defending champion, led a field of eighteen fencers into the semifinal round of the national saber championship at the New York Athletic Club yesterday.
Some of the most rapidly growing municipalities in this area still lack zoning regulations to protect their residents.
Habitues of the Bowery who are haled into court generally stand in silent submission before the bar. One of them, a former lawyer, spoke up yesterday.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 10 --Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will lunch with Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in Washington Wednesday.
WASHINGTON, June 10--The House Committee on Un-American Activities will investigate the Fund for the Republic at public hearings opening June 27.

The Community Mental Health Board said yesterday it was aiding a rapid expansion in they services of voluntary psychiatric clinics here. Some of the twenty clinics that have contracts with the city agency have in less than a year more than doubled the number of cases treated.

A $2,750,000 program "to enable leading economists to conduct research of their own choosing" was announced yesterday by the Ford Foundation. The aim will be to assist scholars at smaller colleges as well as at five major universities.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, June 10--All interest is being focused on next Wednesday's general elections and on developments in the money and capital markets.

WESTPORT, Conn., June 10-- Best-in-show of the LongshoreSouthport Kennel Club event today was a 3-year-old white miniature poodle imported from England last October. He was Ch. Icarus Duke-Otto, owned by L.J. Gunson Jr., of Indianapolis and handled by Anne Rogers.

WEDDING bells pealing loud all over the country this month are ringing for a younger group of brides and grooms than ever before in this country's recorded statistical history. Whether the chimes always ring merrily for these youngsters is open to question. In many cases parental doubts and opposition add a note of jangling discord.
Top unionists, who had resigned themselves to a back seat in the Presidential campaign, are now considering a more active mobilization of their political strength.

NEW HAVEN, June 10--The Bible, the United States Constitution and a liberal education are three sets of principles that will well serve modern man, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University, said today in his baccalaureate address.
The position of coffee in the world today is sound and a general price decline is not expected, according to Dr. Vito Sa, representative of the Brazilian Coffee Institute in the United States.
Experimental summer sessions for personal injury cases in the Supreme Court, City Court and Municipal Court in Manhattan and the Bronx were announced yesterday.
A LONG about 9:15 Saturday night, the leading lady in Max Liebman's musical production titled "Holiday" remarked to the leading man: "Aren't we having, a dull conversation?"

Charles Zenker, long a leading publisher of press books and other promotion and advertising material for the motion picture industry died Saturday of a heart attack in St. Clare's Hospital. His age was 81. He lived at 320 West End Avenue.

CHICAGO, June 10--Wheat futures in the last week showed surprising strength in view of the fact that harvest operations are expanding rapidly, with the next few weeks the usual season for big marketings and heavy hedge pressure.
HIGHLANDS, N.J., June 10--Fletcher Pratt, historian, scholar and writer, died today of cancer in Monmouth Memorial Hospital, Long Branch. He was 59 years old.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., June 10--Gene Littler coasted to a decisive triumph in the Palm Beach round-robin golf tournament today.

PARIS, June 10--Khrushchev's savage posthumous quarrel with Stalin involves method, not philosophy. Like the dead tyrant, he also claims to be an excellent Leninist. Lenin remains untarnished. Khrushchev referred to "our party's holy Leninist principles." He concluded his tirade: "Long live the victorious banner of our party--Leninism."

CANTON, N.Y., June 10 (AP) --The "slave economy and philosophy of exploitation" in the Soviet Union belong to an outmoded order from preceding ages, Chancellor William P. Tolley of Syracuse University said today.
Governor Harriman declared last night that his understanding of the international situation and of the needs of the domestic economy made him the strongest Democratic candidate for the Presidency.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP) --After losing six straight games to Detroit, Washington turned on the Tigers to take a double-header today.
New York has more union members than any other state, but it ranks fifteenth in percentage of organized industrial and white-collar workers.

Plans of the American Hawaiian Steamship Company for the Construction of ten roll-on-rolloff ships moved one step closer to reality yesterday. The Maritime Administration in Washington took action to expedite the final review of the company's application for Govern ment building aid.

AT GRACIE Mansion this afternoon Mayor and Mrs. Wagner will be hosts to members of the New York Newspaper Women's Club. For the occasion the Tea Council, representing tea packers in this country, has devised a delectable tea punch that will be served to guests, including women members of United Nations missions.
TOKYO, June 6--Seizure of fishing vessels by the Soviet Union apparently was one of the pressures applied by Moscow in forcing the recent conclusion of a fisheries agreement with Japan.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) --Reuben B. Robertson Jr., deputy Defense Secretary, said today that in the "total picture" of missile development the United States was "equal to or ahead of the Russians."

SINGAPORE, June 10--The United States is fighting the "cold war" in Southeast Asia with its hands tied behind its back, according to many of the officers charged with conducting the propaganda war in this part of the world.
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, June 5--Coffee and fruit growers are becoming concerned over the discovery of significant inroads of the Mediterranean fruit fly.
A delegation of American builders will leave for the Soviet Union today to study housing and building practices there.

CHICAGO, June 10 (UP)--The Chicago Cubs swept a doubleheader from the Philadelphia Phillies today, winning the first game, 2--1, on an eleventh inning single by Eddie Miksis and wrapping up the second game, 5--2, behind the six-hit pitching of Sam Jones.
OMAHA, June 10 (AP)--Wyoming eliminated New York University, 8 to 2, today in the opening game of the second round of the National Collegiate baseball world series.

STOCKHOLM, June 10--The Equestrian Games of the sixteenth modern Olympiad were opened by King Gustaf Adolf today with traditional ceremonies including a colorful parade of 250 horsemen and horsewomen of the teams of twenty-eight competing nations.

STALINGRAD, U.S.S.R., June 10 (Reuters)--President Tito of Yugoslavia and Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist leader, continued their talks today aboard a special train taking them to Stalingrad, famed World War II battleground.
WASHINGTON, June 10--The current term of the Supreme Court is scheduled to end tomorrow in a deluge of opinions and orders.

Churchgoers over the nation bowed their heads yesterday in solemn prayer for the speedy recovery of the President. Their supplication was reminiscent of the country-wide petition to Divine Providence offered up last year when General Eisenhower suffered his heart attack.
New studies by the New York Stock Exchange have indicated that there are now some 8,000,000 shareholders in the United States, Keith Funston, its president, said yesterday.

BOSTON, June 10 (AP)--The Chicago White Sox capitalized on a fourth-inning break to score all their runs and edge the Boston Red Sox, 3-2, today as Billy Pierce posted his eighth victory with a six-hitter.

WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)-- The Administration's foreign aid bill, already slashed more than a billion dollars, was lined up for formal House passage tomorrow before heading into more trouble in the Senate.

In an investment deal in the downtown Manhattan civic center area, the seventeen-story office building at 80 Lafayette Street has been purchased by a syndicate represented by the law firm of Borrok, Steingart Borrok.
NYACK, N.Y., June 10-- Whistles blew and hundreds of persons cheered today as a twenty-eight-foot sailing craft set off for Greece.
WASHINGTON, June 10--The Assistant to the President, Sherman Adams, emerged today, as he did after President Eisenhower's heart attack, as the substitute captain of the Eisenhower "team."
The streets of Harlem have never been cleaner than they are today, according to veteran observers of the uptown scene.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 10--The thirtieth annual World Music Festival of the International Society for Contemporary Music ended tonight with a concert of orchestral music in Stockholm's Concert Hall.

LONDON, June 10--After starting with what could be described as "Black Monday," the stock markets staged a fair recovery following three days of sharp decline and closed the week with a moderate display of confidence.

Once mankind had to content itself with such oracles as those at Delphi and Dodona, sibyls such as the Cumaean, Cimmerian, Tiburtine and Hellespontine. Today we have a new breed of soothsayers, most of them masquerading as corporation presidents, a few as doctors of philosophy in economics.
MANHASSET, L.I., June 10 --Nicholas Ludington of Harvard University won the James H. Van Alen Cup for court tennis today.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (AP)-- Fifty bright young men and women law school graduates will go to work for the Justice Department this week.
A Greenwich Village clergyman charged yesterday that the puzzle contest being sponsored by the American Church Union had reached its "lowest ethical point."
In a bruising, thrill-packed game made to order for 9,000 enthusiastic onlookers at Gaelic Park in the Bronx yesterday, New York's No. 1 selected team beat County Dublin in Gaelic football, 14--11.

PARIS, June 10--France's foreign commerce wound up at the end of the first four months of this year with a deficit of 102 billion francs, or $291,000,000. The amount of foreign currency reserves also diminished between January and the end of May, but financial experts emphasize that the problem of monetary reserves is not serious.

A CURIOUS figure at the United States Military Academy graduation at West Point the other day was a tall, rapid-talking civilian, an honorary member of the class of '3l. He virtually ran class' twenty-fifth reunion. He wriggled with delight as West Point's high brass and cadets hailed him at all turns and called him by name.
The Military Sea Transportation Service reassured tanker operators over the week-end that it would continue to charter privately owned vessels wherever possible.
Roman Catholic institutions of higher learning were urged yesterday to produce their quota of individuals intellectually mature and morally sound enough to cope with today's problems.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., June IO (AP)--Consumers, who have piled up a record debt so far this year, are also setting a record for debt repayments, a poll of banking and credit executives showed today.

ST. LOUIS, June 10 (AP)--The St. Louis Cardinals, thrashed, 11--3, in the first game today by a former team-mate, Luis Arroyo, came back to gain a virtual first-place tie on Herm Wehmeier's six hit 3-0 shutout over his favorite "cousins," the Pittsburgh Pirates.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., June 10-- Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Lines have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Louise Lines of New York, to Edward Ernest David Michael Oates of Cambridge, England. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Oates of Wadebridge, Cornwall, England, A December wedding is planned.
CASEY STENGEL stood in the doorway of his office yesterday and his eyes swept around the Yankee dressing room. He was grim and unsmiling.
WASHINGTON, June 10--Part of Washington's diplomatic community was vexed and all of it was puzzled this week-end by the United States' attitude toward neutrality.

WHITE PLAINS, June 10-- The Facts for Taxpayers Committee asserted today that its opponents were spending "tens of thousands of dollars" in an attempt to defeat a long-term school bond issue in Tuesday's referendum here.

MARION, Mass., June 10--A consistent record of a first, two seconds, and one third gave George O'Day of the host Beverly Yacht Club-a 10-point lead over the runner-up in a field of twenty-two contestants in the Eastern Olympic monotype eliminations today.

A filmed baseball program featuring outstanding events in major league games and interviews with the players who participated will make its debut this week over Channel 5. "Baseball Hall of Fame" will be televised each Saturday from 10 to 10:30 A.M.

The United Jewish Appeal reported yesterday that it had raised $40,350,000 in its 1956 fund campaign. The money will be used to aid needy Jewish men, women and children throughout the world, with emphasis on Israel.
WASHINGTON, June 10 (UP) --The National Planning Association urged the United States today to put its Point Four program on a long-range basis.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 9--There is a paradox in the drive for Western European economic unification. The chief impetus behind the movement is the widespread and growing belief that European countries are "too small" to provide markets large enough to enable their industries to develop ...
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 10 --Film rights to the life story of Jack Dempsey, former world heavyweight champion, finally have been acquired by Sam Weisenthal, independent producer.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va., June 10 (AP)--Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge of Asheville, N.C., gained only 2 points today, but won the $12,000 Triangle round-robin golf tournament.

ZURICH, Switzerland, June 10 --Despite the good mood resulting from the news that France and Germany at last had reached, an agreement on the future of the Saar, stock exchange business in Zurich remained quiet last week.

It is not certain whether Paul Osborn's mythological comedy "Maiden Voyage" will reach Broadway in October, as planned. Last season Billy Rose, the producer, had under contract a glamorous leading lady--Claire Bloom--but he was unable to find an available theatre to house the play.
WASHINGTON, June 10--In view of the President's illness, the timing of the Republican National Convention this year may be regarded as another example of the remarkable "Eisenhower luck."
Bronx real estate deals reported over the week-end included the transfer of ownership of many small residential properties.

PRINCETON, N.J., June 10 --Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of Princeton University, today called upon the 653 members of the graduating class to assist in providing "the leadership which our country must have or perish."

Never should anyone attempt to outguess Casey Stengel, who made one slightly puzzling move at the Stadium yesterday and forthwith paved the way for the Yankees to post a 6-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians.
The Public Housing Administration announced yesterday that on June 27 it would offer for sale $93,310,000 of new housing bonds.

PITTSBURGH, June 10--Steel demand as evidenced by the volume of new orders last week was not off as much as had been expected. While new orders booked for flat-rolled items declined from a month ago because of auto cutbacks, demand for other products still was heavy.

WASHINGTON, June 10-- President Eisenhower walked thirty painful feet with help this morning. When asked to exercise a second time this afternoon, however, he turned down the chance with the remark: "Once was enough."
CINCINNATI, June 10--The Dodgers, though still unable to extricate themselves from the second division, today continued to throw their weight around in the West.
WASHINGTON, June 10--A high Administration political figure said today he doubted that President Eisenhower's second illness would be seriously adverse to Republican election chances.
The Dayton Rubber Company has put into operation a huge German-built machine that turns out twenty-two pounds of polyurethane foam a minute.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The United States Information Agency has instructed its offices in Tripoli and Benghazi, Libya, to cease showing movies or distributing news bulletins outside of Government premises.

MOSCOW, June 11--The Crown Prince of Yemen arrived here today. He was the first leading representative of an Arab country to make a mission to Moscow.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 11--The emphasis was on correct easy paces as the Equestrian Olympic Games competition got under way today with the dressage phase of the Three Day trials.

WASHINGTON, June 11--The Navy is about to abandon the twentieth century zipper and sail back with tradition to the medieval gusset and the thirteenbutton "broad-fall front" in its bell-bottomed trousers.

Summer Tan came back to the races yesterday, but he finished in back of Red Hannigan. Established the odds-on favorite by the crowd of 23,739, Mrs. John W. Galbreath's good colt made his first start of the year in the six-furlong feature event at Belmont Park. According to "expert observers" he was just a little short.
THIRTY-THREE homebodies made themselves comfy at the Coliseum this week and started stitching their way toward a $25,000 pot o' gold.
PRINCETON, N. J. June 11-- Archibald L. Gillies of Plandome, L. I., and Coleman B. Brown of Evanston, Ill., were honored today at the class day ceremonies of Princeton University's Class of '56.
BOSTON, June 11 (AP)--Tom Brewer held Cleveland to three hits for his ninth victory of the season tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Indians, 6--1., for a split in a day-and-night program.
LONDON, June 11--The advent of the hydrogen bomb has led the British Government to plan sweeping economies in the armed services.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 11-- The fifty-ninth annual convention of the American Federation of Musicians opened fittingly here today with a concert. But on the basis of all present indications, that may very well be the last harmonious note sounded for the next several days.
Traffic was tangled yesterday and there were many pedestrian hurdles in the Third Avenue redevelopment project, but almost everyone kept a remarkably stiff upper lip.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., June 11 (AP)--Edwin Corle, known for his stories of the Southwest, died in a hospital here today of cancer and an embolism. He was 50 years old.

National Gypsum Company is offering to its common stockholders rights to subscribe for 417,403 additional shares of common stock at $47 a share on the basis of one new share for each eight shares held.

WASHINGTON, June 11 (AP) --Mike Baxes and Vic Power slammed home runs to give Kansas City a 6-3 victory over Washington in the second game tonight. The Senators took the opener, 4--3, on Carlos Paula's three-run pinch homer in the eighth inning.

The defending titleholder, Abraham Cohen of the New York Fencers Club and eleven other qualifiers gained the final round of the national individual epee fencing championships last night at the Concourse Plaza Hotel in the Bronx. The final round-robin will be held Thursday.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 11 --The signing of a "mutual aid and assistance" agreement between the Screen Actors Guild and the Canadian Council of Authors and Artists was announced today by John L. Dales, national executive secretary of the United States union. Both organizations have pledged to protect each other's wage scales from "cut-rate competition."

RABAT, Morocco, June 11-- The United States elevated its diplomatic mission in Morocco to the status of an Embassy today and named William J. Porter Counselor and Charge D'Affaires until an Ambassador is appointed. Mr. Porter has been Consul General here.

The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday an expansion of its national scholarship program. The names of the year's winners also were made public.
