Whitey Ford, who had not been sharp in his previous two starts, recovered his edge last night at the sight of the White Sox.

PARIS, June 12--Six leading artists have just accepted commissions for decorating the headquarters building of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization now under construction in Paris.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- Contempt of Congress proceedings were begun against Paul Robeson today as the upshot of a shouting, table-thumping and gavel-banging hearing at the Capitol.

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP)-- Kansas City erupted for six runs in the fifteenth inning to defeat Washington, 9--3, tonight. Enos Slaughter's double and Mike Baxes' single broke a 3-3 tie and the Athletics went on to ...

ATLANTIC CITY, June 12-- Arthur W. Hooper of New York, executive director of the National Association of Electrical Distributors, said today it would become increasingly difficult to channel this nation's expanded production smoothly to the consumer "unless the distribution machine is put in tune with production."

WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) --New construction volume reached a new high of $15,760,000,000 the first five months of 1956, although the pace of residential building slumped sharply from advance forecasts for the year.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 12-- Eleven West Coast insurgents who had fought their president, James C. Petrillo, were disciplined today by the American Federation of Musicians.
WASHINGTON, June 12-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer urged the United States today to take the initiative in new efforts to bring about the reunification of Germany.
Today's new film is "The Proud and Profane," a drama of love and war in the Pacific during World War II, starring William Holden and Deborah Kerr, at the Astor.
PHILADELPHIA, June 12-- The Advertising Federation of America was told today that about $14,700,000,000 would be spent on advertising in 1960, compared with about $9,500,000,000 this year.

Stocks opened strong yesterday, worked higher all day and ended with a burst of strength that carried The New York Times combined average to the best level since May 21. Thus, all the loss suffered last Friday on President Eisenhower's hospitalization has been recovered.
APPARENTLY the old adage, "a new broom sweeps clean," is more than just a saying. According to the National Broom Manufacturers and Allied Industries Association, this common ...
A leading educator scored retailers yesterday for being "negligent" in failing to attract a sufficient number of college graduates to work in retailing.

The decision of the Supreme Court that the present Federal employe security program has been carried far beyond the limits intended by Congress is a judicial way of saying one of the things that lay critics have been saying all along.
GENEVA, June 12--Tunisia, the Sudan and Morocco were admitted to the International Labor Organization today.
WASHINGTON, June 12--Following is the text of the brief digest of findings and recommendations in the report on "The Biological Effects of Atomic Radiation":
Forced labor is the number one issue before the thirty-ninth conference of the International Labor Organization, which has begun in Geneva this week.

Almost all commodity futures closed higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Trading increased in most markets. Cocoa, coffee, cottonseed oil, zinc, copper, rubber, soybean oil, lead, hides and potatoes rose. Price movements for sugar and wool were mixed. No item closed lower in all traded months.
CHICAGO, June 12--President Eisenhower's physical condition has been "propagandized" in a "new science of politicomedicine," Paul M. Butler, the Democratic National Chairman, charged today.
Low-rent housing heads for big-money backing two weeks from today.
WASHINGTON, June 12--A committee of outstanding scientists reported today that atomic radiation, no matter how small the dose, harms not only the person receiving it but also all his descendents.

CHICAGO, June 12--Al Dark booted two grounders and Wes Westrum missed a knuckleball third strike pitch from Hoyt Wilhelm today. All of that added to three unearned runs and the margin of victory for the Cubs over the Giants at Wrigley Field.

Twenty-five million dollars is a small sum when it is set beside seventy-one nations with a total population of two billion souls, more or less. It is not much when it has to be distributed among agencies designed to improve the condition of labor, to promote agriculture, to ...
The cotton futures market moved 2 points (10 cents a bale) off to 4 points (20 cents a bale) up yesterday. Sales on the New York Cotton Exchange were around 25,000 bales.

Orlon will make a major invasion into the men's hosiery field this fall, according to E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., producer of the synthetic fiber. Du Pont reports that more than eleven manufacturers of major branded hosiery lines are making plans to use the fiber.
MOSCOW, June 12--Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia has endorsed the Soviet view that now is not the time for the unification of Germany.

The Standard Oil Company of California plans record capital expenditures this year of more than $350,000,000, T.S. Petersen, president, said yesterday. At a press conference, he said this would exclude the bonuses paid for off-shore leases and the costs of exploring and developing any such lands acquired.

There were stakes-winners in the line-up for the $7,500 race that headed Belmont Park's program yesterday, but they were also-rans. The horse that took first money was the only one that had been racing all season in claiming races.

In the last twenty years New Yorkers have come to expect a steady growth of park and recreation areas without being fully aware of the many problems involved in the increase from 14,000 to nearly 28,000 acres of play and rest space developed under Commissioner Moses.
The country's three largest steel companies are scheduled to start telling the United Steelworkers of America today how large a wage "package" they are prepared to give this year.
The General Precision Equipment Corporation, producers of precision equipment, proposes to round out its line of cameras through the purchase of Graflex, Inc., of Rochester, N.Y.
Management and labor were described yesterday as associates in a reign-of-terror conspiracy to monopolize the $10,000,000-ayear pickle and condiment industry.
HOUSTON, Texas, June 12-- Miss Vale Asche was married to Marion S. Ackerman 3d here tonight in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. John the Divine.

Former Mayor William O'Dwyer charged yesterday that the Government's claim against him for tax deficiencies was motivated by "ulterior political purpose or advantage, particularly in this Presidential year."
TOKYO, Wednesday, June 13 --Moscow has accused the United States of dropping atomic bombs on Japan in World War II for "political" purposes over the objection of the Soviet Government.
BRISTOL, England, June 12 (UP)--Althea Gibson of New York began a bid for her tenth straight European tennis tournament with two straight-set triumphs today in the West of England competition.
MASSENA, N.Y., June 12-- A basis for possible private utility support of state development of Niagara River power came under active study today.

Gerald B. Waldron, a Colorado oil broker, filed a $109,260,000 damage suit in Federal Court yesterday against seven major oil companies. He charged that they frustrated his efforts to sell 15,000,000 metric tons of Iranian oil.

PARIS, June 12--George Orwell, a man of particular genius, wrote in 1946: "In five years it may be as dangerous to praise Stalin as it was to attack him two years ago. But I should not regard this as an advance. Nothing is gained by teaching the parrot a new word."

WASHINGTON, June 12-- President Eisenhower sent from his hospital bed today an appeal to the Senate to restore $600,000,000 to his foreign aid program as it had emerged from the House of Representatives.

ATLANTA, June 12--New York City is a filthy, dirty town in a continual traffic jam and, except for public transportation, segregation is just as strong there as any place in the South, a retiring utility official said here yesterday.
Summer, in one of its less welcome aspects, has cast its shadow before it. A recent shower, one ...

Louis Henry Schroeder, a manufacturer of corrugated paper, died Monday in New England Deaconess Hospital, Boston, after a long illness. He was 63 years old. Mr. Schroeder's home was at 22 Wickham Road, Roslyn Heights, L.I.
WASHINGTON, June 12 (AP) --The scheduled airlines urged the Civil Aeronautics Board today to expand its proposed fare investigation to include all carriers.

Eight Russian church leaders yesterday wound up their series of formal "conversations" with Protestant clergymen in this country. The delegation will depart for Moscow this evening from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

OCEANPORT, N.J., June 12 --Monmouth Park opened its eleventh season today, with the Oceanport Handicap serving as the feature. This six-furlong sprint was run in two divisions, with ten horses competing in each group.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company and its subsidiaries reported yesterday a 21.5 per cent increase in earnings for the six months ended April 30. Sales were 2.4 per cent above those of the corresponding period a year earlier.
FATHER will have his Day soon. But just how much of it he can call his own--to do with as he pleases--remains to be seen.

CHICAGO, June 12--Samuel Cardinal Stritch, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Chicago, pronounced a policy today of helping Puerto Ricans "Integrate themselves religiously, socially and economically" into the life of the city.

Credit John Montagu, fourth Earl of Sandwich, with an assist for Madison Avenue. When National Sandwich Month is celebrated in August, his memory will be honored by the advertising men who have elaborated on his idea of two centuries ago.

WHITE PLAINS, June 12-- Voters authorized long-term bonds today to finance a new senior high school and a new elementary school. It will be a $7,700,000 step in the Board of Education's proposed $10,900,000, five-year educational expansion program.
The Pepsi-Cola Company bought the building at 500 Park Avenue from the city for $2,000,000 at a public auction yesterday. It is on the southwest corner of Fifty-ninth Street.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., June 12 (AP)--United States District Court of Wyoming today granted Standard Oil Company of Indiana an injuction against use of the marketing trade-mark "Sohio" in its fifteen-tate area. The decision denied a crossclaim by Standard Oil Company of Ohio for summary judgment, accounting and damages.

Gertrude and Lester Palmer of Maplewood, N.J., occupy an unusual place in golf. They probably are acqainted with more players in the metropolitan area than any other wife and husband. And there is no question that they have posted the scores of more golfers than any other similar team.

Phelan Beale, retired New York attorney and sportsman, died yesterday in Pass Christian, Miss. He was 75 years old. He went to Pass Christian about two years ago after illness had forced him to retire from the New York law firm of Bouvier Beale.

Ralph Morgan, character actor who had appeared in more than sixty days and a score of films, died on Monday afternoon at his home, 515 East Eighty-ninth Street. Mr. Morgan, who would have been 73 years old July 6, had been retired and ill with a lung ailment for three years.

Richard Stoliker Davis, president of Denman Davis, steel distributors, died on Tuesday in Ottawa while on a fishing trip. He was 60 years old. He had resided for the last several years at Steelway, his estate in Dingmans. Ferry, Pa.
CHICAGO, June 13--With the scars of recent court litigation fully healed, opera will return to Chicago next season.

MILWAUKEE, June 13 (AP)Danny O'Connell's three triples and home runs by Del Crandall and Eddie Mathews sparked a fourteen-hit Milwaukee attack tonight as the Braves beat the Philadelphia Phillies and Robin Roberts. 8-6.

WASHINGTON, June 13-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Secretary of State Dulles challenged the Soviet Union today to prove its professions of peaceful intention by agreeing to the reunification of Germany.
Cotton futures closed barely steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Prices were 5 to 17 points (25 to 85 cents a bale) lower than Tuesday.

ALBANY, June 13--Louis A. Wehle resigned today as state conservation commissioner. However, the controversy over his charges of "gross negligence or sabotage" in the Conservation Department continued unabated.

ALGIERS, June 13--An unspecified number of Arab inspectors of the judicial police force and of the investigation department and one Arab policeman were arrested in Algiers today for complicity with the nationalist rebels.

GULFPORT, Miss., June 13 (UP)--A tropical storm battered 300 miles of the Gulf coast tonight with winds up to sixty miles an hour. A tugboat sank with fifteen men aboard. Nine of the crew were reported picked up and a search was being conducted by the Coast Guard for the others

PORT SAID, Egypt, June 13 --Britain quietly ended today her seventy-four-year occupation of the Suez Canal Zone. She handed over to the Egyptians full responsibility for defending the great East-West shipping lane.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 13 --Harvard's John Simourian belted two 400-foot home runs to beat Yale, 6--4, today on Soldiers Field, in a game called in the last of the eighth because of a thunderstorm.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- The Army got a flag of its own today after seven major wars and 145 campaigns.

CHILDREN are curious. Children are adventurous. Children have a taste for excitement in their play. Even when they are well supplied with safe toys and carefully laid-out playgrounds, their search for something different to do can all too often lure them into danger.
CHICAGO, June 13--"Generous to a fault" might be an aptly descriptive term for the Giants. Yesterday they gave three unearned runs to the Cubs. Today the gift amounted to five tainted tallies.
Dr. Jacob Shatzky of 360 Cabrini Boulevard, a Jewish historian, died yesterday of a cerebral hemorrhage in the Presbyterian Hospital. His age was 61.
MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 13--The rebellious Scarsdale Post of the Westchester County American Legion was censured tonight for attacking the County Legion's Un-American Activities Committee.
Acquisition of the Bay Refining Corporation by the Dow Chemical Company is under consideration.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 13 --The controversy over racial integration in the South will be dramatized in a picture to be titled "The Till Murder Case."

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel B. Webb of 133 East Eightieth Street and Shelburne, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Holly Webb, to Michael Darling, son of Mr. and Mrs. James L.A. Darling of Lancashire Lodge, Warwick, Bermuda.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The current term of the Supreme Court has ended in one of those heated public disputes over its rulings that recur from time to time. And once again the court's harshest critics have been its own dissenting justices who have charged the majority with inferences unsupported by the facts and with assumptions of jurisdiction unwarranted by Constitution or statute.
With their paws stretching from cages, cats latched onto callers yesterday at the BideA-Wee Home Association and meowed for affection.
Puerto Rico's "bootstrap" industrialization program, hitherto concentrated on United States mainland manufacturers, is turning riow to Europe.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- The National Broadcasting Company withdrew its television film camera today from the Senate Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee's hearing on television network practices. No one attending the hearings was in the least sorry.

WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Nine officers will accompany Gen. Nathan F. Twining; Air Force Chief of Staff, on his visit to the Soviet Union. They are technical or tactical specialists. Most are general officers.
Threats of a motormen's strike against all subway lines and a one-day work stoppage of Third Avenue bus employes hung over the city yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 13-- Southern Democratic Senators are being asked to consider a third-party movement if they are dissatisfied with the outcome of the Democratic National Convention. The convention opens Aug. 13 in Chicago.
Atomic radiation is not so easy to measure as a pound of steak or a yard of cloth, as the committee of the National Academy of Sciences pointed out in its report Tuesday in Washington.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) --Henry Willcox, president of a Long Island construction company, testified today he took part in a 1952 "peace" conference in Red China.
ST. LOUIS, June 13 (UP)--General Manager Frank Lane of the St. Louis Cardinals said tonight the New York Giants had made "an attractive offer" of a player trade but "nothing has jelled yet."

MANHASSET, L.I., June 13 --Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Joseph Bowditch of Manhasset and Vineyard Haven. Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Elise Bowditch, to James Gordon Ogden 3d.
Leopold Seyffert of 1 West Sixty-seventh Street, portrait painter, died yesterday in the Bound Brook (N. J.) Hospital. His age was 68.
The departure of eight visiting Soviet clergymen was delayed about four hours last night and early today by a false, anonymous report that a bomb had been placed aboard their plane.

ALBANY, June 13--Following are the texts of the letter of resignation by Louis A. Wehle, State Conservation Commissioner, the letter of acceptance by Governor Harriman and a statement on the resignation by the Republican legislative leaders, Senator Walter J. Mahoney and Speaker Oswald D. Heck of the Assembly:
WASHINGTON, June 13--The Vice President would decide when a stricken President was unable to perform his duties under a bipartisan bill being prepared for Congressional action early next year.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) The Federal Housing Administration reported today that its home improvement loan insurance program slumped last year because of its drive to eliminate shady operators.

HISTORIANS, Steve Allen indicates in "The Funny Men,"* repeat themselves; comedians repeat one another. "I have long maintained," he maintains longingly, "that the hue and cry about new jokes is a personal concern of the critics and is a matter of no interest whatever to the public, who have the capacity of a sieve for remembering funny stories," This may be known as Allen's Law.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP) -The House of Representatives Armed Services Committee recommended, 22 to 1, today that Congress veto the proposed sale of a Government alcohol butadiene plant at Louisville, Ky.
TRENTON, June 13--Had the late Dr. William J. Sweeny better appreciated the inherent pride of the folk in Ireland, ten years of litigation might have been avoided.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan suggested yesterday that the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations investigate the Distillery, Rectifying, Wine and Allied Workers International Union of America. The prosecutor said he believed there might be a shortage of about $100,000 in the union's funds.
BONN, June 13 (AP)--The West German Minister of Economics, Ludwig Erhard, called today for an international conference to straighten out "distorted" rates of foreign exchange.
A major controversy has developed in educational circles over admission policies of city high schools, and about 1,100 pupils are innocently involved.
"BOY In a Cage" by Paul Monash brought an almost documentary quality to the "Kraft Television Theatre" last night on the National Broadcasting Company network.

Cocoa prices soared as much as the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit yesterday" on the New York Cocoa Exchange. The volume, 506 lots; was the third largest of the year. Prices closed at the highs of the day. Final quotations were up 89 to 100 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). The deferred options were strongest.
BRISTOL, England, June 13 (AP)--Althea Gibson gained the semi-finals of the West of England lawn tennis championships today by scoring her fourth victory of the tournament.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- President Eisenhower spent thirty minutes at work today as his physicians reported that his recovery continued to be "satisfactory."

WASHINGTON, June 13--The Administration is seeking legislative authority to use $22,000,000 in local currencies of a dozen countries to promote scientific, cultural and educational activities in those countries.
It is against all the best tradition to speak of them, even softly, as those miserable birds, Habit
Contracts for the construction of a $6,000,000 Medical Research Center at the Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton, L.I., were awarded yesterday.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 13--Craig Wood was telling the story of his repeated frustrations in the United States Open. "Then one day I dropped a razor blade," he recounted wryly. "When I bent down to pick it up, I couldn't straighten my back. Fearful that I wouldn't even last through the 1941 Open, I played restrainedly, well within myself. And that's how I won the Big One."

CHICAGO, June 13--Data indicating that heredity plays an important role in the development of peptic ulcer, cancer of the stomach and pernicious anemia were presented today at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.
Competition of city and state governments to attract new enterprises, providing jobs and incomes, is producing a trend in advertising. Such linage is gaining steadily.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) --Air Force testimony that it plans a fleet of 600 B-52 intercontinental jet bombers by 1959 was released today by a Senate subcommittee.
Miss Emma Mills of 360 Central Park West, lecturer and critic, died yesterday in French Hospital after a short illness. Her age was 80.

Plans for a $750,000 medical and dental clinic for Brooklyn's 15,000 longshoremen and their families were interrupted yesterday. The New York Shipping Association recommended that its members take no action on requests for loans to help finance the project.

OLD WESTBURY, L.I, June 13--The first of the 1956 debutantes to be presented to society in the Long Island "little season" will be Miss Gail Whitney, daughter of Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney and Mrs. Josiah Marvel of Wilmington, Del. Miss Whitney, who was graduated this
William T. Moore, president of the Moore-McCormack Lines, has been elected chairman of the Committee of American Steamship Lines.

John F. Curry, former head of Tammany Hall, and Mrs. Curry are observing their fiftieth wedding anniversary today. The couple yesterday looked forward to the observance in their cool, spacious apartment at Fifth Avenue and Eighty-second Street.
Two items in this newspaper yesterday shed some interesting light on differences today between the Soviet Union and its Eastern European satellites.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)-- Kansas City vacated the American League basement with a twenty-one-hit barrage against four Washington pitchers today. Tim Thompson and Vic Power got five hits apiece as the Athletics mauled the Senators, 13--4.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., June 13-- The Suffolk County Bar Association will be asked on Monday to condemn the issuance by law enforcement officials of statements that tend to impede a fair trial for suspected wrongdoers.
Demands by Czechoslovak university students for more democracy were reported yesterday to be among the most sweeping to be submitted to a Communist government in recent years.
Refinancing was arranged in connection with the sale of an East Side property yesterday.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 13--The equestrian British team lengthened its lead in the Olympic three-day trial today and after a grueling test of endurance appeared a certain gold medal winner.

Nature took a hand a week ago in the controversy over development of more electric power from Niagara Falls when a series of rock slides wiped out two-thirds of a private utility's generating plant at the Falls.

WASHINGTON, June 13-- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended June 6:

WESTFIELD, Mass., June 13 Former Gov. Joseph Buell Ely of Massachusetts died today at his home here. His age was 75. Mr. Ely, former Democratic leader, served as Governor from 1930 through 1934, He underwent in operation for a brain tumor Dec. 17 at the New England Deaconess Hospital, Boston.

WASHINGTON, June 13-The House of Representatives passed today a bill to initiate a ten-year, $500,000,000 program to combat water pollution, largely through Government financial grants to municipalities.
LIMA, Peru, June 13--A dark horse is attracting wide attention in the campaign for Peru's Presidential election Sunday. He is Fernando Belaunde Terry, a Texas-educated architect.
LONDON, June 13--Britain is gradually putting together a major addition to the West's strategic deterrent force, a force long composed almost exclusively of American planes.
BOSTON, June 13--The Government dropped today the prosecution of Dr. Wendell H. Furry of Harvard University on indictments charging contempt of the United States Senate.

LONDON, June 13--Prime Minister Eden revealed today that the United States Government had backed the British offer of self-government to Cyprus and had done its "best" to win Archbishop Makarios' acceptance.
WESTPORT, Conn., June 13-- Marie Abrams Lawson, writer and illustrator, died today at Norwalk Hospital after a brief illness. She was 62 years old.
"Man Against Crime" is returning to the scene. The private detective series, in which Ralph Bellamy once enjoyed a long run on television, will be revived as a summer show starring Frank Lovejoy.

PURCHASE, N. Y., June 13-- David L. Yunich, 39-year-old president of L. Bamberger Co., shot an 85 to take the retailers' first low-gross prize in the twenty-seventh New York City Newspaper--Retail Dry Goods Association golf tournament at the Century Country Club today.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)-- Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. announced today return of a criminal indictment against the Rumanian-American Publishing Association of Detroit, Mich., and nine of its present and former officers.
NEW HAVEN, June 13--It was ladies day today at Yale as the seventh annual June conference on "Women in the Community" got under way.
SINGAPORE, June 13--The principal problem faced by the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization has been pointed up by the meeting of the military staff planners here.
Vermont will open bids June 21 on $7,632,000 of various purpose bonds dated July 1, 1956, and due on July 1 from 1957 to 1966.
A builder of many notable public works advised a group of budding engineers yesterday to learn "to read and write simple Anglo-Saxon."

Middle South Utilities, Inc., expects earnings this year to rise more than 10 per cent, Edgar H. Dixon, president, told the annual meeting yesterday at the company's headquarters, 2 Rector Street. He predicted that the system's electric load over the next few years would grow at a rate of 8 per cent compounded annually.
Four banks in the Detroit area plan to merge, it was reported yesterday. They are the Detroit Bank, Detroit Wabeek Bank and Trust Company, Birmingham National Bank and the Ferndale National Bank.
Sponsors of the Lincoln Square redevelopment will pay at least $2,500,000 to help 6,000 families now living in the eighteen-block area to find suitable new homes, Robert Moses promised yesterday.
BOSTON, June 13 (AP)--Boston and Cleveland struggled for nearly four hours to an 8-8 tie before rain ended play.

BONN, Germany, June 13-- The Social Democratic party made known today the draft of its foreign policy program, with which it hopes to overthrow Chancellor Konrad Adenauer in the general election next year.

mayor Wagner swore 372 recruits into the Police Department yesterday and addressed 570 men who were being graduated by the Police Academy. The ceremonies, at Lewisohn Stadium, were attended by 3,000 persons.

Stocks advanced yesterday for the third day, but a good deal of the steam evaporated. Prices closed with only moderate gains on quiet trading. The gains ranged from 1 to 3 points. There were a fair number of losers.
City College conferred baccalaureate and master's degrees last night on 2,671 students at its 110th commencement exercises. Eighteen thousand persons attended the ceremonies in Lewisohn Stadium.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, Thursday, June 14 (AP)-- The Dutch Government shied away yesterday from a dispute over a faith healer's influence on Queen Juliana. But most of the Dutch press printed the story for the first time today.

Eight directors of Bellanca Corporation met in New York yesterday and issued a statement that recent gyrations of the company's stock had not affected its basic soundness. The corporation, they said, would continue operations as in the past.
General Electric has circulated a bulletin among its supervisors and executives urging business men to embark on a direct political action campaign.
Strontium 90, an element with a chemical half-life of about twenty-eight years, will shape the future of generations yet unborn. It also has become a factor in political and military policy-making.

PARIS, June 13--Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress and of the Jewish Agency for Palestine, charged today that Moroccan leaders had violated assurances to permit mass emigration of Jews from Morocco.

Preferred stock of the Boston Edison Company, for the first time in its seventy-year history, is going on the market today. A syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation is offering 180,000 shares of 4.25 per cent cumulative preferred, par value $100, at $101.625 a share.

BALTIMORE, June 13 (UP)-- Billy Loes made a sensational debut as an American League starter today, but Charley Maxwell's two-run ninth-inning homer off a relief pitcher, George Zuverink, gave the Detroit Tigers a 2-0 victory over the Baltimore Orioles.

The six little children who played unnoticed by their elders in an excavation in Brooklyn Tuesday night until a sudden avalanche of sand and rock crushed them to death received a great deal of attention yesterday.

James R. Hoffa, powerful Midwest teamster leader, has been subpoenaed to appear here June 26 before the special Federal grand jury investigating racketeering in the trucking and garment industries. The announcement was made yesterday by United States Attorney Paul W. Williams.
Following are the texts of citations for honorary degrees yesterday at the Fordham University commencement:
WASHINGTON, June 13--The Senate Democratic and Republican leaders warned the Eisenhower Administration today that only its sustained and urgent exertions could win the foreign aid fight.
Leonard Sillman's "New Faces of 1956" will be introduced to Broadway first-nighters this evening at 7:45 at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

Apparently no one knows railroading like the railroads. That was demonstrated once again yesterday when the Pennsylvania, Railroad unveiled for newsmen on its PhiladelphiaNewark main line a new milliondollar lightweight passenger train, Called the Keystone, the
The public bond market put up another $50,000,000 yesterday for California's thirty-five-yearold program of acquiring homes and farms for resale on easy credit terms to war veterans.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The coming retirement of an Army general and the imminent transfer of three Army colonels was linked by reports tonight to the recent dispute over Army and Air Forces roles and missions.
WASHINGTON, "June 13Frank Stanton, president of the Columbia Broadcasting Syster, said today a network either had to maintain control ever its programming or turn the medium over to advertisers.
WASHINGTON, June 13--Labor and capital in the soft coal industry have formed a $50,000,000 shipping corporation to speed their product to a growing European market.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 13-- James C. Petrillo suggested strongly here today that he might back President Eisenhower for re-election.

Yesterday was the hottest day of the year here. More heat was predicted for today. At the Battery, the mercury rose to 89.2 degrees at 3:30 P. M., but dropped back to an even 89 twenty minutes later. The previous high for the year was 87.6 degrees, registered just a month ago.

A decline of 461,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks in the week ended last Friday was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. Total supplies on Friday were 184,409,000 barrels, compared with 184,870,000 a week earlier and 166,233,000 a year ago.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- Following is the text of the communiqu issued by Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany and Secretary of State Dulles at the end of their talks.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP)-- Rebellious "Young Turk" Democrats on the House Labor Committee failed today in efforts to win immediate consideration of Taft-Hartley law revision and extension of minimum wage coverage.
WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) -The pink footed goose, long thought of as a two-egg mother, actually lays four eggs. Sometimes more, even as many as seven.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (AP) --Three major railroads today entered objections to the pending proposal of the Union Pacific Railroad to acquire control of the Spokane International Railroad, which operates between the western Canadian provinces and the United States Pacific Coast.

CHICAGO, June 13--Hot weather, with only a few scattered showers reported, stirred up an early bullish sentiment in wheat, coarse grain and soybeans, with substantial advances in all pits except for old crop corn futures.
IN "Shangri-La," which opened at the Winter Garden last evening, Broadway has given everything it has in an effort to escape this too solid earth.
"I'M firmer than I look," says Freda Rubenstein. A pleas antly mild, soft-spoken young woman, Miss Rubenstein is advertising manager of Jay Thorpe.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13"Waging peace depends upon being strong," Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. told the 2,084 graduates today at the University of Pennsylvania's 200th commencement.
LOON BAY LODGE, N. B., June 13--This was the kind of day on a beautiful river that makes people want to be forest rangers, guides, lumbermen or rich.

COLUMBIA, S. C., June 13 (UP).--A Federal District Judge dismissed today for the second time a suit against a segregated bus system. He held that a higher court did not make retroactive its ruling that segregated seating was illegal.
Governor Harriman declared last night that "there are certain people in our country who are trafficking" with the Communists.

The spell the Yankees had exercised over the White Sox was broken yesterday. Hammering five members of Casey Stengel's wobbly pitching staff for ten hits, the Chicagoans whipped the Bombers, 7-5, for the first time in seven 1956 tries.

SYRACUSE, June 13 (UP)-- Joey Giambra of Buffalo spoiled John L. Sullivan's farewell United States appearance tonight with counter left hooks and right leads to gain his second straight unanimous decision over the former British middleweight champion in their return ten-round bout.
WASHINGTON, June 13--The United States is reviewing its position with regard to the Korean truce.

WASHINGTON, June 13--The Defense Department announced tonight that the American National Red Cross would offer to re-employ Irving I. August, a Korean war veteran who was forced out of a Red Cross job after the Army declared him a security risk."

GLEN COVE, L.I., June 13Mrs. Norman Woolworth of the Wee Burn Country Club, Darien, Conn., shot her second 76 today to take the lead in the Women's Eastern Golf Association's 54hole medal play amateur championship.
PHILADELPHIA, June 13-- Howard Pyle, deputy assistant to President Eisenhower, told the Advertising Federation of America today that its members were key troops in the cold war for men's minds.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Thursday, June 14--The Labor party has won a surprising victory in the Dutch general elections.

CHINESE restaurateurs rely on specially staffed, special ly equipped kitchens. Their cooks, as skilled in cutting food as a dressmaker in cutting cloth, chop ingredients with murderous cleavers. They heat them in round-bottomed utensils of simple esthetic design, called wocks, that fit into the tops of ranges built for the purpose.

Hunter College will confer 1,653 degrees at its 109th commencement today on its Bronx campus at Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue. Dr. George N. Shuster, president of the college, will preside. The exercises will begin at 5 P.M.

CANNES, France, June 13 (UP) --Officials of twelve airlines flying the North Atlantic were reported today to have agreed to cut first-class fares. They also plan to start a low-rate "thirdclass" trans-Atlantic service, it was reported.

GENEVA, June 13--The International Labor Conference's committee on forced labor completed today general discussion looking toward adoption of a new international instrument to condemn and outlaw forced labor wherever it exists.
The chances for enactment this year of basic Eisenhower Administration trade measures were all but written off yesterday by leaders of a major importers' group.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., June 13 -As the 162 eligible golfers assembled for tomorrow's start of the United States Open championship, they appeared to be in accord on one matter. That pertained to the "fairness' of the Oak Hill Country Club course, where the competition will be held.
A gradual improvement in business conditions as the year progresses was predicted yesterday by Clarence G. Michalis, president of the Savings Banks Association of New York State.
TRUMPETER James Caesar Petrillo, who sounded a fanfare for President Eisenhower yesterday, two years ago played a duet with pianist Harry S. Truman.
WASHINGTON, June 13-- United State officials confirmed today Prime Minister Eden's account of the Cyprus negotiations, but added some details that he had left out.
PARIS, June 13--The French Cabinet approved today a farreaching shuffle of diplomats.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 18 --Warner Brothers announced today that Ed Sullivan had arranged to have "The John Huston Story" as his entire July 1 television show. Listed as appearing live, in addition to the director, are Gregory Peck, Jose Ferrer, Orson Welles, Edward G. Robinson and Vincent Price.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., June 13--Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold pinpointed today the Middle East as the area most lacking in United Nations assistance in the economic and social fields.

WASHINGTON, June 13 (UP)--The Government received a Congressional go-ahead today to construct eleven new Federal buildings and post offices in eight states. Most costly project was a $45,300,000 courthouse and Federal building at San Francisco.
Two Connecticut girls made their debuts last night and a New York girl, a debutante of the 1955-56 season, was honored at a dance.
WASHINGTON, June 13 -- Ezra Taft Benson denied today that he had reversed himself in deciding to grant soil-bank payments to farmers for 1956 crops by drought or natural causes.

The fundamental principles of American foreign policy have been stated so often in word and deed as to make it clear that the only one aim we pursue is a just and lasting peace in an atmosphere of expanding freedom. But the application of these principles in a complex and constantly changing world is a task requiring the highest type

BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 13--The official newspaper of the Yugoslav Communist League charged in Belgrade today that "reactionary American circles" had revived the case of Milovan Djilas to reopen a campaign against Yugoslavia.
The country's three biggest steel producers offered higher wages, supplementary unemployment benefits and other major contract improvements to their 350,000 union employes yesterday.

The immediate and larger effects of atomic explosions on communities have been dwelt upon in countless monographs and articles, but what we are apt to regard as the "minor" effects have received less attention. What we have needed is a survey of what our new mastery of atomic energy means for the future of mankind.

RYE, N. Y., June 13--Franklin (Fitz) Clement, the plus-2 handicap player from Lake Forest, Ill., today increased his lead in the fifty-second annual United States Seniors' Golf Association championship at the Apawamis Club. He carded a 1under-par 71 for a two-round total of 144.
PARIS, June 13--The French Government declined today to react to an offer by Ferhat Abbas, Algerian Nationalist, to negotiate peace in Algeria in return for a promise of selfgovernment.

Long before the days of Columbus, Magellan, Cabot and Vespucci, tinkers and inventors tried to make boats go better and faster. Even the Polynesian aborigines experimented with their tree-trunk creations.
C. V. Whitney's entry of Snow White and Defilade finished one, two in the $38,920 National Stallion Stakes, filly division, at Belmont Park yesterday.

Former Mayor William O'Dwyer's assets amounted to $57,096 just before he resigned his city post Sept. 2, 1950, according to a statement disclosed yesterday. Of this, $42,000 represented pension credits.

The Sperry Rand Corporation and its predecessor companies in the year ended March 31 increased earnings 4 per cent and sales 1.6 per cent over the previous year. The company also announced it will file a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering 2,570,846 new shares to be offered by subscription to common stockholders.
Fordham University held its 111th annual commencement on the Bronx campus yesterday. Graduate and undergraduate degress were conferred on 1,347 candidates from seven schools.

The Senate Judiciary Committee has chosen to show its displeasure with the Supreme Court by approving a bill that could only cause untold legal chaos in the area of Federal-state legislation. Senators Kefauver and Langer--one liberal

LONDON, June 13--The stock markets extended their rally today though early gains were not fully held. The improved figures for foreign trade in May and Wall Street's firmness yesterday encouraged a little more demand and prices were sensitive.

Commodity futures closed irregularly yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cottonseed oil and soybean oil were active but most other markets were dull. Coffee, zinc, rubber, and wool rose; cottonseed oil, soybean oil, cocoa and sugar declined and price movements for potatoes, hides and conner were mixed.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., June 14 --Providence is playing host to an orchestral behive.
The attention of two more official agencies was drawn yesterday to the excavation in which six children died when a dirt wall collapsed on them while they were digging Tuesday evening.

With the warm weather the horse carriages based along the edge of Central Park at Fif ty-ninth Street are doing their seasonal thriving business. They amble along the southern drives of the park, providing their tourist-customers with a nostalgic hint of a day that is no more.

The Pierce Governor Company of Anderson, Ind., announced yesterday that its connection with the business empire of Sydney L. Albert, Akron financier, had ended, and with no adverse effect on its prospects.
The Stadium Symphony Orchestra will be welcomed to the Harlem community tomorrow afternoon by the Women's Cul tural Division of the Truman Democratic Club, Inc.

New York took the sudden subway strike in stride yes terday. There was confusion, complaint and congestion. But quick and efficient police action eased the dangerous accumu lation of crowds at key terminals.

The American Cyanamid Company announced plans yesterday for large-scale commercial production of a new acrylic textile fiber to be trademarked Creslan. The step marks the company's entry into synthetic fiber production.

CHICAGO, June 14--The long-rumored big Giant trade materialized today, on the eve of the June 15 deadline. It proved to be a whopping four-for-four transaction with the Cardinals, involving three "name" players.
Pickets will march in front of City Hall today to demand better treatment of slum dwellers whose homes are demolished to make way for urban redevelopment.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 --The "Dan McGarry and his Mouse Kitty" stories, which have been appearing in This Week magazine since 1940, will be made into a filmed television series.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., June 14--Kathryn Ekirch of Bonnie Briar led a field of sixty-two players by carding 41, 42--83 over Winged Foot's East Course in the one-day tournament of the Women's Westchester-Fairfield Golf Association today.

RABAT, Morocco, June 14-- Fifteen Israeli citizens connected with Jewish agencies in Morocco are understood to have received expulsion orders tonight. The action followed the Government's suppression of Cadima, the organization that sponsors emigra tion to Israel.

Two hold-up men took $20,000 in cash yesterday from Benjamin Leiken, a contractor, in front of his home at 1384 East Twenty-second Street in the Nottingham district of Flatbush. A month ago Mr. Leiken lost $7,500 in cash, on the same spot, in the same way.
Yesterday's heat pushed all other hot days this year into the shade. It reached 96.1 degrees at 1:30 P.M.
AKRON, Ohio, June 14. (AP)-- Mr. Albert held closed-door conferences here today in attempts to untangle his financial affairs, affecting about seventy companies.
GLEN COVE L.I., June 14-- Mrs. Norman Woolworth of the Wee Burn Country Club won the Women's Eastern Golf Association's fiftieth anniversary championship today.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, June 14-- The possibility of a pre-election revolt in Bolivia is said to have diminished greatly as a result of the punitive action taken in Argentina against Peronist rebels this week.

A report that marketing, held back by the easy selling days of World War II and the shortage years that followed, has "more than made up the lag" was presented yesterday by Dr. Henry Bund, vice president of the Research Institute of America, and his associate, James Carroll.
Bob Grim, the Yankees' only undefeated pitcher (4--0), yesterday went all the way for the first time in a year.

A denial that "reactionary American circles" were using the case of Milovan Djilas, former Vice President of, Yugoslavia, to attack Yugoslavia was voiced yesterday by the American Committee for Cultural Freedom.

Gordon L. Edwards of 9 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn, who retired six years ago as vice president and treasurer of the United States Steel Corporation, died yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn.
Numerous delays were reported by the major railroads last evening as a result of the transit strike.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Robert W. Sarnoff, president of the National Broadcasting Company, revealed today that his network made a cumulative profit of only $2,315,000 in its nine years of operation between 1947 and 1955.
TOKYO, June 14--Japan is about to send a seagoing trade fair on a tour of Asian ports as part of her campaign to become the workshop and arsenal of the East, Besides ...
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 14--"I just couldn't hit a long enough ball," said Bob Rosburg, "so I quit."
ST. LOUIS, June 14 (AP)--Red Schoendienst, who has been with the Cardinals for twelve seasons, took the news of his trade to the Giants stoically.

Highways leading into the city from the suburbs were sweltering traffic traps yesterday. Normal congestion was increased by thousands of extra cars. Most of them brought into Manhattan night workers who were unable to follow their usual pattern of riding the sub ways.

CHICAGO, June 14--Forecasts for cooler weather with scattered showers in the principal grain areas caused pressure on wheat, corn, oats and new-crop soybean futures in early trading today on the Board of Trade. There was active buying of wheat on the declines. This grain later became strong.
BOGOTA, Colombia, June 14 (UP)--Hernando Santos Castillo chief editor of the liberal opposition newspaper Intermedio was indicted today on charges of disrespect of President" Gustavo Rojas Pinella.
LONDON, June 14--The British Government announced today it was willing in principle to permit the Texas Company to buy the British-owned Trinidad Oil Company.

The merger agreement between W.R. Grace Co. and the Cosden Petroleum Corporation has been terminated, according to a joint announcement yesterday by J. Peter Grace, president of W.R. Grace Co., and Raymond L. Tollett, president of Cosden Petroleum.
The daily index of wholesale commodity prices of the Bureau of Labor Statistics was 89 on Wednesday, unchanged from Tuesday. The figure for June 15, 1955, was 90.6.

With volume down to 1,670,000 shares from 1,760,000 on Wednesday, the stock market put on an inconclusive performance yesterday. It was the narrowest session since Nov. 11, for only 1,099 issues were traded. Of these, 481 fell and 367 rose, but The New York Times average

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, June 14 (AP)--Petrus Kastenman, a Swedish cavalry lieutenant who almost wasn't picked for the equestrian Olympics, and a team of three British riders today won the first gold medals at the 1956 Games.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- Vice President Richard M. Nixon said today that Soviet leaders could prove the sincerity of their "changed attitude" by releasing individuals from slave labor camps.

Nine hundred families will be housed in an apartment development planned near Fairmount Park in Philadelphia at a cost of about $15,000,000. The project will have three interconnected buildings, each twenty stories high and occupying a site at the head of Benjamin Franklin Parkway.
WASHINGTON; June 14-- John Stewart Service lost a round today in his long fight for reinstatement in the diplomatic service.
Loans to business by leading New York City banks rose $145,000,000 in the week ended last Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

It will be three months next week since President Eisenhower sent his last foreign aid message to Congress. This document had been delayed two weeks while certain features in it were carefully studied. The President was especially concerned with what he and his advisers took to be the need for commitments extending over a period of years.

When posterity thumbs through the mass of colorful material about New York that has been gathered by the New-York Historical Society, it will come across Giuseppe Ravita, the fiddler of Fifty-seventh Street.

NEWPORT, R.I., Jne 14-- When Thomas Fleming Day proposed and then organized the first yacht race from Gravesend Bay, N.Y., to Bermuda in 1906, some hard things were said about his sanity. Starting Saturday, the ocean between here and Bermuda will be cluttered with medium to small sailing vessels.

The Very , Rev. Dr. Israel Brodie, Chief Rabbi of the British Commonwealth, emphasized last night that the close association of the United States and Great Britain constituted "a hopeful buttress to the structure of a decent world to which we aspire."
Chancellor Konrad Adenauer was told yesterday by Governor Harriman that a national Democratic administration would continue to work for German unity.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Friday, June 15 (AP)--Prime Minister S. W.R.D. Bandaranaike yesterday ordered emergency supplies airlifted to an area of Ceylon that has been ravaged by riots.
The American Broadcasting company radio network, which begins a two-and-a-half-hour country music show on July 1, plans to add a two-hour program of mood music from 10 P.M. to midnight.
Cotton futures yesterday closed unchanged to 5 points (25 cents a bale) off. Volume on the New York Cotton Exchange was estimated at about 35.000 bales.
CHICAGO, June 14(AP)-- Continental Can Company today opened what it described as the largest and most advanced research and engineering laboratory in the canmaking industry.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., June 14 --Miss Laura Spelman Rockefeller and James Herbert Case 3d were married here this afternoon in the Union Church, Pocantico Hills. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert McCracken, who was assisted by the Rev. Richard Hanson.
A sudden wildcat strike tied up a large part of New York's subway system during the evening rush hour yesterday, hut was called off last night.
RABAT, Morocco, June 14-- The headquarters of the United States Seventeenth Air Force will be moved during the summer atom Rabat to Tripoli, Libya.
BONN, Germany, June 14-- West Germany is seriously short in scientific manpower and doing very little to fill the vacuum, according to Dr. Otto Hahn, a leading scientist.

After seventy-four years of standing guard, Great Britain has taken the last of her troops from the Suez Canal Zone and base. This departure from a long-held traditional position has more importance from the symbolic standpoint than it has in military realities.
Two narcotics cases over which General Sessions Judge Jacob Gould Schurman and District Attorney Frank S. Hogan had clashed were settled yesterday.

The United Seaman's Service provided lodgings for 3,449 America seamen and served 287,454 meals at its nine centers in various parts of the world last year. This was reported yesterday at the organization's fourteenth annual meeting in Whitehall Club.
The subway strike came and went yesterday without use of the Condon-Wadlin Act. If the Transit Authority had invoked that law, the motormen would have been subject to automatic dismissal.

ST. CROIX, N.B., June 14-- Chiputneticook is a name that can be pronounced but it has to be done from memory and that seems hardly worth the trouble. Visitors here have been known to finesse the name with delicate tact by referring to "them lakes that separate Canada and the U.S."
Four thousand passengers on three IND trains to Brooklyn were stranded underground in dark, hot cars last night when an unidentified person threw the power switch near the Church Avenue Station.
A TRIM mother of four with an eye for color and line, Mrs. J. Floreine Doss, will go home to Portland, Ore., richer by $25,000, top prize in the Singer Sewing Machine Company's sewing contest.
A wink foiled an attempted bank robbery in Queens yesterday.

LONDON, June 14--Interest in stock markets here today was focused on Trinidad Oil Company shares, which jumped 3s 9d (52 cents) in active dealing on the announcement that the Government would sanction sale of Trinidad to the Texas Company.

WESTBURY, L.I., June 14-- New York City's subway strike affected the goings-on in and around this quiet Nassau County village tonight as officials of Roosevelt Raceway staged the eleventh edition of the $25,000 American Trotting Championship.

NEWARK, June 14--Shoplifters may soon become the most outspoken critics of television. The impetus for such a development has been provided by L. Bamberger Co. The department store put into operation today a closed-circuit television hook-up that is being used to seek out shoplifters.

HEWLETT, L.I., June 14-- Mr. and Mrs. Daniel L. Monroe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Coe Monroe, to John Matthew Emery 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harvey C. Emery of Princeton, N.J.

Hudson County, N.J., received bids yesterday on $5,060,000 of building and nursing home bonds due serially on Aug. 1 from 1957 to 1981. The best bid was a price of 100.07063 for obligations bearing 2 per cent interest. This was offered by a syndicate headed by Chase Manhattan Bank. Subject to award, the bonds were reoffered at prices to yield 2 to 2.75 per cent.
LONDON, June 14--Archbishop Makarios, exiled spokesman for Cypriote independence, has declared that the issue of the island's future can be solved only by negotiation.
MILWAUKEE, June 14--The Giants flew home with a threegame losing streak after dropping tonight's contest, 5--2, to the Braves before 23,188 fans at County Stadium.

A five-story and basement building on lot 36 by 77 feet at 84-86 Pearl Street in the Hanlover Square area has been purchased by W.R. Grace Co., international chemical manufacturing, industrial and trading concern which is expanding its lower Manhattan realty holdings.

"A Republican Looks at His Party," by Under Secretary of Labor Arthur Larson, will be published July 11 by Harper. The purpose of the book is to examine the actions and objectives of the Eisenhower Admin istration "to see what kind of pattern of political philosophy they make." Harper is also the publisher of Dean Acheson's "A Democrat Looks at His Party."

The President had a very comfortable night. He had a good night's sleep. His temperature is 99, pulse 88, blood pressure 118 over 70, his respiration is 20--all of which indicate a normal reaction at this time.
St. James Protestant Episcopal Church was the scene here yesterday afternoon of the marriage of Miss Judith Rodel Coste to Gilbert Whipple Chapman Jr.

A seven-Sear no-strike contract was signed yesterday by four locals of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters and officials of the Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York, Inc. It covers 1,500 drivers and plant workers in the area.
ST. LOUIS, June 14--Two officials of the Truman Administration, Matthew J. Connelly and T. Lamar Caudle, were convicted by a Federal jury today of having conspired to help an income tax dodger.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., June 14 --Senator John F. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, returned today to Harvard University, his alma mater, with a plea for increased cooperation between scholars and politicians.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- President Eisenhower received Dr. Konrad Adenauer, the West German Chancellor, today and discussed with him the issue of German reunification.

BRISTOL, England, June 14 (AP)--Althea Gibson of New York, displaying the crushing tennis game that has gained nine European tournament victories this spring, defeated Australia's Mrs. Jennifer Hoad, 6--4, 7--5, in the West of England women's singles today.
The North Harlem (Delano Village) urban redevelopment will receive its first mortgage installment next week and expects to have 780 apartments ready for occupancy next spring.
Some Wall Street brokers were griping yesterday--and not solely about the weather.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 14-- A group of responsible Greek Cypriotes is now willing to "study secretly" any draft constitution for Cyprus proposed by Britain and pass it on with recommendations to the exiled Archbishop Makarios.

UNEASINESS stirred two days ago by the scientists' report on radioactivity might be eased a bit if folk in town knew that the Fire Department had been turning out a corps of monitors to detect danger spots.
A convention of African students here heard Chester Bowles, former United States Ambassador to India, urge an expansion of American economic aid to African countries yesterday.
GREENWICH, Conn., June 14 --Upsets marked the quarterfinal round of the fortieth Eastern Interscholastic Golf Association championship tournament at Greenwich Country Club today.
American families of high income spend more money proportionately for clothing, transportation, recreation and house furnishings than do low-income groups.
Phone calls into the Transit Authority offices in Brooklyn reached 8,000 an hour yesterday afternoon and early last night as the public tried to keep up with the spreading walkout of subway motormen.
LIMA, Peru, June 14--The Apristas, possibly the deciding factor in the Presidential election Sunday, returned to the streets tonight in mass for the first time in eight years.

Recognition for a high level of safety in sea-going operations was given the United States Lines yesterday by the Marine Section of the National Safety Council. The company won first prize for 1955 in the annual competition among American-flag cargo and passenger ship lines. Its record was 5.45 lost-time accidents a million man-hours.
Pressure on reserves of member banks ,of the Federal Reserve continued to ease in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.

OUR two books for today are about different wars and different aspects of war; but they are alike to the extent that both are short and both are extremely well written. One is a powerful and pathetic narrative of the horrors of war as seen by a 15-year-old girl, "I Am Fifteen and I Don't Want to Die,"* by Christine Arnothy.
The long-simmering controversy over "displaced pupils" in the city high schools burst into the open yesterday.

It would provide that:

WASHINGTON, June 14-- James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, advised reporters today to take the word of "the doctors on the case" when questions were raised about the possibility of a recurrence of ileitis in President Eisenhower.

Words can be used either to convey thoughts or to conceal them. In the latter case our language has the expressive phrase "double talk" to express the situation. It is as masters of double talk that the Soviet leaders appear on the world arena.

The regional office of the Securities and Exchange Commission will add fifteen new employes to its staff of 100 and move to new headquarters at 225 Broadway, J. Sinclair Armstrong chairman, said yesterday. The old headquarters are at 42 Broadway. Both the move and staff enlargement would take place on July 2.
WASHINGTON, June, 14--A Texas oilman testified today that an industry committee had spent $1,753,513 to "educate the public" on what it termed the dangers of Federal regulation of natural gas.
ROME, June 14--Foreign Minister--Gaetano Martino pledged today Italy's "immutable faithfulness to the principles of demperatic policy, of which the Atlantic pact is the expression and instrument."
MADRID, June 12--The Spanish Government feels that the United States is not giving it enough military and economic aid. That, of course, is not new.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) --Trevor Gardner, former Air Force research chief, said today that the Administration's "austere" military budget "will guarantee us the second best air force" iii the world.
A new plan to modernize the West Side IRT subway and speed its service was announced yesterday.

VICTOR BORGE provided a cool finish toy a hot day by proving last night that you can't beat humor for getting laughs on television. Armed with only a piano and, for one interlude, a prop consisting of a forty-three-man orchestra, he expertly maintained a high level of risibility for an hour on the Columbia Broadcasting System.
BUENOS AIRES, June 14-- A gang armed with machine guns today seized former Gen. Raul Tanco, the fugitive rebel leader, and six others from asylum in the Haitian Ambassador's residence.
The American railroad industry has drawn a kind of Iron Curtain around itself, according to Robert R. Young, chairman of the New York Central Railroad.

RYE, N.Y., June 14--Unless Thomas C. Robbins of Winged Foot, Theodore S. Stacy of Binghamton or James Packerman of Princeton, N.J., can shoot a 70 tomorrow, or other contenders can do even better, ...
Hunter College conferred degrees on 1,642 graduates last evening, one of the largest classes in its history. More than 5,000 attended the exercises held on the Bronx campus.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- Britain will profit from the pioneer experience of the United States in atomic-powered submarine construction, thanks to a new agreement announced today.

Yesterday's short-lived strike of numerous subway motormen was a violation of state law. It was a strike of civil service employes against the New York City Transit Authority, and thus within the explicit terms of the Condon-Wadlin law enacted in March, 1947, a strike against government and the people as employer.
WASHINGTON, June 14--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today an addition of $600,000,000 to the foreign aid program as it had come from the House of Representatives.
New Yorkers have gone through innumerable subway strikes in the last fifty-one years. They have been both formal and wildcat, including two that lasted as long as three weeks in 1916 and 1926.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 14 (Reuters)--Queen Juliana today began consultations with Parliamentary leaders on the formation of a new Government following national elections yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, June 13-- Western diplomatic circles in the Middle East are afraid the Soviet Union is preparing to come out in full support of the Arab states against Israel and against the Western powers.

Eddie Arcaro made 111 pounds yesterday as he won the feature seventh race aboard Peignoir at Belmont Park.

CHICAGO, June 14--The development of an effective vaccine against two recently discovered viruses that produce acute illness of the upper respiratory tract was announced today at the annual meeting of the American Medical Association.

The attitude of Actors Equity concerning the employment of foreign performers in this country is hampering the activities of Robert Whitehead, who is eager to bring over "Separate Tables" intact from London.

Congress must promptly authorize the State Power Authority to build a hydroelectric plant at Niagara Falls to replace the loss of the Schoellkopf station there in a rockfall on June 7, Robert Moses declared yesterday.

With the endorsement of President Eisenhower, delivered in his hospital room to Chancellor Adenauer, the United States has again called on the Soviets to honor their Geneva commitment and take action to reunite Germany by means of free elections and within the framework of European security.
The John W. McGrath Corporation spent $5,000 entertaining Jersey City officials, but no cash was ever given to these men, it was testified yesterday.

WASHINGTON, June 14 (UP) --Dr. Bells Dodd, a former Communist patty leader, testified today she had known the confidential secretary of former Mayor William O'Dwyer and several other New York political figures as Communists.
Abe Cohen of the Fencers Club scored a 5--3 victory over the united States Navy's William Andre in a fence-off, to keep the national epee title yesterday; at the Concourse Plaza Hotel, the Bronx.

THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 14 (Reuters)--A Dutch Government spokesman tonight denied rumors published in the foreign press that Queen Juliana was seeking a divorce from her husband, Prince Bernhard.

As a prominent contributor to the Democratic party and chairman of the board of a big brewery, Mr. Wehle may have been a leading Rochester ...
TRENTON, June 14--Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed a record appropriation bill today calling for expenditures of $320,834,671 by the state in the fiscal year beginning July 1.

WASHINGTON, June 14--Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 9 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes in sees from like periods of 1955:
WASHINGTON, June 14-- David P. Findling, associate general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board, died today at George Washington Hospital. He was 47 years old.
WASHINGTON, June 14--The Administration's civil rights program appeared headed for the House floor today after a heated squabble is the Rules Committee.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 14 --Republic Pictures will resume filming operations the middle of next month. A program of eighteen low-budget pictures was projected today by Herbert J. Yates, president.
WASHINGTON, June 14-- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 787,075 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

The Long Island Rail Road introduced a cool and pleasant note into the hot and bothered transit situation yesterday. It announced faster schedules for 688 trains and wider use of air-conditioned cars.

Former Fireman John P. Crane underwent cross-examination yesterday on his fiveyear-old story of having handed $10,000 to Mayor William 0'Dwyer in October, 1949. He conceded that his memory had changed.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 14-- The American Federation of Musicians took decisive action today to smash future revolts by insurgent locals.
Three old bells that have called worshipers to service or tolled in mourning for seventyfive years were brought down dustily yesterday from the belfry of DeWitt Memorial Church.

WASHINGTON, June 14--If the record of the last term of the Supreme Court is a reliable guide, Chief Justice Earl Warren of California has joined what some people call the liberal and others the "so-called liberal" wing of the nation's highest tribunal.
LEONARD FRANKLIN McCOLLUM, president of Continental Oil Corporation and chairman of the Natural Gas and Oil Resources Committee, has been in a hot seat before.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., June 14 --A golfer who wanted to withdraw from the tournament took the lead in the first round of the United States Open golf championship today.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 14--V.K. Krishna Menon of India today urged support for efforts ao get a settlement of the Algerian conflict by direct negotiations, without airing of the problem in the United Nations at this time.
The New York committee that has conducted the year-long commemoration of the 250th anniversary of Benjamin Franklin's birth completed its work yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., June 14-- Miss Angela Bayard Brown, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Nicholas Brown of Providence and this city, made her debut here tonight at a "pink" ball given by her parents at Harbour Court, their Newport estate. More than 600 persons attended.
WASHINGTON, June 14--The Justice Department pledged "full compliance" today with Monday's Supreme Court decision limiting the Government security program to employes in sensitive jobs.
WASHINGTON, June 14 (AP) --A rabbi and a union organizer from New York refused to tell the House Committee on UnAmerican Activities today about their travels abroad.

FOR Sunday's dinner choose a thick, tender steak, chicken for frying or smoked ham that may be served in thin, cold slices. These are the items being featured at many meat counters now. Equally important, they are the kind of foods that please the man of the house, whose day it will be on Sunday.

A syndicate headed by Salomon Bros. Hutzler is offering a new issue of $7,725,000 of Northern Pacific Railway equipment trust certificates due annually from 1957 to 1971. The certificates bear a 3 per cent dividend and all maturities are priced at 100.
A picture of the post-Stalinist rivalry between Soviet leaders has been given by a former highranking Polish official now in the United States.

BOSTON, June 14 (AP)--Jackie Jensen and Dick Gernert accounted for seven Boston runs today as the Boston Red Sox defeated Cleveland, 10--9, in a joint feast on wobbly, pitching staffs. Six hurlers were hammered for a total of thirty hits.
Miss Joan Stuart Comfort was married yesterday afternoon to Herbert Alden Johnson Jr. in the chapel of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church.

MARION Mass., June 14--A pair of second places gained a 4-point lead for George O'Day of the host Beverly Yacht Club at the conclusion of the first day's racing in the United States Olympic Monotype sailing trials on Buzzards Bay today.

A nation-wide survey of housing problems of minority groups was announced yesterday. Special attention will be paid to the difficulties of Negroes, Puerto Ricans and Americans of Mexican and Asian descent.
John Morrell Co. and subsidiaries realized a 39.9 per cent increase in earnings in the twenty-six weeks ended April 28 on a sales gain of 5.3 per cent over the corresponding period last year.
Longshore grain trimmers at the New York Central Railroad's West Shore grain elevator in Weehawken, N.J., went on strike yesterday morning for the third time in two weeks.

Most major coffee roasters have raised the wholesale price of vacuum-packed coffee 3 cents a pound, it was announced yesterday. Retail chains have not announced increases on their own brands nor raised the retail price of others.

ROME, June 14--A report generally favorable to the establishment of an international food fund and food commodity reserves was issued today at the headquarters of United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.

BONN, Germany, June 14-- Only three currencies in Western Europe are valued correctly in terms of the United States dollar, Dr. Ludwig Erhard, West Germany's Minister of Economics, said in an interview here today. He named them as the Deutsche mark, Belgian franc and Swiss franc.

WASHINGTON, June 14-- Legislative action to return to their original owners all seized German and Japanese assets was being prepared on Capitol Hill today, in the wake of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's visit to Washington.

SINCE they are new faces in "New Faces of '56," which opened at the Ethel Barrymore last evening, they are not old pros. And that may be the reason their show just misses the final excitement of a firstrate musical revue.
Michael J. Quill, international president of the Transport Workers Union, called the subway motormen's walkout yesterday afternoon "a stab in the back" of the public and organized labor.

BONN, Germany, June 14-- The West German Students Association, representing 140,000 students, issued an interim report last night urging that every effort be made to reunite Germany before attempting to arm West Germany.

WASHINGTON, June 15 (UP) --Two sets of United States Government agents, each mistaking the other for Russian spies, fought it out in a Washington restaurant in 1950 trying to "protect" a refugee Soviet pilot.

The grounds of the Turf and Field Club at Belmont Park were the setting last night for the eighth annual Belmont Ball. The fete, a dinner dance, was a benefit for the Visiting Nurse Service of New York.

The volume of commercial paper outstanding in the United States increased moderately in May, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. The month-end total, 2,607,000,000, was $93,000,000 or 4 per cent above the April level and $272,000,000 or 12 per cent higher than the May, 1955, figure.

Monday will be D Day-Delivery Day--for Manhattan's telephone directory. Distiribution of nearly 1,000,000 copies will begin then.
A DOCTOR expects only a husky "Ah" from a patient, but he demands a bit more conversation from his office assistant.

The Chancery Office of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York announced yesterday that twenty-two newly ordained priests would be assigned to special work among Spanish-speaking churchgoers in New York.
The Plymouth Cordage Company is diversifying its rope and twine business through the purchase of W.W. Cross Co. at Jaffrey, N. H. and the J. C. Rhodes Company at New Bedford, Mass.

TRENTON, June 15--Retail price controls on milk will be restored in New Jersey on July 1 for the first time since February, 1955. The action will result in a one-half-cent-a-quart increase to consumers in much of the state.
Cottonseed oil was active and weak yesterday on the New York Produce Exchange. The volume, 848 tank cars (60,000 pounds to a car) was the second highest since 1952.
WOR-TV, which has been buying large quantities of top-priced films, has added two Stanley Kramer productions to its collections.

With three of their new players in the line-up and another contributing a valuable bit of piece work, the reconstructed Giants downed the Redlegs, 4--3, in eleven innings at the Polo Grounds last night.
George Donald Harrison, president of the Aeolian-Skinner Organ Company, manufacturers of pipe organs, died Thursday in his home at 1019 Third Avenue. His age was 67.

BERKELEY, Calif., June 15 (AP)--Ken Bantum of Manhattan today became the third man to put the shot more than 60 feet as meet records were shattered in five events at the national collegiate track and field championships.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., June 15 --Dimitri Mitropoulos threw a bombshell this afternoon into the Providence convention of composers, conductors, managers, orchestral boards and committee members. He told them to relax.

CLUJ, Rumania, June 15--An American visitor to this Transylvanian university city is likely to undergo an astonishing and heartwarming experience if he comes in a shiny new car that labels itself "Made in U.S.A."
Seamen stranded "on the beach" between shipping jobs become eligible today for benefits under the first industry-wide supplementary unemployment insurance plan in the United States.

The heat and humidity have started a run on room air conditioners. Yesterday wholesalers who funnel the heat-beaters from factories to stores in the metropolitan area were rushed to fill orders from opening to closing. In some instances warehouses stayed open beyond midnight.

Henry Amster, one-time law partner of the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia, died yesterday after collapsing in Manhattan Supreme Court. His age was 72.
BARCELONA, Spain, June 15 --United States Ambassador John Days Lodge urged the Spanish Government today to relax restrictions on foreign investments.

VIENNA, June 15--The Czechoslovak Communist party rebuked Czech writers and college students today for using "anti-Stalinism" as a basis for criticizing the regime and communism generally.

Another heat record, the second in two days, toppled yesterday. A new high mark for June 15--94.8 degrees--was reached at 4:50 P.M.
AKRON, Ohio, June 15 (AP)-- Attorneys for Sydney Albert and a million-dollar creditor conferred today on methods of settling the debt.

Leaders of 650,000 union steel workers rejected yesterday a proposed five-year no-strike contract with fixed annual wage increases, a fifty-two-week unemployment pay plan and other employe gains.
CLEVELAND, June 15--Samuel A. Horvitz, president and founder of two of the state's largest construction companies and publisher of two Ohio newspapers, died here today at the age of 67.

MILWAUKEE, June 15 (AP)-- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer of West Germany said tonight that he was "returning home strengthened in the conviction" that the people of the United States and Germany have the same goals.

BONN, Germany, June 15-- The independent press of West Germany appraised today the results of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's mission to Washington with cautious reserve and some misgivings.

VENICE, Italy, June 15--The twenty-eighth Venice Biennale, the contemporary art world's "biggest show on earth," opens tomorrow. It contains acres of painting, sculpture and graphic art of thirty-four countries.
CHICAGO, June 15--Weakness in July soybeans unsettled grain futures today on the Board of Trade.
Cotton futures declined 13 to 22 points (65 cents to $l.10 a bale) yesterday, with a fairly large volume of business on the New York Cotton Exchange.
WASHINGTON, June 15--A newly patented "beanie" enables a girl to notify all observers that she has, or has not, been dated for the prom.
In the corridors leading to the Print Room at the Metropolitan Museum is a small show of engravings by the Italian Renaissance printmaker Marcantonio Raimondi.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., June 15 --Efforts to end the spread of the gypsy moth into woodlands east of the Mississippi will be completed here tomorrow.

High school students, who traditionally have been foot-loose and fancy-free in the last week of June after their Regents examinations, were ordered yesterday to attend classes every day until the end of the school year on June 29.

The United Steelworkers of America rejects as entirely inadequate the wage and contract proposal made by the Big Three steel corporations.

A sports event that recalls glorious days in Our Town's past takes place today.
