BEIRA, Mozambique, June 12 --Modern industry and agriculture are making the former jungleland district of Manica and Sofala one of the more prosperous of Mozambique's four districts.

LEEDS, England, June 9--The Queen's English is spoken with a radio accent in Britain today, a student with a sharp ear believes.

A STATEN ISLANDER has written for help in planning a champagne party for about twenty-five guests. The cost, she added, was a problem. Could we recommend a good but rather inexpensive champagne, and suggest what to serve with it?

WASHINGTON, June 15-- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee recommended today the restoration of an additional $100,000,000 to the foreign aid bill as it had emerged from the House of Representatives.
LONDON, June 15--British defense officials expressed gratification today over the AngloAmerican pact for the exchange of nuclear information.
BUENOS AIRES, June 15-- The Haitian Embassy announced today it had asked Argentina to give former Gen. Raul Tanco and six other Argentine rebels permits to leave the country.
Cherif Hamia, an Algerian featherweight who lives in Paris, defeated Miguel Berrios of Puerto Rico in a savage tenround contest at Madison Square. Garden last night. The verdict was unanimous.

Miss Ruth Woodhull Lawrence, a founder in 1893 of the National Society of Colonial Dames in the State of New York, died on Thursday at her family estate at 35-10 Twentieth Road, Astoria, Queens. She was 90 years old.
LONDON, June 15--Active dealings in oil shares enlivened the stock markets today. A big two-way business left most prices above yesterday's closing levels. But some closed below their highs.
Garson Kanin has agreed to stage Robert Whitehead's forthcoming production of the Arnold Shulman play that is tentatively titled "The Heart's a Forgotten Hotel."

LONDON, June 15--British concern over the health of President Eisenhower, which rests more on personal than political grounds, has been aggravated by concern over the results of the United States-West German policy discussions.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, June 18--The question at the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club tonight was whether Harry G. Haskell Jr.'s new seventy-three-foot yawl Venturer, getting her heels wet in any race for the first time, could break the record for the passage to St. David's Head.

Johnny Antonelli found a formula last night for overcoming the chronic Giant scarcity of runs. It was classically simple. He shut out the Cubs, 2--0, on five hits before 7,650 chilled onlookers at the Polo Grounds.

The International Brotherhood of Longshoremen, A.F.L.-C.I.O., announced yesterday that there had been no change in its plans to force another representation election for dock workers in the Port of New York.
WASHINGTON, June 19-- Robert B. McLeaish resigned today as Administrator of the Farmers Home Administration, twenty-four hours after a Senate committee had begun a public investigation of his agency.

WASHINGTON, June 19--St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church was the setting here this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Rosalind Hollow Morgan to Stuart Wesson Rockwell.

New York City's basic real estate tax rate has now passed $4 for each $100 of assessed valuation for the first time. When, to the basic rate of $4.02, assessments for local improvements are added, the total rate paid will range in the various boroughs from $4.08 to $4.11.
WHEN the Goldman Band began its thirty-ninth season last night in Central Park, there was no familiar white-haired figure to come bounding out of the door beneath the large American flag.

The National Broadcasting Company plans to overhaul its daytime radio schedule on weekdays. One of the probable casualties will be the program entitled "Weekday," which is presented locally from 10 A.M. to noon and from 2 to 3:45 P.M.

The Cornell and Yale varsity eight-oared crews were jointly seeded No. 1 and the Navy Admirals were seeded next yesterday in the draw for the Olympic rowing trials.

MILK for dessert? Nutritionist and epicure join in an em phatic "yes, by all means." When milk rounds out a warm-weather meal in the guise of a cool pudding or even cooler sherbet, it boosts health, pleases palates.

Ogden Phipps' Bureaucracy was the best of the colts competing in the $39,670 National Stallion stakes at Belmont Park yesterday. The 2-year-old son of Polynesian took the five-furlong sprint by almost two lengths, with the Brookmeade Stable's Encore, second.
FRANKFORT, Ky., June 20-- Joseph J. Leary, Frankfort attorney, declined today to accept the interim appointment to the Senate given him Monday by Gov. A.B. (Happy) Chandler.

The International Brotherhood of Teamsters plans to review the charters issued to seven controversial new locals in this city.
WASHINGTON, June 20-- James C. Hagerty, the White House press secretary, continued today to parry questions about President Eisenhower's political future.

LONDON, June 20--Activity remained at low ebb in the stock markets here today, the start of a new bookkeeping account.

THERE is the same slim, trim boyishness to Red Schoendienst now as there was when he broke into the big leagues in 1945. He still doesn't look his age, which is 33. But at least he no longer has any difficulties with the guardians of the players' entrances at the various National League ball parks. They greet the freckle-faced youth with a cheerful, "Hiya, Red," and wave him past. 'Twas not always thus.

Production and consumption of newsprint in May continued the record pace that has prevailed for more than a year, according to trade reports yesterday.

Fog hid the shores of the Hudson River yesterday, but there was sunshine aboard the Alexander Hamilton. The craft sailed with 1,600 handicapped persons to Indian Point Park on the twenty-seventh annual boat ride of the Institute of Crippled and Disabled.

Georges Guetary, French singing star, is being considered for the male lead in "Happy Hunting," the musical comedy by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse starring Ethel Merman.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 --Arthur Godfrey and his troupe will air their Columbia Broadcasting System television shows from San Francisco from July 2 through July 5, the first time the programs will originate on the West Coast.
WASHINGTON, June 24 (U.P.) --American families set several income records last year.

PITTSBURGH, June 24 (U.P.)-- The Pittsburgh Pirates got an assist from the weather to snap an eight-game losing streak today, The Bucs scored a 1-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs in a rain-shortened second game after dropping the opener of a doubleheader, 5--3.

CAIRO, June 24--Lieut. Col Gamal Abdel Nasser was overwhelmingly acclaimed today as first elected President of the Egyptian republic. His new Constitution was accepted by an equally sweeping majority.
THE HAGUE, the Netherlands, June 24--The size of next year's defense budget has become one of the stumbling blocks to the formation of a new Dutch Government.

The fact that yesterday was one of New York's typical dog days did not seem to hamper a little English-bred wirehaired fox terrier, who pranced about in the heat to take best-inshow honors at the Staten Island Kennel Club's seventeenth annual all-breed show. The show was staged at the Cromwell Center in Tompkinsville, S.I.
BEIRUT Lebanon, June 24-- A report that Dag Hammarskjold may visit the Middle East again in search of a way toward permanent peace is said to alarm the Arab states more than it pleases them.
MOSCOW, June 24--A new Soviet effort to pry Iran away from the Baghdad Pact was initiated here on the eve of the arrival of the Shah and his wife on a state visit.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., June 24 --For the second straight day skippers competing in the regatta of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound were greeted by fine sailing weather.

ATLANTIC CITY, June 24-- Governor Harriman arrived here today for the forty-eighth annual Conference of Governors. Within an hour of his arrival he predicted his own nomination for President at the Democratic National Convention which opens Aug. 13 in Chicago.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, June 24--President Tito of Yugoslavia began official talks on "friendship and peace" with Rumanian leaders today.
The nation's steel companies said yesterday the new five-year contract they had offered the United Steelworkers of America would cost the concerns two and a third billion dollars.

WASHINGTON, June 24-- Senate resentment at the conversational style of Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has increased the likelihood that the Administration may get $1,160,000,000 more than it had asked for the Air Force in the next fiscal year.
An economics race whose outcome could decide the fate of the world is in progress. The leaders of international communism expect to win the contest by beating capitalism at its own game--production.
Fine summer weather sent a good many New Yorkers out of town for the week-end, but it also brought in a large contingent of visitors.

The steamship charter market last week continued the slightly downward trend of the last month. Rates have not reached anything approaching distress levels. But the market is controlled by the charterers.
A Sandy Hook pilot who had one of the most complex routing jobs in New York in World War II is going to try to bring more order into the way pilots are paid in ports around the country.

National advertising linage in newspapers spurted sharply to new highs in May and the first five months of the year, according to word from the Bureau of Advertising, American Newspaper Publishers Association, and Media Records, Inc.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., June 24 (AP)--Vice Admiral Francis X. McInerney, U.S.N., retired, died in Naval Hospital today of a cerebral hemorrhage. His wife died a month ago. He was 57 years old.
The Christian is confronted by two "perhaps even greater threats" to freedom than totalitarianism and discrimination, worshipers at the Riverside Church were told yesterday.
The six-story and basement building on lot 32 by 100 feet at 47 Beaver Street has been purchased by Smith, Kirkpatrick Co., an import and export concern in the downtown financial district since 1877.
TORONTO, June 24 (AP)--Roy H. Davis of Welland, chairman of the board of Atlas Steels, Ltd., died today after a long illness. He was 71 years old.
A FEW nights ago fifteen men in their 50's, gray haired, white-haired, mostly a little on the portly side, faced each other across candlelit napery in a room in the Capitol Hotel.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, June 24-- The bluff, hearty abbot of the Kykko Monastery, returned triumphant to Nicosia tonight after successful negotiations with the British on the number of monks needed to maintain the ancient abbey.

Mayor Wagner said yesterday that he was disposed to favor state legislation next year forbidding the sale of intoxicating beverages to persons under 21 years old. Existing state law forbids such sales to persons under the age of 18.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Monday, June 25--A British Overseas Airways Corporation airliner crashed and burned, killing twenty-six persons, shortly after taking off from the North Nigerian airport of Kano last evening. One person of the forty-five aboard was missing.

Western Massachusetts Companies is offering holders of its common stock rights to buy 92,237 shares of additional common stock at $37.50 a share on the basis of one new share for each twelve held. A syndicate headed by the First Boston Corporation and White, Weld Co. is underwriting the transaction.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., June 24--The Information Center for the United Nations is scheduled to go out of existence July 1 because of lack of financial support. Mrs. Davenport Bryan, director of the unit throughout its eight years of volunteer service to the public, made the announcement today.

PHILADELPHIA, June 24 (U.P.) --Frankie Baumholtz hit a bases-filled pinch-single in the ninth inning today to enable the Philadelphia Phillies to gain a 3-2 decision over the St. Louis Cardinals in the second game of a double-header. Ken Boyer's two homers and a triple paced the Cards to an 8-4 victory in the opener.

VIRGINIA WATER, England, June 24 (AP)--Depite a stampeding mob of 20,000 golf fans. Ben Hogan shot a brilliant 31, 37--68 today to tie Peter Thomson of Australia for the individual lead in the Canada Cup international golf tournament.

PARIS, June 24--Imports to France are expected to increase by $300,000,000 this year, according to estimates by foreign trade experts. This includes $200,000,000 in raw materials and $100,000,000 in capital goods.
A prominent clergyman of the Dutch Reformed Church in South Africa pleaded with Christians here yesterday for an understanding of his nation's racial problems.
The 10,330-deadweight-ton freighter Etrusco has been declared a total loss by her Italian owners and turned over to Trieste insurance underwriters.
ATLANTIC CITY, June 24--Four Democratic Governors staged today a preview of the kind of fight their platform writers must resolve to write a civil rights plank for 1956.

GUATEMALA, June 24--The Government suspended most constitutional rights for thirty days by a decree issued early today. The action was taken because of what was said to be a Communist plot to create disturbances.

An unprecedented "agonizing reappraisal" is now going on everywhere within the Communist parties of the free world--the party in the United States being the latest to announce its shock--and among those who have sympathized and worked with them.

FOND DU LAC, Wis., June 24--Robert Jacobson, a 32-yearold outboard racing enthusiast from Flint, Mich., won the annual Winnebago Lake outboard marathon today. It was punishing, bruising, extra-rough going. Officials said that the water conditions were the worst they ever had seen at any race.
For better or for worse, the Long Island Rail Road and its commuters seem to be fated to depend on each other.

BAKERSFIELD, Calif., June 24 (AP)--Dave Sime of Duke and Franklin (Bud) Held, the recognized holder of the world javelin record, today received permission to compete in the Olympic track tryouts in Los Angeles next Friday and Saturday. The action, by the United States Olympic Committee, was unprecedented.
Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly yesterday urged daily visits to "our Eucharistic God" is Roman Catholic churches.

DETROIT, June 24 (U.P.)--Mrs. Marlene Bauer Hagge, the 22year-old Asheville, N.C., star, calmly tapped in an 18-inch putt on the first extra hole today to win the Ladies Professional Golfers Association championship. She defeated Patty Berg of St. Andrew, Ill., for her third straight tournament triumph.
ALBANY, June 24 (AP)--Governor Harriman announced today appointment of a ninemember permanent State Youth Commission and designated Mark A. McCloskey of New York City as its Chairman.

MOSCOW, June 24--Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Air Force Chief of Staff, made a vigorous defense of United States disarmament policy today in the presence of the top Soviet leaders. The occasion was a reception given by Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, Soviet Defense Minister, on Soviet Air Force Day.
OMAHA, Neb., June 24--The threat of new legal battles loomed here today over the merger of the Congregational Christian Churches and the Evangelical and Reformed Church.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, June 24--Lauris Norstad, the handsome young Air Force general who will assume command of NATO's armies at the end of this year, is one of the few American officers who foresaw the problem of defending Europe against Soviet pressure long before the end of World War II. In this he agreed with Churchill, not Roosevelt, Marshall and Eisenhower.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., June 24 --David O. Selznick and Twentieth Century-Fox have completed arrangements for Fox to handle the world-wide distribution of the producer's longplanned film version of Ernest Hemingway's "A Farewell to Arms."

STRATFORD, Conn., June 24 --The observation by a character in Shakespeare that "my dial runs not true" is finding an echo here, and not in lament.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- There has been a marked change in the reporting and comment on President Eisenhower's illness during the last few weeks.
A committee of fifty-five business and professional leaders has been named to integrate plans for the redevelopment of lower Manhattan.

DETROIT, June 24 (AP)--The Baltimore Orioles whipped the Detroit Tigers twice today by identical scores of 3--2, dealing the Tigers their seventh and eighth consecutive defeats. It is Detroit's worst losing streak since 1953.

CHRISTIAN DIOR'S millinery collection is a good one. The fact that it is integrated so well with the fashions that make up his American collection occasionally results in the customer's overlooking the millinery as millinery. But there it is, and it is a positive and trend-setting group of hats.

A team of eight players from Harvard, Yale, Princeton and Pennsylvania left for England by plane from New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday to engage Oxford and Cambridge in the first international intercollegiate match in court tennis.
THE Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, which is not often seen hereabouts, danced last night at Lewisohn Stadium in its first New York appearance since its Stadium engagement last summer.
With the enthusiasm of a doting father, Anthony DeBaise showed off the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel last week.
Recognition Day, marking the end of a year of activities, was held yesterday afternoon at St. Nicholas Houses, the social group division of the Morningside Community Center at 210 West 131st Street.
KATONAH, N.Y., June 24-- The bitter story of Madea was performed here last night on Caramoor's Field of the Columns in the soft night air laden with the sweet perfume of honeysuckle.

CHICAGO, June 24--Seesaw trends were the rule in the grain markets last week. Trade was largely of a local professional character, although at times there was some investment buying of grains on the theory that prices may rise after the harvest run of wheat is over.

The marriage of Miss Barbara Ann Bodne to Andrew A. Anspach took place last night in the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Ben B. Bodne of the Algonquin Hotel, formerly of Charleston, S.C. The Rev. Dr. Israel Goldstein performed the ceremony.
PITTSBURGH, June 24--Steel shipments boomed last week as steel users hedged against a steel strike. There were some deterrents, however, to capacity steel shipments.
OTTAWA, Ont., June 22--Canada's home building industry is showing increased alarm at the "squeeze" on credit caused by the Government's tight money policy. make a protest to the Government this week.
WASHINGTON, June 24-- President Eisenhower began his last week in Walter Reed Army Hospital today.

HARRISON, N.J., June 24-- The Elizabeth Falcons scored a 4-3 victory over the BrookhattanGalicia eleven today to tie for first place with the Philadelphia Uhriks in the American Soccer League. The Falcons held a 3-1 lead at halftime.
Packaging is an extra manufacturing cost that almost always must be borne by the manufacturer, an executive with experience in the candy, liquor and garment industries said here yesterday.
The American Shakespeare Festival's second season of repertory at Stratford, Conn., will begin at 8 o'clock tonight and continue through Sept. 9 in the air-conditioned 1,478-seat house.

WIMBLEDON, England, June 25--Jaroslav Drobny, the 1954 champion, was upset in the first round of the All-England tennis tournament today. The fifth-seeded Drobny lost, 6--1, 4--6, 6--1, 6--4, to Ramanathan Krishnan of India, who was making his first appearance on the famed center court.
Seven crisp young Boy Scout candidates for a frigid job in the Antarctic tried not to wilt in the heat mid-Manhattan yesterday as they were interviewed for final selection.
CHICAGO, June 25--Short covering lifted prices of wheat, corn and soybeans today on the Board of Trade.
Prices of cotton futures moved 1 point off to 9 points up (5 cents a bale off to 45 up) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

REYKJAVIK, Iceland, June 25--A Progressive-Social Democratic coalition pledged to oust United States troops from Iceland won a smashing victory in yesterday's Parliamentary elections. But it fell just short of a clear majority needed to take over the Government.

Royal Game II, an Argentinebred horse recently flown here from Brazil, won the feature race at Belmont Park yesterday.
A top negotiator for the "Big Three" of the steel industry warned yesterday that the cost of any steel wage settlement would be passed on in higher steel prices.

Speculator buying, manufacturer purchasing for price fixing and short covering strengthened cocoa futures yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Volume was the second largest of the year. Commission house profit taking and scattered hedge selling supplied the contracts.

JERSEY CITY, June 25--Fans of New Jersey still may not be of a mind to take to the Dodgers. But this somehow didn't concern the world champions a great deal tonight as they played their third championship game of the season in Roosevelt Stadium.

Far East steamship lines that carry rubber to New York and other ports have set up a special task force to assault an old enemy.

GUATEMALA, June 25--At least three university students were killed tonight and nineteen others wounded as the police opened fire on student protest demonstrations. At least one policeman was slightly wounded during the shooting on the city's main thoroughfare.

IN France, butchers pride themselves on their special ril lettes, a pate of chopped lean and fat pork served as an hors d'oeuvre. The rillette de Tours, one of the most famed versions, now is sent here in a six-ounce tin. Packed by J. Dreux, the savory spread is $1.50 a tin at Maison Glass, 52 East Fiftyeighth Street.
WASHINGTON, June 25-- Senator Herbert H. Lehman announced today that he would offer an anti-segregation amendment to the school construction bill when it reaches the Senate.
BERLIN, June 14--The showing of fall and winter fashions in West Berlin that has just ended is being hailed as a big success.
